Title: Erika Henry
Comment: It's critical to consider the safety of cyclists on our roads. Please include measures for better data collecting & reporting of accidents and fatalities, as well as a robust, mandatory education plan for motorists and cyclists, and plans for improved infrastructure to support bike riding and cycle commuting nationwide. Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I see no reason why persons with service animals for emotional support should be required to show documentation more frequently than those with service animals for physical disabilities. The ADA does not discriminate against mental disabilities, therefore the animals used to aid those who suffer therefrom should not be subject discrimination either.

Title: Hillary Pate
Comment:
While section 11143 of SAFETEA-LU charges the Secretary of Transportation with allocating a set $15 billion among qualified highway or surface freight transfer facilities nation-wide, it does not list criteria he is to take into consideration when doing so. For example, is there a priority determined as to projects? What about the deteriorating conditions and/or life spans of projects, are these considered? I would also want to ensure money is distributed equally between states to ensure that the entire amount isn’t allocated to projects in only one or two states? Ultimately, I believe that having such criteria for the allocation process is extremely important as it will allow you to give an explanation of why you have denied/approved someone for funds and will cut down on the appearance of bias. 

Likewise, is there an appeal process for the individuals denied qualified highway or surface freight transfer facility funds? Simply saying you’re denied when there is no set criteria and at the pure discretion of one person doesn’t usually sit well and or seem right without some sort of appeal process in place. 

It also seems troubling that the Department states, “The Department is not specifying any form for an application.” I do believe that uniformity in the application process would not only be easier for the applicant, but also be more cost efficient for the individuals on the other end who are processing such. 

Thank you for you time and consideration.

With Regards,

Hillary Pate

Title: Rachel Ayscue-Wright
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam, 

     I am writing to comment on the application process and the exercise of allocation authority concerning Docket No. OST-2005-23418, Applications for Authority for Tax-Exempt Financing of Highway Projects and Rail-Truck Transfer Facilities. 

     I am dismayed to learn that DOT does not have a standard process in place for the application process. It would seem a logical step to create a uniform application form that requests all of the information that would be necessary to evaluate the applicant's project. Not requiring any form for applications and not requiring the initial application to include all of the pertinent information is a gross mismanagement of the process. The process would be streamlined by requiring all of the information up front instead of burdening DOT employees with chasing down the information in order to provide a thorough evaluation of the applicant's project. This amounts to a waste of tax-payer money and employees time that could be better spent in other areas.

     I would also like to comment on how the exercise of allocation authority occurs. There is very little information concerning how projects are evaluated and chosen. I think this stems from the lack of a coherent national transportation plan, especially concerning the movement of freight. This money should be funding projects that relieve bottlenecks and encourage the efficient flow of freight through the country and at our nation's ports as well as funding improvements to our nations most heavily used roads. It appears from the limited information provided that projects are simply approved if they meet the applicable statutory requirements and tax-exempt authority is available for the type and location of the project. Saying that allocations are occurring in a fair and reasonable manner is very abstract. Who is determining what is fair and reasonable? What are the criteria for fair and reasonable? 

     I do believe that this allocation of funds is badly needed to fund infrastructure improvements however, I am concerned that the implementation is lacking in certain areas. Thank you for allowing me the opportunity to comment.

Rachel Ayscue-Wright, CTL

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Because of the importance of maintaining a safe transportation system throughout the United States, PABs are a useful financing and economic development tool.  These bonds are supported by US Congress and encourage private investment in projects that may not receive conventional financing.  Most highway and freight transfer facility projects are funded by multiple entities, some private and some public. It’s useful to have the additional lending options PABs provide to access capital for projects. 

The state and local governments should continue to carefully review projects that are issued PABs to ensure the projects are qualified and contribute to economic development. This will help maintain the integrity of the program to improve the American economy and deter opponents.  

Part B of Section 11143 of SAFETEA-LU lists the process of applying to the Department of Transportation DOT for allocation of PAB’s.  Number 7 on that list requests that the applicant provide a project description. I would suggest adding to the requirements by asking the applicant to provide the perceived economic impact of the project that is requesting the PAB allocation. This would require the applicant to do some research for the purpose of maximizing the positive community impacts of the project.  This should be one of the main determining factors to receive an award.

Thank you,

Aisha Eccleston

Title: Andrew Partidge
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

The document, with reference identifier OST-2005-23418, prompted me to make a suggestion on the application process for PABs. Currently, there is no standard application. The document states some suggested information for the applicant to submit, but then explains that all of the information suggested is not required. I am confident that a standard, comprehensive application can create uniformity amongst applicants. This will require the applicants to be sincere and prepared before applying, as well as enable the DOT to efficiently review all of the applications on an informed basis. 

Additionally, an online portal for applicants could be created. There, the applicant could retrieve, revise and submit their application electronically. Furthermore, the applicant could track the status of their application and receive any necessary communications from the DOT. This would have a positive environmental impact and enable applicants to more easily file and revise their application.

Thank you in advance for your time.

Respectfully,

Andrew Partridge

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Good day, US Government. I read through the instructions of the PAB application process and it looks very confusing. I think a more streamlined process is warranted here, specifically listing exact bullet points that need to be addressed in an application. I can see where important information could be left out of an application inadvertently and could subsequently delay the whole process, costing the private entity and the government wasted time and money. For legal reasons, the information listed in the application process should be given, but the actual application can be summarized and organized much better.

Title: Comment from Tosha Gillis
Comment:
No Fear Act Notice
On May 15, 2002, Congress enacted the “Notification and Federal Employee Anti-discrimination and Retaliation Act of 2002,” Public Law 107-174, which is now known as the No FEAR Act. One purpose of the Act is to “require that Federal agencies be accountable for violations of anti-discrimination and whistle-blower protection laws.” In support of this purpose, Congress found that “agencies cannot be run effectively if those agencies practice or tolerate discrimination.” The Act also requires this agency to provide this notice to Federal employees, former Federal employees and applicants for Federal employment to inform you of the rights and protections available to you under Federal anti-discrimination, whistle-blower protection and retaliation laws.

I am for the No Fear Act 110%. No employee or person for that matter, should ever feel afraid due to discrimination. Unfortunately, it is a problem I have seen first hand. Even with the No Fear Act, I think there is still fear when it comes to discrimination. It is very beneficial to have a rule like this for the protection of all.

Title: Vicky Boyod
Comment: Ever since DOT required airlines to break down expenses, it's been much easier as a frequent flier trying to determine which fare is cheaper. Now comes all of the add ons. Fortunately, I fly Southwest mostly where the first two bags fly free. But it's not that easy with other airlines. All airlines need to put their fees in plain site where potential customers can compare apples to apples. Hotels do it. Every time I book, I know what parking will be, what resort fees will be, what local taxes will be, etc., before I click "reserve." Same goes with rental cars. I know that if I book a car at Little Rock, the base may be $22 per day, but the taxes and other associated fees may be more than that per day. But it's all itemized and all in plain site. Don't let the airlines bamboozle you into letting them continue all of their add-ons behind the scenes. They claim that they would be the only part of the travel industry required to do so. I don't know if hotels and rental car agencies are required to do, but they all do in my experience. Just look at all of the profit the airlines have made from these add-on fees. That's what is keeping them flying, not the actual ticket. It's like Barbie. The Barbie doll is cheap. It's all of her clothes, accessories and automobiles that drive the cost up. Please hold tough and don't let the airlines have their ways. Having all of the fees in plain site will be good for consumers, especially those who are frequent fliers.

Title: Charles Trant - Comments
Comment:
With regards to e-cigarettes in any enclosed space: First, tobacco plants produce nicotine to stop insects from eating the leaves. Nicotine is still used as a powerful pesticide and the earliest use dates back to our Colonial days. 

If an adult wants to consume nicotine regardless of the risks, that is completely their business, but they still have to exhale. Do I have the right to expose their children to pesticides, even in minute amounts, regardless of parental concerns? No, and neither does anyone else.

Title: Brenda Curtis
Comment:
Vaping, or using an e-cig is not smoking. There is no smoke. It's water vapor.  If it is to be compared with anything it should be compared with using a medical nebulizer. There is natural nicotine in many natural foods such as eggplant, cauliflower, tomatoes and potatoes and those aren't considered cigarettes either. Second hand vape releases so little that it isn't considered measurable  so other passengers aren't affected. Any ban at this time is unnecessarily preemptive and unneeded. 
Thank you! 
A Vaper that loves flying the skies. 
Brenda

Title: Betty C. Jung
Comment: Since air inside an aircraft is re-circulated air, it is a very good idea to ban the use of E-cigarettes to protect the health of all passengers and crew members from being exposed to the propylene glycol being emitted from E-cigarettes. According to the  Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, "If it escapes into the air, it will take between 24 and 50 hours for half the amount released to break down." This means, that in a re-circulated air environment, the exposure would be prolonged. Also, "studies of people and animals show that if you have repeated eye, skin, nasal, or oral exposures to propylene glycol for a short time, you may develop some irritation."  While the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has classified propylene glycol as “generally recognized as safe,” (acceptable for use in flavorings, drugs, and cosmetics, and as a direct food additive), it has said nothing about its safety with E-cigarettes. (http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/tp189-c1-b.pdf). Thank you for protecting the health of the public and those who must work in aircraft with this ban.

Title: Erik Vinters
Comment: The use of vapor cigarettes should be allowed on airplanes in areas of the airplane sanctioned for their use. There is little to no evidence that second hand vapor causes health problems and without the threat of heat, fire, and lighters aboard a plane there is little for concern. I do believe that there should be a section for people who do not wish to be around the vapor created by these devices as it could possibly cause someone to become uncomfortable. I think there is no threat just as long as the e-cigarettes were used in sanctioned areas of the plane and just as long as the airline retains the right to tell anyone who is using such devices to stop. E-cigarettes have helped more than 10 people who I know stop smoking and the possibility that they ever would have stopped on their own is very unlikely. Please allow the use of e-cigarettes on flights so as to not further stigmatize these life saving devices anymore than what they already are. We need to take a stand and shed light on the good aspects of these devices in comparison to traditional tobacco use..

Title: Sandra Young
Comment:
Smoking of electronic cigarettes on aircraft should be PROHIBITED.  I do not want to breathe nicotine and whatever other substances might be released from e-cigarettes.  

I will not fly on a plane if the smoking of e-cigarettes is permitted.

Thank you.

Comment: Electronic cigarettes should not be allowed on airplanes. We know that their aerosol contains 10 chemicals known to be carcinogens and/or toxins. That is enough. This is a public health issue, and no one (airline workers nor travelers) should be forced to inhale the aerosol. Thank you for looking seriously at the issue and for passing an official regulation. I hope the DoT can get the regulation into effect very soon.

Comment: Please prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on all aircraft  Flight attendants and the public should not be expected to differentiate between a tobacco cigarette and an electronic smoking device, nor should they be exposed to any type of secondhand smoke or aerosol.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: E-cigarettes are obscene - do not allow them on airplanes!

Title: John M. Leli
Comment: NO, Not ever! Common sense!

Absolutely, positively e-cigarettes should NOT, NOT, NOT be allowed on airplanes. Any form of tobacco encouragement is simply unacceptable and goes against all public health efforts.

Comment: Electronic Cigarettes should be prohibited on aircraft. They produce volatile emissions with unknown health effects and they are a fire hazard. The substances they contain also pose a poisoning hazard. There is absolutely no reason to allow their use on aircraft--there are already effective nicotine dosing devices (e.g., gum, patch) that can be used by nicotine addicts.

Title: Chris Heckman
Comment: stop the e-cigarettes on all air crafts now. what are you waiting for?

Title: Joan Eisentodt
Comment:
There are numerous reasons e-cigarettes should NOT be allowed to be 'vaped' on airplanes:
1. Contrary to their much hyped marketing, there IS an odor and it's noxious and obnoxious. For those of us w/ chemical sensitivities - covered by the ADA - this interferes w/ our rights.

2. Until it is known that the vapor is not carcinogenic, there is no reason to allow such behavior. Smokers who are using these know the rules of not-smoking on airplanes and they have survived many years. Flight attendants who sued the airlines for clean air don't need this other interference. Non-smokers who are using these to look 'cool' don't need them anywhere let alone where they interfere with others' rights.

3. E-cigs are used to vape marijuana, still Federally illegal. Let's keep it from planes.

Flying is miserable. Having people vaping will make it more so. Don't allow it.

Title: Gary Buchwald
Comment:
E-cigarettes do not just emit harmless water vapor. In fact, water is not an ingredient in these products.
Secondhand e-cigarette aerosol contains nicotine, hazardous ultra fine particles, volatile organic compounds, and other chemicals, some of which are carcinogenic (e.g., formaldehyde, metals like cadmium, lead, & nickel, and nitrosamines).
At least 10 chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.  It's about time that these were banned on all aircraft.

Title: Suzette Ahrendt-Janoff
Comment: I am against e-cigs being allowed on airplanes or in any indoor public space. I am a former AA flight attendant who testified before Congress to get smoking banned on the airlines and then went on to work on smoking bans in my city and state. I recently sat next to a young woman who used an e-cig on an American Airlines flight. I told her I did not believe they were allowed and she used it anyway. Because I have chronic sinusitus and asthma and am very sensitive to the particulate matter given off by cigarettes and these e-cigs, I ended up getting sick shortly after the flight with a sinus infection, 2 rounds of antibiotics and steroids over the course of a month. I sent letter to the flight attendant union and the American Airlines CEO and heard nothing back. I also expressed my concern for safety as an e-cig was to blame for a fire in the baggage compartment on a JetBlue flight recently. E-cigs should be prohibited from being carried on or checked and certainly not used in an enclosed aluminum tube at 35.000 feet. Because the airlines won't listen to common sense we need federal regulations to protect the flying public. Some things never change, airline CEO's do not "protect the public", they only protect their bottom line.

Title: William Baldga
Comment: NO!!! Do not allow air pollution on airplanes. Please ban all smoking devices. Thank you

Title: Dave McNab
Comment: I am a retired aircraft mechanic, current aircraft use a lot of recycled air, putting pollutants in this recycled air (in my opinion) is not a good idea for the health of the crew and passengers. Prior to banning smoking in aircraft, the build up of tar and nicotine on items such as the pressurization regulators was disgusting and added a lot of defects to the aircraft systems i.e.. sticking regulators and a lot of dirty sensors. There is enough dirt in the air we breath, we do not need any more from such things and electronic cigarettes

NO- NO- NO

Title: Dale Hillard
Comment:
Dear Department of Transportation,

It's my understand that you has been promising to finalize the rule that would prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on airlines.

This is a public health issue: Flight attendants and the public should not be expected to differentiate between a tobacco cigarette and an electronic smoking device, nor should they be exposed to any type of secondhand smoke or aerosol. 

E-cigarettes do not just emit harmless water vapor. In fact, water is not an ingredient in these products.

Secondhand e-cigarette aerosol contains nicotine, hazardous ultra fine particles, volatile organic compounds, and other chemicals, some of which are carcinogenic (e.g., formaldehyde, metals like cadmium, lead, & nickel, and nitrosamines).

At least 10 chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.

For the above reasons, please make your decision to finalize the rule that would prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on airlines soon.

E-cigarette users can basically choose 3 types of systems:  a disposable, non-refillable e-cigarette; an e-cigarette where the user can change the nicotine cartridge and a "tank" system, that the user fills with their own "e-juice".  Basically, the second and third options can be filled with ANYTHING - e-juice bought at a vape store, or on-line, or made at home on your kitchen stovetop.  The second option can be refilled using a syringe or a toothpick (see youtube for refilling demonstrations).

Allowing e-cigarette use on planes means that you have no idea what is being vaped in a very small space.  It could be flavor and nicotine or be THC or something else that is either illegal and/or causes a "high".  This is the problem with allowing e-cigarette use in workplaces but clearly becomes more serious in the relatively small space of an aircraft.

Title: Kate Bauer
Comment:
E-cigarettes are likely safer than regular cigarettes, but they still contain poisons (nicotine and often other toxins) and the aerosol vapor containing those toxins that they produce is not something that innocent, non-users should be exposed to in airplanes, or anywhere else.  That should be reason enough, by itself, to issue a strong rule prohibiting any e-cigarette use on any  flights.

Allowing e-cigarette use in airplanes would also be a giant step backward in the denormalization of smoking/nicotine use that would model not just e-cigarette use but also smoking-like behavior to all the youth, and others, on the plane.

Also, prohibiting any e-cigarette use on airplanes would also help to discourage smoking, because smokers would not be able simply to switch to similar e-cigarette use while on flights, with no interruption of their lung-based nicotine consumption and no withdrawal symptoms to remind them of their addiction (or to prompt them to try to quit).

Looking at it from the other side, those smokers who are so addicted that going without smoking during a flight is painful can still use nicotine replacement therapies (e.g., nicotine gum or patches) to reduce their symptoms and get through the flights.  But having to use NRTs to do that (instead of a recreational e-cigarette) will remind them of their medically undesirable addiction  and the need to quit.

But the bottom line is that flights should not accommodate unhealthy behaviors by a small minority that expose innocent bystanders, possibly including small children or even babies, to physical irritation and significant health harms.

So stop the delay and issue the rule.

Title: Janie Hammerberg
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should absolutely not be allowed on air planes or in any other public venue. Smoking is smoking regards of what type of material you choose to smoke.

Title: Joseph Wilson
Comment: There are too many unknowns with electronic cigarettes, and data surrounding their use in public has yet to be aggregated with enough history to validate their effect on bystanders.  Recommend their use in closed public spaces such as airplanes be forbidden until additional data can be obtained and reviewed.

Title: Jeanne Prom
Comment: Please do not allow e-cigarettes on airplanes or in airports or anywhere in or near indoors.  The secondhand and thirdhand aerosol contains nicotine as well as other chemicals that flight attendants and passengers including small children and infants, should not be exposed to.  The complete picture of what is in e-cigarette juice and the airborne aerosol it produces is not known, so until such time they are fully studied AND proven to be safe, e-cigarettes, e-juice and similar products should not be allowed on airplanes, in airports or near airports where people gather.  E-cigarettes and similar products can also explode.  New generation "tank" e-cigarettes contain liquid called e-juice. The e-cigarettes and e-juice are not regulated products, so there are no product assurances or standards.  Some e-cigarettes have malfunctioned and exploded.  Other e-cigarettes are designed specifically for "stealth vaping," which promotes using the product without being noticed.  Refillable tank system e-cigarettes could be used to store any kind of liquid, including other drugs and controlled substances or highly flammable material never intended for human consumption.  For public health and airline safety concerns, please do not allow e-cigarettes of any kind to be used in airplanes, airports and near airports and planes.

Title: Betty Campbell
Comment:
ARIZONANS for NON-SMOKERS' RIGHTS (ANSR) 

ANSR urges the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) to adopt rules that prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) on all airlines and in all transportation terminals without exceptions.    

A review of published data, titled, "Electronic cigarettes:  Human health effects," written by Dr. Priscilla Callahan-Lyon, Office of Science, Center for Tobacco Products, Food and Drug Administration, lists 48 references in regard to research on how e-cigarettes affect users and those nearby.  The review informs the public, "Nicotine is readily absorbed through the airway, skin, mucous membranes and gastrointestinal tract.  Acute exposure to inhaled nicotine may cause dizziness, nausea, or vomiting."

ANSR is receiving complaints that confirm that non-smokers who suffer from respiratory and cardiovascular impairments are reacting to exposure to e-cigarette vapor.  Immediate reactions include wheezing, difficulty breathing, oxygen deprivation and reduced levels of consciousness.  Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability in air travel.  See:  14 CFR Part 382, Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel.  SUBPART C - REQUIREMENTS CONCERNING SERVICES Section 382.31 Refusal of transportation states,  (a)  "Unless specifically permitted by a provision of this part, a carrier shall not refuse to provide transportation to a qualified individual with a disability on the basis of his or her disability."  

On October 24, 2013, CBS 5 - KPHO news reported "faulty e-cigarette likely to blame for fire that injured Vietnam Vet."  The first fire scorched the carpet.  The second fire "gutted the bedroom of their Sunnyslope area home."  The home owner "blames his wife's overheated "Smokin'T e-cigarettes chargers for starting the fires."  "They just exploded."  he said.  

The use of e-cigarettes threatens the health and safety of all passengers and all airline employees.  Infants, young children, the elderly and disabled passengers are especially vulnerable to exposure to e-cigarette vapor (ECV).  The risk of fire must be eliminated. 

The Department of Transportation must support the action taken voluntarily by the airlines by taking action to prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on all air carriers and in all airport facilities without exception and without delay.
