Title: Eleanor P.
Comment:
While I understand the public necessity of maintaining a healthy and safe environment for airline passengers, I am not sure that banning the use of electronic cigarettes would affect that objective. It is indeed possible that e-cigarettes present a real danger on flights; however, your department offers no scientific proof of this conclusion and seems to be creating arbitrary regulation.   

Traditional cigarettes were banned on commercial airlines because they were PROVEN to create a fire hazard and excess second-hand smoke for other passengers. However, until it is PROVEN that e-cigarettes can cause a similar danger as traditional cigarettes, I am not convinced that banning them outright will do anything except create needless regulation. 

If your only justification for banning e-cigarettes is that they may make passengers feel uncomfortable, then why stop with just these devices? Why not ban passengers from eating garlic on the plane? Certainly these garlic-consuming passengers' neighbors will feel uncomfortable sitting next someone with smelly breath. Or, why not ban passengers who might snore from falling asleep during the flight? Others around them will definitely get a better night's sleep if not inconvenienced by the snores of that passenger.  Or, most importantly, why not ban airlines from installing the tiny, economy-sized seats in their planes? Most passengers over the age of seven feel uncomfortable squeezing into such a cramped space. The list for all potential flight nuisances is lengthy, but it would be absurd to ban most of these.  I cannot distinguish how e-cigarettes are any different than these other annoyances unless provided some concrete evidence to support such a conclusion.  

To ban a product just because it is a nuisance for other passengers would bring about a slippery slope. Unless the department can offer some real correlative evidence that e-cigarettes have a direct harm for airline passengers, I am not convinced that this regulation will do anything but restrict individual passengers' liberty to enjoy non-smoke cigarettes on their flight.

Title: Pat Goltz
Comment: It is critically important that you act to ban electronic cigarettes from all places open to the public that are under your jurisdiction. They are not safe, and I have not consented to breathing these aerosols. If these are not banned, I will be unable to travel on public conveyances until that changes. Please act decisively against the use of these in public transportation. Thank you.

Title: Dr. Ebert Hino
Comment: ABSOLUTELY, NO E-SMOKING ON AIRPLANES, OR ANYWHERE, WHERE THE PUBLIC WOULD BE SUBJECT TO SMELLING OR EVEN BREATHING, ANY OF THE VAPORS EMANATING FROM THEM. IT IS A PROVEN FACT THAT THEY PRODUCE OTHER HARMFUL CHEMICALS THAN CONVENTIONAL TOBACCO PRODUCTS.

Title: Barbara Andrist
Comment:
All Electronic nicotine delivery devices should not be allowed on air crafts for the health of our children, passengers and  flight crew.  I do not want my grandchildren or anyone exposed to vapors which have not been proven to be safe.  The scientific reports coming in currently show secondhand e-cigarette aerosols are not harmless water but rather ultra fine particles lodging deep in the lung with volatile organic compounds along with known carcinogenics.  All the advertising in the world saying e-cigarettes are safe doesn't make it any more true.  Tobacco prevention efforts have worked to make smoking combustible products a thing of the past.  E- cigarettes, until proven safe, remain in the combustible tobacco products category, of use as directed and die taking a life or two with you as a result of second hand exposure. 

I appreciate flying in a smoke-free cabin; free of combustible tobacco products along with the absence of electronic cigarettes.  Please keep the electronic nicotine delivery devices off the aircraft and in the airports.

Title: Stacy Langen
Comment: Please consider banning all forms of vaping or use of electronic smoking devices on aircraft.  There simply is not enough research to support the safety of exposure to the secondhand vapor.  Initial studies have shown there is detectable Nicotine in this exhaled vapor as well as chemicals that are found in the main ingredient Propylene Glycol (a food additive approved by the FDA, but how safe is it to breath in).  These electronic devices also have many other consequences such as increased rise in use among US youth.  Please help to promote a healthier future for our youth, by not allowing them to see the use of these products in your public aircraft.  Nicotine is a terrible addiction, and these devices can often be a gateway to using traditional tobacco products.  Bottom line:  we are working hard to promote a healthier tobacco-free future for upcoming generations and these Electronic devices are a huge step in the wrong direction.

Title: Annie Peterson
Comment:
ASHRAE stands for the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning engineers, the folks who set clean air standards that are highly regarded worldwide.

In their recently released paper from June 2014, this was their conclusion about vapor devices. 

"We conclude that e-cigarettes emit harmful chemicals into the air and need to be regulated in the same manner as tobacco smoking. 

There is evidence that nitrosamines, a group of carcinogens found specifically in tobacco, are carried over into the e-cigarette fluid from the nicotine extraction process.10 There is also evidence that the glycol carriers can by oxidized by the heating elements used in e-cigarettes to vaporize the liquids, creating aldehydes such as formaldehyde. Consumers should be warned that, while the health risks associated with the usage of e-cigarettes are less than those associated with tobacco smoking, there
remain substantial health risks associated with the use of e-cigarettes."

The entire document can be found in the June 2014 ASHRAE Journal at ashrae.org or the document itself at 
2014June_038-047_IAQ_Offerman_rev.pdf

The Department of Transportation should move immediately to make the ruling against use of vapor devices on aircraft permanent.

Title: Carl Stein
Comment:
For the benefit of people who work in airplanes (flight attendants) as well as for the benefit of all airplane passengers, it is essential that DOT prohibit the use of e-cigarettes in all airplanes. E-cigarettes emit aerosols that contain nicotine, volatile organic compounds, lead, formaldehyde, and other chemical substances. Some of these substances found in aerosol from e-cigarettes are carcinogenic and are included in California's Proposition 65 list of substances that are identified as carcinogens and/or reproductive toxins. It's possible that we don't know yet all the substances that e-cigarettes emit. 

Prohibiting tobacco smoking from airplanes was a great step forward in protecting the health of people who fly in airplanes. To protect the same people's health, it's important that the use of e-cigarettes also be prohibited so that people who fly in airplanes are not forced to breathe the toxins that are emitted in the aerosol of e-cigarettes. Please do not take a step backward by allowing the use of e-cigarettes in airplanes.

Title: C. David Brown
Comment: Electronic cigarettes should not be permitted on commercial airline flights. Passengers have little control over the air quality in aircraft. A passenger cannot, for instance, easily move to another seat if a nearby individual is smoking. It is unacceptable for people to be exposed to pollutant-emitting products against their will in a confined space such as the cabin of an airplane.

Title: Sarah McGee
Comment: Please prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on all aircraft. I do not want to be exposed to any type of smoking devices and the aerosol they release into the air while cooped up in an airplane, and I'm pretty sure other passengers and the crew don't want to be exposed either.  This should be a no brainer!!

Title: Marty Eckrem
Comment: We have worked so hard to clean up the indoor air that we all breathe on airplanes and airports. Do not go backwards and allow e-cigarettes to be used in these areas. Airplanes are especially concentrated small pockets of air, and we feel very trapped in them anyway. E-cigarettes emit at least 10 chemicals that are carcinogenic or cause birth defects. The propolyene glycol is also a throat irritant.

Title: Lucille Ramirez
Comment:
E-cigs should absolutely NOT be allowed on aircraft!
This is a public health issue: Flight attendants and the public should not be expected to differentiate between a tobacco cigarette and an electronic smoking device, nor should they be exposed to any type of secondhand smoke or aerosol.
E-cigarettes do not just emit harmless water vapor. In fact, water is not an ingredient in these products.
Secondhand e-cigarette aerosol contains nicotine, hazardous ultra fine particles, volatile organic compounds, and other chemicals, some of which are carcinogenic (e.g., formaldehyde, metals like cadmium, lead, & nickel, and nitrosamines).
At least 10 chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.

Title: Robin Hobart
Comment:
I am writing to BEG you to prohibit the use of e-cigarettes or other vape devices on planes.

Air quality is paramount on planes.  Even IF e-cigs aren't as bad as what cigarettes put out, they still release toxins and small particulate matter into the air, none of which I should have to breathe just because someone else wants a nicotine fix.  It is impossible that e-cigs improve the air quality of the plane, they will degrade air quality and should not be allowed.

I have a better idea - let people chew nicotine gum if they can't wait.   At least secondhand gum doesn't threaten my lungs and my health.

Title: Martha Lannan
Comment:
Smoking of E-Cigarettes should NOT be permitted on aircraft.

This is a public health issue that would expose others to toxins, not just "harmless water vapor." Water is not a part of smoking an e-cigarette.
Secondhand e-cigarettes emit nicotine, toxic ultra-fine particles, and other chemicals including the carcinogenic formaldehyde, metals like cadmium, lead, & nickel, and nitrosamines. At least 10 chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.

You should NOT approve any proposals that involve smoking of e-cigs on aircraft.

Thank you.

Title: Lorraine Waldau
Comment: I am for restricting e-cigarettes and other aerosol/vapor delivery devices on all transportation - airplanes, trains, buses, etc.  The side vapor contains many of the same items as cause cancer in cigarettes.  The group of items in questions should be regulated the same as tobacco.

Title: Jennifer Knight
Comment: Please do not allow smoking of electronic cigarettes on aircrafts.  In addition to nicotine, the cartridges and vapor from some e-cigarettes contain volatile organic compounds such as acetone, cresol, xylene, styrene, ethyl alcohol, and acetaldehyde; all of which are associated with negative health effects. Carcinogens such as formaldehyde and -nicotyrine have also been found in e-cigarette cartridges and vapor. Not only do e-cigarettes contain potentially dangerous chemicals, but they also emit fine and ultrafine particles into the air, polluting the environment.  Let's continue to protect the health of all those on the aircraft and do not allow smoking of electronic cigarettes.

Title: Jean Salmon
Comment:
I hope that it is not corporate influence that is preventing the DOT from finalizing the rule to prohibit using e-cigarettes on airlines.

It is not harmless water vapor in e-cigarette's aerosol - it contains nicotine and other carcinogenic toxins.  With 10 of them being on California's s Prop 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins, your responsibility is to protect riders, flight attendants and pilots.  No one should be forced to breathe carcinogens when they need to travel.  

For too many years, smoking was allowed free reign, sickening many and increasing everyone's taxes to cover Medicaid/ Medicare.  Don't continue that shameful pattern.     E-cigarettes are nicotine delivery devices for addicts that should not be encouraged, especially when they hurt others.  Please take your responsibility seriously and act.


Thank you.

Title: Joy Zakarian
Comment:
E-cigarettes are dangerous to the public health and their use should not be allowed on airplanes. Their aerosols include nicotine, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and carcinogenic tobacco-specific nitrosamines (TSNAs) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). They also produce dangerous fine and ultrafine particles that may be deposited in the human lung. As their nicotine is deposited in the seats, ceilings, carpeting, and other surfaces of an aircraft, that may undergo further chemical reactions to form secondary organic aerosols and novel TSNAs not present in e-cigarette aerosols.

I urge the DOT to ban the use of e-cigarettes in all aircraft.

Thank you for your consideration of this important issue.

- Joy M. Zakarian, MPH

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Electronic cigarette vapor may contain harmful chemicals such as formaldehyde, propylene glycol, heavy metals, nicotine, and acetaldehyde. Research continues to emerge on the risks to users and nonusers breathing in the secondhand vapor. These are dangerous products already banned in public places in many cities and counties across the country, and on transit systems such as Amtrak. Airline passengers should not be subject to the health hazards of someone else's addiction to nicotine or chemical vapor products. The perfumey smells these dispensers release may also trigger migraines in sensitive individuals. Please keep e-cigarettes off our planes.

Title: Michael Takahara
Comment:
I would proud if US would prohibit e-cigarettes use on aircrafts.   Flight attendants and the public should not be expected to differentiate between a tobacco cigarette and an electronic smoking device, nor should they be exposed to any type of secondhand smoke or aerosol.  E-cigarettes are not regulated so we don't know what other particles are emited with the vapor.  I've seen research papers that have determine there are hazardous particles in the e-cigarette aerosol, including 10 that are on California's Proposition 65 lists of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.  

Please continue to prioritize the public health of our people.  Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I would like to see American continue to service SUX. We fly several times a year to Washington D.C.. The flight schedule out of SUX is convenient and so are the connecting flights from ORD to DCA and back. Give American a chance to build its customer base and maybe they will add flights to DFW

Title: Wilson
Comment:
As an individual who uses a wheelchair when traveling I urgently request that the kiosks are at a level that can be used by persons with disabilities.  And, not having one or two kiosks, but all.

Can you also require all airline agents to talk directly to the passenger (in the wheelchair) and not to the porter or other who might be pushing the chair.

Title: Richard Emel
Comment:
The final rule should require all airlines' reservations / ticketing methods, whether directly with the airline, web based, or through agents of ANY type, to automatically post/notify the proposed passenger and booking entity of any and all information/notifications/actions required of the airlines per the Air Carrier Access Act - Passengers with Disabilities section.  

The rule should require any such third party (i.e., other than the passenger booking directly for themselves) to notify said proposed passenger(s) of the posted information.  

Any data entered into any system providing scheduling / fare / cost / flights information, which contains keywords that indicate the possibility of a disability (service animal, oxygen, wheelchair, elderly, disabled, disability, etc) should trigger this information to be immediately displayed.  Any reservation and ticket issued to a disabled person (at their preference) should have the availability of the rights of a disabled passenger notated on the issued documents.  All computer data accessible at ticket counters / boarding areas / passengers service agents, of any type should be required to readily show the existence of the particular passenger as being disabled if the passenger so desires at the time of purchase or any time following, until completion of all travel in said ticketing, including connections.  

www.serviceanimalrefused.com

Title: Transportation Trades Department, AFL-CIO (Comments)
Comment: See attached pdf

Title: Nicholas Cohn
Comment:
I support strict limitations on the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft for these reasons:
1. Frustration and arguments between passengers will ensue, as many people will be irritated. These will escalate and result in more aggression on aircraft.
2. Safety: in case of incidents for which passengers should be paying attention to the crew and following directions, voice calls will be a big problem. Passengers will be calling everyone in a panic and not paying attention to safety procedures and actions they need to take.
3. Noise pollution and loss of restfulness on flights. Planes will become giant phone booths with everyone on conference calls or talking to their families. This will negatively impact the entire travel experience for all.

Thank you.

Title: Darrell Heinrichs
Comment:
No, no, 1,000 times no!  I fly approximately 28 times a year (56 legs) so while there are certainly people who fly much more than me, I fly enough to have a very strong opinion on this.  It is simply amazing to me what people talk about while on their cell phones.  As near as I can tell they must assume that a "cone of silence" surrounds them when they put the phone to their ear!  When I am sitting in the airport waiting for my flight I can move away easily enough but when I am stuck on a plane with no empty seats that option simply would not exist.  Those 3 - 4 hours in the air are absolutely precious to me - I can get ready for whatever I am flying too, or frankly wind down on my way home so I am not worthless when I hit the front door.  If I had to sit there for 3 hours listening to the details on somebody's latest affair, or whatever elective surgery they have planned next, or their plans for a "swingers" weekend (all conversations I have had to listen to in the airport waiting area in the last 60 days) I am sure my blood pressure by the end of the flight would be through the roof.

I suppose if the DOT is inclined to pass this anyway then you should be required to give every traveler a pair of noise cancelling headphones.  However, since they run $300 a pair, and according to the NATCA there are between 25,000 and 30,000 traveler per day (just in the U.S. - can you imagine sitting on a 12 hour international flight with the person beside you gabbing the whole way?!?!?!) that would run about $7.5M a day.  Hardly seems worth the trouble!

Title: Rebecca Petri
Comment:
With regard to a proposed rule regarding the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft, I would like to submit my comments in support of banning voice contact during an active flight.  

As an airline customer, I feel that allowing the use of connection for the purposes of texting, e-mailing, web-surfing, and other non-voice activities can be imperative to customers.  Some people traveling need access to online systems for work or family obligations while traveling.  If these activites do not pose a safety risk with electronics and communications for the flight itself, I see no reason not to allow passengers the additional communication or entertainment during flights.

With regards to voice communication, whether via mobile phone or internet, I believe it should be banned for the comfort of the other passengers.  Having people around you holding voice conversations constantly can make a long flght down-right unbearable and is even rude to the other passengers.  That said, there may be others that would contend they should be allowed to use their phone for an emergency reason.  If you are traveling, then arrangements should already be made for an alternate emergency contact while you are on the plane.  Should a dire emergency arise on the flight, people may ignore the rule, but in mose cases I feel that banning voice activites is best for the flying public.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comment!

Title: Glen Woods
Comment: Please, please, please DO NOT allow cell phone calls from inflight aircraft.  It seems people have cell phones implanted into their hands now-a-days.  Can't we at least disconnect for a few hours?!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please ban the use of wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  I am one among many travelers who enjoy peace and quiet on a plane - particularly for business travel.  Relative quiet on the plane gives me the opportunity to read, sleep, watch a movie, or do some work.  Mobile device callers are frequently rude and disrespectful of other people around them with regard to the volume of their voice, content of their conversations, and/or the length of conversation.  Some things simply don't need to be shared in a public forum.

Title: Anastasia Christman
Comment: I cannot urge you strongly enough to prohibit the use of cellphones for voice calls on aircraft.  These are small and constrained spaces where already tensions run high for passengers and flight attendants alike.  Whereas a train can reserve call-free areas ("quiet cars"), a plane cannot; just as people in non-smoking rows used to be smell the smoke drifting from the smoking areas of the cabin, so too will we all be subjected to the noise of phone calls no matter where the caller is.  The paramount issue on an airplane is safety, and the chance of disagreements or even violence breaking out over the din of voice calls is simply too high to allow the rule to change.  The second most important element is customer satisfaction, and we of the flying public cannot bear any more cuts to our comfort or dignity while flying.  Please, do not allow voice calls on flights, I beg of you.  The inevitable problems that will result are just not worth any purported convenience that advocates may claim would come with holding phone conversations while tens of thousands of miles above the earth.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a safety issue this should not be allowed.  The only result of non-emergency calls aboard aircraft, with multiple personalities in a confined space, will be an increase in inflight violence.  I urge you to not allow non-emergency voice calls aboard aircraft.

Title: Gene Hayes
Comment: Relative to the proposed rule to allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft I am very much opposed to this action.  It is my opinion that such an action would be a detrimental to both the general traveling public as well as potentially dangerous to the aircraft personnel.  After a recent three hour rail trip north from New York City in which the person in the adjacent seat took the opportunity to catch up on their political fact finding and gerrymandering opportunities in a voice which allowed/insisted that all within a 15 ft radius were able to see how "important" he/she was in his/her eyes (mind), I can only say that I was fortunate to be able to vacate my seat and head to the club car for some peace and quiet.  Had this incident happened on an airflght then there would have been no escape and given the apparent personality of my fellow traveler he/she would have been more likely to tell me to take a flying leap rather than affording me any consideration.  Unfortunately relaxed/considerate travelers is more of an oxymoron and given that with the pressurized cabins the gaining of altitude/thinning of the air supply no longer works the miracles that it did in the past I remain appalled to the aspect of allowing voice calls on commercial flights.

Title: Dan Kirby
Comment: As a very frequent (multi-million miler) flier, I urge you to conclude that the use of cellular phones on aircraft within or to the USA would be so disruptive as to be inconsistent with adequate air transportation.  Some passengers are so loud and inconsiderate on cell phones that I have seen numerous arguments and potential fights in boarding areas and on board before the doors are closed.  This type of disruption in the air could have disastrous consequences.

Title: Wade White
Comment:
There is little logic to prohibit the use of wireless phones on planes while not prohibiting the use of wired phones on planes- forgiving the profit margin on the later.  The fact that some folks do not like hearing someone else talking on a phone (and I'm one of them), personal distaste does not constitute enough of a basis to justify government intervention.  The proposed regulation lacks a logical nexus to public interest that supersedes personal liberty.  Just because you can do it does not mean that you should.  

If a traveler does not like hearing the people around them speak to others in person or on the phone, perhaps they should invest in a set of headphones rather than trying to use the power of the federal government to regulate what is otherwise benign behavior.

Title: Cindy L.
Comment: I recommend continuing the prohibition of using mobile wireless devices for voice calls on commercial aircraft.  Allowing voice calls during a flight would be disruptive to other passengers in addition to the call participant, especially during safety instructions or in-flight announcements from the flight crew.  The flight crew provides verbal safety instructions that may be difficult to hear and follow if other passengers are engaged in conversations on the phone.  Unlike a conversation with another fellow passenger that may stop when an in-flight announcement is made, a speaker on the phone may not be aware that there is a safety announcement occurring and the conversation may not cease to listen to the announcement.

Title: Kirk Haybarker
Comment:
I am opposed to allowing any mobile wireless voice or computer generated voice communication by passengers, or like personal voice communications by airline personnel, on airlines when the doors are closed. This would be an unfair, unavoidable, disruptive and dangerous intrusion that will have adverse affect on the passenger's flight comfort, health and post arrival safety.  Real and true in flight emergency calls can be done by airline personnel. 
 
In response to the numbered sections on this website:
1) To allow voice or computer generated voice communications would be unfair to all airline passengers as it would be disruptive to personal conversation, and reduce or in some situations totally preclude any manner of personal focus, concentration and work productivity.  It would also reduce the ability of passengers to rest or sleep on the plane for all flights, including but not limited to early morning and evening flights, and in so doing would present a danger to many persons, not the least of which is the international flyer and frequent business flyer, both of which I am one.  These individuals already live with a disrupted sleep pattern, like the majority of us, and the further intrusion into their rest by non-stop phone calls will surely result in further incidents of sleep deprived auto accidents and other serious incidents of injury at their ultimate destinations.
3) A passenger's exposure to any manner of voice communication, whether personal or electronically produced, and whether at the spoken/transmitting or receiving end, will have similar adverse effects.  All manner of mobile wireless voice communication should be prohibited in flight.
4) The only exception to a total ban on mobile voice communication on airlines I could see as reasonable would be allowances for single entry charter flights where all passengers were employees or members of an organization that was paying 100% of the flight cost of all passengers on the airline, with no payment by the passengers for their participation in the flight.  The rules would have to be tightly written to preclude carriers from finding loopholes that result in unaware passengers being exposed to undesired mobile device disruption.
6)  All voice/ sound communication receiving and/ or transmitting devices should be banned on airlines in flight except for emergency communications by flight crews and emergency personnel.
7)  Use of mobile phones and like communications until the aircraft door closes and once again after it opens works now because it enables passengers to communicate travel delays and arrange pickups and the like all at once and be done with it, without becoming overbearing to fellow passengers with prolonged communications. This is the limit of what should be allowed.
8) Crew members, air marshalls and the like should not be exempt from prohibitions on mobile device voice communications for other than emergency purposes.  Personal and business mobile device voice calls should not be allowed in flight by anyone.  If true emergency calls are required, they can be accommodated by crew members.
9) When on an aircraft, the person sitting next to you is not across the table from you, nor even at a comfortable sitting, let alone a comfortable working and listening distance.  They are not just "in close quarters," they are literally in you personal space for the duration of the flight.  Psychological consultation and testing would be warranted as to the effects of intermittent and uncontrollable voices in a person's ear for which they have no control over duration or volume.  As referenced in comment one above, it is unfair, unhealthy and dangerous to introduce into an aircraft for sustained periods such a disruption to sleep, work productivity, and any means of focus and concentration.  As a business traveler I am especially concerned with the adverse effect on ability to be productive when working in flight, the discomfort of having the individual next to me talking in my ear where I hear both ends of an unwanted conversation spoken at abnormally loud volume, the unavoidable sound of unwanted voices all around me with no control (sounds like a psychological thriller if ever there was one) and the effect of traveling at odd hours, not just night, and then driving in a strange rental car in a strange city while overly tired because I was unable to sleep during my flight because of the sound of voices all around me.  It creates a dangerous situation on our highways that the USDOT should be well aware of.  As an individual who has experienced this, and who has been responsible for reviewing highway accident statistics associated with dozing while driving, this warrants a lot more analysis before any consideration of allowing mobile voice communications on flights.  I am staunchly opposed to the use of mobile voice communications devices on flights

Title: Barry Graham
Comment: Mobile wireless use should be allowed on aircraft.  it's no more intrusive than a regular voice conversation.  What needs to be adjusted is people's attitude towards others, and then flights would be happier for those that are bothered by the thought of this.  I don't plan to use my cell phone for voice calls, however it's wrong for the government to regulate something that is illegal only because there is a law making it so.  The government should not be passing laws to prevent voice calls just because they might annoy some people.  Also these calls have been allowed overseas for some time and there are no issues reported.  Likewise when there were phones on planes, there were no issues.  There are more important things for the DoT and people to be worrying about.

Title: Joseph Cottrell
Comment:
I strongly support the continued prohibition of the inflight use of mobile devices for voice calls on aircraft.

My background includes being a commercially rated pilot, frequent airline traveler, and smart phone user. The airline cabin environment is a complicated one, and is at times stressful. One of the problems in today's already stressful environment is that strangers, of different cultures and sometimes languages, are placed in extremely close proximity. Behaviors and activities that are appropriate for some may be considered inapropriate for others.Loud speaking and phone use are extremely intrusive and will only serve to raise the stress level further.

Last week, I had to summon the flight attendant to deal with a lady, seated behind me, who was talking on her cell phone, throughout the safety announcements and subsequent aircraft taxi. I can only imagine an emergency evacuation when people are trying to call network news and take videos instead of exiting the aircraft in an orderly fashion. In addition to the imposition on other travelers, I ultimately think we are dealing with a safety issue as well.

I strongly support the continued prohibition of phone calls during flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Given the space constraints and the density of people I hope that this will never be allowed. Also, with seating space being quite narrow, people holding up their phones to their ears will infringe on the space of other people since their ellbows, will always be in other people's faced.

Please DO NOT allow voice calls. Even messages are bad enough given that most people will forget to mute their phones until they receive the first messages.

Title: M. Breitstein
Comment: Do not ban cell phone use on airplanes.  People need to be polite a self-regulate their conversations, regardless of where they are.  Just because some people might be annoyed is no reason to legally prohibit an activity.  If that were the case, there would be laws prohibiting cell phone use in many many situations (grocery stores, waiting rooms, beaches, etc.).  But that is not the way life works.  People need to be polite, but polite is not a legal matter.

Title: Vikas Garg
Comment: Absolutely not. Imagine hundreds of people talking in limited space. I do agree that we should allow messages, internet, etc., but definitely not voice calls.

Title: Matthew Murray
Comment: No! Quality of air travel is already decreasing quickly, the one thing we have left is the ability to work or relax without hearing others' conversations. Allowing phone calls would pollute the already polluted aircraft, and foster a hostile environment at best for crew and pax.

Title: Christopher Luczak
Comment: TEXTING AND WEB ACCESS BUT NO VOICE CALLS....COMPROMISE IS FINE!

Title: Anne Lance - Comments
Comment: Allowing the use of cell phones on airplanes during flight sounds like a nightmare. It's already bad enough being squashed into seats without sufficient room to be comfortable, dealing with screaming kids and surly adults, listening to audio from the movie, music and games from the people who turn it up loud enough to hear outside their own headphones,  and all the other nightmares that go with flying nowadays. This will send things over the edge. We don't need idiots talking constantly on their cellphones (yes they do talk louder on phones than in person), hearing cellphones ringing multiplied by however many people want to use them. I rarely take a plane anymore because it is just so uncomfortable already - if cellphones are allowed I will reconsider travel plans even more. Amtrak is already much better - lots of space in the seat, a quiet car, the ability to walk around at will. Air travel has no appeal and cellphone use will make it worse.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed in allowing the use of cell phones on airplanes.  Conversations going on while others are nearby in an enclosed area is distracting and you can't escape from them.

Title: Robert Slade
Comment: Please, if the issue of cell phone use on airplanes comes onto the DOT agenda, don't allow it!  The cramped confines of an aircraft where you are now elbow-to-elbow with seatmates is not the place for unfettered access to voice calls.  While common sense should make phone use unthinkable on airplanes, people have become so jaded and selfish about their own circumstances, they think nothing about the rights and feelings of others.   So, please, please, please, if the FCC drops the current ban, please put something in place to maintain the status quo and give travelers some respite from the electronic intrusion that exists virtually everywhere else in our lives.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly oppose the use of mobile devices on airplanes except for texting only.  There is no escaping from an inconsiderate user when in flight.  No loud noises should be allowed.  Moreover, if mobile wireless devices are allowed, the flight attendants would then be required to police misbehavior which simply is not fair to them.  Please, please, please do not allow phone usage during flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a frequent flyer, PLEASE do not allow cell phone usage on flights, unless you can provide an area where they can go have their conversations in private, away from the other passengers.  Cell phone users are loud and there is no escape from them while bucked into my seat.  I do not want to be held hostage to their loud and annoying conversations.

I do not have any objections to text messaging, if done in silent mode, so I don't have to hear the constant clicking.

Title: Michael
Comment: As a frequent flyer I do not want to be on a plane and listen to half a dozen phone conversations while I'm trying to reach my destination.  Please do not let it happen.  Thank You.

Title: Steven Loftin
Comment: I am firmly against allowing voice calls on aircraft. As a frequent flyer experienced with both domestic and international flights, I am all too familiar with the many invasions of personal space by obnoxious passengers. I cannot imagine being forced to endure listening to a protracted, loud, non-urgent phone conversation by my seatmate.  I cannot move to another seat, away from such events, as I might on other forms of public transportation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As close as all passengers sit on planes there would not be a comfortable volume for a caller to use to not disturb the passengers around them. The flight crew have enough to do and monitor now that to increase their responsibilities to have to monitor and decide what is too loud sees unreasonable. In the every day world, there is enough intrusion of cell phone users who cannot police themselves but usual a person has the ability to move away from disturbance. That will not be the case on an airplane. To give passengers the ability to text would seem to appropriate.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The inflight use of voice communication devices should be prohibited on all commercial flights operating from or within U.S. airspace.  Given the fixed, close proximity of passengers, ambient noise within the cabin, and the general sense of interpersonal tension, the incorporation of voice enabled devices would be tantamount to adding a spark to a compressed combustible gas.  At altitude, a highly volatile and undesirable situation.

Title: Robert Horne
Comment:
No, No, No. Please do not make any changes in the current rules which limit the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. We have all already experienced the use of mobile devices at the airport gates by loud, obnoxious persons who either have little regard for their fellow passenger or erroneously believe that their fellow passengers are somehow interested in their conversations. 

Already we see that some persons take liberties with the current privilege of being able to use their mobile devices while at the airport gate by trying to expand the use of their mobile phones beyond the point where the aircraft doors are closed. This creates consternation among the flight attendants who have to deal with these abuses before the plane even leaves the ground.


I can only imagine the "air rage" that might occur when passengers are forced to sit next to a rude and obnoxious person who talks loudly while on the plane during a four hour trip from the east to the west coast. Just the potential alone of "air rage" is enough of a safety concern to realize that this is not a desirable situation. Air travel has become tough and stressful enough already. Please don't make any changes which will adversely affect the situation.

Title: Constantina Landt
Comment: No. Phone calls were never allowed on airline flights in the beginning for good reason and they shouldn't be allowed for any other reason, especially because people are whining about it. It's gonna cause a major incident one day. I say remove the phones from the persons body until they land at their destination and then give it back. Problem solved.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No voice calls on aircraft flights. Too confined an area for a lot of voice calls. There probably will be phone rage sooner or later.

Title: David Mann
Comment: Continue the ban on cell phone voice calls on aircraft.  Too many passengers are causing problems on aircraft for many other reasons and cell phones voice calls will certainly make it worse.  Allowing voice calls will be detrimental to flight crews and passengers.

Title: Gary Glojek
Comment:
I am against allowing cell phones in commercial aircraft, BUT if you do, have them all sit in the back of the plane and charge them an additional fee for the right to use a cell phone.
Later, Gary

Title: Linda
Comment: NO cell phones on aircraft where there is no escape from the annoyance.

Title: Craig Devenport
Comment:
Common sense is all that is necessary here.  The use of cellular phones should be prohibited on scheduled airlines. The tight proximity of passengers, the inability of many people to manage their phones in courteous manner will lead to verbal and sometimes physical altercations, due to an adjacent customers inability to remove his/her self from the offending parties incessant phone use, complete with loud voice and vulgar language and the airing of personal disputes. This can and will cause instances that may endanger crew members and passengers unnecessarily .

The use of cellular phones should be permitted on General Aviation and on demand Pt. 135 flights as these passengers are generally related in some way, through employment, relationship, etc. This use of the phone can be self regulated by the passengers in this case and altercations would be unlikely- however, the ultimate decision on whether cellular calls be permitted on GA or Pt. 135 aircraft should be made by the operator of the aircraft or the PIC.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO THANKS!!!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cellphones on planes. It is annoying enough to listen to loud conversations in the airport where you can walk away.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I understand the reasons to allow cell phone use on flights, a major one being that people already have conversations with each other on flights so why not allow people to talk to others on a phone; however, I think cell phone use on planes should absolutely not be allowed.  Public phone etiquette is nearly nonexistant.  People speak louder on phones than they would to someone in person, reception will be dicey and cause connection issues, resulting in the oh-so-annoying "can you hear me know" phrase, and phones ringing will add noise (annoying tones, often) to an already noisy flight.  The seats on planes are restrictive enough without adding people's elbows at near face level to the mix or others desperately shuffling to get to their under-seat bags to find the ringing phone before they miss a call.  Lastly, planes already have multiple annoyances that are out of passenger's control (e.g. babies crying, restless animals, people listening to movies or music loud enough for the rows around them to hear, narrow seats and aisles where you are constantly squished, bumped into and uncomfortable, etc.) that adding phone conversations on top of it is preposterous when it can be prevented.  People will be fine not talking to someone on the phone; we have done it for years and no one has died from not making a phone call on a plane.  I welcome the opportunity to put down technology during a flight.

Title: Jim Mitchell
Comment:
Allow the AIRLINES to make this decision.  

Here is why........

Yes - the FCC and DOT should definitely allow this technology....

TEXTING using cellphone technology through  picocells should certainly be allowed
100% full time.  Not an issue to other passengers.   This helps people inform loved ones about delays, ride pick-ups, travel status.  Airlines can always regulate when and of voice is available (early and late phases of flight perhaps).

My last flight had an alzheimer person in my seat
row.  Our flight got rerouted 100+ miles away due to fog.
This person could not even find her way to the rest room.
There was no way to inform her loved ones where she was
headed nor did she understand her predicament.

A cell call would have saved this poor lady a lot of stress
And her family a lot of concern.

No doubt there are a lot of patients like this,
Children traveling alone etc.

I have not heard about any international issues that have deployed this technology

JM

Title: Mark Wolinski
Comment: I support the continued strict limitations on the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  Unfortunately, some people cannot self-monitor their behavior and how it impacts those around them.  Giving people the "right" to make calls during flights will undoubtedly lead to frustration and arguments between passengers and passengers and airline staff.  We all know how problematic this type of situation can be and contemplating a verbal and/or physical confrontation in the confines of an aircraft is very troubling. Removing the limitations on phone calls during flights is a terrible idea: The limitation should not be changed.

Title: John Freiler
Comment:
See Attachment:

I hope that consideration of a ban be concluded as that it is not called for, that rude or disruptive passengers with a cell phone in their hand can just as easily be treated the same as rude or disruptive passengers without a cell phone.   This proposed regulation is onerous and unnecessary.

Title: Sam Thompson
Comment: No, I don't think it is a good idea to use cell phones while flying and here is why, it is disruptive especially to those on long flights, I don't want to hear other peoples conversations while I am flying, it is stressful enough to just get from point A to point B, and unless it is an emergency I don't think there is any need to use a phone while flying, it is to small of a space to try to carry on a conversation while flying.  I think any calls can wait until landing.  I like as much peace when flying as possible, thank you

Title: David Corban
Comment: As a lawyer who regularly travels by plane and who regularly flies to visit family in two states over 1000 miles from my homse, I adamantly oppose the use of cell-phones on airplanes in flight.  Even on the longest flights, any emergencies can be addressed via the crew, and everything else can wait.  The maintenance of peace and security aboard airplanes trumps any minor convenience from being unable to use one's cell-phone for idle chatter, and with shrinking seats and personal space on most flights, being forced to listen to another passenger's business or personal concerns will acerbate the friction that already exists over limited elbow, ankle room and overhead bin space.  The growing inconveniences of routine air travel have frayed tempers enough.  If unnecessary telephone talk is added, there will be trouble.  Finally, if anyone thinks that compulsive cell-phone users will adopt a civil tone and limits their invasion of others' personal space, just listen to the loud and purposeless conversations that take place in the pre-boarding areas.  Those will be repeated on the planes in transit, ad nauseum.  In sum, opening air travel to cell-phone use is a TERRIBLE IDEA.   No no no, a thousand times no.

Title: J. S.
Comment: I am against allowing voice calls on commercial aircraft during flight.  They are a huge annoyance in public now and I can only imagine the annoyance of everyone, trapped in an aircraft fuselage, trying to talk over all the other callers.  In the already noisy environment of an aircraft in flight, the yelling would be intense.

Title: Connor Nelson
Comment: I would urge you to prohibit the use of voice communications on airplanes because of how confined the space is. People are already on edge after a long flight and do not need somebody obnoxiously talking on their phone with disregard for everyone else on the plane.

Title: Julian Fisher
Comment: While cell phones may not cause interference with avionic, they will certain cause interference with the already crowded and unpleasant cabin experience.  They would be most disruptive and should not be approved for use while the airplane has pushed back or is in flight.

Title: John Gonzalez
Comment: Noooooooooo!!!!! Please don't subject us to listening to others' private idiotic conversations. Please don't listen to the lobbyists who just want to make money. I beg that you never allow cellphone conversations in such tight quarters. There will be actual violence.

Title: R. McD
Comment: Absolutely not!  There are enough irritations when flying already.  If cell phone use is allowed, I'll have to quite flying.

Title: Chip Orum
Comment: Absolutely not!!! no, no, no, no

Title: Kirsten Fitrell
Comment: If the plane is in the air, NO VOICE CALLS!  Period.  I don't want to spend my flight captive to someone else's chatter.  But, more importantly, I don't want my safety threatened by interference.  There's no definitive proof either way, but why take the chance?

Title: Lesley Dehaan
Comment:
No.
I am against the just of phones on commercial aircraft

Title: David Lum
Comment: Absolutely Not, do you how distracting and annoying it would be for four hundred people to be talking on their phones and  locked in a plane together for four hours. Nothing anyone has to say on a phone is so important that they can't wait until they are in their own private area.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft.  Airplanes are cramped enough as is, and I don't want to listen to people loudly talk about their personal lives the entire flight.  Can't there be one place where we can just sit quietly for awhile?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow cellphone conversations on board planes.People have shown themselves to be unable to self-regulate in order not to annoy others nearby, and it's not reasonable to expect flight attendants to modify these behavoirs.  It's already hot, crowded and noisy on board, don't make it even worse.

Title: Sue
Comment: Please do everything possible to prevent voice cell phone calls during air flights.  If allowed air travel would be miserable.

Title: James Allen
Comment: Please, please....no talking on cell phones on planes.

Title: Pat Hannigan
Comment:
Please do not allow phone calls on planes. Traveling is difficult enough these days without a bunch of people talking for hours about absolutely nothing. 
Thank you.

Title: Fred Bruno
Comment: As a regular business flyer, I find the current state of the plan environment to be stressful, uncomfortable and confusing. Permitting the use of cell phones by passengers would only increase this level of discomfort and add a truly annoying activity within a confined space. Obviously, I am against allowing cell phone usage on aircraft.

Title: James Tiffee
Comment:
Department of Transportation, Docket DOT-OST-2014-0002

Please don't lift the ban on voice calls.  Air travel is crazy enough and the only sanctuary sometimes is while actually flying through the air.  From the time you start your trip you are subject to crowds, repetitive robotic PA announcements in the airport, gate agent announcements, etc.  When you finally in the air and the flight crew announcements are done you can take a sigh of relief and sit back and enjoy a nap, a book, or music.  Most planes now have WiFi so business travelers can email and conduct business quietly via their laptop or tablet.  The last thing we need is some business guy conducting a conference call or a 15 year old teenager gabbing with their friends about Justin Beiber for the duration of a 2 hour flight.  Many people don't seem to understand that the phone amplifies their voice and carries it away to the caller at the other end.  They talk twice as loud to their phone as they would to someone sitting next right to them.  Many people become self absorbed in the phone call and unaware of their surroundings and the impact their actions are having on others around them.  

Please, allow data, silent texting, web browsing, etc.  But there is no room for voice calls on airplanes.

Title: Jason Rabinowitz
Comment: I believe that voice calls should be allowed on aircraft. Many airlines across the world have had this feature for years with not a single recorded instance of abuse or passenger fights. The high cost prevents passengers for making lengthy calls. A ban on calls just shows that people do not understand how the technology works. This ban is unnecessary and should be left for the individual airlines to decide. This is not a government issue.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The USDOT should NOT prohibit voice calls (whether conventional cellular or VOIP on aircraft, however if necessary, it should make clear that each airline has the authority to set its own rules.  The CAB precedent that smoking was NOT harmful to non-smokers on airlines and that it could still be prohibited on the grounds of it being injurious or harmful was a mistake and should not be used to justify a prohibition on cell phones.  Let the industry compete and experimentation determine what customers want.  This topic can be re-evaluated after several years of actual experience. 

While a passenger cannot remove himself from a seatmate making a call, the practice is not unfair, nor does it render air service inadequate. 

Addressing the specific questions:
1) No, it is not necessary to Is it necessary for the Department to propose a rule to deem passenger voice 
communications as an unfair practice, and ban voice communications on passengers’ 
mobile wireless devices on flights under any of the regulatory parts cited in the ANPRM.
2) As a traveler, I would rarely make a call from a flight, but may for a high priority business purpose or family emergency. The Department should refrain from issuing a notice of proposed rulemaking on this topic and 
instead allow the airlines to develop individual policies.
3) Provided it is technically safe, no voice communications should be banned, regardless of media type.
4) No ban should be put in place, however if one is, than charter flights, and especially single entity flights should be excepted, since the chartering entity should set it's own rules for such use, provided it is safe.
5) No comment
6) Text to speech SHOULD be excepted, especially as the user could use ear buds,or a headset. The primary "noise" to other passengers is from the passenger talking, as the other party is typically heard through a headset or ear buds.
11) Requiring use of some form of headset and not allowing speaker-phone use would cut down on the overall noise level. .

Title: Larry Prescott
Comment: I am absolutely opposed to cell phone usage on airplanes.  Anyone who thinks this is a good idea should go sit in the waiting area by an airport gate and imagine being trapped inside an airplane with the cell phone loud mouths yelling away about their personal lives.  There will be personal confrontations occur inside airplanes that won't happen with the ban in place.

Title: Denis Bekaert
Comment: Voice calls should be absolutely banned on commercial aircraft from the time the doors are closed until landing.  Text and data communication would certainly be acceptable if audible notification was silenced.  Having to listen to one-sided inane conversation while trapped at altitude would be cruel and unusual punishment to other passengers. Please do not allow this rule change!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No.  Since the interior is so confined and lots of people do not understand/practice telephone etiquette or common courtesy then allowing calls on an airplane is a formula for a stressful environment and possible confrontation.

Title: Louis Peterson
Comment: You think you have security concerns now? Wait until you have a dozen chattering idiots on a flight running their mouths off nonstop! No, heck no! Use some common sense man! You have a closed environment from which you have no escape. Throw in incesant chatting on cell phones and you have the perfect mix for tons of violence and fighting in the cabin. Allow cell phone use in flight and you will end up with tons of emergency landings due to fights. Why on earth would you want to open this can of worms? Don't we have enough to worry about with in-flight safety? Whose idiotic idea is this?

Title: Janice Lukas
Comment: Please NO CELL PHONE CALLS ON PLANES.  Too many people already are inconsiderate users of this device. It would be most uncomfortable to sit inches away from a loudmouth barking into bis/her phone for any amount of time.

Title: Kerry Berger
Comment: I feel cell phone calls should NOT be allowed on airplanes.  People tend in the US, to talk very loudly on phones and in a closed cabin such as a plane, the sound of someone talking about their poor pet or Aunt Betsy is disturbing and so unnecessary.  We lived so many years without a cell phone, we are not allowed to use them in theaters or at concerts, so why would we create noise pollution on an airplane flight.  It's bad enough when people switch on their cell phones when planes are taxiing for take off or descending for a landing, after flight attendants have specifically announced that phones must be shut off.  These people show a complete lack of respect for others around them and in the case of an emergency, how would flight attendants deal with them?   This is a horrible proposal and should be prohibited.

Title: Ryan Sullivan
Comment: Allowing the use of voice calls during will cause already miserable air travel conditions to become unbearable. If this proposal is approved, conflict and violence between passengers and crew are almost certain. The close, uncomfortable quarters of modern air travel already prevent privacy and any ability to truly control noise levels. These circumstances increase anxiety and agitation among people on board. Increasing noise levels with an entire aircraft full of passengers yelling into their cell phones is a nightmare scenario that will further compromise air safety, comfort, and working conditions for airline crews. Please do not allow this proposal to advance.

Title: William Fletcher
Comment: I do not believe that cell phone calls should be allowed while the plane is in flight. No one should have to listen to another person during a flight, while they ramble on and on.

Title: Cathy Parker
Comment: This will increase the already uncomfortable, unbearable conditions in-flight.  Nobody wants to hear someone talking on the phone during a flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I don't want to pay for plane tickets only to listen to someones cell phone calls.  Nothing can be that important that it can't wait until the plane lands.  I vote NO!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No phone calls on plane flights, thanks.

Title: Jim Smith
Comment: LISTEN TO YOUR FLIGHT ATTENDANTS. ITS HARD ENOUGH FOR CURRENT ELECTRONIC USERS TO PUT IT AWAY . I DO NOT WANT TO LISTEN TO SOMEONE TALK ON AN OVERNIGHT FLIGHT AS IT IS. FLIGHT ATTENDANTS HAVE SPOKEN ON LOS ANGELES TV SAYING THEY FIND IT PATENTLY UNSAFE. DO NOT LISTEN TO THE PUBLIC. YOUR FLIGHT ATTENDANTS ARE YOUR ONLY SOURCE OF ACTUAL SAFETY PERCEPTION ON THIS. THEY HATE IT. PLEASE DO NOT LET THIS HAPPEN. NO CELL PHONES ON .

Title: Kathy Choice
Comment: I believe if the use of wireless devices for cellular calls are allowed on aircraft there will be a need for air marshall on every aircraft.  Tensions already run high with air travel, having to listen to someons conversation for an hour or more will result in pandemonium among passengers and be absolutely disasterous.

Title: Judy Kosovich
Comment: Cell phone calls and other wireless devices should not be permitted on aircraft.  It makes air travel unavailable to the electrically sensitive population, a growing constituency.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I Don't Mind as Long as I don't have to hear any of it or it does not interfere with me sleeping.

Title: Ron Locklar
Comment: I do not want telephone calls allowed on flights, it is too closed an environment to have people talking on the phone.  I am fine with allowing texting though.

Title: John Vogt
Comment: Do not allow calls to be made on aircraft. If anything it will create more issues in the air as more people talk and eventually upset one another. It is not only a safety issue but a security issue. People WILL get upset with eachother and terrorist COULD use it to talk to teams on the ground or in the air.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It seems perfectly reasonable to allow data and texting during the flight, and calls only during the last portion for when it might be more urgent to arrange ground transport, etc. And to request ringers be turned off at the start of the flight, perhaps during the fasten seat belts order. I fear too many unruly passengers if they are allowed to make voice calls and end up being asked to keep their voices down.

Title: Aranza Kottmeyer
Comment:
Hi. Please do NOT allow anyone to talk on their cell phone or whatever during a flight unless to call for 911. PLEASE!

Some people are so loud and rude and could be having an argument with someone and keep everyone who wants to read or sleep from doing so.

I cannot stand being on the DC Metro listening to the conversations and so I do NOT want to be an airplane for hours at at time in some cases.

I do understand that someone might want to clear up a misunderstanding or arrange for a babysitter but if you allow for email or text that should not be a problem. 

Please do NOT allow for any use of cell phones during a flight. Thank you for your time. Thanks.

Title: Lynne
Comment: DO NOT ALLOW PHONE CALLING,TEXTING OK

Title: Lee Fox
Comment: I want to strongly recommend that NO changes be made that would allow for the use of mobile cell phone or any other device for communicating by voice, ie. talking, while aboard an aircraft while in motion. The rules as presently used should remain in full force and effect regarding the use of cell phones. I'll give you an antidote that occurred while I was getting a foot massage in Thailand last week. I was serenely resting in a lounge chair getting a foot massage, and as the chairs were close to each other, a foreign speaking dude sat next to me. He suddenly begins to have a cell phone conversation and is no more then 2 feet away from me (ear) while talking in a loud voice and completely unaware of annoying me or others in the vicinity, never mind that he was speaking in Russian or whatever language, and after giving him a severe dirty look that didn't even phase him, kept on talking!  I can only imagine this scenario taking place on an airplane with numerous people all talking at the same time in close proximity, and then  justifying their right to do so come hell or high water, and  listening to the inane conversations that take place.  We survived 20 years ago WITHOUT cell phones and we can certainly survive WITHOUT cell phone conversations on an aircraft now!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly support the continued prohibition of phone calls on airplanes.  I don't believe it's reasonable to expect passengers to engage each other (asking someone to please quiet down.)  This places additional strain on flight crews, who will inevitably be required to intervene.

Title: Sean Sullivan
Comment:
Please do not allow the use of cell phones for voice calls on airplanes during flight.  Voice conversation via cell phone will make flying almost unbearable and will cause serious safety problems.  It is  is an incredibly bad idea and I find it hard to believe this is even being considered.  I can not state my opposition more strongly. 
Please use common sense.
People can text all they want.  But NO voice calls.
"Just Say NO"

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please, please do not allow the use of mobile wireless devices on aircraft. I do not want to sit and listen to somebody's conversation. It is bad enough in the airport before the flight.

Title: Brad Peterson
Comment:
Please do NOT allow this.  As a frequent flyer I believe this will lead to violence on airplanes.  In other places people have the ability to walk away as they talk or if I can walk away if they are talking to loud.  I do not have the ability to walk away on an airplane. 

I do not want to listen to someone talking about their weekend for the whole flight when I'm trying to sleep or work on the plan.  Nothing good will come from allowing cell phones on airplanes.

Title: Andrea Bryant
Comment:
Voice call are not necessary - or wanted.

NO ONE is important or busy enough, to have to spend a flight TALKING on a cell phone.  
If you are - or your business is so urgent - stay 'home' and take care of it.
There are multiple options already available for anyone who MUST conduct business while traveling without adding voice calls.

People will not be considerate of their neighbors, or if inclined to - with the shrinking aisle, seat room - we are traveling on top of each other - and do not need the added intrusion.

I travel over 40 weeks a year on business and do not want to be subjected to cell phone chatter on ANY flight I take.
Please do not allow a few to impose on the majority.

NO VOICE CALLS!

Title: Philip Oakes
Comment: Absolutely NOT!!! Please don't allow this to happen! Being trapped in that tube speeding through the air for...however long it might be...is bad enough if you have a cramped row all to yourself. Turn that into a full flight where you might have a middle seat and feel claustrophobic and the person next to you is obnoxious anyway...and now you want to give them a cell phone?!? NOOOO!!!!!! Please don't do it! Please no! It serves no purpose!

Title: Felicia Jackson
Comment: Text messaging on flights is totally acceptable and enough to allow for communication. Please do not allow voice calls during flights because I don't want to be subjected to someone else's conversation for hours....with no way to get away.

Title: MyGina McAboy
Comment:
I think that cell phones should be aloud to be used on an airplane if: 

- It does not effect any or important airplane functioning devices 
- Flight attendants are aloud to confiscate a cell phone due to the use of that cell phone being disruptively distracting or being used in a rude inappropriate manner (Cell phone use should be a privilege not a right)

Thank you for taking the time to listen to my point of view on the matter. I don't know how you are but have a lovely day.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow phone calls on aircrafts. These calls would be most irritating to the general traveling public. Just because we have the capability to do something doesn't  mean we should do it. Life is annoying enough without this.

Title: Bryan Newshan
Comment: Please Keep the Cell phone Ban in effect on all Flights. Thanks

Title: Elaine Poole
Comment: The call can wait.  Annoying your fellow passengers is not the answer.  Some folks do not know how to speak quietly on the phone.  I do not want to know anyone business.  Before a plane took off I have overheard how much money people are making and problems in the office.  It is a tranquil time in flight and should not be interrupted by another passenger's conversation.  Average flying time is probably an hour or two.  It can wait.  We use to use interoffice memos that were shipped from office to office.  And business continued on even at that snail pace.  No phone calls in the air!!!!!!!!!  Period!!!!

Title: Mark Anton
Comment: No, No, No, a thousand times NO.  I don't want to have to sit there for 4-5 hours listening to someone talking to each and every one of their family and friends.  It's bad enough that you have to sit there and listen to a baby crying the entire trip but that cannot be helped.  No to talking on cell phone on a plane.  Simple enough.

Title: Greg Green
Comment:
Absolutely NOT!!!!!!!

It is bad enough with all the other things that people do on planes and this would also be a huge safety concern.

Title: Chris Clarke
Comment: Please don't allow cell phone usage on flights.  I feel (1) it will make journeys noisy and obtrusive and (2) it may possibly make things more dangerous when flight attendant messages could be missed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As long as there is no screaming or yelling over the cellphone, I am okay with it. WE should be able to use cellphone at 35k feet.

Title: Richard Chuises
Comment: Voice calls on aircraft while in the air would be an inconvenience to other passengers and crew.  Typically, people speak much louder on mobile wireless devices.  If studies show that navigational or aircraft systems are not directly impacted by using the mobile devices, letting people text would be fine, but no voice.

Title: Kathleen Walker
Comment: Please do not allow calls. It will be a nuisance and I can see people getting in fights. Sound free typing and texting would be ok.

Title: Nathan Gray
Comment:
Please respect our right to not have to listen to mundane cellphone conversations during our already problematic travel experience. We have to pay fees for everything from water to food to extra room. We have to watch as person after person brings aboard a bag that is obviously NOT going to fit in the overhead or under the seat. 

Allowing people to chatter on their phones while the rest of us just want some peace and quiet would be akin to a Black Friday event where the store has one item at that price but 500 people outside. It would lead to confrontations, irritated passengers and (even more) stressed out personnel. 

Let us keep our quiet time. Nothing we can do about crying babies onboard but we can stop this from happening!!

Thanks for your time.

Title: Jeffrey Kuhlmann
Comment:
Plain and simple, NO!  This is one of the worst ideas that's been proposed.  I travel frequently.  Listening to others voice calls on a plane is it a good idea. . 

I'm willing to help anyway possible. 

Jeff

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It is a puzzle to me as to why this would even be up for public vote...I WOULD NOT continue to commute via the airlines if this ban were to be lifted.  It would be a safety hazard NO. 1, and a public nuisance to be surrounded by airline passengers on their cell phones.

Title: Tom Cameron
Comment:
I'm against allowing telephone calls during flights.  I kind of like the term "right to quiet enjoyment" used in many real estate rental contracts.  I don't want to be annoyed by somebody nearby yapping away.

Allowing calls during the last 10-20 minutes of the flight might be okay though, allowing travelers to make contact with their rides, etc.  I'm also in favor of allowing calls if the flight becomes delayed or gets rerouted after departure.

Title: Steve Stutheit
Comment: Not only NO, but HELL, NO!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly oppose the proposed Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft.  It serves no purpose, other than distraction & annoyance to others.  It is also a safety issue:  unless you fly every week as I do, you cannot imagine being marooned next to a person for a 6-hour flight who is talking (loudly, because of ambient aircraft noise) the entire time.  I have experienced this with the old phones that were supplied in aircraft in the 1990s.  Revisiting this would certainly result in passenger fist fights!  In all seriousness, with the inclusion of wifi on flights, this certainly allows business passengers and the like to stay "connected!"

Title: K. Abbott
Comment: NO. For the love of whatever you consider to be holy and good in this world, DO NOT LIFT THE BAN on cell phone use (conversations) on planes.  It is already exceedingly crappy to fly in economy these days, I can't even imagine having to listen to someone screaming into their cellphone on top of it.

Title: David Haigh
Comment: Please do NOT allow Cell Phone calls during flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please keep the ban on talking on cell phones. It would be great to allow all other smart phone, iPad, laptop uses during an entire flight, but flying with 300 people talking on their phones would make what has become a tedious adventure unbearable.

Title: Daniel Lukash
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phone talking usage during flights

other uses such as texting, other social media would be fine

The multiple conversations woulsd cause a distraction on multiple levlels from both a comfort and safety perspective

Title: Tina
Comment: Before cell phones, we knew that my grandmother was on on a long distance phone call-she spoke very loudly. Now with the advent of cell phones, I know when others are on their cell phones-they speak loudly. When on a flight and someone is speaking loudly enough to be overheard, does their business on the phone now become my business and I can comment about the conversation as I feel? I recently was on an Amtrak trip that was only 24-hours long. At 3:00 AM, the gentleman two seats behind me apparently decided to change his ringtones, testing each sound option so that everyone could hear.  At ringtone number five, I evaluated my options - a) visit the closed dining car, b) go to the scenic part of the train that is glass enclosed where I could enjoy the scenic route in the dark, or c) politely ask him if he could perhaps choose another point of time in our journey to select ringtones for his phone. I chose option "c" which was closely followed by my hearing loudly, "Wow, I don't believe it. This lady asked ME to do my phone some other time. Now, what am I supposed to do? I can't sleep. What are you doing?" That was, to my great relief, followed by, "Hey, are you still there? D*amn, I lost my signal again."  I can only imagine what other cacophonies I will have to look forward to on my next plane ride.

Title: Anonymous

PLEASE do not change the current rules

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on airplanes. I think they are disruptive and unnecessary.

Title: S. Hogg
Comment:
I greatly oppose allowing voice calls on mobile wireless devices on aircraft.   It's bad enough that they're allowed on passenger trains (except in quiet cars, and some rude idiots can't keep their mouths shut even then) and buses, and riders are so often subjected to endless loud conversations of other passengers.   

It's difficult for me to understand why there's even any debate about allowing it.   Why would the DOT want to allow such annoying, disruptive, intrusive and rude behavior?   More then a small amount of shampoo is too dangerous to bring on board a commercial flight, but potentially subjecting paying customers to hours of loud drivel isn't a problem?  Couldn't  possibly increase the risk of physical harm or at the least increased levels of blood pressure among other passengers?  Get real.   It's bad enough boarding the plane behind people who block you while talking on their cell, who slow down boarding (it's hard to cram your over-sized bag that should've been checked into an overhead bin while talking on your cell, you know?) and who talk and talk and talk until they're finally told they have to shut off their phone because the plane's going to take off.   Some of those people will NOT SHUT UP for an entire 4 to 7 hour flight if they're not forced to.   Perhaps the DOT is aware of the woman Amtrak passenger who made the lives of other passengers a misery by talking for 10 hours?   Who was finally taken off a train for her behavior when finally told to get off the phone that she was bothering other people?  Does the DOT REALLY believe that only rail passengers are that self-centered?   

If people can't text, then the message can wait.   People have managed FOR YEARS without continual contact or communication with family, friends, employees, co-workers, and employers.   They can now experience it w/e-mail, texting --they don't ALSO need to talk.   There is just no reason to allow a behavior that (1) isn't essential (text or e-mail will be available modes of communication) (2) is already known to be so disruptive and unpleasant for anyone forced to be in the area of the perpetual talker.   

It is incredibly stupid to expect people to be polite, courteous and considerate of others.   Too many are not.  Flying is an uncomfortable, unpleasant experience as it is, and is likely to get even worse (even smaller/narrower seats,etc), why would the DOT decide to increase the possibility of it becoming a living hell?  Children who cry for 4 hours straight isn't a sufficiently bad audio experience?   At least with the children, they are often too young (and their parents too stupid) to understand what they're inflicting on those around them or able to control themselves.   Cellphone talkers aren't and yet they don't.  So don't enable them.

Title: J.W.
Comment: Prohibitions against use of cell phones should NOT be lifted.   Just who thinks they are so important that they can't be out of touch for couple of hours are just "full of it".   With most airlines now offering in-flight Wi-Fi, that should be enough communications access.  Those with the phones would just be social butterflies and a nuisance to all around them.

Title: C. Howe
Comment: I feel that all people need to unplug once in a while. Texting will be alright but I don't feel there needs to be phone calls. Everyone sits so close on the planes and some people are so loud when they talk that it would be an invasion on other passengers sanity. There are enough rude people on planes now, why add another layer.

Title: Stan Lacey
Comment: We all know there are calls deemed important.   For the benefit of this response lets assume 90% of these potential calls are very quiet, and spoken professionally.  But, It is incompreshensible to imagine what will transpire on an airplane when the flying public are forced to listed to someone else's conversation, which at times will be, loud, obnoxious, topics you don't want to hear about, and at times full of vulgar swearing.

Title: Charlie Bunton

I don't need to hear about someone's problems at home, problems at work, 401K or IRA performance information, dry cleaning problems, grocery list items, and other supposed "critical" items that people broadcast widely already.
