Title: Anonymous
Comment:
At first I thought passengers should be free to use their phones if it didn't actually interfere with the safe operation of the plane and/or its navigational systems....... BUT THEN.....
Well... what is it that's SO important that you can't wait a few hours ?  I mean, sure, if the plane is going down and you want to say good-bye to your loved ones, I doubt the flight attendants will take the time to lecture you - but think of what we (the passengers who enjoy flying in peace) already have to put up with.
After waiting for an hour or longer at the gate, while the business-person sitting next to you carries on a VERY vocal conversation via their mic/earplug that apparently picks up nothing softer than a scream.... or while the college kids replays last night's party with their friend, starting each sentence with "Dude, dude, dude..." and sprinkling it with numerous "like"'s... we THEN get onto the plane and take our seats next to (or near) that beautiful cooing baby, and fight for armrest room with the person next to us who should have booked 2 seats while the person behind us jams their knees into our back through the seat because they're 6'-03" tall.  Annnnnd... we get wheels-up.  And the baby becomes possessed by the eardrum-pressure demons.
Let's just add another person into the mix, who NOW has to yell over the engine noise, the friendly chatter, the screaming baby, and the behemoth next to us who snores like a tank !!  Oh yeah... and all they wanted to do was tell their buddies about last night's party !!
I say we just leave things as they are with the phones - but increase leg room and arm room, and create a special section for use as a nursery so we can enjoy our $15 cheese tray.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow passengers to make voice calls during flights.  As a frequent air traveler, I am familiar with the many stressful situations that passengers already face.  Placing dozens of strangers in a cramped, confined space for several hours already makes for an unpleasant experience, and enabling cell phone calls during that time would be even more disruptive for fellow travelers.  Use of non-transmitting portable electronic devices during the entire flight has already made my travel experience much more pleasant, providing a quiet, unobtrusive means of work or entertainment while traveling.  However, allowing voice calls during flights would not only be highly disruptive to both other passengers and flight crew, it is also unnecessary given the other communication options available to fliers.

The nuisance of being subjected to other travelers' cell phone conversations is one that is unavoidable by passengers.  According to page 10 of the proposed regulation, "the Department has found acts to be “unfair” if they are harmful to 
passengers but could not be reasonably avoided by passengers".  Being confined to a small seat, with few options for moving elsewhere to avoid the noise of seatmates' cell phone conversations, would have a large, negative impact on the air travel experience.  As noted in the proposed regulation, people tend to talk longer and more loudly on cell phones than they would during conversations with fellow travelers.  Moreover, I believe that frustration with phone-using seatmates could lead to more frequent conflict with other travelers, causing difficulty not only for travelers but for airline crew.  Even under the current regulations, I have witnessed travelers who refused to end cell phone conversations when asked to do so by a flight attendant, causing delays and increased stress for everyone on the plane, and making it harder for flight crew to do their jobs.

There are other options available for passengers who wish to communicate while flying.  I would be pleased to be able to use my phone's text messaging or data capabilities while in flight.  In addition, many flights now offer in-flight internet access.  Travelers can email or chat while in flight, allowing them to stay connected without disrupting fellow travelers.  Voice calls, while potentially contributing to productivity for some travelers, also make it hard for other travelers to focus on their own work.  While it is technologically possible to make voice calls over the internet, I feel that these should also not be allowed, as they would be just as disruptive to travelers and crew as cell phone calls would be.    

I feel that text-to-speech software, as referenced on page 16 of the proposed regulation, is not the same thing as a voice call and should be exempt from any ban.  The proportion of passengers who need to use this functionality is likely very small as compared to the total number of passengers, making it unlikely that such software would be disruptive, and the point of any such regulation should be to enhance passengers' safety and comfort.  Those passengers who need text-to-speech software should be allowed to use it with headphones. 

I see no need for a talking area or physical separation of phone-users from those who are not using phones as referenced on page 18, item 10 of the proposed regulation; in fact, I believe that this would be worse than an outright ban.  As passengers, we do not always have control over our seat assignments.  Getting rebooked due to travel delays or cancellations is already stressful enough, and often results in getting an undesirable seat assignment; even worse would be the possibility of being stuck in the "talking zone".  Having a designated talking zone would simply limit seat choices even further, and requiring an enclosure would entail additional costs to airlines without necessarily solving the problem.  Sound travels, and those passengers sitting near the talking zone would likely still be subjected to unpleasant noise levels.

Based upon my experiences as a passenger, I am convinced that the disruptive nature of voice calls exceeds the potential benefits to a few travelers.  I urge the DOT to allow all other mobile wireless communications services in flight, but to ban voice calls.

The lack of decency, manners or ability to follow simple directions will enflame many within a confined space 30,000 feet above the ground. Title: Jeanne Belliveau
Comment: No no absolutely not!  This would cause undue stress on an already increasingly stressful environment. Please do NOT allow any use other than SILENT use.

Title: William Rising
Comment:
I fly frequently for work, often on small regional aircraft and sometimes on larger international aircraft. Allowing phone calls on these flights would make all the hours of travel completely excruciating. People already talk louder on cell phones than they do when talking to their neighbors. The loud ambient noise from the engines would cause those speaking on phones would exacerbate this to the point that the plane would sound like a bevy of Dick Vitales all calling different ballgames over the roar of engines. Painful. [You already mention this point, sans Dick Vitale, on p.11 of your notice.]

In the notice, you mention the idea of having 'quiet sections' of the plane on p. 14.  Perhaps this could be rephrased as allowing 'loud sections' or even something akin to phone booths to isolate the callers. The downside of having such regions on the plane, however, would be that the airlines would then figure out a way to charge more for the quiet seats.

You mention that there could be people who would like to use their phones for 'important business or personal calls' on p. 16. There are many people under the mistaken notion that all their calls are important, so making such a distinction would be futile. Those who claim they need such calls should have long-since realized that there are times at which they simply cannot be in touch via voice, and they should learn other mechanisms for communicating. Some of us like to be able to work on a plane in an environment that is no worse than working in a bus station. Cell phone usage would make this work environment far worse because of the proximity of the loud voices talking into cell phones.

You mention text-to-voice applications on p.17. This is somewhat beside the point, because the problem is with voice-to-phone. Those needing text-to-voice can wear headphones, just like those who like to listen to music. (In this context, allowing conversation would be analogous to allowing people to play instruments on the plane.)

Do what you would like with texting and other globally social, locally antisocial behavior, but please save us from having to hear extremely loud half-conversations for hours on end.

Title: Matthew
Comment: Please continue to prohibit the mobile usage of voice calls on passenger flights. It is a small space and with lots of people on board these crafts, and noise will be too stressful for those who are traveling as it is stressful enough at airports, Texting and Data usage I believe is  a different story, however voice services should still remain banned.

Comment: Please - make a rational decision and NOT allow cell phones on planes. Plus, less potential arguments or confrontations from irate passengers to each other, if one is too loud and acting obnoxious. No cell phones on planes.

Title: Carl S.
Comment:
It's simple, really.

The use of cell phones on planes cannot be a safety issue, because if so, then every single wireless device in or near an airport would have to be destroyed.  QED, it's not a safety issue, but rather a control and fiscal issue.  Que "those airline provided phones that cost a bundle . . ."

As to whether or not cell phones should be allowed on planes, the decision point is this:  They're allowed on public sidewalks, buses, trains, and in public buildings and such, are they not?

It is an education and courtesy issue, so the DOT and the FCC need to step back and remove themselves from the arena.

Comment: I do not believe that the use of cell phones should be allowed on the plane. Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly oppose any use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  Please do not permit this.

Title: David Carlson
Comment: not only distracting but rather rude. where is the respect of others these days? Cell Phones can be used in so many ways, including the unimaginable. So to answer the question NO, do not allow Calls or Phones period! In today's age, remember Safety is number one (1) and should be a priority.

Title: George Mellen
Comment:
ABSOLUTELY NOT!  

Please, I have to sit next to 300 lb. women; don't give them a cell phone too!  

On a plane is the one time I can get a little rest (babies not withstanding) and having someone needlessly babbling would destroy that.  

If you approve this measure, be ready for a huge number of physical passenger confrontations.

Title: Pat Galante
Comment: Please, please, please NO cell phone conversations on airplanes! Bad enough listening to loud mouths talking to each other when both are on the plane.

Title: Kimberly
Comment: ABSOLUTELY NOT! It's bad enough listening to people prior to takeoff and after landing. Worst idea ever.

Title: Tony Hall
Comment: Please NO.  People are generally incapable of using indoor voices on cell phones, on a plane you would potentially have 200 people talkng in a small confined space. NO ONE IS SO IMPORTANT THAT THEY CANNOT WAIT AN HOUR OR TWO TO TAKE A CALL.

Title: Nathanael Bray
Comment: No, this is a safety issue because someone is going to punch someone for talking to loudly. No one wants to listen to someone else's conversation while trapped on a plane.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am not in favor of allowing voice calls on airplanes.  Not sure I want 100+ people taking at the same time on an aircraft. I do however think that text would be okay as it can be done with little noise.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Allow texting only. I don't want to listen to 100 people yelling over the top of jet engine noise.

Title: Carolyn Pierce
Comment: NO. NO. A third time, NO! Please do NOT allow passengers to make cell phone calls on flights. It will cause arguments between passengers. Most people talk too loudly on cell phones, and it would be even worse on aircraft. Please use common sense. If you approve cell phone use for voice calls on aircraft, you will have to assign at least 1 air marshall for every 15 passengers, at least. Seriously, this is not a good thing! Thank you!

Title: Cris Flyer
Comment: Please dont allow phones to be used on aircraft.  It is already a very cramped situation and I dont want to listen to people yacking away if I am within a few feet of them and cant move away.  Also I feel it is a safety issue that could be used for bad things if exploited in evil ways.   PLEASE DONT ALLOW CELL PHONES

Title: Renee Coffman
Comment: Please do not lift the ban on calls and texts made on personal mobile devices. I already dread the idea of texting allowed for the sole reason many mobile users for one reason or another will not turn their alerts to silent or vibrate when in public. Even with the assumption that connection costs would be high initially, there will be usesrs, there will be obnoxious, incondiderste, users that will negate those whom are considerate. Take what would usually be a quiet night time or early morning flight, add beeps, ringers, obnoxious song tones, loud voices.  How can anyone with reason believe there will not be added stress, that frustration and annoyance will not drive more customers to a breaking point of which will add much more work and stress to the flight crew which will decrease the safety of air travel. One of my greatest joys of flying is the time when phone calls and tones from texts are silenced. I will fly less if current standards change.

Title: Mary Lou Miller
Comment: Absolutely NOT.  No one wants to hear someone else's conversation even if they are talking softly (which most people dont').  It's uncomfortable and obstrusive.

Title: Laurie Recsetar
Comment: I vote NO cell phone conversations on aircraft. Passengers read, sleep, do work and watch movies with ear buds in. Sometimes the quiet of an aircraft is a nice respite after the craziness of rushing to pack and getting to the airport. There are enough crying babies on flights making unwanted noise.  We don't need to add some blowhard across the aisle talking at the top of his lungs trying at impress us with how important he is!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # N/A
Comment: No please don't let people use their phones during flight.  I believe it will cause disruption to the flight and in turn a disruption to the flight crew.  The flight attendants will be separating people arguing over the loud conversations and trying to control discourteous flyers.  I think there will fighting amongst passengers as people disturb others with their phone conversations, while others want to have quiet while traveling.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of voice calls on aircraft.  It has been proven that most people cannot control themselves nor think of others and especially in a confined space airline personnel would have to tend to issues and not be able to do their main job.

Title: Theodore Santos
Comment:
I believe that this reversal of the present law would be a huge mistake..
Think about the fights onboard the ruckus from people who are constantly yaking..and who is left to police the freak outs the crew 
 Don't you think that they have enough to do..




Sincerly,

Theodore Santos

Title: John Oliver
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the use of verbal calling on planes. I am in favor of texting or emails being allowed via smart phones or tablets.

Title: Donald Mathews
Comment: Unless this is a safety issue the department of transportation should not impose a rule on the airlines.  The airlines should  be able to have whatever policy they deem serves their customers best.  Some airlines could choose to allow the calls and others could choose to not allow them and then customers could choose to fly with the airline that meets their needs best.  Airlines could be free to have special seating where the calls are allowed or not allowed.  They could impose a charge for phone free seats or phone calls allowed seating.

Title: Dennis L. Westman
Comment: Please, please, please do not allow cell phone usage for voice calls on aircraft.  People are already so rude and sitting next to someone on a call would be miserable. Again, please do not allow voice calls and aircraft.

Title: Mary-Ann Sandford
Comment: Most definitely no! On voice calls. Maybe for SILENT texting and internet but who is going to enforce it if they don't keep it silent?  Too much potential for misuse.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No, voice calls should not be allowed on aircraft. Conversations among other passengers are plenty, we don't need someone yelling into their phone for an entire flight. Flying is unpleasant enough without adding to the unpleasantness!

Title: Steven Nofziger
Comment:
Please don't. Don't do it. Don't allow cell phone usage on planes. There is so much tension on overcrowded flights anyway. This will create so much tension. There is no where else to go if someone is talking on their phone. You are literally inches away from conversations that shouldn't be forced upon you. Not even getting into having to listen to inappropriate content, sexual discussions, family fights, business sales pitches, etc. There will be fights. 
Being in the air is one of the only places to be free of that distraction.  It is the one thing that is right about air travel. Don't screw that up.

Title: Andreana Phelps
Comment: No, I do not think cell phone.calls should be allowed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Do not allow phone calls on planes

Title: Greg Ramsaran
Comment: Do not allow this, it's obnoxious and should stay banned.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that cell phone calling should not be allowed on planes. I think for safety reasons the phone should be left off.

Title: Raven Flores
Comment:
Please DO NOT allow cell phone use on air crafts.  It would be loud, rude and annoying.  

If you decide to do this...allow it ONLY at the rear of the plane and install a sound barrier between the cell phone seats and the rest of the plane.

Title: Richard Peterson
Comment: I am opposed to the use of cellphones on airline flights. It is an imposition on surrounding passengers.

Title: Duane Rodriguez
Comment:
Please DO NOT allow cell phone calls on planes!!
Please?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
NO!  I know people that would be using their phones making calls that aren't important.  Flying has become a hassle as it is without the millions of rude people that would be talking loud on their phones.    Business people will communicate via their computers, quietly.  

If there was an emergency, the phones will come on out as is, but the one place that is relatively quiet is a plane.  I appreciate that you can listen to your music, you can use your computers on take off, but you still have to pay attention to the safety drill.  There is always a chance of problems.

Title: M. Lee
Comment: I am against this in several ways.  1) this space is too confined, you will be forcing people to listen to conversations they have no interest in and in todays society there appear to be to many people who have no regard for others personal space.  2) why would you permit people to carry cell-phones so they could use (possibly) as a method to trigger another device located in the luggage compartment?  Far to many negatives to this proposal for it to ever be beneficial.

Title: Daniel Littwin
Comment:
Department of Transportation Docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002

Please do not allow cell phone conversations on planes once the doors have closed.  Text messaging and other silent communications are perfectly okay, but please limit the conversations. Planes are already noisy and stressful environments without the added distraction of shouted responses over faulty cellular connections.

Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am against allowing voice calls on aircraft. Quarters are just too close to make this a good idea.  You'll be risking creating a lot of irritation and tension.  You can almost guarantee it'll be the loud-talkers who don't care about others flight experience...lol!

Title: Sheila Strunk
Comment: I oppose any change to allow the use of cell phones on airplanes. People sit in such close proximity, you would be unable to avoid hearing private conversations. With multiple people talking at one, noise levels woufl be bothersome. Let them text message if they must, but NO conversations, please.

Title: Phil D. Jernes
Comment: voice NO. text YES.

Title: Bruce McInnis
Comment: Telephone calls on airplanes make little or no sense. Generally speaking, people already talk too loud on phones. Imagine if there are jet engines roaring a few feet away. The perceived notion to speak even louder than normal would only be heightened. Also, I would expect there would be many confrontations by other passengers who just want peace and quiet or who might be trying to carry on a normal conversation with their seatmate. The percentage of times a person would absolutely have to place or receive a call in such a confined space during flight time is an extremely small percentage. Do the right thing and do not open this Pandora Box.

Title: Kyle
Comment:
I strongly support the continued prohibition of in-flight cell phone voice communication. The notion that people should be allowed to talk on their mobile devices, governed by the rule of self-regulation and common courtesy, is inconsistent with reality and would create a major nuisance for the majority of air travelers. In my opinion, carrying on a personal phone conversation in a confined space, in such close proximity to other people who have no choice but to endure it is a form of noise pollution. To allow this would simply encourage bad behavior, add to the potential for altercations between passengers, and quite possibly discourage a significant number of people from traveling by air at all.

Please, for the sake of what few good things remain about flying, do not permit people to make in-flight cell phone calls.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Lifting the ban is a bad idea from a safety point of view. Should an event occur requiring communication from the staff, it would be inaudible to passengers not talking on their devices for all the noise from the remaining passengers who are. The more important an event to hear staff for instruction, the more panic & voice calls there will be obscuring what may be life saving instruction.

As for comfort, when was the last time you stood in line at the bank, post office, grocery store, restaurant, etc and was NOT made an involuntary participant in another person's business? Now, what makes you think folks will display any more courtesy stuck on an aircraft with nothing to do? Using European conduct as evidence is irrelevant. There are too few Europeans in the American population to make it relevant.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow mobile wireless devices to make calls on aircraft.  It will cause more inconvenience for other passengers to have to deal with people speaking on their phones and being distracting then it will cause convenience for those wanting to make a voice call.  It also brings up potential safety concerns if the person on a voice call is not attentive to alerts from the flight crew.  Use of non-voice text and data services should be allowed and would permit a person to communicate any important information if need be without having to make a voice call.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Absolutely against use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on any aircraft.  I cannot imagine being in the confines of an aircraft having to listen to a multitude of people chatting away on their phones.  When paying to fly one should be able to fly in peace without a constant auditory overload of meaningless conversation.

Title: Larry Anderson
Comment:
Please do not allow phones on commercial aircraft. Planes are already over crowded with stressful fliers just trying to maintain their cool until the reach their destination. I guarantee that by allowing phones that the number of in flight incidents will sky rocket, Also, after paying hundreds or thousands of dollars for a flight I want the peace that I am entitled to and
have no desire to listen to others conversation. I am not the NSA.

Title: Chris L.
Comment: If the technology is available and there is no interference with navigating the aircraft, I believe voice calls should be approved by the government.  That said, I also believe it should be left up to the airline to decide if voice calls on aircraft should be permissible. I personally would not want to be on a flight where cell phone calls were ok, so I would avoid carriers that permit calls in flight.  Let the free market decide...certain airlines may see their business prosper as a result, while others may lose.  Let talkers fly the carrier that supports their need...that is giving consumers what they want and is capitalism at its best.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am against any cell phone usage on any commercial aircraft. Regardless of whether or not it is a safety issue, having to listen to other peoples phone conversations  in a confined area is way to annoying. People that can't wait a couple of hours to gab on a phone have serious issues and little or no consideration for the people around them.

Title: Jim Vance
Comment:
I support a complete ban on in-flight cellphone usage involving all voice calls between closure of an aircraft door prior to departure and transition from runway to taxiway following aircraft landing.  However, I support a specific narrow exception to permit such calls during an emergency in the event of a hijacking attempt which has been successful and resulted in the effective transfer of an aircraft's flight control decisions to those involved in the hijacking effort, regardless of whether the original crew remains in operational control of the cockpit systems under duress.

I have no objection to the use of cellphones for texting in silent mode at any time during a flight, so long as those transmissions would not interfere in any way with communications or performance of the aircraft's crew and systems, but I support a complete ban on any texting activity in which "silent mode" is disengaged or otherwise unavailable on a mobile device.  I also support imposition of very high financial penalties on anyone involved in any infraction of the prohibitions.

Title: Dan Herlihy
Comment:
As a long time Frequent Business Flyer, the possibility of allowing cell phone calls on airplanes is a horrible idea.  Although cell phone use no longer posed a technological threat to navigation and aeronautic safety, what some are ignoring is the hazard cell phones present to the well-being and peace of mind of passengers confined inside the cabin of a plane with nowhere to flee while rude seatmates incessantly yakked away.
 
If cell phone voice calls were permitted, flight attendants would be placed in the impossible position of having to referee disputes between passengers who, jammed tightly into their seats on packed planes, argued over telephone etiquette and common courtesy (which is no longer so common at all). Travelers would demand to be moved; when no others seats were available, hand-to-hand combat might break out. On a street or in a public building, you can always walk away from a loud and obnoxious cell phone user. On a plane? Where are you supposed to go?
 
There is a simple solution to satisfy those who wish to communicate with people on the ground during a flight: Allow text messages, e-mails and social network postings from the air. Engaging in those activities actually calms passengers, soothes their nerves. Voice calls? The opposite

Title: C. Chang
Comment: Allowing people to use their cell phones on an airplane is an absolutely bad idea.  It's already difficult to travel in those cramped coach seats.  Imagine having to listen to someone hold a conversation while you're flying?  If it's a long flight, having people talk on their cells will spark unneighborly conduct.  I foresee people being irritated by having to listen to someone talk on their cell phones for the duration of a flight.  I seriously hope the government BANS ALL CELL PHONE USAGE on airplanes.  If people need to talk, they can wait until the plane lands!

Title: Katherine Delia
Comment: I am opposed to allowing the use of cell phones on commercial flights at any point. Unless there can be sufficient evidence provided to show this to be a safety issue (and it hasn't been up until this point), this change would be likely to cause the same disturbances and intrusions on personal space that cell phone use on public transportation already causes-- in an even smaller space, where people are often unable to stand up & walk away for extended periods of time due to safety issues.

Title: Elridge McMillan
Comment: Text only. I do not want to hear anyone  talking.

Title: Lois Thurston
Comment: NO!!!  I oppose the prospect of having to listen to an airplane full of people and their individual phone calls probably all happening at the same time!  When you are on a flight, you do not want anxiety.  Riding in the plane is anxiety enough and a lot of people need this time to stay calm and "try" to enjoy the flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: N-O spells no.

Title: Todd Haroldson
Comment: yes phone calls should ba e allowed

Title: Robert Schweitzer
Comment:
Not only are we against any proposal to allow cell phone voice calls on in flight planes, we are baffled that this has even been suggested. This is the kind of proposal that will result in an overall increase in the general stress of flying. Between going through TSA, minimal seating space on todays planes, and bad passenger behavior, this will result in potential aggressive and perhaps violent behavior by passengers irritated by someone talking loud on an entire flight in the next seat.
What a stupid idea!

Title: Toni
Comment: As a frequent flier, I would greatly oppose the use of cell phones for the use of phone calls on planes. As it is, people are already in uncomfortably close quarters with others on planes, and already have to tolerate each other. As many people tend to talk quite loudly on their phones, I don't see this adding to the flying experience. I will fly with airlines who oppose the use.

Title: Edward Vidricksen
Comment: Please to not allow the use of phones on airplanes. I to not want to listen to phone calls all the way to my destination.

Title: Mike Flannery
Comment: I strongly urge you to continue the prohibition of using Mobile Wireless Devices on aircraft.  If people would only use the phone for a quick two minute call that would be fine but we all know that isn't going to happen.  There's plenty of people that spend half their waking hours with the phone to their ear and I for one am not going to sit next to someone who is talking on the phone for two hours.  I would go so far as to tell you I think you will have passengers fighting with each other if you allow the use of cell phones on aircraft.   Nothing is that urgent that you can't wait until the plane lands.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please, PLEASE do not allow cellphone calls on planes.

Anyone who thinks this is a good idea doesn't ride public transportation. 
We here in the Northeast are suffering enough riding trains and
buses where people talk at the top of their lungs. And that's for short trips.
We can move to a different car on a train. But how do you escape
this annoying behavior on a plane? There's nowhere to go. 

The incidents of air rage will increase astronomically if you allow 
voice calling on planes.

Title: Dee Lamb
Comment: Please do not allow phone conversations on an airplane. The last thing I want to do is listen to a rude person's loud conversation for three hours on a flight. I'd rather be able to peacefully fall asleep without waking up to phone sounds. Thank you.

Title: Curt Rapp
Comment:
I fully support lifting the ban on in-flight cell phone use.  The only question to be considered is flight safety.  If cell phone use won't affect safety then the ban should be lifted.  Period.  The ban has had an adverse impact on my productivity and life.  I have had times when being able to call someone in-flight would have saved a lot of time and inconvenience.

Some commenters have said they don't want to be subjected to others loud phone calls, but that is not an issue.  People need to take personal responsibility for their behavior and not rely on the government to "regulate" behavior.  If someone gets out of line with their cell phone like vulgar language or shouting there are other avenues deal with that problem.  I don't see that being the norm and concerns over a few isolated cases shouldn't be the reason to deprive everyone of their rights.

Title: Edward Kessler
Comment: OPPOSED.  Am opposed to use of any form of such device on plane whether it be smartphone or iPAD type devices with phone capability.  Passengers not using such devices deserve privacy and absence of voice chatter from adjacent passengers choosing to use the devices.  If enough passengers used such devices, the cacophony of noise would make flight conditions uncomfortable for others who prefer silence for reading, sleeping, studying or prefer conversing with next-seat occupant, etc.

Title: Mary S.
Comment:
ABSOLUTELY DO NOT ALLOW cell phone conversations after the plane leaves the gate.  People are too close together and it would be an infringement on privacy to have to listen to someone's conversation.  Also, it would likely cause in-flight altercations and bad behavior to increase dramatically. Even separate sections would not help because the people in other sections would still hear the conversation.  Making someone pay more to sit in a section that does not allow calls would be outrageous.  Passengers already pay for so many things that used to be a free part of the service, no one should now have to pay for peace and quite!  If airlines want to offer cell phone options, let them build "cones of silence" like they had in the old "Get Smart" TV show - something that would encase the person while talking and block out any noise!

It would be fine to allow the use of tablets, laptops, games, etc during flight - that would allow people to stay in touch for personal and business matters, or entertain themselves during a flight, but it would not be disruptive to other passengers.

Title: Sean Parham
Comment: The idea that people will be able to have voice calls on commercial flights makes me want to never fly again.  It's bad enough that seats are closer together and planes are fuller than ever, but imagine being trapped in a center seat next to someone for hours while they chat.  "Hello!  Can you hear me now?  Hello!"  As the Corporate Travel Director of a large corporation and the President of the Los Angeles Business Travel Association, I strongly oppose the use of voice calls on ANY commercial flights.  I urge the DOT to spare the traveling public and the flight crews from what is surely to be a disaster in the making if voice calls are aloud.  Imagine the onboard arguements, fights, and resulting lawsuits from angry passengers.  It is just not a good idea.  Let people text.  That is how people communicate more and more today.  Voice calls have no place on a commercial aircraft.

Title: Susan Phillips
Comment: Can't think of many things worse than having to listen to someone else's telephone conversation while captive on an airplane! Most people who talk on their phones in public places seem to have no inhibitions about what they say or how loud they say it which would be no different in the close quarters of an airplane. Really, really bad idea to allow use of cell phones for voice calls on aircraft!

Title: Greg Cofer
Comment: Although I, myself, do not think I would not make a practice of talking while in flight due to the noise level, I would not object to allowing in-flight telephone calls.

Title: Ross Anton
Comment: As a flight attendant I am strongly opposed to allowing voice calls on airplanes. This will create a lot of problems for the crew and passengers who wants a quiet,  relaxing atmosphere.  This will be a big problem on such close proximity. A lot of people have NO situational awareness,  and will make for a long and miserable flight.

Title: B. Shaw
Comment: Please do not allow phone use on the plane.  As a frequent flyer, I can easily imagine the problems and conflicts that phone use could easily lead to on board. For the sake of airline employees and the flying public at large please do not allow voice calls to me pane while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please, please, no.

Text and data - no problem. If you've eer taken public transportation with someone screaming into their phone, you would know how horrible it is.

Title: James Michael
Comment: As a regular flyer, I am opposed to voice calls, but in favor of texting and data retrieval. Voice calls would be terribly annoying, as we already know from sitting beside people in an airport terminal, on a bus, etc.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Absolutely not!  The behavior is disruptive, particularly when you are trapped on the aircraft with others.  In addition, too often, people are not paying attention to safety announcements as it is.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow voice telephone calls in flight.  It's bad enough on the ground before and after.  One rude, arrogant person can and does create a lot of misery for many more who are unfortunate enough to sit in their vicinity.  After all, it's not like you can get up and walk away from them.

Title: Gregg Smith
Comment: Please, please no cell phone use on Aircraft. PLEASE.

Title: William Wojtas
Comment:
As a private citizen, I am opposed to allowing phone calls (cell, Sat or VOIP) during air transport domestically or internationally.  

It is disturbing, so much so that on railroads, we have the option to move to a separate car known as quiet cars to avoid loud conversations.  You can not do this on an aircraft, it is not possible, Distance from one end of the craft to the other will not silence loud conversations.

Title: Laura Englebrecht
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on airplanes.  Most people are rude enough as it is and talk loudly without regard to the presence of others while on their phone calls. I think also people will talk on their phones while the safety demo/video is playing and this could be a safety issue distracting others from concentrating on said demo/video.   I think texts and emails and other silent forms of communication should be allowed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Personally I am very much against allowing cell phone usage on aircraft flights.  I think they will be intrusive and noisy and also could pose a safety hazard if people on calls ignore flight intendant/pilot advisories.

Title: Phyllis English
Comment: Are you out of your minds! NO! Your restricted to a small cramped space where personal space is non existent and then add cell phone use....seriously there are people out there with no concept of inside voice!! At no point should this idiotic idea be allowed to be considered..ever!

Title: Laura Englebrecht
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on airplanes.  People are rude enough as it is and talk loudly without regard to others while on their phones.  I also think that people will use their phones during the safety video/demo and this could be a safety issue by being a distraction to other passengers trying to concentrate on the demo/video

Title: Donald Golofski
Comment: I think it would be a very bad judgement to allow mobile phone calls on aircraft.  Part of the comfort of flying is to relax, without hearing gossip or another person's business affairs while in flight.  As far as I am concerned the paying passenger deserves better than to allow this rule to go through.  It is bad enough that passengers are trying to relax and stay calm while there are unruly or noisy children in the tube.  Please do not let this fly!

Title: Alan Shinosky
Comment: I am against allowing voice calls on aircraft.  I strongly believe that it is not in the best interest of the flying public.  Because of the nature of the close seating and the addition of the noise it has the possibility of causing situations on aircraft which are very undesirable and unsafe.

Title: Brian Hafner
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone use on flights.  It would increase the discomfort level exponentially

Title: Duluthmama
Comment: Do not allow cell phone calls on planes during flight. Texting is OK. Flying is uncomfortable and stressful enough. I do not want to be trapped in a small space and forced too listen to a bunch of people screaming into their phones. Planes are noisy enough already from plane engines, intercoms, your neighbors games/music, loud conversations, etc. without adding endless phone conversations.

Title: Charles Trieloff
Comment:
This would be a total disaster. As a traveler who has well over a million miles, this would be a game changer for me.

Let people text or email so we can have a little civility in the cabin!

Charles J. Trieloff

Title: Steven Brown
Comment:
I am OPPOSED to allowing the use of wireless devices in order to make voice calls on aircraft. Imagine, if you will, 300 people on a flight trying to speak on the phone at the same time. Imagine the seat passenger next to you talking the entire flight. Imagine the discomfort and aggravation this would cause to all the passengers in the vicinity of the talker especially since the ambient noise of an aircraft is high as it is and, therefore, the talker(s) will also have to speak louder.

As a frequent traveler, both of pleasure and business, I can't see a single reason why wireless voice calls become a necessity. Even in the case of an emergency what is the passenger going to do but have to sit and wait until the plane lands. Constant connectivity isn't necessarily a good thing.

Title: Deborah Hancock
Comment:
Please no!  I strongly feel it would lead to "air rage"!  Allot of business people use this time to catch up on work they cannot get to by constantly being interrupted by the phone.
Mothers with small children trying to sleep and being interrupted by someone on the phone.  
A passenger having a conversation whilst walking up and down the aisle, loud, letting everyone know his conversation.  
A passenger sitting beside you while your trying to catch a nap before a meeting, talking on and on.
A passenger who is going through a break up with partner and not being able to control the emotion and yelling at the ex on the phone.
A passenger that is grief stricken sobbing on the phone.
A passenger who decides what an easy way to pick up "for sex" through many websites speaking and hooking up on the phone.
The list is endless.

One of the worst ideas you can even entertain.

Begging you please do not invite air rage into the sky!!!

Don't even get me started on what advantages you could give to terrorism!!!!!!!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Don't allow any cellphone use inflight except for texting with no volume.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phones on commercial flights.  As a somewhat frequent flyer (75k - 80k per year) I can only imagine how disruptive and annoying it would be listening to one sided phone conversations.  It's bad enough in the lounges and gate areas.  People do not realize how loudly they speak when using cell phones.

Title: James
Comment:
NO!
Did I mention NO!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not lift the ban on cell use during flights.

Title: James
Comment: NO!

Title: Ted Dudziak
Comment: I am not in favor of allowing voice calls on a flight. I have no interest in hearing about any issue that my neighbor is having or the elevated noise when they are talking. Thank you.

Title: Margaret Hoffman
Comment:
To impose more stress onto an already regulation burdened public by allowing those few who dont have the self control to leave their cellphones off for a few hours would obviously create an environment ripe for altercations.

To expect flight crews to monitor and referee the behaviour of the general public as they refuse to adhere to any phone call time limitations would undoubtedly take time away from their more important safety and security duties.

I can see absolutely no reason to allow this already behaviour to extend to the confined spaces of an aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I think the airlines are looking for trouble if they allow this. We will have air rage just like road rage. My flights are a place to finally relax and get away from the phone. Please DO NOT pass this!!!!!!

Title: Roger Evans Jr.
Comment: I oppose the use of cell phones on airplanes for voice calls.  I hope that you will allow the ban to remain in place.  I would not like the idea of having to listen to hunderds of people talking at once in such a confined space as an airliner.  It is hard enough getting everyone to settle in now that some devices are allowed to be used from gate to gate.  Please do not make air travel more uncomfortable by allowing phone calls in flight.  Thank You

Title: Mister Traveler
Comment:
Hello;
I would like to strongly encourage the DOT and FAA to NOT allow making or receiving calls or talking on cell phones, period. Due to no real feedback when using a cell phone you can’t hear yourself talk thru the phone, so most people talk very loud on the phone. I couldn’t imagine people trying to hear a phone conversation over the engine and wind noise of a jet aircraft. Then talking very loud or screaming to the other person on the call due to the lack of voice feedback thru the PDA.

Next thing you know you have passengers yelling at each other to be quiet, other passengers claiming they have the legal right, etc. Next you’ve invented “air-rage” like road rage but on a commercial flight. Who’s to dictate what’s too loud? The passengers, a flight attendant, the DOT, FAA? Right now things are nice. Folks put on their head sets, listen to music, watch TV, read or sleep. Having loud phone conversations will only make flying more miserable for everyone.

Thank you for allowing our input.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Greetings to the folks in the Department of Transportation,
I do NOT support cell phone use on flights.  

I just read an article in my local paper regarding the use of cell phones on planes.  I did not read the 22 page document associated with this issue.

Bottom line: PLEASE, please do NOT allow the use of phones on planes.  Reasons noted in the article include: [1] people tend to talk louder on cellphones; on a flight the potential exists for longer conversation; [2] concern for the accumulative impact of allowing in flight calls in an enclosed cabin; [3] creates a negative impact on an already stressful (and sometimes testy) flight experience; [4] flight attendants oppose lifting the ban for reasons (i.e., passenger management issues; increase cabin noise).

Frankly, in general, people have horrible cell phone etiquette.  On the ground I can escape such things; in the air I am trapped.  

Let's just not go there.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Anthony Knight
Comment:
Please continue the ban on use of cell phones (DOT-OST-2014-0002) on aircraft commercial flights.  While it's nice to believe that people will self regulate, current experience in theaters, libraries, hospitals, museums, and other environments in which whispered communication and/or silence was considered the norm, demonstrates that there always will be those among us who disregard those norms. 

Moreover, I regularly see on flights men and women who blatantly disregard aircraft personnel when asked to power off cell phones and other electronic devices just before take off and/or landing.  If staff are unable to effectively manage this behavior, why consider adding yet another level of passenger activity that will not be managed properly.  

Finally, in an environment as confined as that of an airplane, it would just be annoying to have to listen to a person's conversation when I might be tired, or traveling to a funeral (or some other stressful life event), and just be in need of some time to think and be silent.

Title: James W. Farley
Comment: It is absolutely a terrible idea. Whatever is left of common courtesy will go right out the window if phones can be used on a plane. Allowing individuals to use laptops, iPads, to play games, watch movies or just work is entirely appropriate. Let's not get carried away and leave well enough alone. Title: V. Lin

Comment: Do not allow cell phone use on airplanes. As a flight attendant for 40 years, I can assure you that the end result will be an ongoing series of fights among passengers. There is nowhere to go on an airplane except the crew, who will be asked to referee. There is NO reason that people need to have cell phone access in the air. People today have little to no consideration for others in today's world, they cannot be allowed to use cell phones onboard.

Title: Bruce Kalt
Comment:
Please do NOT allow the use of voice calling on cell phones on commercial aircraft.

Flying has already become a nearly intolerable experience: long lines for TSA security checks, overcrowded terminals, even more overcrowded airplanes, reduced leg room, overabundance of carry-on baggage, and passengers who are already in arguments about reclining seats and shared armrests.

The very simple and obvious facts are that the American people (and foreign visitors) are increasingly inconsiderate.  You can rarely sit in an airline gate area without having to move or listen to two or three personal conversations.  Before the door of airplanes are closed you have to hear banal phone calls of people telling others that they are "on the airplane" and upon touchdown at destination you can't hear landing announcements for the number of other passengers advising callees that the are "on the ground".  

Can you possibly consider allowing a situation that puts an airline passenger in a middle seat without use of either armrest, scrunched up with minimal legroom - and now have to listen to innumerable nonsense conversations.  How many of these calls can you possibly think will be of any real importance and not something that could easily be accomplished at either end of the flight?  Certainly, if safety is not impacted, texting would be more than sufficient (and still annoying on overnight flights).

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As an airline pilot dealing with the various emotions and anxious states of every day customers I can attest that this will only lead to air rage. Maybe in small quantities at first however it will grow and create more of an issue than necessary. Inevitably it will be deemed necessary re instate the ban however the pundits will cry rights violation and this will drag on. Avoid the unnecessary, we have survived since the wright brothers without cell coverage up to this point. As a matter of fact, phones were tested in earlier years and proved unnecessary. In addition, regardless of what documentation is out there I personally can attest to the fact on several occasions cell phones do cause a disturbance whether in systems or in communication with ATC. Shooting an approaching to minimums in New York city in snowy weather is not a time I wish to hear buzzing in my ear because customer righteous wants to let grandma know he is about to land. Unfortunately are worst at behavior then little children when they are told to put something away or quiet down.  Do not create more of an issue by given them more toys to handle. They can wait.

Title: Bob Yesselman
Comment: No, no, Please no.  I can think of no greater hell than being trapped in an overstuffed airplane with the person seated next to you jabbering away on a cell phone.  Surely, there must be some escape from our cell phone smothered world.

Title: Michael Cook

If cell phones are allowed to be used for data purposes (which I would support), I would ask that you phrase the rule so that any kind of voice communication (one or two way) was banned. If you simply ban cell phone calls, I believe many people may try to use Skype, FaceTime, and other programs to talk even though they're not using the voice functions of the cellular network.

Title: Jordan Heckley

This will be a danger to the aviation industry and could collapse an entire industry as a passenger I can say that no one would be able to have an enjoyable experience and travel in peace when people are aloud to have loud distracting conversations and disruptions to other passengers. Please do not allow this to happen!

Title: Anonymous

Please DO NOT allow calls on aircraft.  That many people in an enclosed place with one annoying person on the phone is just looking for trouble.  People are inconsiderate enough and volatile  enough, you're just looking for trouble. No call is so important that it can't wait until you land. 

In the days of Airfone, one person on a call was very disruptive,

Thank you

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow phone calls one planes.

Title: Amands

Title: Anonymous

I believe that voice call communications on board an aircraft is not necessary. An aircraft is a confined area especially in cases when there is full flight and having people talk on their cell phones inside the aircraft would be extremely disruptive to the flight experience. There are many other ways to communicate using portable electronic device such as, texting, which is less disruptive. Texting allows passengers to communicate while being on the aircraft without being so disruptive to fellow passengers. It would be to presumptive to expect passengers to respect their fellow passengers and not talk on their phones in a rude or loud manner. I think the best way to regulate this activity is not to allow voice calls at all unless it is prior to take off. Creating "quiet areas" would not be good use of space on an aircraft given that most aircraft are already pressed for space. 

The DOT should ban passenger voice communication through portable electronic devices on aircrafts.

Title: David Zakem
Comment:
Please do not let voice communications become allowable on airplanes.

Title: Anonymous

Title: Charles Byrne

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Such regulation is not necessary – the market will determine the appropriateness (including the if, when, and how) of permitting voice calls on flights. There is a niche opportunity for new and existing business to cater services towards consumers who want to make in-flight voice calls and are willing to pay for the privilege. The fact that a majority of consumers oppose voice calls in flight suggests that the carriers would not abuse passengers by foisting the choice onto them industry-wide. So long a reasonable number of practicably affordable flights are “voiceless,” or that voice use is curtailed in such a way as to minimize cumulative noise impacts on passengers, consumers have a reasonable means of avoidance and the practice is not “unfair” under § 41712. If airlines are ceded the authority to develop customary policies and procedures for self-regulating the use of voice calls, the market will necessarily adapt (and conceivably, innovate) to address passenger comforts; there would be no such impetus is a ban is adopted. If the use of voice calls ultimately (through cumulative use, changing behavior) rises to the level of a health and safety threat, or is so discomforting and unavoidable as to constitute an unfair practice and/or interfere with the air service, the OST should then issue a NPRM, but not before, especially where the anticipated downside of failure for lack of regulation is merely passenger “discomfort.”

Title: Anonymous

Title: Anonymous

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I've got a Chinese lady on one side of me and a Spanish lady on the other - both decide to use their "rights" of making calls on the plane. Now, put that in the more enclosed airplane environment - or worse, in the seat next to you as you try to catch some sleep!   You've got to be kidding!   If you think that most people who decide to place a call are going to talk in "hushed tones", then you've got your head in the sand!   Yes, I'm angry that this topic is even being proposed to airline passengers.   Who would want to sit next to someone who is having a heated argument with their spouse, boyfriend, girlfriend, parents, whomever ...?   NOT ME!   And finally, what is so Freakin' urgent that can't wait until the passenger lands?  Nothing, that's what!

Title: Bob Stine
Comment: Of course voice mobile phone use should be banned in airplanes.  This is a no-brainer.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO cell phone use on aircraft!  Nothing is so important as to distrub those around you.  I find it extremely annoying (and rude) when people use their cell phones in any public area.

Title: Brice Salek

Title: Anonymous
