Comment: Use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft should be not allowed inflight.

Title: Robert Jardin
Comment: NO, please no to cell phone voice use on commercial air plane flights.

Title: Seanne Warfield
Comment: Absolutely not.  This is just ridiculous. No one wants to hear someone blabbing away for hours. Planes have wifi, that's quite enough. There is no NEED for it, it is a safety issue.

Title: Jason Lewis
Comment: With WiFi available on most US commercial flights, fliers are able to communicate with whomever they desire via email, or other mobile communication system they employ. This kind of communication does not disturb other passengers. Very few planes still have the Air-Phones, and the cost made them a novelty at best (most cell phone plans have unlimited voice minutes built into them). With increased security and cost cutting measures already degrading the flying experience for consumers, allowing cell-phone calls on airplanes will invariably cause more discomfort to frequent fliers. Even if the FCC deems cell phone calls "safe," the DOT should ban them from gate to gate. With text messages, email, instant messenger, multimedia messaging, and other non verbal electronic communication available through WiFi, there is no need to allow voice calls on airplanes.

Title: Shawn Orgel
Comment:
Hi there,

I want to put in my two cents. 

Absolutely no voice calls should be permitted on flights. 

Please keep us relaxed in the air. 

Thanks,
Shawn

Title: Stan Whitcomb
Comment: In my opinion, it would be fine to allow use of cell phones for accessing email, for texting, and for other data usage, but I would find voice calls on planes to be quite annoying due to the increased noise level.  Cell phone conversations are difficult to ignore and typically much louder than normal face-to-face conversations.  I encourage regulations that would prevent cell phone calls while in flight.

Title: Gail Robertson
Comment: I have over 3 million lifetime miles.  I have witnessed, on many occasions, people who will stand idly about before a flight and the minute they sit down in the plane, whip out the phone and loudly talk. Apparently to impress those within hearing range. Many people are boors to start with and being forced to sit next to one, on the phone, for an entire flight would lead me to consider bus travel.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
It is difficult enough to be crammed in an airplane with many people.
Even if a small portion of the people are talking on the phone, it would increase other's irritability and lead to conflicts in the air.

Title: Michael Kiffney
Comment:
Docket No. DOT-OST-2014-0002

As a member of the flying public, I am 100% against allowing the use of telephones for voice calls on airplanes when they are airborne. This would be disruptive and, I expect, regularly lead to significant problems on flights (e.g. arguments, verbal altercations, and possibly violence between passengers). In addition, with flights already short-staffed by flight attendants, I expect that most of their time would be spent mediating such disputes. An already exhausting and annoying process (flying generally - to include arriving early, checking in, security, boarding and then finally flying to yout destination) would be greatly diminished to the point that some people, myself included, would restrict myself to flying only when absolutely necessary. This would clearly reduce demand for airlines, thereby resulting in economic hardships in the long run.

Title: Kathleen Yhip
Comment: The DOT should absolutely not allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  Voice calls during flights represents a public safety hazard - they will more likely than not result in confrontation between passengers as the individual participating in the voice call disturbs other passengers ability to work, read, sleep, and generally pursue their own activities.  There is already enough tension for passengers and, more importantly, airplane crews, due to security considerations, dealing with weather, and cramming so many people into a confined space.  There is no phone call that cannot wait until the airplane lands - if necessary, the passenger can utilize texts or emails for communication during flight.  In the interests of public safety, sanity, and to maintain civility, DOT should not allow voice calls once the doors are secured.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Allowing cell phone calls on airplanes is a truly bad idea.  You think the drunks are bad?  Wait until 2 people start arguing over that loud obnoxious call.  I personally HATE listening to other people on the phone (ex: rude people talking on the phone on an elevator or in the bathroom).  Please please please leave flying as a sanctuary away from rudies and their phones

Title: Liz Morris
Comment: Please do not allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on planes. Like smoking polluted the air on planes, the space is too small to tolerate the noise pollution. We can wait to smoke and we can all wait to make those calls.

Title: Patrick Obregon
Comment: I don't view this as a safety issue so much as a social contract and common decency issue.  On an airplane, you are trapped in a confined space with no option to move away from someone who is talking on their cell phone.  And unlike trains, airlines don't have the option of designating "quiet cars" where cell phone use is prohibited.  Allowing voice calls on planes might also have the unintended effect of increasing incidences of sky rage.  At the very least, it will make air travel, which is already rather unpleasant in this country, even more frustrating for the majority of customers who are willing to wait till the plane lands and is taxiing before they start making calls.

Title: John Powell
Comment:
I oppose permitting the use of wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.

The cacophony resulting from permitting such use would render air travel even less endurable than it has now become.  The very idea is incomprehensively absurd.  This would be funny if it were a Monty Python episode, but as a serious proposal it is utterly baffling.

Please do not carry this forward.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed to allowing voice calls to be made from aircraft while in flight.  These are offensive enough in the airports and during loading and unloading (I will not call the way passengers are treated by the airlines in the U.S. "De-planing," etc.)  Because of the poor directionality of all modern cell phone microphones and their tiny speakers, users must speak loudly or even shout.  The usually high ambient noise level in airport boarding areas and aboard aircraft in flight make this even worse.  Lastly, our airlines pack us in like sardines in order to maximize their profits.  We have seen services on board disappear one by one and the comfort of the traveling public is increasingly degraded.  Allowing passengers to shout into their cell phones on board aircraft will just add to the claustrophobia and discomfort of our passengers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am asking that the DOT regulate voice calls on aircraft and NOT ALLOW such communication.  While I support relaxing the rules for other data uses (i.e. allow internet access from a browser, use of cloud services such as DropBox, spreadsheets connected to a common server for business, email and the like) these are common sense uses that do not detract from the flying experience for those around the data user.  That cannot be said for using cell phones for verbal communication, and studies have shown that cell phone users use a louder voice when talking on a cell phone than when talking to someone face to face (like their seatmate.)  
  There are certain things that I just can not control when flying, like a crying baby seated behind me.  I understand that and realize that is part of the flying experience.  I also understand that the DOT has allowed the airlines to enhance their revenue stream by using add-on charges or by putting in one (now two) more extra seats in a row than the plane was designed for.  That has impacted the flying experience as well and while I don't like it, I can choose to limit its impact by my flying habits.  This is the world we live in.
  However, the use of cell phones for voice calls goes beyond this and strays into the realm of the social compact.  Just as we will not allow (and I hope the DOT is not going to allow) someone to connect a speaker to their iPad or mobile device and use Garage Band (or their digitized music already on the device) to play music at a loud (say, 80 decibels- the sound of a 'quiet' food blender) level because they have the ability, I hope you will not allow someone to sit in a seat next to me and talk loudly on a cell phone for the duration of the flight because they have the ability.  If it is a communication issue then they can communicate (using email, SMS text, etc.)  but PLEASE do not allow voice communication.

Title: Dylan McGinty
Comment: NO NO NO!  A terrible idea. People who need to communicate can use nonverbal means, such as texts or emails. Passengers on planes are captive, and would have no recourse, such a moving, when someone is blabbering on about last night's reality tv show.

Title: Charles Knoeckel
Comment: I am strongly opposed to permitting mobile wireless phone calls on aircraft.  passengers would be captive audiences to the conversations of those using such devices, with no recourse or escape in the event of lengthy, loud, or unusually obnoxious conversations.

Title: L.B.L.
Comment: I  am OPPOSED to allowing voice calls on aircraft in flight.  I am a frequent business traveler, including over 1.5MM miles on one carrier,  and I use my cell phone often.  I do NOT need to use my cell phone when I am in flight.  I do NOT want to have to listen to others talking on their cell phones while in flight.  Flying has become so burdensome already... PLEASE do not add the cacophony of other passengers' cell phone conversations to the existing noise and other discomforts of air travel.

Title: Dale Zschoche
Comment: The use of mobile phones on commercial aircraft should NOT be allowed. The close confines of other travelers in a setting with high levels on ambient noise is a recipe for travelers' confrontations over the use of these devices. Most airlines have WI-FI connectivity to allow those persons who must communicate to do so without imposing their voices to surrounding passengers.

Title: Daniel Lawrence
Comment: Cell phones should continue to be banned on all aircraft. One-sided cell phone conversations are annoying and distracting. A study in the journal PLOS ONE finds that when people are trying to mind their own business, overhearing a cell phone conversation (by accident, of course) can steal away your attention much more than being witness to an old-fashioned, two-sided conversation.

Title: John M.
Comment: Please don't allow cell phone use!  I would get so irritated and angry having to listen to someone chat on their phone for long periods.  The issue is not that it's talking, it's that we hear only one half of the conversation.  Plus, people talk too loud because they have trouble hearing the person they're talking to.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow voice calls, but text messaging and email via cell should be fine. Alternatively, voice calls could be allowed at specifically allotted times in the flight -- e.g.1/2 hour to landing -- or areas of the plane -- like being at your seat and not in the bathroom. Otherwise the incentives created for customer behavior modification -- e.g., people staying in bathroom, or moving around the little space left on the plane so as to have a phone conversation. Ultimately, the cost of installing the system may create incentives to create a revenue stream from its usage, which could lead to voice calls. Now just imagine with the little space available between seats how would you feel with someone next to you potentially talking on the phone for multiple consecutive hours, or just screaming for a few minutes... I would consider myself a victim of an assault on my senses ans sensibility, a helpless victim. Thanks for thinking about individual customers and allowing us the opportunity to contribute.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no!   I travel a lot and this would be extremely disruptive!  The average traveler does not know basic manners this would devolve very fast

Title: John Mittelstedt
Comment: No voice calls. The planes are bad enough without people screaming and hollering in a closed, confined, unescapable place!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a bad idea.  Apart from being incredibly annoying to only hear one side of a conversation or having to hear a conversation at all, especially when people may talk loudly into the phone because of all the ambient noise in an aircraft, telephone conversations can be the source of all sorts of different emotions that aren't agreeable with being confined in a tight crowded space.  Whether it be boisterous laughter, angry yelling or anything in between, these kind of emotions may present a security issue as all passengers will be affected by the emotional swings effected by the calls.  If a passenger is already having a bad day and on top of that he/she receives a bad phone call in the middle of a flight he/she may in turn become angry/rude at fellow passengers and crew.  That behavior, will in turn may make other passengers uncomfortable/angry, which may lead to confrontations and unsafe situations, which may be hard to control by the crew.  Additionally, the noise level inside the cabin will certainly go up as you have dozens of people talking over each other.  In a worst case scenario, if there's a potential hostile inside the cabin, he/she may be able to coordinate actions with collaborators on other aircraft or on land.  No, this is a bad idea at all sorts of levels.  The confined space inside an aircraft is no place for telephone calls.  Please leave the "friendly" skies as they are today.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am against this proposal. I have a cell phone, in fact, it is my only phone. I believe I know where and when to use it properly without infringing upon the people around me. This is true at home as well as in public. Unfortunately this is not true of everyone and I am amazed at how many people there are that are simply so full of themselves that they could care less about others overhearing their "important" conversations. It is bad enough in public but at least you can move away fvrom the offensive person. I just can not imagine how that is going to play out on a captive audience in an aircraft. I see words between passengers and even scuffles perhaps if this ill thought rule is allowed. Air travel is bad enough when you are in the coach "cattle pen" section without having to listen to the blah, blah, blah of a neighboring passenger. Ear plugs and headsets are only good to a point.

Title: Jerry Mandel
Comment: Please, please do not allow cell phone usage on any flight. It will made the flying experience horrible and frankly will result in som every bad behavior. I fear also forthe crew. They will need to become the"phone police" and make the job harder than it is now.

Title: Vicky Boyd
Comment: I don't care if cell phones won't interfere with airline electronics, I don't want to see them allowed in planes in flight. I fly quite a bit, so I know what I'm talking about. I'm not one of those vacation fliers who may board a plane once a year. I'm on planes just about every week. It's bad enough having to sit next to some blabbing seatmate who won't shut up for a 6-hour cross-country flight. (As my father used to joke, that person needs a serious case of lock-jaw.) Now take that non-stop talker, boost the decibel level because people tend to talk louder on a cell phone, and now try sitting next to that person for a half day. Talk about road rage.  Fliers are testy enough as it is, what with surly cabin attendants, flight delays, smelly seatmates who don't believe in bathing, crying babies, and overweight seatmates who ooze into your space try to take over two seats. Now throw in a loud talker on a cell phone who is talking about inane subjects, such as who she or he bedded last night, personal medical issues, Peyton Place within the family, and other nonsense, and it's enough to prompt a linching. So to keep the stress levels within those airplane cabins below the threshold for mass riots, I urge you NOT TO ALLOW CELL PHONE USE IN FLIGHT.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed to the use of cel phones on flights. I would hate to have to listen to a loud boisterous passenger seated next to me talking during the flight. Let's keep the skies peaceful and civilized. Businessmen are the worst. They tend to bark into their phones and want all to know how important they are.

Title: Paul Hendrickson
Comment: Cell calls allowed on a commercial flight other than while the plane is on the ground will be a big intrusion in the ability of fellow passengers to endure a crowded plane suddenly lifted to cacophonous heights by numerous passengers talking over each other to be heard and understood by their appointed parties on the other end of their phone connection. Please do not authorize this further invasion of relative peace and quiet while in transit by airplane.

Title: Mark Lewis
Comment:
Hello,

As a very frequent flyer I can think of nothing with the potential to be so devastatingly annoying than allowing mobile phone use on commercial flights.

Air travel today is already a gruesome, cramped, frustrating experience.  Being trapped in a metal tube with someone shouting into their phone could inflame an already tense environment.

Title: Robert Robertson
Comment: Although technically it can be done with today’s cell phones I think it would be a bad idea to have people talking business or personal on any flight. There are so few places these days one can be without the constant yammer of someone on a phone. I would ask that voice calls should only be aloud prior to landing for those that need to contact someone for a ride or to look into their connecting flight. I think a plane ride sould be like a movie theater. It allows people to sleep or watch the onboard movie without listening to someone on a phone talking about business or their latest encounter the night before.

Title: Nick Tonkin
Comment: I fly coast to coast several times a year. I completely oppose all use of cell phones on planes. I support a rule that would ban use of cell phones while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Lifting the cell phone ban is a recipe for disaster.  There is already an almost complete loss of civility amongst travelers (and the public at large).  It's bad enough listening to people bawling into their cell phones pre-departure and post landing, adding this misery to the entire flight will make an already uncomfortable situation unbearable.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of mobile phones for voice calls on planes.   In this age of everyone having their "rights" we have to recognize the rights of the people around them.   Flying is not a pleasant experience as it is.   And we all know there are many people who consider themselves and their phone calls more important, more interesting, and more entertaining than they actually are.  Do not make flying any more of a pain than it already is.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: While opening up data usage for anytime during a flight is 'OK', the use of cell phones for voice conversations should not be allowed.  The current time frames (prior to closing the door on take-off and after the start of taxiing on landing) should be retained.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow the use of mobile devices for voice calls on aircraft. Traveling is very stressful, as it is, and allowing their use will, only, add to the stress. 
The normal atmosphere on an airplane is noisy, as it is. In order to be heard, people would have to shout into their mobile devices which would make it even noisier. 
Also, if there is a disagreement between passengers about the use of their mobile devices, a flight attendant could be the arbitrator which would make their jobs even more dangerous when dealing with, potentially, explosive situations.
All in all, a bad idea.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # N/A
Comment: NO Cellphones on planes!!! NO NO NO!!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No No No cell phones on planes. Way too noisy.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO!!!! Let 'em text if they want (on silent, please) but I really don't want to sit next to someone yapping away in an inane conversation. I read, might even take a quick nap, or simply enjoy looking out the window. Please don't ruin flying for me.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Not sure why the DOT would even entertain allowing cellular voice calls on commercial aircraft flights. I am adamantly opposed to this proposed policy. Not always, but many times flying is stressful for a variety of reasons. Allowing someone to endlessly engage in mindless chatter on a cell phone would, to me, only serve to create additional stress for passengers and have an adverse effect on the overall flying experience. You might as well recommend increasing the amount of seat recline while you are at it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
NO, absolutely NO, 
Flying in Coach with (0) Cell Call allowed = CattleCars  Today.
Flying in Coach with Cell Call Allowed =  A significantly higher  rates of air rages,Much greater discomfort for passengers, and incidents of Rudenessin Said Cattle Cars. .

Title: Gail Sonenshein
Comment: I urge you in the strongest possible terms to continue the ban on cell phone use in flight on airplanes. People who speak on cell phones tend to speak louder. And so many people appear addicted to using chatting on their phones, that there would be no peace for anyone flying if people are allowed to talk on their cell phones on a plane. It would be the equivalent of allowing people to shout on the plane whenever they wanted regardless of the inconvenience to others.

Title: Yvonne Cunningham
Comment: I vote no .

Title: Helmar Bayer
Comment: The average traveler is impolite and the cell phone addiction is rampant.  Please do not permit cell phone usage during flights.

Title: Lisa Cadman
Comment: Please do NOT allow cell phone use on airplanes, it would make flying a nightmare.  Being able to send emails would be sufficient!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no. On planes, a traveller's voice carries forward. Due to the noise of the airplane people will need to talk loud to be heard. People will use speaker phone. All I see is trouble and a large increase for in flight issues. Please keep the ban for in-flight cellular phone calls.

Title: Jan Donatelli
Comment:
ABSOLUTELY NOT!!!!!  I can stress strongly enough how much I hate the idea of having anyone seated around me speaking on the phone.  This would be abused by so many thoughtless people--loud, non-stop, hours long conversations.

Also--have not terrorists used cell phones to detonate bombs?  The thought that someone at the DOT, and FCC, would even consider this has me questioning the whole point of the TSA.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I can't even imagine sitting in on airplane where it is allowed to talk on the phone througout the flight when it is already annoying when one person is entertaining half the airplane with their phone conversation as soon as they touch down at their destination.
A lot of people don't know what an inside voice is and don't seem to care either weather they bother people around them.
On top of that imagine the aggression text messaging already creates in movie theaters and now thinking of allowing calls at 35000 feet in a metal tube with no escape...scary!!!

Title: Mark Sylvester
Comment: No, no, no...  You're asking for trouble if voice calls are allowed on aircraft.  Most people do not want to listen or be disturbed by someone else talking on a phone.  Add to it, a confined space where people can't escape the disturbance, and you've got a recipe for heated exchanges, arguments, and even violence that could endanger persons on board aircraft, and the flight itself.  It is a guaranteed disaster.  People will be free to communicate via text message or e-mail.   That is more than enough while flying.  For international flights, have a designated area in the plane where phone calls can be made.  Most of those planes are large enough to accommodate such an area.

Title: Sally Burke
Comment: Totally opposed to the use of mobile phones on ANY aircraft!!!

Title: Carol Metzger
Comment: Please do not allow mobile wireless devices (cell phones, etc) for voice calls on airiplanes.  The last thing any of us want is to sit next to someone constantly talking on their cell phone.  Flying can be stressful enough without having to put up with people on phones.

Title: Robert Meyer
Comment: Absolutely not!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Silent texting and days is fine, but NO voice/phone calls please! We all deserve some peace and quiet in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Absolutely not!! Too much chaos on would be created, yet another regulation flight attendants would have to adhere to, with the understaffing that's happening across the airline industry!!

Title: Stephen Kepes
Comment: While Airline lounges have quiet areas, where travelers can get away from people who can't or won't put their phones away, you are not allowed that opportunity when you have a cabin full of phone chatters. Even one loud or animated person talking on a plane can be an irritant for people aisles away. If all passengers are allowed to use phones in flight many will. People tend to speak loudly when they use cell phones. Some people are just plain impolite and boisterous when they get on a cell phone. What about passengers who are trying to relax, take a nap, read a book, etc.?  With dozens of people raising the volume in the cabin, it will seem more like a terminal than a airplane cabin. If you need to communicate....texts or e-mails are fine. Disrespectful people, unruly children and crying babies already test the patience and sanity of travelers today. If you really want to up the tension in the passenger cabin, then let dozens of cellphone conversations enter the mix. You'll find a new phenomenon making headlines..."Air Rage!"

Title: Brian Thorn
Comment: No! No voice calls. No web chats. No VOIP calls. No Skyping. Data access is fine but I don't want to listen to Joe Hotshot Businessman talking about his latest deal, nor do I want to listen to Teenybopper Suzie talk about the last totally rad party she just attended.

Title: Brian Heinrichsen
Comment:
I am opposed to the use of voice calls on aircraft during flights.  Phone conversations would be very disruptive, too many people have nothing better to do than talk for hours.   Also there are many individual's that for some reason have to raise the tone of their voice while on the cell phone to impress those around them.  I travel for pleasure and to relax, I should not have to have to be bombarded with these conversations when planes are relatively quiet now.
I am a frequent flier, elite flier and fly over 40,000 miles per year.

Title: William Giesecke
Comment:
NO NO NO NO NO NO NO

As a professional pilot in the aviation community I can tell you this is a terrible idea.  I have already seen people not turning their phones in airplane road with the new rules.  FA's not enforcing it.  This DOES CAUSE POPPING IN OUR HEADSETS.  I guess it shows that SAFETY IS NOT A PRIORITY!  Now imagine people trying to sleep and people on their cellphones claiming "its my right," "its my personal freedom" and that unfounded road.  They have WiFi on most aircraft now.  Let them put their phones in airplane mode, connect to the WiFi and send texts via it. That is at least quite and acceptable.  And even with that their phones should be required to be on silent.

I just sat thru a flight with 6 guys YELLING the WHOLE FLIGHT.  EVERYONE on the plane was glaring at them.  The FA told them to be quiet.  Passengers told them to calm down.  We told them to calm down.  Nothing.  Now imagine 50 ppl or more on phones and pissing everyone off.  This is a terrible idea and considering safety has already been compromised this is awful.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am not in favor of allowing passengers to talk on cell phones during a flight. A telephone conversation impacts other passengers, mostly in a negative way. There are many other methods of communicating such as texting, using social media and emailing that don't impact others. Allow these methods, but not telephone conversations.

Secondly, the air travel experience is challenging enough:  getting through security, the boarding process, the small confines of the plane and being in close proximity to others. Allowing passengers to talk on cell phones during the flight means the nonstop banter of the business person "thinking outside the box" and dealing with the "paradigm shift."  It means listening to people talking too loudly into their phones.  It means two to three hours of listening to people regurgitate the minutiae of their day, their week, their lives. Can you imagine?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please, do not allow.  The last thing the flying public needs is to be stuck in a long tube, surrounded by inconsiderate people all having different conversations at varying level of noise.

We can all wait until we land for the conversations, texting and email, okay.

Title: G. Tenenbaum
Comment:
The proposed rule DOT-OST-2014-0002 should NOT allow mobile wireless voice calls on aircraft when in the air. I fly about 40,000 miles per year, some for business and primarily for pleasure. I treasure my in-flight time for resting, working, catching up on reading or just "quiet" time. This would be impossible if such voice calls were allowed in flight.
   Our brains are wired to try to fill in the blanks of the other side of the conversation we hear, which, we obviously, cannot do.  Hence it is extremely distracting to involuntarily hear one side of another person's cellphone conversation. It is not just "white" noise. Furthermore, the content of other persons' calls may be even more distracting, annoying or intemperate.
    Please leave this one place in our too-busy world free of this use of technology.
    I would also object to allowing mobile voice calls in just a portion of the aircraft. As we learned with smoking cigarettes on airplanes, the practice is bothersome to others even if they are not sitting close to the smoker. The same would be true if persons in certain rows were allowed to use their mobile devices to make voice calls at will on an aircraft in flight.
    Please do not allow mobile wireless voice calls on aircraft in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I oppose in flight voice calls. I am in favor of silent communications such as messaging and data.

Title: Robin Wearley
Comment: No. Please no calls. Texting fine. Flying is miserable enough without having to listen to some inane teenager going on and on about nothing or some jackass business person big dealing it across the continent. I will end up with a police record for jamming phones down the throats of those who think they are so important that they must interrupt the little peace and solitude we get in-flight. People have lost their sense of civility as it is in public. This will put us over the top. I am a Delta Diamond Medallion flying 125k miles/year. Please, for the love of God, do not allow calls.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Phone calls should NOT be allowed. The last thing that I want on a long flight when I am trying to read/work/sleep is to have the person next to me on the phone for hours, loudly sharing personal business. Planes are loud enough anyways without cell phone chatter.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a flight attendant, allowing the use of cell phones to make calls during flight is just asking for trouble and destined to make our flight time working more difficult.  Passengers now fight (sometimes literally) over overhead storage bins, armrests, seat recline, noisy children, stinky food.  You name it.  Allowing people to speak on phones during flight is guaranteed to make the cabin environment even more stressed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Data and text communication aboard commercial aircraft seem quite reasonable and would offer pleasant,if not expensive,safe passenger distractions aboard long flights. Permission to allow voice communication on the other hand is an open invitation to foster bickering among already stressed passengers. Who is going to mediate disputes, the flight attendants or cockpit crew? How many aircraft are going to be diverted due to passenger arguments over the unregulated use of mobile phone communications?
Please let us consider aircraft safety first not just convenience . ....

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO! NO! NO! Do not put the F/As in the position of having to police one more thing. Passengers still cannot police themselves with regards to simple things such as over head bin space, arm rests and reclining seats. To add voice calls into the mix would be volitile. Don't do it. Common sense and common courtesy are long gone from commercial air travel.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Cell phone calls are not allowed on busses, and trains, and the same should apply to airplanes.

Title: Marilyn Caplovitz
Comment: I think it would be quite disturbing to have people speaking on their cell phones while in flight.  People seem to speak much louder than normal when they are using a device.

Title: Deborah Brown
Comment: Absolutely no.  It is already out of control.  I don't won't to hear these people and their business deals or about their family situations.  Some people that just want to relax after a busy day or maybe someone is one their way to be with a loved one who is dying.  I think it should never be allowed.

Title: Paula Vaccariello
Comment: No please. I don't want to hear a plane full of people all talking on the phone during my flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am against this.   The calls can wait. Flying is chaotic enough these days.

Title: L. Sutterer
Comment: As someone that travels extensively (>100k miles per year) for business and pleasure, I feel strongly that allowing cell phone calls on flights would have a profoundly negative impact on the flying experience.  Increased stress and conflict in the air (expect arguments and fights at 30,000 feet) is not in anyone's best interest.  This would be annoying at best and dangerous, even deadly, at worst.  PLEASE do not allow cell phone calls on airplanes!!!

Title: Jacalyn McCarthy
Comment:
As a frequent flier, I am certain that the use of cellular phones would be so disruptive as to be inconsistent with adequate air transportation, and that the use of cell phones may result in an increase in violence.  

People cannot be counted on to regulate their voices and, in fact, may not even realize how loud they are.   Other commenters asked why an airplane should be regulated instead of a grocery store or a beach.  The answer:  People can walk away from a loud, disruptive, rude person on a beach or in a store, but that is not an option on an airplane.

If there is no safety risk, approve texting and surfing the web, but definitely ban talking on cell phones during all flights, not just ones at night.

After this, please work on the fact that the seats are getting so small it is ridiculous and would be a hazard in the event of a crash. I am not even talking width (though that is certainly annoying).   When I sit, my knees are at the seat in front of me, unless I pay extra for "economy plus".  This is getting stupid. Add several loud people talking on phones, and its a recipe for disaster.

Title: Karen Cobb
Comment: I would prefer the standard "no calls once the door is closed" stay as it is.  During the flight, I would find it very disruptive to hear passengers talking on their phone.  It would be especially hard on the flight crew during any safety instructions and the drink & meal service.  Texting would be okay, but please do not allow phone calls!  If allowed I would hope the airlines would have the option to opt out!  Thank you for letting me give my input.

Title: Angela Keeney
Comment:
Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft after the main cabin door has been closed for push back until the plane has arrived at it's destination.  

I am a flight attendant for Southwest Airlines.  My job will become extremely difficult if passengers are allowed to conduct phone calls during flight.  The safety of all passengers and crew should be the only consideration.  Allowing voice calls will disrupt others, and could cause someone to be injured or killed for not being able to pay attention during an emergency.

My employer, Southwest Airlines, has publicly stated that voice calls will NOT be allowed onboard SWA aircraft.  Many other airlines are following suit.  Please back us up and keep our skies safe.

Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO NO NO

Title: Chris Anderson
Comment: Please please please don't allow in-flight calls by airline passengers. Flying is already unpleasant enough.  This would make it unbearable, and I would be forced never to fly anymore.

Title: Eric Poulssen
Comment: Regarding docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002. I am against this proposal. It would be as distracting in the same way as having to sit next to someone in a phone booth (and that is a realistic analogy for a person sitting in economy class today) and listen to their conversation for the entire flight. No thank you.

Title: Chris Aubanel
Comment:
Voice calls on an aircraft! NEVER
Can you imagine a five hour flight sitting among people screaming on their cellphones? and getting louder and louder to heard.
This would be complete chaos. 
BAN any voice call on a plane. 
People with urgent business can use text instead, so there is no way they are cutoff from their offices, bosses or family
when in a plane now.

Title: Lawrence Thomas
Comment: I am a frequent flyer, having traveled by air for years and find that traveling can be stressful enough as it is without having some jerk sitting next you talking in a loud voice on a cell phone.  I imagine that this will lead to physical confrontations, especially if one is trying to rest while on a multi segment flight schedule.  Do not allow cell phone use on airplanes. There is no need for it.

Title: Robert Perrin
Comment:
As a frequent flyer, I would strongly recommend that the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on commercial aircraft be prohibited.  Flying is stressful for many reasons, excessive noise and distractions throughout the travel experience being one of the main reasons.  Though commercial aircraft cabins are not especially quiet, they can offer a respite from an otherwise stressful experience.  By adding the capability for voice calls on wireless devices, the atmosphere would become tense and distracting that it already often is.  It is very difficult to read or sleep when someone nearby is carrying on an intense business-related conversation. 

Therefore, NO mobile calls on aircraft.
Thank you

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly oppose the use of cell phones for voice calls on aircraft. Airline flights are horrible enough without 300 people yakking in an environment where you can't get away for eight hours. Allowing voice calls would be a recipe for disaster, in my opinion. I truly don't think that's an exaggeration.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am not in favor of allowing the use of cell phones on aircraft while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Not interested in being forced to overhear personal calls for hours

Title: Richard Taketa
Comment: Why change what seems to be working for all of us.  No cell phone calls while in the air or taxing to take off.  Calls allowed when taxing to gate. I really do not want to listen to other people's conversations while flying.

Title: Nancy Lambert
Comment:
I am very much opposed to cell phone use on commercial airlines!  Passengers are "captive" in an airplane.  Having to listen to a one sided conversation by a stranger sitting next to you truly is CRUEL & UNUSUAL punishment.  

When I purchase a seat on a plane, I think I have the expectation that "my space" will not be violated in this manner.  We already deal with children/babies and their noise.  The little people are excusable because they don't know better or are affected by air pressure changes. 

I urge you ... PLEASE don't make me sit next to or between two conversations.  These people can email or message and communicate.  Their right to talk on a cell phone stops at my ear.

Title: Bill
Comment: I absolutely do NOT want the DOT to allow use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on commercial aircraft. I will not sit close to a stranger and have to listen to them argue with their spouse, cuss at a vendor, have a love discussion with their mistress, discipline their child, or vocalize any other personal communication sitting within earshot of me. I would anticipate many upset forced-listeners to get physical with the person making the call--seriously. Do not allow this to happen. I have talked to many experienced travelers as myself and I have not heard a single person who did not think that allowing voice mobile wireless device calls would be a very stupid move.

Title: Rom Kollmansberger
Comment:
I am totally against allowing cell phone calls on aircraft in flight.  I travel quite a lot (American Airlines Platinum member) both nationally and internationally.  There is no way to control either duration of calls or loudness of calls on an airplane.  I try to do business paperwork or catch up on reading on many flights and I can imagine the difficulty of doing that with incessant phone calls going on all around my aircraft seat.  Please retain the current rules of no in-flight phone calls. I have no opinion on allowing texting, but verbal phone calls should not be allowed.

The potential for "conflicts" between passengers over the disturbing nature of these phone calls would be a big problem on any flight allowing phone calls.  

Please DO NOT ALLOW in-flight phone calls.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No, No, No....do not allow cell phone calls on airplanes

Title: Chris R.
Comment: No, definately no!  It's bad enough have a screaming baby or child kicking the back of my seat the entire flight (yes, this has happened just about every time I fly, no joke), there is no way I would put up with someone gabbing nonsense next to me the whole time either.  No, no, no and no!

Title: William Goff
Comment: This is a profoundly bad idea, on so many levels.   Most importantly, it is a critical infringement on a persons ability to relax in peace on a commercial flight.   Please do not lift this restriction!

Title: Dr. James & Diane Tuorila
Comment: My wife and I are frequent airline passengers and both of us feel strongly against the use of cellphones on aircraft. We believe it could result in fights between passengers, disruption of needed rest or sleep and interruption of aircraft crew duties. Please do not allow the use of Mobile wireless devices on aircraft. Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Voice-calls on aircraft should be prohibited.  They are too distracting and far too loud.  Furthermore, people ignore many more rules when they are trying to hear what someone is saying.  I have nothing against texting (provided that the notification sound is not overly distracting) but voice-calls should not be allowed.  (Ever been on a bus with people who won't get off the phone?  Now imagine that one a plane.)

Title: William Hallauer
Comment: Please prohibit cell phone voice calls on board passenger aircraft.  The airlines continue to increase occupancy rates and to cram economy-class passengers more and more tightly into seats.  It's bad enough on the ground when loud, obnoxious people in public places impose their phone conversations on others, but on the ground one often has the freedom to move out of earshot.  That freedom does not exist on flights.  Now, when my flights land and the approval for making calls is announced, it seems that the majority of passengers immediately whip out their cell phones and begin chattering.  That indicates to me that those same passengers are just itching to yak on their phones and certainly would inflight if permitted to do so, most without any concern for their fellow trapped passengers.

Title: Robert Sinert
Comment:
No. No to mobile phones voice calls planes. People are too rude to begin with. Using the theatre movies or concert events as an example, people are told to turn off cell phones and too many times you hear a ring during the program. Totally Rude.
Imagine not hearing important safety announcements from the pilot and flight attendants because of the mobile phone noise.
Having to sit next to someone who is constantly talking is criminal.
No cell phone voice calls in flight. People can wait until they arrive at their destination. 
Nothing is that important.

NO to cell phone voice calls in flight.

Title: Tom Jones
Comment: I absolutely disagree that mobile devices should be allowed for voice calls on aircraft. These are generally long distance trips people are taking in close confinement with sometimes more than a hundred people and the last thing we want is someone talking on a phone next to us for an entire trip. There is absolutely no reason to allow voice calls to be allowed. I would even go so far as saying texting/messaging would also be a bad idea for similar reasons. Someone tapping away on a phone for an entire flight would also be disturbing to most people on a flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I oppose the use of voice calls on flights. Air travel is becoming less and less tenable at best and there are more issues of air rage every day. To allow voice calls will only further disrupt air travel for fellow passengers and increase the instances of air rage and other ill-advised behavior. Please do not allow voice calls on commercial flights.

Title: Tom Jones
Comment: I absolutely disagree that mobile devices should be allowed for voice calls on aircraft. There is absolutely no reason to allow voice calls to be allowed. I would even go so far as saying texting/messaging would also be a bad idea for similar reasons. Someone tapping away on a phone for an entire flight would also be disturbing to most people on a flight.

Title: Geoff Gold
Comment: Voice calls should absolutely NOT be allowed on aircraft.

Title: Robert Cansler
Comment:
I  do not want to hear someone arguing with a spouse or boss at 35,000 feet.  If the choice is to use phones in flight then I for one will travel via auto or train from now on.  I will never fly again if I have to listen to someone on a phone.  

I would hope that all will stop flying if this is approved and let the airlines fail.

Title: Lola Boll
Comment: No way. Its stressful enough in those sardine cans

Title: Patricia Gold
Comment: I absolutely do not want the use of cell phones allowed on airplanes for voice calls. As a former flight attendant, I can only imagine the annoyance that passengers will bare day and night. Please, please, please do not allow this to happen. Everyone needs a break from the real world, even if that break is pushed upon them. If the rules change and mobile wireless devices are allowed for voice calls on aircraft, I will be driving a lot more.

Title: Lisa McSherry
Comment: Please no! We are confined within a small space, to be subjected to multiple people's conversations as they use their wireless device would make a difficult circumstance truly terrible. Please do not allow this.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Cell phone calls should never be allowed on planes! Too many people will be too loud, rude and indiscreet.

Title: Steve Ginn
Comment: I prefer that cell phone usage not be allowed on aircraft flights. Thank you

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO…  absolutely not.

Title: Toni Vitanza
Comment: No!No!No!No!No!No!

Title: Bradley Cullen
Comment: Voice calls should NOT be allowed on airplanes. As a frequent traveler, noise pollution is one of the most common complaints whether it is a crying baby or 2 other people talking too loudly. Similar to why many states have banned smoking in a public area, voice calls on airplanes should remain banned so they do not cause an uproar with other passengers. We live in a society where technology rules all. Texting and emailing should be sufficient means of communication and they can both be done without interfering with the passenger sitting next to you. What could someone possibly NEED to make a personal call for?

Title: Eric Peteson
Comment: Please, oh please, oh please DO NOT allow cell phone calls on aircraft, this is one of the last locations for silence (phone silence that is) that I know of on Earth. If allowed, it would become totally insane in the plane, so to speak.

Title: Jaime Jacob
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on flights.  It is already unpleasant enough to travel by plane.  Loud phone conversations will only make it worse.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed to use of wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please! No cell phone use inflight.

Title: Andrew V, Ruckman
Comment:
I strongly oppose any use by passengers of mobile wireless devices for voice calls aboard aircraft. 

Thank you.

Title: Jeffrey Harris
Comment: The use of any mobile wireless device for voice calls on aircraft should ABSOLUTELY BE PROHIBITED.

Title: Timothy Clampitt
Comment: Does anyone love hearing a person talking loudly on a cell phone in a restaurant or any public place for that matter?  No, of course not.  Traveling on an airplane is already uncomfortable and stressful as it is.  These kinds of situations can very easily lead to violence on the aircraft.  Please do not allow people to be disruptive and flat-out irritating because cell phone companies are lobbying you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I do not want cell phone voice calls allowed on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: no cellphone calls on the airplane.

Title: Andrew Chalot
Comment: I firmly object to allowing the use of cellular phones on airline flights in the USA.  I travel extensively for my job and can attest the passengers who use the phones before the doors close and after landing speak much louder than they normally do and the importance of their subjects of conversation seem to be of low priority.  Occasionally I will see passengers keep using their phones after the FAs have announced that the doors are closed and all passengers should discontinue the use of cell phones.  If the use of cell phones were approved, I could see some people, who are so engrossed in their conversations, miss important announcements over the aircraft PA system, endangering themselves and their fellow passengers.

Title: Marcia
Comment:
I absolutely don't want voice calls to be able to be made on aircraft in flight. Half the plane will be talking at the same time about whatever business or personal things they want, with the other half of the people having to hear it all. It'll be distracting, annoying, and unpleasant (based on how it already is before phones have to be shut off)...which isn't necessarily the DOT's concern, but should be airline managements' concern.  Nobody will hear announcements made by the pilots and flight attendants, people will pay less attention to the flight attendants talking directly to them than they already do, and people will likely feel more stressed having all that noise going on around them....and these could be DOT concerns.
Please, please, please...no cell phone use in flight (otherwise I'll also have to invest in very expensive, noise-cancelling headphones)!!!!
Thanks for asking for comments.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please, please, please, don't let people make phone calls on planes.  Nothing could be worse and could potentially cause major problems then letting people talk on and on next to you on a plane.  Nowhere to excape, nowhere to get away.  It could potentially cause violence between people.  No reason to talk.  People can email or just be out of touch for a few hours.  We can certainly survive without being on the phone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No way do I want to hear anyone talking on a cell phone on a jetliner.  I do not desire to listen to a conversation over the duration of a flight and with no choice to change seats.  Keep the ban on cell phone use during flights.

Title: Becky Bear
Comment: No, no, no. All we need is a confined space and all these people sharing the lurid details of their life loudly and simultaneously

Title: Bob A.
Comment: While I am not opposed to the use of mobile services on in-flight aircraft for non-intrusive activities such as SMS or messaging, I am opposed to the use of mobile services on in-flight aircraft for voice calls or similar activities. Voice calls would be intrusive and annoying to other passengers, leaving them with no option but to listen to at least one part of the conversation or find some way to block the sound. Please do not allow this.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DO NOT APPROVE THE USE OF CELL PHONES DURING FLIGHTS !

THis will consittute a hazrd as some people undoubtedly will use them at inappropriate times such as during annoucements by the captain and/or crew.

Title: Darlene Allred
Comment: I hope the ban on voice calls remains in tact.  I can not imagine this being a good thing, only one more way in which people can annoy each other in the confines of an aircraft.  While there are many who are respectful of those around them, we have all overheard one sided conversations that we wish we could have avoided.  I also think it will add another level of stress to the flight attendants as they will have to mediate any complaints from passengers on the matter.  Please keep the ban on cell phone calls in place.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe allowing voice calls on planes would be utter disaster. We would suddenly find the phrase "air rage" a common part of our daily lexicon.

Title: Tony Charbonneau
Comment: I can't imagine being next to the person arguing on the phone sitting next to you or the teenager who just doesn't care.    It will lead to confrontations onboard which is unacceptable.  There is no reason to allow them on domestic flights but I would not be against allowing them on flights lasting longer than 6 hours when the meal is being served or the last 30 minutes of the flight.  I also see this as a security issue as hijackers could easily use their phones to coordinate an attack.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone usage on planes.  Before retirement I rode a public transportation train to work, it was incredibly annoying listening to these phone conversations.   It is difficult to carry on personal conversations with someone on the plane due to the engine noise.   The electric train I rode had very little operational noise and the cell phone conversations were still very loud.  The price we pay for a plane ride is too high to have to suffer through being more of a captive audience than we already have to tolerate.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Don't allow phones on the plane

Title: Adam Hill
Comment: As a passenger on an aircraft on a regular basis, I do not like the idea of having the use of phones during flights. I believe it will cause more loss of life in an event of an emergency due to distractions during the flight, because passengers will be allowed to use their phones and not pay attention to flight crews. There is a place and time to use a phone, but not on an airplane during flights. I ask you not to approve this proposed rule.

Title: Emma
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls to be made by passengeers on air planes.  It is very annoying to listen to the conversations of others.  It appears that people seem to talk louder when talking on cell phones.  I believe you are asking for trouble.  Emotions will run high when one person asked the other to stop talking or to lower their voices.  I can imagine you will have fist fights over talking on cell phones on planes.  I believe the flight attandance have enough to do without mediating the use of cell phones.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No way!  With no privacy and passengers sitting shoulder to shoulder, this is a real invasion of a travelers right to quiet.  It is bad enough that train riders are subject to constant chatter from fellow passengers, but at least you can get up and move to a quiet car there.

Title: Alex Urbanski
Comment: Absolutely no cell phone calls on planes.  Cabins are extremely crowded and people are inconsiderate enough without another possibility for intruding on others.

Title: Karen Jablonski
Comment: Absolutely not!  It's bad enough having to listen to everyone's conversation in restaurants, on trains, while shopping, in every public place!  In all of these situations, you can get up and move away.  That's not possible on a plane.

Title: Karen Lawrenc
Comment: Please do not allow the use of wireless devices on aircraft.  It is so unbelievably annoying to have to sit 2 feet from someone and have to listen to their phone calls.

Title: Kathy Prickett
Comment: Please don't allow voice phone calls from mobile wireless devices on aircraft flights.  The space is tight enough as it is and I really don't want to listen to my seatmate's -- or anyone else's -- phone call.  Few people are "that important" they can't be off the phone for a few hours.  Plus it allows me, I selfishly admit, a respite of enjoying a bit of relative quiet on my trip -- one that I've paid enough money for and shouldn't have to be subjected to unwillingly eavesdropping.  Many thanks for the consideration!

Title: Joe G.
Comment: Unlike a train where the Railroad can establish a quiet car there is no escaping the chatter on an airplane.  Please no calls

Title: Jim Weber
Comment:
The area on the plane is too close to hold a conversation without invading the privacy of the people sitting around you.  Do not allow phone calls, but do allow texting.  Most people are very adapt at texting and it will provide most of the people with their ability to communicate with their audience without making their trip a nightmare of listing to unwanted conversations.

Jim Weber

Title: Larry
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to allowing voice calls on airplanes.  It will be nothing but an annoyance.  You can be sure there will be arguments between passengers that are trying to sleep or just rest who  have to listen to o personal phone calls made by passengers sitting near them.  I ride the train to and from work and if is annoying when others are talking on the phone and many speak much too loud.

I vote defineley  no to allowing phone calls.

Title: Larry
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to allowing voice calls by phone or any other type of wireless devide on airplane that can be disturbing to other passengers.  It will be nothing but an annoyance.  You can be sure there will be arguments between passengers that are trying to sleep or just rest who  have to listen to o personal phone calls beeping phones from received text messages made by passengers sitting near them.  I ride the train to and from work and if is annoying when others are talking on the phone and usually very loud.

I vote defineley  no to allowing phone calls or having people text or skype their friends and relatives while on an airplane.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on aircraft while in flight. We are in a confined space and cell phone calls would make the flight very uncomfortable and could make it difficult to hear the flight attendants and pilots announcements. Texting and email should be allowed and would provide an alternate way to personally communicate without disturbing your seatmates. I suggest as an alternative, that cell calls be allowed until the cabin door is shut on take off and after the aircraft has touched down on the runway on landing.

Title: Tom Walker
Comment:
With the recent changes regarding the use of technology on flights, I have noticed a significant change in passenger behavior.  As a flight attendant, I get to observe the entire cabin while doing the FAA required safety demonstration.  It was once a priority to get the attention of everyone on board while we perform it.  Now the decision has been made that passengers' personal communications are more important than knowing what to do in a potential evacuation.   I am required by the FAA to attend a safety refresher every year that includes airplane evacuations.  Is it too much to ask the passengers to participate in the safety of everyone on board each time they fly? What if I was allowed to be on my computer or phone during my annual training rather than participate in the safety details that I am required to review?  How would that serve everyone in a potential evacuation?  
I strongly disapprove of passengers being able to have telephone conversations in flight.  The quarters are far too close and I have observed that people generally speak much more loudly on the phone than in a normal conversation.  I don't think that it is fair to subject people that are not directly involved in someone's business to be forced into it by having to listen to a conversation that in no way involves them.  And besides that, I personally don't want to be forced into policing any displeasure with the issue because I am the authority in the cabin!  I also don't want people taking my photograph and posting it for the world to see because they don't understand protocol on an airplane.  
I fear that our lawmakers have been lobbied  too strongly on this issue and that reason has lost its place in the argument.  We have moved swiftly with the use of technology on airplanes in the last few years providing passengers with many options to communicate or entertain themselves.  Before long, most legacy carriers with have WiFi on every flight.  So opportunities to commentate are more prolific than ever.
But telephone conversations, after the airplane door is closed, are taking these freedoms too far.

Title: Monica Street
Comment: The space in a plane is too confined and it will be hard to control inappropriate language. I travel often and I do not want to be subjected to listening to vulgarity and ignorance for an entire flight. Kids and loud talking passengers are already distracting enough.

Title: Marilyn McCall
Comment:
I hope you will not permit the usage of cell phone to make phone calls on any flights.  

The idea of being squeeze in such close quarters and allowing someone to invade my ear space with some loud personal babble is scary. 

Flying these days is not something most travelers relish, this will only add to the discomfort.  

It also poses problems with those lacking in civility and  etiquette skills.

Marilyn McCall
Pittsburgh, PA

Title: Martin Brandt
Comment:
Do NOT allow the use of cell phones on aircraft once the doors close.  
The reason we hear headphones for movies or iPods is so the noise does not disturb other passengers.
We all deserve the same respect, comfort and quite, regardless of seat class or price of our tickets.

Title: Frank S.
Comment: I strongly feel that voice calls should NOT be allowed on aircraft.  People many times "shout" into their cell phone however a cacophony of cell phone voices throughout the aircraft should not be allowed.  It is intrusive.  Aircraft nowadays has become more uncomfortable with tight seats, misbehaving children and adults, body odor, video games with sound, laptops, earbuds with the music loud enough to hear without wearing them, etc.  Add to this the constant chatter of people on phone calls and an unpleasant experience becomes more unpleasant.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No. No. And NO. PLEASE. I do not need to hear a plane full of people's one sided conversations or arguments. Flying is bad enough. This would only serve to make it worse.

Title: Frank Dolce
Comment:
Hello - I am the director of global corporate travel at my company. In my view and that of many other people at my company, allowing voice calls on airplanes is not a good idea. It could very well lead to some unpleasant situations and possibly endanger other passengers and/or the crew. Please, please do not allow it.

Best Regards,

Frank Dolce
Director, Global Corporate T&E
OSI Systems, Inc.

Comment:
