Title: Eric Simpkins
Comment:
I am a frequent flyer in the U.S.  Two characteristics of my air travel are (a) performing business work on airplanes, typically on a laptop computer, and (b) getting sleep in between cross-country flights and on red-eye flights.  I am not in favor of federal agencies permitting the use of cell phones on airlines following closure of the airplane doors, as is the policy at present.  In fact, I strongly oppose the use of cell phones.  There is no need for permitting the use of voice communications; travelers that must communicate may do so using other emerging technology.  Thank you for asking for public input.

Eric Simpkins
Near Space Corporation
Tillamook, OR
541 639-5112
eric.simpkins@nsc.aero

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I humbly request you to maintain the ban on use of cellphones in-flight. Most people are already easily irritable on an airplane especially after having gone through extensive secuirty checks, long lines and possible delays. In a small and constrained space where tensions are already running high it is easy to set off an altercation among two parties both of whom want to exercise their rights; the right to use the phone and the right for peace and quiet. Today we have few such issues since cellphone usage is restricted. As someone who travels frequently (twice a week) for work and uses my time onboard to either catch up on work or sleep, I really do not want to be disturbed by someone who wants to discuss "keeping up with the kardashains" with their friends.

Moreover such a rule would be inconsistent with the rest of the world where mobilephone use inflight still remains banned. American users used to using cellphones in flight will only be asking for altercations when they refuse to comply with rules aboard foreign carriers by citing US rules.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I think allowing phone calls on flights would be terrible idea.  I can't imagine having to listen to somebody sitting in the next seat talking for 5 hours on a cross-country flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'd rather not have to listen to someone chatting away in such a confining space as a cabin of airplane.  It's uncomfortable enough as is to fly now a days and if allowed to talk while flying, it's really going to make things uncomfortable.

Title: M. Greenstein
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002                     
I am totally against allowing cell phone usage on a flight in progress.  People do a lot of things on flights, e.g., read, work, sleep, listen to music, etc.   I truly feel that no one wants to listen to the guy across the aisle or behind you talking on the phone for the whole flight.  It's totally distracting.  Admittedly I don't fly as much as I did before I retired but, flying has become to be "quiet" time and I personally don't want to lose that time. 
Marie Greenstein

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm all for it as long as flight attendants have the ability to take it away, should be a privileged, not a right.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Phone use should be allowed - i.e. texting and data however calls should not. It only takes 1 rude passenger loudly talking on the plane to disturb everyone elses peace.

Title: Bob Abernathy
Comment:
I can't imagine a more unpleasant, painful experience than flying in close quarters with ill-mannered, thoughtless fellow passengers bellowing into their cell phone for countless hours.  It is already bad enough being forced to listen in to the braying of the business class, jabbering away with anything but an indoor voice along the entire walkway and aisle as they board, and then while seated until the Attendant announces the door has been closed.

I though trains were bad enough, but at least one can move around a bit more.

There's nowhere to go on a plane.

It would be awful to endure row-mates making extended calls.  But imagine the spirit dampening din oozing from row upon row behind you, as scores of very important people collectively project their voices to the front of the plane.

The engine noise and the sound of the air conditioning or air circulation would prompt callers to boost their voices ever louder, in the misguided belief that they can't otherwise be heard over the racket.  This would be worse than sharing a ride in a taxi with someone making a cell phone call.

There'd be no sleeping, nor actual working on laptops in the event voice calls are routinely allowed.  And, frankly, i'm certain there are some who might react in a manner similar to those who have prompted the disappearance of peanuts aboard aircraft.

I'm confident there are no actual safety issues -- or this proposed rule would never have reached as far as a comment level.  And I'm sure most aren't deeply disturbed by the frequent calls placed once the plane has touched down, and connections and rides are contacted.

But please consider the cramped, confined space where passengers aboard routinely full planes struggle for comfort in order to endure the hours aloft.  Please don't subject us all to a phone booth with wings.

Thank you.

Title: Paul Childs
Comment: Air travel is bad enough without being stuck in a seat next to some idiot that needs to talk to someone for the length of the trip about whatever pointless drivel they wish to inflict upon you.  Not only will you have to listen to them talk, but because planes are noisy you will most likely get to listen to them shout into the phone.  Just because it is possible to use a cell phone on a plane doesn't mean it is a good idea.  This is the kind of rule that would benefit the rude people out there and make travel even worse for the everyone else.

Title: Sheryan Chester
Comment: I oppose a proposal to allow cellphone use on airlines during flight.  I - and I expect most flyers - do not want to be an involuntary captive forced to listen to another passenger's telephone conversation.  It also will add to the noise level in the plane, which already is high.  Cellphone use during flight has the potential to undermine security, as passengers may disagree and eventually scuffle.  There is nothing so important to be said that cannot wait until the plane is on the ground.

Title: James Dykas
Comment: There is no need to allow voice calls on aircraft; there are plenty of other ways available to communicate with an electronic/mobile device.

Title: William Matthews
Comment: I am against allowing voice communication via cellular phones on any airline flight.  I am also against non-voice communicatio, such as texting.  We are subjected to too many annoying private conversations--such as the airport terminal prior to the flight.  On an airplane, the close quarters with 50 up to 500 people with no where to escape to...make phone conversations something we do not need.

Title: Anne Berlack
Comment: I strongly urge you to continue the prohibition of the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on commercial airplanes.  As someone who flies regularly in all sizes of aircraft, I can atest to the competition for personal space that already exists onboard an aircraft. There isn't enough room now for feet, knees, shoulders and carry on bags. Adding voice calls, with the frustrations of inconsistent satelite wifi connections, and the increased noise of mobile conversations, will increase an already uncomfortable and tense environment.

Title: Stephen Jeffcoat
Comment: I am in favor of banning voice communication via electronic devices not owned and operated by the airline on all commercial flights, unless the airline designates a separate exclusive area of the airplane (at additional or same cost) where calls can be made.  In other words, if people want to pay to talk on their phones, they can sit in a separate part of the plane with people who have done likewise.  Otherwise, allowing unfettered use of voice calls on airplanes is likely to result in extreme discomfort to passengers, episodes of violence, and general disruption of air safety.

Title: MarySue Foster
Comment: I can't imagine a worse hell than being privy to voice calls on the already nearly unbearable experience of flying. Please. Do not do this!

Title: Hagen Frank
Comment:
No. No. No. No. No.

This is clearly a matter of air-travel safety.  Allowing in-flight cellular voice-calls would be the straw that breaks the camel's back.  Air travel is already a miserable experience due to a combination of intrusive security, shrinking seat size, airline overbooking practices that are designed -- and typically succeed -- in full or near full flights, reduced services, luggage fees that cause more and more travelers to hog carry-on space, etc..  As a result, on any flight of any duration, nerves and tempers are already on edge.  And now we're contemplating putting entire cabins at the mercy of every inconsiderate, self-important, cellphone-addicted ass who can't go a few hours without flapping their yaps?  That is guaranteed to produce in-flight confrontations that will not only pose a danger to flight-crews and passengers, but that will also disrupt airline scheduling as flights are diverted due to in-flight fistfights.  Of  course, because these fights will have occurred in the "special aircraft jurisdiction of the United States" per Title 42 of the U.S. Code, it will then be necessary for the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Offices to get involved -- as if Federal law-enforcement has the time or assets to take on even more work.

I am a retired U.S. Marine officer, and have also served as a U.S. DOJ prosecutor for the past 11 years, so I am not especially delicate.  Also, when I travel, it's almost always in coach.  I'm therefore as qualified as any to express an informed opinion on this matter.  The proposal to allow in-flight voice-calls is as profoundly unwise as it is unnecessary.

Hagen W. Frank
Grand Rapids, MI

Title: James Stoutamire
Comment: I strongly support continuing the prohibition on using any electronic device in the passenger cabin of a commercial aircraft while in flight to conduct any form of 2 way voice communication if for no other reason than there are too many people in close proximity to each other with no way to "escape" so to speak.  Now if those who just have to be in constant verbal touch could just go outside to chat I'd have no problem but that's simply not possible.

Title: Steve S.
Comment: I've heard that airlines may not necessarily allow this, even if it's legal.  If my airline does, I will immediately use my accumulated frequent flier miles and never fly with them again.

Title: Greg Pretre
Comment: This is a really BAD idea!!!  It is bad enough we fight cell phones in cars, theaters, restaurants, etc.  Enough already!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Telephone conversations on an airplane would be very disruptive for other passengers.  Text messaging and other smart phone use seem reasonable as long as the phone is operated in silent mode.

Title: Gail des Granges
Comment:
I appreciate the opportunity to comment on regulations that will impact whether or not cell phones can be used during airplane flights.

I would hope that the Department of Transportation will continue the ban on in-flight cellphone calls. I cannot comment on the safety aspects of cell phone use during flights, but I have very definite opinions on the impact of cell phone use in flight on the experience of airplane travel.

Airplane seating is very closely spaced.  It is usually not possible to change one's seat, or even move around freely. Many people are already listening to and watching devices through which sounds seep. Having to try to tune out the conversations of people in nearby seats will further degrade a travel experience that has become only marginally bearable.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The use of cellphones would be very disruptive and could even prevent people from hearing vital instructions from the flight crew.  Please do not allow use of cellphones on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO, NO, NO!  With people playing headphone already too loud, letting them speak on phone will just be another annoyance and is totally unnecessary.  Some business people might want to use there phone but the average user will be the chatty teanager, or other user just wanting to talk about nothing important.  As an airline dispatcher I also see the potential for diverted flights due to passengers getting upset with others talking loudly on phones, as well as added stress on flight attendants needing to police people's activities.  Please don't make our jobs harder.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Not no, but h--- NO!  The last thing I want is to listen to someone talking on the phone while at 35K feet.  You know you are flying well in advance, so plan the that you will be unavailable for phone conversations in advance and don't inflect me with you personal & business conversations!!!

Title: Anna Marie
Comment:
Absolutely not!  For the convenience of a few, the majority on the plane should not have to endure one more thing that will add to the stresses on a flight.
I remember being on a flights years ago when some seats had phones in them and even with the high cost of making calls, people would have conversations where people many rows away could hear.   The flight attendants have a hard enough time getting people to listen to them and dealing with rude behavior, people who don't understand that I don't want to hear their children yelling (small babies cry, that is one thing) and running up and down the aisle, adults who act worse than the most out of control child.

Title: Richard Gazda
Comment: I would not like to see the use of mobile devices to make voice calls be permitted on Aircraft.  I believe it would create something similar to road rage on the aircraft as passengers encroach on other passengers space and solitude.

Title: M. Chiesa
Comment: Self-regulation won't work and flight attendants are busy enough. And a plane isn't a subway or bus where you can get off at the next stop or hopefully, the person being too loud and talking for too long can get off. Trains offer quiet cars to avoid phone callers and have food cars where many people do their phone calling. An airplane is not a train, a subway or a bus. It's far more people in a condensed flying tube where the pilot can't pull over and kick the offending party out.

Title: Andy Odom
Comment:
The use of cell phones on aircraft will create a very intrusive invasion of privacy. 
People naturally talk much louder on the phone than in a personal face to face conversation.
I don't need to hear 20 or 30 conversations going on at the same time.
Please don't subject us to that.

Title: Gwendolyn Lee
Comment: Please do not allow this proposal to pass.  People are already rude enough when others are in a restaurant or at a movie theatre.  People using cell phones talk too loud, disturbing those around them.  Most people who are flying chose to work, read or sleep during the flight.  I enjoy taking a nap on every flight.  I just don't think people will be considerate of others.  Cell phones should be turned off!

Title: Clint Glascock
Comment: Please do not allow use of cell phones for calls on airplanes.

Title: Angie
Comment: Please do NOT allow people to place phone calls or receive phone calls on flights!!!! The amount of noise disruption alone would be ridiculous! As a flier, I like to relax and even sleep on my flights. It does not matter what time of day the flight is. Texting would be fine, but no one wants to listen to the people next to them carrying on a personal phone call! Imagine that annoyance multiplied by the number of people in every row! It is NOT necessary! If you can't wait to speak to someone on the phone for a couple of hours on a flight, don't fly!!! I could understand it on a long flight or an overseas flight, but even then I think it would have to be limited to a set 5-10 minute period per every 4 to 5 hours of flight. Then it should be a set time for all passengers to do it at the same time, so they still don't interrupt the rest of the flight. And if there is ANY chance at all that the calls could interfere with the safe operation of the plane's equipment, absolutely NO call should be allowed! Frankly I don't want to listen to everyone on their cell phones. Please keep my flight time as serene as possible!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
No please, no. Adding voice calls to the ever shrinking confines of a commercial airline would be like sending passengers to hell with gasoline underpants. Already you can feel air on your neck every time the passenger next to you takes a breath, and inane incessant chatter (which it always is when you are listening to a one sided conversation) would be asking for trouble. Air travel is already stressful, the aggrieved party cannot take flight away from an annoying passenger, so they may choose to fight. The airlines have already done an excellent job turning its passengers into cattle, don't slaughter the poor cattle by forcing them to listen to their seat mate's phone call.

With the incessant drone of the airplane, whispering on a call would not be an option, with heightened travel security walking away, to stand in the aisle, is not be an option. We know from experience (movie, restaurant, church, public transportation) that expecting most people on a phone call to show consideration for others within their vicinity is an exercise in futility.  Expecting patience and rationality from a person who feels trapped listening to another person's phone call is unrealistic.

The argument could be made that we survived passengers making phone calls on airlines before, but Airphone never moved beyond the the novelty stage and the cost of the calls kept them brief and infrequent.

In a perfect world there would be no need for regulations to control behavior, but just as there is a need for speed limits and seat belt laws we need one to prevent anarchy in the air.

Title: Stephen Alhart
Comment:
The confines of a cabin of mainline or regional jets at cruise altitude is NOT the place for multiple voice cell phone calls.  Flying in 2014 is not glamorous like it once was.  Fares are low, cabins are full and most passengers appear to have left their manners at home.  Many passengers today are simply rude, expecting the world for the $129 non-refundable fare and want endless service from the cabin staff.  Add the allowance to make cellphone voice calls to this mix of humanity and flying will be nothing more than a bus with wings.  Those of us that have to fly weekly for work take the few hours in the plane as a time to be electronically disconnected from the world 35,000 below our feet.  There is nobody that important that requires instant voice to voice contact.  If one really needs to contact someone on the ground, allow passengers to SILENTLY text/message only!  There is no need for voice to voice cellphone calls TO or FROM an aircraft in flight.

Thank you...

Title: Stefan Moorehead
Comment: I fly quite a bit for work and for vacations and I am definitely opposed to lifting the ban on cell phone calls in flight. Please keep cell phone calls out of active flight time.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Not just no but heck no. The confines of an airplane is not the place to have people talking on cell phones. For a starter most people talk way too loud on cell phones when talking to someone as if they have to shout to be heard. On a recent trip a rude person used his phone to phone someone as we were on approach to the airport and it was as if he were in the seat next to me. I couldn't hear the gate connection announcement. Texting is one thing but no to voice calls. As bad as smoking was this could be just as bad. Flight rage may be a result of this action.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow voice calls on airplanes.  Some people who talk on cell phones insist on talking too loudly.  I do not want to get stuck next to someone having a loud conversation for hours on end.  In any other place I could simply move away from the offending person -- on a plane, I don't have that option.

Phones are already permitted on the ground both before takeoff and as soon as the plane lands.  Please, let's reserve the time in the air for a little bit of peace and quiet.  Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I feel that the use of cell phones on commercial airplanes is not only necessary, it would be quite annoying.  Imagine being stuck in a phone booth with someone talking incessantly.  Now imagine being stuck there for hours. Many hours.  It would cause problems.  People are boorish enough as it is on airplanes.  Allowing phone calls would only make the situation worse.  We as a society have survived this far quite nicely without being able to call whoever whenever.  There used to be phones on the backs of seats in airplanes.  They were prohibitively expensive to use.  We should stay with those.

Title: Oliver
Comment: Cell Phone use should not be allowed in the already-cramped confines of an airplane.  I already have to deal with these people in front and behind me in every line I'm in anywhere.  People in general don't know common courtesy from a hole in the ground anymore and I don't want the person sitting next to me talking about his/her bunions and what, if any, medication they are using.

Title: Peter Lada
Comment: I support mobile use, but please keep the voice calls blocked, unless on the ground.

Title: Veronica Pierce
Comment: I am very opposed to lifting the restriction on the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  In such a small, enclosed space as an airliner, the noice from numerous people making personal phone calls would be terribly intrusive on the other passengers surrounding them.  Some people are very loud when talking on their cell phones and it would be difficult, if not impossible, to enforce any kind of limitation on the use of the phones if other passengers complained.  I do not object to the use of texting or sending emails (although I think people should be required to keep the notification sounds to either mute or vibrate, so as to not annoy other passengers).

Title: Michael Michalski
Comment:
Do NOT allow voice communication on air travel.
It will cause great animosity among passengers.
A one sided conversation is extremely annoying.
People on phones think they are the privileged few and don't care who they annoy with their loud, obnoxious conversations.
It will lead to confrontations and potentially violence.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I think mobiles would not be allowed to be used in airplanes, it will be annoying for passengers to stand call plus call when I want to rest or sleep.

Title: Ken Halverson
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on planes.   texting and e-mailing are fine, but no phone calls.    the  plane cabin is noisy enough as it is.

Title: George Wood
Comment: Texting and data are ok, but absolutely no voice

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO!!!!!!! Aircraft cabins are cramped and crazy enough as it is. Just imagine New York to LA while you listen to people describe how they are in the clouds, eating peanuts, on and on. Flight attendants can't even get people to listen to the safety briefings much less if there is a real emergency, while everyone calls home or the news media.

Title: James Yeisley
Comment: I am a pilot for Delta who commutes weekly to New York from Dallas. I am firmly against voice cell calls inflight. It is aggravating enough to listen to people talk loudly on their phones after landing with no regards to people around them. This would be a nightmare during flight where the flight attendants would be called to solve complaints from irate customers. Please do not approve this!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow phone calls on flights.  Even though most probably would be nice and polite about it, there are always those who would be rude and inconsiderate of others, especially on longer flights.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow call phone voice calls on commercial airline flights! We're already packed in so close to one another that flying is uncomfortable and unpleasant. Listening to someone's loud calls for hours on end will put passengers on edge and maybe even lead to conflict. These days the only nice thing about flying is being disconnected!

Title: Ryan O'Leary
Comment: No Cell phone calls on commercial flights. Thank you

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
It all boils down to flying sucks. Having the most inane conversation in the world happening next to me where I can't get up will only make it worse. Then you will have those business people who are trying to run their empire from right next to you; that will suck. Lastly you will have the nervous flyer who natters and not only annoys you but annoys someone 2000 miles away. 

I want you to think about sitting next to Vicky Pollard on a flight from LA-NYC. Just check YouTube for Vicky Pollard and you will realize that no human should have to sit near that for 6+ hours on a phone. 

Now you are probably looking for some technical reason to stop phone use so I will give you a good one. If you are a frequent flyer and you end up next to Vicky Pollard you might find yourself buying a Cellphone jammer so that on your next flight you can shut her up. But what on earth would a cellphone jammer do to an airplane? So now you have some businessman sitting with smug self satisfaction that the nattering has stopped but potentially so has the nattering in the cockpit with people on the ground; or the navigation system, or some other bit that is needed to keep the airplane in the sky. You might think that most people would know that turning on such a device would be bad for their health but remember that a goodly number of people think that the sun goes around the earth and basically have no real idea how modern technology works. Think of this as a whole new form of air rage. Plus would a business flyer so stupid as to use a cellphone jammer realize that it is his fault that the airplane is now in a spin toward the ground? Would the crash investigation team think to look for such a cause? 

I don't fly much but please not only save me from Vicky Pollard but save me from the business man with anger management issues and his cellphone jammer.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe this proposed rule is not a good idea. As a traveler, I do not want the use of cell phones on aircraft because it will increase the amount of noise and make the flight less enjoyable. I support texts or other silent sources of communications; however, cell phone use should not be allowed.

Title: Gregory Lucchesi
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft ever.   This will make air travel even more distracting and chaotic.  Thank you.

Title: Kenneth Peirson
Comment: I am strongly against the use voice calls on aircraft, with one exception, the aircraft would have to have a special room for the call just like a restroom.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a FA with over 31 years, I can tell you first hand this is a bad idea.
Stress levels are already high, and now you propose unregulated usage of cell calls in a tube at 35,000 ft?

It's tough enough to get passengers to pay attention to safety and exit row safety briefings, this proposal will make it next to impossible....

Feel free to text and email away, but limitless calls with no escape?

Just say NO!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow.  The thought of listening to hard of hearing Louie, yelling at Vinnie from Brooklyn on a bad cell connection all the way from JFK to LAX should be enough to prevent anyone from thinking this is a good idea.

Title: Albert Schrichte
Comment: For the love of peace, quiet and safety on the airplane do not allow cell phone usage in flight. Changing the regulation will only raise tension levels on an AC were people are captive from take-off time until landing at their destination.With internet access readily available today silent communication is possible without disruption by the person seated next to you. With airstream noise abound it will be impossible for most to not have to yell into their phones. Most people do it it standing still on the ground with no noise, on a moving AC it will be worse.And then you have the desparite Sales persons who will no doubt be using the opportunity for live sale pitches (eavesdelivery) as they do today on the ground before door closure.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Absolutely not!!!!!

To force travelers to be subject to constant phone coversations will create severe discomfort that is impossible to escape being buckeled into your assigned seat.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Commercial aircraft cabins are too crowded to allow the use of cell phones.  I do not want to be subjected to listening to everyone else's phone calls when I fly.  Cell phone should remain OFF between takeoff and landing.

Title: Walter Dietrich
Comment: Please do not support allowing voice calls on commercial aircraft. Cell phone conversation is the most invasive thing in a confined space. It will impact my right not to listen to someone's  conversation for hours. I will be a hostage strapped into my seat. I will not fly on any commercial airline that allows this to happen.

Title: Tammi Smith
Comment: I think voice calls are unsafe and have no place on an aircraft.  If there is a safety announcement, or an in-flight announcement, and someone is conducting business on their phone or talking to their BFF, the passengers around that person, as well as that person, may not hear the safety announcement.  It's bad enough now when the flight attendant's are giving their safety presentations and people just talk over them.  For some passengers, that information is very important -- especially if it is their first time flying.  Not to mention the language younger passengers may be subjected to hearing.  And if a passenger wants to sleep, how is that possible?  Everyone cringes now if they are seated near "the baby" because of the noise/crying, etc.  Voice calls are a huge mistake and it would inconvenience the majority to benefit a few.

Title: Marvin Cavender
Comment: NO NO NO dont want to listen to someone else blabber during a flight where you have no where to go

Title: Marvin Cavender
Comment: NO NO NO NO. No need to have to listen to someone else blabber during a flight. they can do without there phone for the flight.

Title: Michael May
Comment: DO NOT allow cell phone calls on aircraft.  The rudeness of people yelling into their cell phones while you are a prisoner trapped in an aluminum tube next to them will cause arguments and probably actual physical confrontations if you allow this STUPID idea to move forward. People need to be respectful of others, not think the whole world revolves around them. Since so many are incapable of this they cannot be allowed to use their phones in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This would be the worst idea ever. it is bad enough having to listen to people's loud conversations at the gate. I dont think I could stand listening to someone talk on the phone for a full flight. I think allowing cell phone calls on the aircraft would lead to arguments and possible fights compromising the safety of passengers and the aircraft.

Title: Mark Meredith
Comment: Please no voice calls. I know my voice is loud but gets louder when I'm on the cell phone. In an enclosed airplane, I feel like this would cause many problems. Sitting beside someone that talks non stop from Atlanta to L.A. would put me over the edge!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO - please do not allow voice calls aboard aircraft!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO!  Please do not allow voice calls on airplanes!!!

Title: Glenn Leonberger
Comment: While I am in favor of the current rules that allow for phone calls while on the ground, I am not in favor of inflight calls.  The environment is too compact and people near the caller have no way to get away from loud talkers.  Additionally, in most cases people have alternate ways to communicate if needed via inflight WiFi.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am for the ban on cell phone use on aircraft. I think people who lack cell phone ediqutte would cause altercations among passengers thus causing safety issues for passengers and the aircraft. As a frequent business traveler I do not really want to listen to other peoples conversations in a cramped environment when I am either trying to rest or work. There has to be a ban.

Title: Tom Baker
Comment: Please do NOT allow voice calls on commercial flights!  This would only make flying more uncomfortable and there is no way to get away from someone's conversation sitting next or around you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I would prefer that the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft not be allowed to happen, unless in the case of an extreme emergency.

I travel a lot for work and pleasure and I can see that flying is stressful for many people.  If you add the additional disruption of people having conversations for hours on end, I am not convinced this will lead to a very safe, condusive environment in the enclosed space we all share on the aircraft.

While roaming costs may prohibit many people from taking advantage of making calls at first, I am sure the providers will overcome this at some later date to make it more affordable to everyone who has a mobile device.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Tom Selman
Comment: Opposed to allowing in-flight calls.  Please do not allow in-flight cell phone use.  The often cramped flight experience will be made much worse when one is surrounded by people talking loudly on their phones.  You are trapped into becoming an audience to their conversation with nowhere to go to get away from it...they could be sitting right beside you.  Privacy from these people you know nothing about is lacking enough on a plane.  Please spare us from unwanted additional noise in the cabin.  I can foresee conflict and fights over this issue and it is not too much for anyone to bear to be separated from their phone for a couple of hours on a flight.  Please do not ruin everybody's flight experience by allowing people to call from the plane on their cell phone.  Thank you

Title: John Seward
Comment:
I would personally like the ban on Voice Calls to be upheld.

It only takes one loud person on their cell phone to disturb another person, multiple that by dozens in an enclosed environment without any option to escape.  It will cause enormous frustration, discomfort, and stress.  Image all the cacophony of all those obnoxious cell phone ring tones alone.

This will also place undo burden upon flight crew in having to maintain order and safety in a noisier, more distracted, and annoyed cabin.

Silent data tranfer such as text, e-mail, and internet services are enough to satisfy any personal or business communication onboard an aircraft outside of an emergency situation.

When travelling I look forward to solace we have at 30,000 ft knowing for at least a few hours we can actually escape not only from our own personal phones but from everyone else's phones as well.

Title: George M.
Comment:
I am totally against allowing phone calls while in flight - at ANY altitude. As a frequent business traveler I would find it quite annoying having to hear multiple passengers phone conversations while either trying to catch up on lost sleep or trying to get work completed. Or worse, just wanting to enjoy a peaceful flight.

I am not against texting while in flight; however, I do believe that the mobile phones should be required to be in either silent mode or vibrate mode in order to reducing the possibility of distracting other passengers.

Title: Eric Pierce
Comment: I am opposed to the expansion of allowable communication via mobile device while onboard an aircraft. As a frequent flier for business purposes (50+ segments annually), I think non-expert fliers (who may be on phone and ignore safety instructions with which expert fliers are well versed) could cause serious problems in the event of an emergency and pose a real safety risk to all passengers. Furthermore, passengers who are on the phone may, in their actions, promote a hostile environment in their immediate environment that would be difficult to resolve mid-air. I think the safety risks involved with this proposal far outweigh the potential benefits. Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Absolutely NOT!!! There are enough annoyances already. I don't want to sit next to someone who is relaying their life story to someone else.

Title: Debra Hansen
Comment:
The use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls should absolutely NOT BE PERMITTED on aircraft. It's a huge potential annoyance to passengers who have paid a lot of money for the privilege of flying. But, perhaps more importantly, I see it as a safety issue. When any flight crew member makes an announcement it's important for all passengers to hear and understand that message. Not only will the passenger who's talking on the phone miss the message but his/her neighboring passengers could miss the message as well. 

Additionally, I can envision a plane on descent nearing the 10,000 foot level, the attendants give the direction to turn off all cellular devises, and having someone refuse to be prompt. Flight crews work hard enough to keep the flying public safe, they don't need any further distractions.

Title: Luke McManamon
Comment:
I am absolutely opposed to Voice Calls on airplanes. First off, it is incredibly rude in a closed and cramped nature of the a airplace. Second, it is not necessary. Now that you allow us to use mobile devices on airplanes texting, instant messaging and chatting via social functions can be engaged in. Please do not turn our flights into an 3-6 hours of being stuck into a sardine can listening to our seatmates private conversations.

I am perfectly ok with using the internet on mobile devices. I strongly encourage you to continue moving to allow this.

Title: Greg Moines
Comment: I was stuck on a bus next to a lady on her cell phone for half an hour and she never stopped talking. Can you imagine being on a plane for 3 or 4 hours next to someone like that?

Title: Su James
Comment: No cell phone use on airplanes!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Absolutely NOT.  It's bad enough to have to deal with people on their cellphones in restaurants and other public places where one can get up and leave.  I can't imagine sitting on a plane and having to listen to someone sitting next to me driveling on endlessly.  Please do not approve cell usage on planes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on flights! People will spend hours and hours loudly talking while crammed in next to other passengers that have no means of moving elsewhere.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow this.  As someone who travels over 160k a year the last thing i want to hear on a plane is someone holding a conference call - or yelling into their phone as some family member on the ground that can't hear them.  Even on a JFK to LAX flight we're only in the air for a short time.  People have been living without cells on the planes since cell phones came out we don't need to talk on them.  Texting and email via wireless is just fine for communicating if they need to.

Title: Heidi Joyner
Comment: I don't think it's fair to expose passengers on airplanes to the conversations of other passengers on the flight.  Especially since there is nowhere to escape.  I believe it could cause rage between passengers and that could lead to having to divert flights because of angry passengers.  That, in turn, would cause disruption to flight schedules.  If people can't wait until they exit the plane to have a conversation, perhaps they shouldn't fly.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Hello,

Even if the FCC allows the use of cellphones on flights I believe it would be everyone's best interests to keep the ban in place. Travelling can already be stressful and having to listen in on others' conversations (with no escape) would only make the situation worse.

Title: Lisa Caretto
Comment: The unintended consequences of mobile wireless service onboard an aircraft are that passengers will not pay attention to safety regulations and announcements during taxi and in flight.  Passenger attention is critical when flight attendants are preparing the cabin for an emergency landing and evacuation.  Phone users will use valuable time making phone calls, instead of paying attention to instructions that will most likely help them survive a crash landing and safely evacuate the aircraft in 90 seconds.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't. It would be fine to allow texting and other quiet use of phones. But there is so little space on planes and so little privacy, allowing everyone to talk on cell phones would be very unpleasant.

Title: Dina S.
Comment: Please do not allow people to start using their mobile phones to make voice calls on aircraft.  As airlines have cut flights to maximize capacity and moved seating closer together, flying has already become less enjoyable.  Having someone yacking on their phone next to you will just make it miserable.  Please limit wireless to email and/or text messaging.  It still allows for business & personal communication while in flight, but minimizes the disturbance to other passengers.  Thank you.

Title: Carin Sweerman
Comment: The public has gotten along just fine without voice calls thus far; there's no need for this. If people were polite and considerate of their fellow travelers, I'd say fine, but we all know there's always going to be those that don't think or don't care that everyone within their parameter can hear their conversation. I vote a big, huge NO on this - I would really dislike being on a plane and having to hear someone else's phone conversation(s). If it were a quick "hey, my plane's late; push back dinner an hour," no problem, but again, you know there are going to be those that will be on their phone the entire flight, spouting stuff no one else cares to hear. Very disruptive.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
If people need to work or stay in touch with friends and family while on a flight, I am fine with them sending text messages or emails. However, I absolutely do not want to be subject to phone conversations in such a small contained area. 

Please do not allow for voice calls on flights. It will only make the air travel experience worse for most fliers.

Title: Lawrence Smith
Comment: I am opposed to the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft after the flight takes off.  I have no problem with voice calls before takeoff, because people often need time to wrap up business.  But after takeoff, everyone should be respectful of others' desire for peace and quiet.  Yes, I can tolerate crying babies, but when they're out of the crying stage, people should have some respect for others.

Title: Michael McCusker
Comment: I am entirely against the use of any device that would allow voice conversations to occur onboard any aircraft at any time. On a plane, unlike in almost any other venue, there is no chance to "escape" the conversation. It is an unfortunate reality that the majority of people today lack basic courtesy, and they will happily prattle on about their mundane lives, oblivious to those around them. In today's modern aviation environment, with oversold flights, record delays and cancellations, smaller seats, fewer amenities, and higher costs for everything from baggage to the tickets themselves, subjecting passengers to others' conversations may be the final straw that causes hostility to erupt on a routine basis on flights. If it is felt that no one should ever go a few hours without being "in touch", then allow email and text conversations to occur. Please ban voice conversations on all flights, from now til the time when Google implants allow us to communicate telepathically.

Title: Linda Jones
Comment: Please please please... no voice calls in the air. Perhaps while during taxi-ing on the ground, but there's nothing that can't wait that long. Preserve the peace and prevent air rage.

Title: Sandra McNew
Comment: Please, please, please do  not allow cell phone use on airplanes in transit. Air travel is bad enough now. Please do not make it less bearable!

Title: James Chimera
Comment: I am 100% opposed to allowing the use of voice cell phone calls on commercial aircraft. People are loud enough when they are cell phones while on the ground, let alone allowing them to be equally as loud in a confined space such an an airplane. Allowing these calls during flights will cause increased aggravation between passengers and incidents of inflight violence.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Why in the world would or should cell phone usage be allowed during flight time on commercial airlines?  Exactly what purpose would this serve other than to cause more problems for flight attendants when a passenger is upset about another passenger talking incessantly or too loudly.  Or the user passenger becoming upset when asked to lower his/her voice or discontinue usage.  Air travel today is bad enough as is without adding one more annoyance to the mix.   The flying public has done just fine without being able to use cell phones on airplanes up until now.  They will continue to do so in the future.  This practice absolutely should not be allowed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Phones on planes is not a new concept. Phones have been on planes for years they just cost a fortune to use which is a big deterrent. I am not opposed to non voice communication but banning texting and wifi (internet) usage is nonsense. We already have internet available on all flights at a premium fee. Travelers should be able to access their own personal internet that they already pay a monthly fortune for instead of paying again just to use the inflight service. I use the internet every time I fly and it never bothers anyone, most people do not even know unless they are sitting next to me and are just interested in what im looking at. Too many government bans already on things not safety related.

Title: Sammy Payne
Comment: The plane ride is one of the few places to escape from endless chatter so would hate to see mobile devices approved for use there!  Even if there are some sort of limits put on their use, people seem to have no sense of common courtesy regarding their use.  Nor will the flight attendants be able to police the activity as the customer is always right!  I vote no!

Title: Trevor Miracle
Comment:
To whom it may concern: 

I am responding to the Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft NPRM. I am currently an Ohio State student majoring in aviation with an interest in the airline industry. It has come to my attention that this NPRM looks to restrict passengers voice calls on wireless cellular devices when the aircraft is in flight due to possible issues of voice calls being unfair or distracting to others on the aircraft; being more specific, during pre-flight safety briefings or night time. This response will cover the responses and effects of public opinion on the restriction of wireless cellular calls in flight.

Summary of response:

Airline surveys of their passengers show that a majority of passengers believe that their flying experience would be negatively affected by allowing calls in flight.

Cell phone voice calls are considered to be ruder than face to face conversations so passengers are negatively affected by listening to the user use their cell phone.

In response to the NPRM question 2:Information on the possible benefits of allowing voice communications on passengers' mobile wireless devices on flights conducted under 14 CFR Part 91 Subpart K (fractional ownership programs), Part 121 (generally scheduled airlines and charter operators of large aircraft), Part 125 (operations with aircraft having 20 or more passenger seats where common carriage is not involved), Part 129 (foreign air carriers), and/or Part 135 (commuter, on demand and air-taxi operations) within, to and from the United States. Are there airlines that would opt to provide this service to passengers, should the opportunity arise? Are there passengers or passenger groups that would like to be allowed to use their mobile devices for voice communications while in flight (e.g., anytime, for important business or personal calls, emergencies)? Whether or not the Department should refrain from issuing a notice of proposed rulemaking on this topic and instead allow the airlines to develop individual policies.

The ban should include all voice calls no matter what mode it is made through. “Since the lift on the wireless devices ban set forth by the FCC there has been an FAA announcement that airlines can safely allow passengers to use all PEDs during all phases of flight.” So the safety aspect on whether or not cellular phones should be allowed has been addressed but passenger satisfaction and opinions hasn’t been. Through a survey done by “Delta Airlines they found that 64 percent of their passengers believe that allowing cellular voice calls on flights would have a negative impact on their onboard experience.” This addresses the fact on whether or not voice calls are an unfair practice and should be restricted or banned. “Southwest Airlines chairman and CEO Gary Kelly stated that Southwest customers don’t want that option if the long-time ban is lifted.” By taking into consideration the results and comments from these two major airlines it’s clear that a majority of flyers don’t want to listen to people using their cellular devices to make voice calls while onboard the aircraft. 

In response to NPRM question 12: Whether permitting in-flight voice calls is more or less disruptive than other current in-flight “disruptions,” such as in-person conversations between passengers If so, why?

Studies done by Jonathan Forma, a Digital Analytics Director, have shown that face to face conversations are considered less rude than cellular voice calls. Through his study he found that people on average talk louder on their cellular devices than when they talk to people face to face. The volume of their voice has been shown to increase with increases in background noise such as other conversations and noises made by the bus he performed his study. The conclusion of his results showed that “The ‘need to listen’ explanation is basically that participants have a desire to hear both sides of the conversation, and the frustration at only being able to hear one side of the conversation produces higher rudeness ratings for the groups where only one side of the conversation is heard.” This experiment found that people were generally more annoyed with people talking on cell phones than people having a conversation between each other face to face because the other passengers couldn’t hear both parts of the conversation with the cell phone user.

Title: David Kuch
Comment:
No one on a plane should be tortured by the incessant chatter of fellow passengers gabbing through several hours of business or social discussion. It's enough to be cooped up in close quarters for several hours without having to endure other people's business dealings or inanities.

 Those who would have it otherwise should be sentenced to sitting themselves unoccupied while  incessant cell phone talkers babble in their ears until they get it.

 There are e-mails and texting for those who simply must be in touch endlessly.

Comment: See attached file(s)

Comment: Please, please, please do not allow voice calls on aircraft.  I can see that this would cause as much irritation as screaming children do.  I like to read during a flight, and it's impossible to concentrate with someone sitting nearby having a phone conversation.  Many times the person on the phone talks very loudly.  People who have been on long flights like to sleep, and phone conversations will interrupt that.  I will refuse to fly on an airline that allows in-flight phone calls.

Title: Joe Gerardin
Comment: I appreciate now being able to use my devices on the airplane but please do not allow cell phone usage while onboard an airplane, at any time. Most people are too inconsiderate of others to be allowed use their phones seated so close to others.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002 

Thank you for providing this forum to express an opinion regarding cell phone usage aboard operating, in-flight aircraft.

My opinion is a resounding no to the use of cell phones aboard in-flight aircraft.  It is common experience that most people generally speak louder than normal while using cellular phones in public areas in order to deal with the perception that they must speak loudly to overcome background noise.  As you may be aware, the background noise level of an operating, in-flight aircraft is quite high.  Such noise levels are created by, among other things, loud engines, wind and passenger conversations.  Since, during normal public area cell phone operations, people speak quite loudly, it is my opinion that they will tend to speak extremely loud during in-flight operations which will be a considerable annoyance to travelers in the close confines of an aircraft cabin, such as myself, who routinely fly for business.  

I have resolved that, should cellphone usage be permitted aboard in-flight aircraft, I will not patronize airlines that allow such usage.

Title: Neal Cleland, Jr.
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone use on commercial aircraft. Not on domestic flights and international flights. No way, shape or form.

Title: Margit Cleland
Comment: Please do not allow wireless devices for calls on airplanes.  Flying is stressful enough as it is (cramped, overbooked planes) with frequent reports of some distraught travelers being apprehended.  Imagine what would happen if travelers were subjected to relentless conversations of strangers for many hours.

Title: Lauren Dobell
Comment:
PLEASE, NO CELL PHONE USE ON AIRCRAFT.

DO NOT ALLOW THE USE OF CELL PHONES ON AIRCRAFT.

Title: Ste Lightfoot
Comment:
Given the close confines and lack of personal mobility on commercial aircraft, I do not believe it is in the interest of the flying public to allow expanded usage of portable/personal voice communication devices. Expanded usage would lead to a deterioration of the temporary flight commons. Increased  overall cabin volume levels and potential for conflict between passengers are at least two of the predicted/potential negative effects. Another potential problem is that flight personnel will surely be called upon to solve/resolve potential conflicts thus diverting them from their other duties. I agree with the statements contained in the filing noted below completely.

"The Association of Flight Attendants filed a comment and replied that voice over internet or cellular broadband should be banned to reduce in-flight disruptions, noting that most flight attendants and travelers find objectionable the possibility of numerous simultaneous voice calls."

"Delta Air Lines also filed a comment stating that 64 percent of its passengers indicated that the ability to make phone calls in flight would have a negative impact on the on board experience."

Title: Ben S.
Comment: No no no, I like many others agree that inflight cell phone use should be banned. We are humans and we sometimes forget what respect means. To all those who want to call a loved one to pick them up, do it when you land.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Ridiculous !  Too many people using cell phones  do not respect other's space, they are "it's all about me" and use profanity without thinking.  Flying is stressful enough, you want to take your mind off the stress, not add to it!

Title: John Deubert
Comment:
This is such a bad idea. Having 300 people in a cramped, enclosed space for hours on end with, say, 10% of them at any given time talking (loudly) into their phones would make flights unendurably noisy. It's important, when you are forced to be cheek by jowl and shoulder to shoulder with a horde of strangers, to be able to maintain a sense of privacy; allowing cellphone use would destroy this entirely. You would be always in the presence of at least one person shouting to make himself or herself heard above engine noise and the surrounding crowd. And these conversations would probably be long ones; the caller has nothing very much else to do, after all.

One of the least-liked "types" of fellow passengers is the loud talker, whose conversation intrudes on the thoughts and quiet conversations of everyone within 3 rows and seats. Allowing cellphone use on flights would institutionalize this intrusion and to no real benefit. Cellphone use would provide entertainment and distraction from boredom, not usually anything critical to anyone's well-being. 

The effect this rule would have on the mood of the planeload of people would be significant and negative. Think of yourself in this situation: you are sitting next to someone talking, laughing, discussing family matters, all at a volume that can't be ignored. What do you do? You can ask them to talk more softly, but they can't, since the engine noise requires you speak up so you can be heard at all. You can ask them to hang up because they're talking too loud and you can't hear yourself think; they'll refuse, since they're having a perfectly good time. Later you'll *tell* them to hang up; they'll refuse, probably rudely. So you tell the flight attendant, who has no legal basis for telling them to hang up, and must therefore appeal to reason and fair play--never a winning strategy. So there you are, sitting next to an ongoing noise source (or two or three) that will not shut up and cannot be compelled to do so. Imagine the frustration. You would certainly be wondering what you have in your possession that you could use to force them to quiet down; what do have that you could use as a cudgel?

Now multiply by 300. 

Managing the mood of a planeful of people is an important component to running a flight. Allowing cellphone use on a flight will make this increasingly difficult. In any group of 300 individuals, there are a couple who don't handle frustration well; this rule sets up a situation where those individuals are tested more than any of us would like.

Finally, this would do the airlines no particular good. They would feel obliged to install the cell equipment on their planes and then would have to bear the consequent decrease in nearly everyone's desire to fly. They would end up spending money to make people like them less.

This rule would do a lot of real damage to the already marginal flying experience and would add nothing of real value. I urge the DOT to not adopt this rule.

Title: Roger Pyle
Comment:
I would have to emphatically state my opposition to the use of any cellular telephone device while on board any aircraft while it is in-flight. Cell phones should only be used while they are in the airplane mode and only while using headphones or ear buds so others would not be disturbed while the devices are being used for gaming or for dictation.

If someone needs to speak with others, instead of voice communication, the use of E-mail or text messaging can be used.  There is already enough noise and confusion in an enclosed and sealed tube and I could very easily see people becoming aggressive to the point that someone could be injured in altercations which will occur as a result of using cell phones .

Title: Alicde Rice
Comment: We are so "plugged in" with all mobile devices that we challenge our ability to communicate effectively.  This is also an era of the need for privacy.  Personally, I cannot imagine having a phone call on an airplane where anyone could listen.  I strongly encourage that regulations DO NOT ALLOW voice calls on airplanes.

Title: Dr. Jonathan S. Shapiro
Comment: See Attachment

Title: Richard Wuerth
Comment: The notion of letting people use cell phones on airline flights is completely insane.  You are in a closed space, captive with whomever they seat you next to and people talk too loud, and are inconsiderate of those around them. There will be violence, fights and confrontations. There are already many electric devices you can use and that should be enough. What if you want to sleep?  What if you want to read?  There is already too much noise in the world and noise is an imposition on sanity. We are living in very noisy times and long flights are places that can still be fairly peaceful.  JUST SAY NO TO THIS STUPID INSANE IDEA OF CELL PHONES ON PLANES!

Title: Christopher Berger
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phones for voice calls. I am a 25 year Flight Attendant for a major U.S. carrier. Cell conversations will not only be a nuisance but is guaranteed to lead to various levels of confrontation on our nation's aircraft.  Conflicts on board airplanes in flight are on the rise. Some lead to flights being diverted to unintended destinations costing airlines a small fortune and inconveniencing passengers. We now allow use of electronics during critical phases of flight; enough damage has been done by relaxing FAR's. We don't need to make it any worse. Thank you for considering my comments.

Title: Ken
Comment:
No, no, no, a thousand times no. 

No.

Title: Irma Serrano
Comment: Not only does it pose a risk factor for passengers but it's also a nuisance for those passengers who rather sleep the flight through.   There are many nervous passengers on board and chatty passengers only complicate the manner.  Please keep the ban on cell phone usage on planes! There's always texting which is quiet.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that this is plausible, but only if certain changes are made to the airplane's structure and policy.  Listening to a stranger talk on the phone is usually not a pleasant experience for most people, but at the same time there may be times when certain people will expect very important phone calls delivering urgent messages.  So I propose a compromise.  Let's create an isolated area on the airplane where phone calls are allowed, away from all other passengers and hopefully soundproofed to a certain degree.  There is no need for heavy modification, for many airplanes already have curtains and such to cut off areas of the airplane, so let's just designate a few of those areas as "phone" areas.  This way if someone absolutely needs to use a cellphone, they get to, yet at the same time the passengers looking for a couple hours relaxation away from the real world flying 30,000 feet high can still get to just relax and enjoy the ride.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a business traveler flying more than 140 segments per year, I personally cherish my quiet time and unfortunately as I try to rest on the "lovely commuter jet network the airlines affiliate with" I am subject to all sorts of chatter and cannot rest nor focus on my work, so I am not rested when I get to the hotel and much work to do. 

I cannot imagine sitting in a cabin with these same inconsiderate individuals (for the most part) and have to listen to their cell phone chatter. I would not object to text or email messages as these are silent except for the ping of the phone and if mandatory instruction to turn ringer off when door closes then I would agree. Please, we already have a culture so obsessed with their cell phones that as an emergency and trauma physician staffing Emergency Dept's around the country, I see too many cell phone and texting accidents. 

Airline frequent flyers and business travelers don't need this disturbance or distraction and we would be satisfied with email or text if we chose to use it. 

Want to offer phone service - make them pay and maybe they won't use it when they know they are roaming at an exorbitant rate. However, I will be the first to tell them - hang up or stop talking as my company just paid over a $1000 for the same seat you paid $300 for and I am trying to get some work done like "important medical charts and records." Does it matter what I am doing, I just don't want to listen to their chatter and welcome any opportunity to upgrade myself to FC, but then again, I am at the mercy of the jiffy jets. 

So NO to cell phone service at this time unless the airlines want to turn the jiffy jets into two cabins, cell phone talkers and the business folks who are busy working. At best, I pray for a "jiffy jet" with WiFi so I can work and most times - not happening. 

Thank you for allowing me to respond. 

R. B. Garelick, BSN, MD FACEP

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please no. I currently do regular train journeys that allow voice calls. It is extremely annoying because you can't help but hear the conversations of others...  even up to 10 or more rows away. 
( and my trip is only an hour long... I can't imagine having to endure it for any longer)  
If someone wanted to try to get a nap ( as many travellers do ), there would be little chance on an aircraft.

Allowing voice calls would open a whole litany of issues on flights which would lead to unnecessary arguments and distractions for the flight crews and other passengers.
No doubt, some carriers will try a to use 'quiet section' & likely try to charge extra for it.
I don't agree with this idea either, as it is a personal right not to be bothered,.. not an opportunity to cash in on something that should be standard in the first place.

As most people seem to agree, silent messaging is bearable and would be understandably convenient for quite a few passengers with minimal invasion of others' space. People have become dependant on being in touch and a tweak of the rules would go a long way into bringing travel in line with modern personal communication patterns.

Title: Daniel
Comment:
I am 110% against the use of cell phones on aircraft for voice communications.

In the close quarters onboard an aircraft at 34,000 feet, with the person sitting next to me or right behind me talking for 90 minutes to their best friend about how she hates Mary Sue Billings, is no different than subjecting me to "water-boarding."

I can't run, I can't move, I can't escape......I'm imprisoned in my seat for another 3 1/2 hours being forced to listen to the mindless prattle going on around me.  I can only conclude that inflight violence will escalate.  How could one conclude differently?

If my fellow passenger wants to rattle on about how she hates Mary Sue Billings, then she can use her cell phone to text her BFF.  (Please have the ring tone for an incoming text put in the vibrate mode.)  I am not opposed to inflight texting.  I am very much opposed to voice communication on a cell phone while the aircraft is moving.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Nowadays, cell phones and wireless communications are using microwaves radio frequencies.

Those are well known for several decades for being harmful to the Living, as many independent studies show, including the one mandated by W.H.O back in 1973: Biologic Effects and Health Hazards of Microwave Radiation (WHO International Symposium Research Agreement No. 05-609-04 - 1974). The human systems are affected by microwaves as for example neuronal, vascular, heart, thyroid, thrombocyte, eyes, sleep disorders, behavior issues, diabetes, DNA damaging, cell membrane damaged, and radiation exposure is cumulative too.

Furthermore, the increasing number of persons who are electro-hypersensitive (EHS) would no longer be able to travel by plane. All together the chatter which would be produced and the additional hazard of aggressive behavior which might be produced by microwaves radiation within an enclosed Faraday cage might greatly increase airplanes incidents and accidents.

It would be much better and safer to keep the ban of wireless on airliners until new technologies like Li-Fi (light fidelity) are widely available within the next few years.

Thanks for considering these comments.

Title: Michael Baker
Comment:
I am 65 years old and have flown almost 3 million miles in my career which has not ended yet.  I have noticed in the past 10 years or so that people on their cell phone while waiting in the airport to board a flight have become much more distracting.  They tend to talk on their phone as if the person on the other end is not able to hear them.  That means that I am part of their private conversation whether I like it or not.  At least in the airport or even a restaurant, I always have the option to move if I am bothered by their talking.  In an airplane, I am stuck in the seat assigned for 30 minutes before departure until arrival at the destination.  DC to LA can easily be a 6+ hour trip including the time after boarding but before departure.
  
Although I know I can control my urges, I do believe that there will eventually be flare-ups between passengers who cannot control their urges.  If an obnoxious person is talking and their seatmate does not ask them nicely to please quiet down, things may get out of control very quickly.  Airline travel is already stressful enough.  Adding an annoying person close by who is talking until their battery dies is not something that I think I should have to endure, especially when I may have paid upwards of $500 for my ticket.  I and other passengers should have some consideration for their right to have a quiet flight since they paid for it.  Screaming kids is more like an act of God and cannot always be controlled.  But no passenger should have to right to knowing inflict noise pollution on fellow passengers.

Airlines are already installing Wi-Fi which could allow flyers to use email while in-flight.  There is nothing so important that a person cannot wait until they arrive at their destination to make a cell call.  I also believe that business travelers in particular will want to talk at length if calling is allowed.  They should be able to maintain all necessary contact via email while in flight.  When I was a senior officer in the USAF, I had a Blackberry.  I found myself responding to emails immediately even though the content of the email did not require my immediate response.  I found myself sometimes making a call in response instead of an email.  I fear that business travelers may also have a habit on the ground that they carry into the airplane in an environment that is not appropriate for their responses.

Please do not allow cell phone calls while in-flight as it is not fair to all the travelers who are NOT talking on a phone.  Almost every airline has phones on the plane for use.  Sure, they cost a lot to use, but they are there if someone has an emergency that they must respond to immediately.  Their rights would not be abridged as they would have an alternative way to make contact rather than use their cell phone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do NOT allow voice calls on passenger aircraft.  People are much too confined - with no opportunity to flee the noise generated by multiple phone conversations - as we know these are louder on cellphones than face-to-face conversations. The concern is the cumulative impact of allowing in-flight calls in close quarters and the potential for unsafe, angry confrontations between passengers. There is also the concern of passengers who will be angry over not being able to control their environment from noise and unwanted loud conversations for hours on end.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm not going to pay hundreds of dollars to listen to someone chat for hours. It's a violation of personal space.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the idea of allowing use of cell phones for conversations on planes during flights.  I believe the lack of courtesy demonstrated by passengers while on the ground is a likely indication of what to expect if calls are allowed throughout the flight.  Being confined on a flight in such close proximity to people speaking loudly and with no respect for the rest of the passengers would be a terrible experience.  Access to email, and potentially text messaging should be sufficient communication options that are much less intrusive on fellow passengers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002

In regards to cellphone use on aircraft,  please don't allow!  People have a tendency to talk louder when on a cellphone so the thought of cell phone use on aircraft sounds like a very bad idea!

Title: Diana Maurer
Comment: Please don't allow phone conversation in flight because of the inability of other passengers to leave the immediate area if the caller is loud or otherwise inconsiderate.  The ability to send texting would be appropriate.  Some of my older family members are unfamiliar with texting and I would be unable to contact them during flight if only texting would be allowed, but I am comfortable if the arrangement of texting/no calling were implemented.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No phone calls on airplanes!  There's no privacy & no one wants to hear other people's phone conversations. Please, no phone calls on planes in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phones on the airplanes. There are plenty other forms of technology available to use that they could potentially use that are SILENT and would not disrupt other people on the plane. I don't believe it should be allowed anywhere on the plane--and it should not be an "optional fee" that airlines can use to charge more for a "cell phone free seating" or other bogus charges. There is plenty of time to take care of business before and after the plane ride. I want to be able to sit back, relax, and enjoy the flight... not be disrupted by cell phones ringing or incessant chatter by fellow passengers on their cell phones.

Title: Joyce S.
Comment: Please DO NOT allow widespread cellular calls on commercial aircraft. Peace and quiet are the last true positive attributes of air travel. Comfort is gone, snacks are gone, but we can still relax and read/watch/work in relative silence. Don't take that away. Tempers will flare, and travelers will begin to loathe their time in the sky.

Title: Roger Halverson
Comment:
With the ease of texting and email there is really no need to use a cell phone and unnecessary conversation interrupting others in close proximity. I personally like my conversations to be private.
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a frequent flier for business I am not interested in hearing the people around me chatter on their phones.  It is a good time to think, get some work done and even a snooze!  People are constantly on their phones...give us some peace and quiet while on a plane!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am highly opposed to cell phone use on aircrafts.  In flight travel is already an uncomfortable experience.  Adding the ability to use a cell phone will make air travel worse.  I believe that use of cell phones on aircraft will lead to (more) altercations between passengers and between passengers and aircraft personnel.

Title: Paulette Buck
Comment:
I travel quite often and would seriously curtail my traveling if airlines allow cell phone usage. There are some seriously rude, obnoxious people in our world and having to deal with their loud conversations in a trapped environment could lead to angry, passengers, violent confrontations and  disrupted flights. I feel angry and tense just thinking about it! 

Before any decisions are made on this ridiculous idea, have those in favor of it be forced to fly to New Zealand or some other long distant flight  and be surrounded by cellphone users. This experiment needs to happen more than once. Make sure that these decision makers are very tired, let's add a screaming baby or two and of course all participants must be sitting in economy class, no first class for this group. 

 Of course it is all about the all mighty dollar. For once, can common sense prevail?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Do not allow phone calls during flight. Extremely invasive

Title: Robert Freeman
Comment: PLEASE do not allow phone conversations on planes!!

Title: NJ Moga
Comment: No! Please don't let the people that talk loudly to ruin the last quiet place in travel.  Its bad enough they can talk till the door is closed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I would be in favor of allowing text messages on flights, but cell phones calls should be prohibited.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: ABSOLUTELY NOT!!!  I am a frequent flyer, and I can't imagine the magnitude of potential issues that will come with such a ruling.  Please NO, NO, NO, and 1 Million times NO!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I oppose the use of cell phones and similar communication devices on airplanes. Passengers deserve a quiet atmosphere without endless phone calls taking place.

Title: Jay Johnson
Comment: In-flight calls should not be allowed due to safety issues. People need to pay attention while instructions are given. As well there will be an increase of disputes involving passengers irritated with their chatty neighbor.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I urge you to NOT allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. 

I'm sure each and every one of you has been in a restaurant where the person in the next booth is engaged in a conversation over the phone. Often the person is speaking loudly and I'm sure you found it annoying. 

Imagine this occurring in an airplane where other passengers have nowhere to go in order to escape this annoyance. Aside from the discomfort to other passengers, undoubtedly tempers will flare and lead to confrontations. It would be unavoidable.

Again, I urge you to NOT allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.

Thank you.

Title: Tammi Steyn
Comment: Please do not allow unrestricted voice communication use with cell phone on flights.  Air travel is already stressful enough, with an increasing number of impositions including the close proximity of strangers who often do not include common courtesy in their set of skills.  These impositions create severe headaches, lack of adequate sleep, and other mental and physical problems.  Adding voice calling ability to already congested and difficult flights will just make a miserable situation even more so.  In addition, I see potential safety issues - currently callers already have a hard time hanging up when the cabin door closes.  If there is an in-air emergency, will they hang up or continue their conversation instead of listening to directions?

Title: Paul Collins

Title: Kenneth Waldmann

Title: Kristen S.
