Plus people are absolutely boorish and think their conversations are *so* important when they're just obnoxious. Oh please, no.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't start letting people talk on the phone on planes! It would be horrendous to be stuck listening to half of a conversation for hours on end.

Title: Ethan Jones
Comment:
I argue strongly against this proposal.  An airplane is one of the few places left in the world that is a semi-public space free of the incessant yammering of cellphone calls.  The grueling process of actually going through TSA security and being herded onto the tiny, cramped airplane would be made even more unpleasant by the addition of cute ringtones and loud conversations about things best left in private.  

Beyond the annoyance factor, however, there's a safety issue to keep in mind.  Allowing electronic devices during takeoff and landing is dangerous enough - not because the devices themselves interfere with flight systems, but because distracted passengers might not be aware of a developing emergency, which is more likely to occur during takeoff and landing than it is in-flight.  Adding actual cell phone calls into the mix, and allowing them throughout the flight, further distracts passengers and makes it less likely that everyone can react quickly, calmly, and correctly if and when an emergency occurs.  

Instead of pondering the addition of cellphones to flights, why not think about regulating legroom, seat comfort, things like that?

Title: Dick Bednar

This is not a decision for the airlines.  They make passengers miserable enough now...we don't need to encourage them to make us more miserable by sitting it teeny seats, paying for lousy food, and having to listen to a cell phone conversation from an adjoining seat.

Imagine if you will the repercussions involving a similar conversation, as described above, in an aircraft when one objects to s person sitting in the next seat at a distance of 18-24 inches. Title: Matt
Comment:
Dear DOT,

Allowing in-flight voice calls would make air travel--already an increasingly unpleasant experience--intolerable.  

To choose one out of the barrel of good reasons why this would be a bad idea, note for instance the difficult position that this policy would put the flight crew.  Already now their challenge is to keep people calm and comfortable even as while trapped in a small space with a large numbers of strangers.  In-flight voice calls and the attendant disagreements that come with them--you're talking too loudly, you're talking in a way that offends me, you're talking when I trying to work/read/sleep/watch TV, etc.--would result in a lot more in-flight disagreements and fights that the flight crew would have to respond to.  

Please do not amend or abandon the existing policy of not allowing in-flight voice calls.  If someone absolutely must communicate during a flight, let them text.

Best wishes,
Matt

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I vote NO to cellphone calls on aircrafts!  Allowing civilians to make cellphone calls while on an aircraft that is "in-flight" poses several dangers to EVERYONE on the flight, including the passenger making the call! 1) Some people will NOT be considerate of other passengers and may have very loud, boisterous conversations lasting an interminable length of time while placing others completely at their mercy and disrupting other passengers' quietude/sleep! 2)There is NO way to KNOW for certain - unless NUMEROUS tests are conducted in advance - as to EXACTLY how many cellphone calls can be made "in-flight" simultaneously without endangering the flight itself! Furthermore, how would aircraft personnel REGULATE WHO can/cannot make a call at a specific time? 3) While some passengers may NOT make "in-flight" calls, their safety will AUTOMATICALLY be AT THE MERCY of someone making an "in-flight" call which is grossly unfair! 4) If the aircraft is endangered due to an in-flight cellphone call or calls (as soon as one passenger makes a call, other passengers will suddenly realize they NEED to make an "in-flight" call) and there is collateral damage, exactly WHO will be to blame? WHO should be SUED?  The passenger(s) who made the call(s)?  The Airline?  or The FAA? 

"In-flight" cellphone calls will most likely pose significantly greater danger to the flying public than a quick "I'm on the plane and should arrive at the airport around 9:15p.m.so see you then." should be worth!

Please, please, PLEASE do NOT allow "in-flight" cellphone calls!  Ity is too dangerous! Thank you!

Given one passenger is able to annoy everyone within a 10 foot radius (~20 or so people), and the penchant for already annoyed airgoers, this seems a recipe for conflict.  The flight attendants already have enough to do, but hoping one person on a phone does not annoy any of the 20 distracted people seems to be asking a lot.

I certainly would travel whichever airline enforced a cell phone conversation ban.

Title: Waldemar Cordero

When it comes to flying there are many things that are uncomfortable, yet necessary. We know that there are not many technical impediments to operate wireless communication gear on board an airplane with only some exceptions. After the events of 911 and all that the US has gone thru, the lost of lives in CONUS and those lost overseas we have to stop for a minute an analyze the actual implications of having unrestricted communication channels on board airplanes. What a great commodity? What an awesome way of spending your flight shooting debris, or maybe conducting business or perhaps coordinating an act of terrorism? Maybe a good idea would be to relax all TSA check points and only do irregular scanning of passengers and baggage. Have we as country lost perspective of the threats that still exist and have we lost respect for all those who fought and keep fighting to keep us safe? Have we gotten so fat and lazy that the need to use a cell phone overrides the preservation of life. If we provide the opportunity bad things will happen as evidenced by past events.
Now, the prohibition could be lifted only if all passengers agree to complete and I mean 100 percent surveillance and recording of all phone calls with real time analysis of the data so that the same discipline that is required from passengers in the cabin apply to the phone lines. There is no way that communications going out and coming into a commercial flight would not be monitored to every nibble of data being passed.Establish a comprehensive monitoring and action plan, fail proof and there should be no issues with lifting the ban. Lifting a ban without safety features will set the scenario for more disasters.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
February 23, 2014
To Whom It May Concern:
This is a response to the Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft NPRM. I believe adopting a rule to ban voice communications on passengers’ mobile wireless devices on flights within, to and from the United States is the wisest course of action given the current state of the industry. The aviation industry, being as complex as it is, is not known for adopting new rules or regulations in a quick manner. However, there is good reason behind this. The country as a whole is very dependent on the safe and efficient operation of the industry, so changes that may affect the industry’s ability to transport over two million passengers per day in this manner must be closely studied and analyzed (www.rita.dot.gov). Having just passed new rules on the use of portable electronic devices (PEDs) on aircraft in late October of last year, I believe it is much too soon to attempt to allow inflight calls on mobile wireless devices. 
	Summary of Response Main Points
•	Insufficient time given to asses impact of recently relaxed PED regulations
•	Passenger discomfort/safety impacts
•	Inadequate proof that concentrated use of mobile phones for voice communications in commercial aircraft will not result in potentially dangerous interference
A very recent regulation was passed which allowed airlines to safely expand passenger use of PEDs during all phases of flight (www.faa.gov). This was a great victory for many, as it greatly increased passenger comfort and entertainment during flights. The testing that took place to analyze wireless devices’ effects on aircraft took several years as it needed to be proven that their use would not impact the functionality of cockpit systems and radios. With that being said, I feel as though it is unwise to suggest adding voice communications into this technological mix without first analyzing the status air travel after the expansion of PED’s. Having just implemented the new PED regulation in October of last year, not nearly enough time has passed to truly understand its impact, let alone begin adding more capabilities to the devices. In order to even consider adding voice communications, ample time must be given to be sure that the expanded use of PEDs continues without issue. Four months is hardly enough time to say for certain that their impact is negligible, and without evidence that the aviation system will continue to run smoothly, thought should not be given to further expanding PED capabilities. 
The use of mobile devices for voice communications also has a tremendous impact on passenger experience. A recent poll distributed by Associated Press-GfK showed that 48% of people were opposed to the use of cell phones for voice communication, while only 19% were in favor. This poll, as well as many others which yielded similar results, show that a majority of passengers are still against the use of mobile phones for voice communications. Flight attendants feel the same way; A recent quote by Corey Caldwell, a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants, argued that “Allowing passengers to use cellphones during commercial flights will add unacceptable risks to aviation security, compromise a flight attendant’s ability to maintain order in an emergency, increase cabin noise and tension among passengers…” (www.huffingtonpost.com). She expresses a valid argument as she describes the safety risks that would be associated with in-flight mobile device calls, ranging from an increased workload for flight attendants to passenger confrontations. The potential problems far outweigh the benefits this service would provide, especially when one considers that fact that communication is no longer completely dependent on voice. Passengers can now use Facebook, Twitter, access emails, and the like, so adding yet another form of communication which brings along a slew of issues does not benefit anyone traveling commercially, whether it be passengers or crew. 
My final point in favor of a rule that bans voice communication on passengers’ mobile devices stems from the lack of conclusive research regarding the effect of mobile devices on aircraft systems when emitting a signal (not in “airplane mode”). While evidence showed that relaxing the rules on PEDs would not negatively affect these systems, no such definitive research exists for situations when mobile phone signals are being sent to and from ground stations. As reported in a CNN article, the risk of interference is low, but the consequences are high. During critical phases of flight, even small deviations of cockpit instruments due to interference can result in higher workload, higher stress situations for pilots. In fact, there were 75 instances of suspected electronic interference, including 29 related to mobile phones, reported by pilots between 2003 and 2009 (www.cnn.com). These interferences affected almost every aircraft system, revealing that interference cannot be predicted.

Title: Sherri Taylor
Comment: That would make travel horrible! Everyone has learned how to email. And we are watching movies or sleeping so now we have to wear plugs? If certain airlines prohibit it I would choose them first.

Title: Marie Z.
Comment:
Talking on cell phones absolutely should not be allowed on planes.  If communication is so important to someone, they can send an email or text; they do not need to disturb everyone around them by talking on their phone.  People already talk louder when they talk on cell phones.  Additionally, airlines do not allow people to blast music or movies into the plane (instead they expect passengers to use headphones).  This is a clear recognition that unnecessary noise is aggravating to other passengers, and passengers talking on cell phones would be just as aggravating.

Cell phone use already creates a good deal of hostility between people in public places where people are not packed in together like sardines.  The airlines are already doing everything they can to create conflict between people (by packing seats closer together front to back, but not preventing seats from reclining (which especially is a problem as they pack seats closer together front to back), and by making seats narrower (so they can pack more seats in from side to side).  This means that someone talking on a cell phone is going to have his/her babbling mouth about 8 inches (or perhaps less)  from a total stranger.  What government regulators should be looking into is restricting airlines from packing people too closely in planes.  Airlines clearly are not capable of regulating themselves, because they have already demonstrated they have little common sense about human beings.

Title: Cindy Rohde
Comment: I am begging you, BEGGING!, please do not allow passengers to place or receive cell phone calls during the flight.  This would be such an invasion of the modicum of peace and privacy that currently exists.  We are trapped in a small space during a flight with no opportunity to remove ourselves from any annoying situation such as a loud talker going on and on during a cell phone call.  It would be an entirely different question if we were taking about a location where people could move away from the annoying caller but this is not possible on an airplane.  If calls during flight are allowed it is entirely predictable that this will increase the number of disputes between passengers as they have disagreements over thoughtless people talking too loud or too long.  It is not fair to the flight attendants to put them in the position of being referees over cell phone fights.  They really have enough to do already completing their assigned tasks, managing the usual requests and complaints and managing the drunks on board without adding this to their list.  Think about a long flight where a business person is making business calls, droning on and on during the entire flight.  Or an overnight flight to Europe were it is 4 am for you and you are supposed to be trying to sleep but the business person thinks Well, it's 9 am where I'm headed so let's start making calls!  While I'm trying to sleep right next door to them!  Please do not subject us to this!  Thank you.

Title: Kristen O'Brien
Comment: Pls. No calling on the plane. It's loud enough. Texting ok.

Title: George
Comment:
Under no circumstances, should cell phone voice calls be sent or received while a passenger or flight attendant is on an airborne flight.  Good judgment and common sense should be the rule.  It seems asinine and ludicrous that this is even being discussed.  The FCC says that calls no longer impact flight instruments.  However, non-interference of instruments and allowing calls to be made is "apples and oranges",  The pacman who appears on the screen at movie theatres and tells the audience to turn off all sound devices should perhaps visit those who are even considering allowing phone calls on planes.  Texting would be harmless and would be a compromise to those who think they should be able to talk on a phone while their seatmate is fast asleep or reading a good novel.  Amen

George
Minneapolis, MN

Title: Deborah Levision
Comment:
Please do not allow passengers to make phone calls.  While quiet texting does not disturb one's neighbors - and neighbors are VERY near in most seats - speaking on a phone is certainly going to be audible, especially as voices raise to be heard over airplane noise. There are various issues here:

(1) Courtesy:  basic politeness dictates that one not make private phone call in a stranger's hearing.  Subjecting strangers to one's conversation - when they cannot escape - is especially rude.  And yet we all know that many people will be rude, if phone calls are allowed on airplanes.

This is related to (2) Externalities.  In economic jargon, right now passengers have the right not to be subjected to others' phone calls.  Why change that?  

Shifting the rights to those who don't mind disturbing others may (3) lead to increased conflicts and violence in very small spaces. 

Surely courtesy and safety should be our priorities.

Title: Mark
Comment: Definitely not. Most people would abuse the ability to make calls on planes. The biggest fear is a prolonged call by a obnoxious passenger who does not adhere to any established guideline could ruin the trip for everyone else. The fellow passengers couldn't read, concentrate on their work, sleep or watch a movie or listen to music in the comfort of their own seat. This is similar to sitting next to someone who is smoking; like second smoke, this is second hand noise that you would have to put up with without any control.

Title: Robert Horwitz
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phone calls on flights. The airlines want all the passengers and revenue they can in this competitive industry, and if it's approved they will be too fearful of losing passengers and revenue to be the force of discipline to say "no".  It will get out of hand before any of them develop the sense that " we shouldn't have started this". 

 Imagine multiple phone calls going on around you when you are trying to relax and sleep on a return flight from a long day, or when you have an early morning flight and need to prepare for a big meeting. 

Please, please keep phone calls out of the sky and peace and quiet on the airplanes.

Title: Mark
Comment: Definitely not. No win situation for passengers who want the peace and quiet to sleep, read, listen to their iPod or movie. Too much second hand noise would drive everyone crazy who is not interested in hearing others conversations. Do not budge. Vote this proposal down!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002-0018

Do not allow cellphone voice calls on airplane flights. This has become our last bastion of peace and quiet. Even an upset baby settles down, but a plateful if passengers will never be still and quiet. The ability to relax, read, sleep, and/or prepare necessary work for business and school will be totally interrupted. A true emergency will always be addressed. So called ersonal issues can wait a few hours or be dealt with via wi-fi.

Title: Michelle M.
Comment: No! Air travel is cramped, awkward, and uncomfortable enough as it is without introducing hundreds of one-sided conversational noise, inescapabale eavesdropping, and unsolicited instances of TMI (too much information) to the mix.

Title: Chester Jacobsen
Comment: Cellular voice calls on aircraft should continue to be banned while the aircraft is in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to allowing cell phone use in flight.  With the increasingly tight accommodations on planes, it is an additional intrusion on a person's privacy, personal space and comfort.  I feel this is also a safety issue where confrontations between passengers could likely occur over the use of cell phones.

Title: Keith K.
Comment:
I spent 10 hours on planes yesterday. The flying experience is hectic, cramped, and lacks any sort of allowance for personal space. The majority of fliers are inconsiderate, self-centered and just plain rude.

Adding the ability for each of the passengers to make voice calls would make traveling by plane unbearable. Being forced to occupy a cramped space with several hundred people yelling into their phones is the worst idea I can imagine.

People have plenty of options to communicate in ways that do not intrude on others. Please do not allow voice calls.

Title: C. Oaks
Comment:
I 100% OPPOSE the use of cellphones during flights. 
The additional tension and potential conflicts is immense.
There is no way to leave, avoid or escape the noise pollution it will create when in the air .
The flight attendants needs the attention of all passengers when they are providing safety instructions .

Title: Edgar Heston
Comment: Please continue the ban on use of cellphones on aircraft in flight.  Allowing such use will be disruptive to other passengers and could well cause numerous altercations of objectionable uses of cellphones.  Aircraft noise levels result in louder than normal speech which will be objectionable to others..

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please--NO CELL PHONES in the air!!!!  It sounds like unimaginable torture to be sitting for a 3 or 4 (or longer) flight while everyone sitting in front, behind, and on either side is talking (loudly, like people do on cell phones) non-stop.  This is not necessary, and would make flying in close quarters so much more difficult!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Voting to allow cell phone use in the air will create a nightmare for travelers. Vote no.

Title: Barbara
Comment: Please, please do not allow. Just sit in a boarding area before plane departure and listen to those people yell into their phones.

Title: Don
Comment: NO! We are already subjected to endless, inane, one-sided conversations in almost every other public situation. The flight is one of the last places where we can think. keep the phones calls off the airplanes!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm very supportive of allowing texting, emails, etc but no voice calls please.  We all don't need to listen to everyone else's conversations.  Thanks!

Title: Rick Caldwell
Comment: I am totally, 100% against allowing voice calls on domestic flights. I have elite status in my airline's frequent flier program, and fly on business at least twice a month. I enjoy the relative quiet and peacefulness on a flight, allowing for either relaxation or paperwork without major distraction. Allowing voice calls would be like being locked in a phone booth with at least a dozen loud-mouths: pandemonium to be sure. I like being able to use my iPad / tablet throughout the flight and having text and email communication (both silent) available through in-flight WiFi. E-mail and text are silent, and should be enough connectivity for anybody.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: DO NOT allow cell phone usage on airlines!!!!  Cell phone users tend to talk loud and long.  It would be very unfair to subject passengers to those conversations in a small contained space where a person cannot move away from it.  If it should be approved, space should be provided where cell phones could be used away from other passengers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I appreciate having the opportunity to provide input to the proposed use of cell phones on comercial aircraft.  It has generally been my thought to relocate to another room should a family member be engaged in phone conversation.  I find that the conversation of others is annoying as I go about my home life.  

This said, I belive being forced to endure the conversation of strangers would be sinful.  In no way am I interested in being forced to listen to 123 people's personal drama while sitting in an enclosed space.   PLEASE do not allow passengers to use phones on aircraft.

Title: Carol
Comment: Please please please do not allow the use of cellphone voice calls on airlines. I do not want to hear constant chatter of my seatmate as I fly to my destination. Not only will I hear the chatter but the people sitting in front and behind me will hear this chatter as well. Who wants to hear about Aunt Betty's illness or the quarrel between siblings, etc, etc?? Who will regulate the length of a phone call or the loudness of the speaker? We are inundated with people talking on their phones everywhere we go. In public places we have the opportunity move away from the chatter if its annoying. Tell me,where can I go to get away from the cellphone chatter in an airplane? Nowhere!! People can use their laptops to email if conversation is important but please no cellphone voice calls on airplanes!!

Title: Carol Daniels
Comment: Please!! NO cell phone use on flights!!!

Title: Nancy Verba
Comment:
Please allow access to only data and text services on board aircraft.  I oppose granting the ability to use voice mobile services, even if they are granted to only part of the aircraft seating area (because with my luck I'll get seated right next to that section).  

Thanks.

Title: Daniel Poyourow
Comment:
I am against allowing cell phone use in flight. People tend to talk loudly on cell phones -- practically shouting.  I can imagine several very unpleasant situations.   What about the person who wants to read a book?  Or sleep?  Or just relax?  Or watch in the in-flight movie?  They are stuck sitting next to a person who is having a disturbing phone call -- perhaps using their phone the entire length of the flight, or having an argument on the phone.   It is not like they can get up and move to another location, as many flights are full, or they have to keep their seat belts on.  And if it is a parent sitting next to a child, then they would have to relocate both seats.  Also, people on cell phones are less mobile, so it presents problems for people who need to get up to use the lavatory, or speak with the flight attendant, or simply pass trash to the aisles.  Phone users will also miss most announcements.  

People now have an expectation that you cannot make calls during flights, so the rest of the population understands and works around these short hours.  A few hours without media is actually a good thing.

This is going to create so many conflicts.  Please continue the ban on in-flight calls.

Title: Richelle Beck
Comment:
In response to your request for public comment on the issue of allowing the public to use their cell phones on airplanes, I beg you not to allow this.  

First of all, it raises serious concerns for me that cell phone usage will interfere with the pilot's ability to communicate with those on the ground.  For someone who already struggles with the fear of flying, this will only work to enhance that fear. 

Secondly, there is nothing more annoying than having to listen to someone in a seat right next to you talking on their phone.  Headphones/ear plugs are not strong enough to drown out the loud conversations people tend to have on their phones.  With the white noise that already exists on an airplane, people will talk loudly, of this I have no doubt.  Please don't put us through this.  If someone has an important enough issue that they must make a call, let them use the phones already in place on the airplane and pay the high fee for usage.  But to give all publics access to making calls on their cell phones will merely create havoc and irritation in an area where fear, frustration, and impatience is already unusually high.

Thank you for allowing me to comment on this important issue.  Again, I beg you to reach a decision that does not allow cell phone usage on airplanes by the general public.

Sincerely, Richelle Beck

Title: Jo Portman
Comment: Flying is already an expensive, exhausting and overly complex experience that the very thought of having to be trapped in a metal tube listening to the loud talkers discuss the most mundane aspects of their life would make me fly the one airline that says they won't allow it (Delta) or boat travel. Please don't make this change.

Title: Roger Merrill
Comment:
I recommend that you do not allow cell phone use on airline flights. I fined unrestricted cell phone use an annoyance and an invasion of my privacy.  I took four flight segments in the last two week, and there were numerous times in the  airports I visited that I was walking and thought I was being addressed, since every one around m was moving, and I heard a loud voice. But no, it was just a cell phone user thoughtlessly talking loudly. This is especially the case when the user has a handsfree  device.  

I recommend that you do not permit cell phone usage on airline flights. Those flights are one of the last refuges from obnoxious cell phone users. If you could restrict cell phone usage in airports to areas set up for it, that would also be an excellent idea. It would go a ways towards making airplane travel more enjoyable again.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow mobile phone calls on planes! People are aggressive enough just putting their bags in the overhead bins, let alone having to listen to conversations. The noise level would be ridiculously high if everyone is trying to talk over one another. Flying is already getting more and more unpleasant, this would be the icing on the cake. Can't we have a few hours of silence?

Title: Tony Pociunas
Comment: One loud baby is bad, but just one loud, inconsiderate person on their phone would be 100 times worse, now multiply that by a plane load of talkers.  If cellphones are allowed, require those needing to use their phone, to sit in the last 5 -10 rows of the plane in a sealed off sound proof section, and have them pay a premium for this.

Title: Tanner Prestegard
Comment: I think voice communications should continue to be banned, primarily due to the fact that it could be extremely unpleasant for other passengers to have to listen to the phone conversations of others throughout an entire flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: To allow cell phone use during flights would be a design for disaster. First of all, travel through the air is unique because of the inherent dangers involved. Many passengers are in close proximity...which creates an uneasiness, already. Many people will want to talk on their phones...leaving a stressful and edgy situation for all. This certainly would lead to conflicts in the air between passengers. Thus, the whole consideration for flight safety will be compromised.

Title: Amber Jensen
Comment: I am a flight attendant for Delta Air Lines. WE ALL SAY "NO" to cell phones in flight. Thank you.

Title: Eric
Comment: Please DO NOT allow the use of cellphones for conversation on flights.

Title: C. G. Bellinger
Comment: Absolutely NO allowance for voice calls when airborne.  Loud babies and children are enough of an annoyance.  We don't need extraneous, personal gabbing throughout a trip.

Title: Karen MacDonald
Comment: Please no cell phone usage on planes.  Texting and silent ring to indicate messages only.  Use of cell phones by passengers would be too disruptive to fellow passengers making already uncomfortable 'cattle cars'  more unpleasant and take away the last shreds of the joy of travel.

Title: William Fitzgerald
Comment: I am against the proposed cell phone use in airplanes. The small confined space of an airplane is no place for a phone conversation.  There is no place to go to get away from private conversations and I don't need or want to know about some stranger's life or personal business. I cannot believe that anything is that important that you need to have cell phone service while on a flight especially a domestic flight.  Just imagine the noise pollution of many phone conversations that you can't get away from.  That would make flying even more stressful and annoying.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I feel that the confined spaces and fixed seat locations on planes make allowing phone conversations a nuisance to other passengers. Without the ability to change seats, conversations could disrupt other passengers ability to read, sleep, or relax. As per the recent Associated Press poll last, 48% of Americans oppose allowing cellphones to be used for voice while flying,while only 19% support it. While there are limitations to polling, the drastic contrast in a poll done by a reputable source should display the fact that many Americans are in agreement that while there is an added benefit of cell phone use, it poses a greater risk of becoming a detriment to the atmosphere of flying in order to satisfy the desires of the noisy few.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am opposed to use of cellphones on aircraft because:

Many passengers will resent the noise and distraction of loud and extended phone conversations, leading to negative social interaction and creating safety hazards.

Airplane crews are already required to confront people who disregard regulations pertaining to use of electronics.
Cellphone use will only complicate this problem.

Title: Hugh
Comment:
Do not allow cell phone use for voice calls, and do not allow VOIP on planes.  Allow texting.

Consider the train analogy.  I regularly commute to work by train, and it is abundantly clear that on trains, the use of cell phones is disruptive and annoying to everyone (except of course the cell phone-using jerk).   I estimate that perhaps 20% of cell phone users on trains are respectful in terms of their voice volume.  The other 80% cause everyone around them discomfort and displeasure, and occasionally cause unpleasant words to be exchanged.  And my train rides are usually only about 45 minutes.  Imagine the extra tension resulting from being stuck next to some chatty jerk for the longer duration typical of airpline flights.

Do we really need to add more reasons for airline passengers to get into fights?

There is also the question of economic fairness: is it fair that a cell-phone talker pays the same ticket price as all the many non-cell-phone-talkers around him, who experience a far lower quality of service (i.e., noise)?

Those who want to communicate while on a plane have the perfectly acceptable, perfectly quiet alternative of texting.  By banning cell phone voice use we do not infringe on their ability to communicate, but we do increase the safety and comfort of the travelling public.

Title: Roger
Comment: Loathe the idea of cell calls on airplanes.  Please don't allow it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed to using mobile phones on aiircrafts.  People talk loud on the ground, it would be a bunch of people screaming into their phones in a small enclosed space.  Plus people are already distracted using their phones while driving, so I don't see them paying attention on an aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm claustrophobic just thinking about people on phones on flights. Terrible idea.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I do not want cell phones to be used during airline flights.  I believe it would be very disruptive to other activities and the sensibilities of everyone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phone for talking during a flight on board a passenger airliner. I do not want to be seating next to someone who will be talking during the entire flight and I will not have the option of walking away from him/her.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Flying has already become quite unpleasant, as much of the flying public already knows, and allowing cellphone conversations in flight will make it much more so.  I tend to read a book during flights, and I am certain phone conversations will make it difficult or impossible for me to focus on my reading. This proposed new rule would in effect be giving carte blanche to self-absorbed boors--the last thing in the world that our society needs.

Title: Diane Couper
Comment: No.  The airlines have done everything they can to jam more seats onto airplanes.  Thus we are even closer to each other.  The thought of being forced to listen to people on their cell phones, at 30,000 feet, is horrifying.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I oppose allowing voice cell phone calls to be made on commercial aircraft. As annoying and loud as people are on cell phones while on the ground, allowing their use in as confined a space as an an aircraft would certainly cause conflict between passengers.

Title: Patrick Frank
Comment: DOT-OST-2014-0002: I oppose allowing cell phone conversations on aircraft. Such conversations render airline travel far less pleasant and efficient. Cell phone conversations in close proximity disturb neighboring passengers, who may be working or having their own whispered conversations with neighbors, or even trying to sleep.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am in support of allowing voice calls in-flight.

Allowing phone calls to take place in a public environment is not an unfair business practice. Individuals have no more right to avoid the sound of the human voice than they to do have silence. 

The DOT should not try to regulate whether or not phone calls can be use on flights -- they should allow airlines to decide for themselves. The market will shift depending on whether or not an airline allows in-flight calls: Some airlines will pander to business flights and allow the calls, and other airlines that target families will disallow them. 

While the DOT does has statutory authority to regulate fair business practices, it does NOT have authority to make subjective judgment calls as to whether or not a certain practice will be annoying and outlaw it on that basis. The DOT should not take a "passenger inconvenience" and declare it an unfair business practice. If anyone can point to tangible financial or physical effects of allowing phone calls in flight I would love to hear them. Predictive claims related to passenger discomfort will not be enough to bring this issue under the purview of 49 U.S.C. § 41712.

Title: anonymous
Comment:
I am a frequent flier with 50000+ miles a year. The amount of disruption by calls prior to closing the door (as it works right now) is high with users being able to get very loud inside a very confined space. Cell phones for voice calls should be blocked by airlines.
However, texting with no sounds would be beneficial. This would allow a level of communication to the outside while disrupting other passengers' space.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Calls should be permitted on aircraft in flight if there is no safety risk.

Title: John Barrett
Comment: there are already too many loudmouths, talking on their phones, on the airplanes before take off and when landing.  I have yet to overhear of a potential life threatening situation or business deal gone bad. This is an enclosed space and voices carry.  It has the potential to be an explosive issue between the cell phone users/abusers and the general plane population.  Use of cell phones on an airplane is NOT a RIGHT.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Comment on use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.

Calls should be allowed for emergencies only.  

Sitting next to someone and having to listen to one side of a long and often loud voice call is torture when you don't have the option to move, which you usually don't on a flight.  DO NOT ALLOW any voice calls (except in emergencies).  

People should be able to text, send emails, and anything else that does not disturb others.

Title: Ed Nomura
Comment: Allowing voice calls on airplanes will be a nightmare.  It is already allowed on trains and just one person on a phone disturbs the entire car (and for the people most near it is so loud and intrusive).  Allow texting, people can still communicate.  There is no need to allow voice calls.  Complaints to flight attendants will skyrocket and they will be overworked.  Please do not lift the ban on voice calls.  Thank you.

Title: Jon Hill
Comment: As a business owner who flies regularly, I am against the use of cell phones on airplanes.  However, I do not think that DOT or any other government agency should regulate this but should leave it up to the individual airlines based on feedback from their customers.

Title: Al Bonowitz
Comment:
I implore you in the strongest way possible: Please do not allow cellular voice communications on commercial aircraft. I understand that the safety issues may have been resolved, but the possibilities for abuse of the social contract are simply too great to ignore. I am not interested in being subjected to my seatmate's conversations for two minutes, let alone for the duration of a cross-country flight.

I have no scientific backing for this, but it has been my experience that the more inane the conversation is, the louder it gets. It's not a matter of people knowing how to use their "indoor voice": Even that is too loud when it is only a foot away. And if two adjacent people are involved in verbal cell communications, they will certainly escalate their voices because they can't hear themselves. I am a musician and have seen this phenomenon play out on stage where a guitarist will turn up his amplifier if he can't hear what he's playing, not thinking in the least about how that will affect the onstage sound, or that it might lead to others raising their volume.

I can't think of any emergency that is so dire that its resolution can't wait until the passenger has landed. If a person's input is so important, they perhaps they shouldn't be flying. We're getting by just fine without this: Please don't make an already bad situation worse.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
No voice calls, PLEASE!  Unlike buses and trains, airplanes do not afford someone an opportunity to change seats in the event they find themselves sitting next to someone loudly talking on their phone. Air travel is enough of an ordeal without someone holding a conversation half the plane can hear throughout the duration of the flight.

But I do understand the need of business travelers to want to stay in touch with their office, colleagues, etc., so I do support the use of texting, online chat functions, and instant messaging.

Calls, NO.

Texts, online chat, instant messaging, etc., YES.

Thanks for listening.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Cell phone use should continue to be banned.  Merely restricting such use to night time hours would not be an adequate safeguard against the serious nuisance factor cell phone conversations would constitute.  Travelers crossing time zones may need to nap during the day if that is when jet lag makes them sleepy.

Having experienced needlessly loud, overly personal conversations in other public settings, I do not want that experience extended to airplane interiors.  I am also concerned that annoyance with such conversations would lead to arguments and further escalate the nuisance level for the captive traveler audience.

Title: Matt Mees
Comment: I fly quite frequently, and a plane load of people talking on their cell phones would be unbearable. If people must talk on their cell phones, then I would hope there would be a place on the plane separate from the rest of the cabin to do so, otherwise texting only should be the rule. It would be a cacophony on the plane. Many of us use flights to sleep before doing business.

Title: James Eigen
Comment: I'm totally against cellphones on airlines!

Title: Harold Guilfoil
Comment:
Please, please do not allow people to make phone calls on planes....Travel can be stressful enough without having to listen to someone else's conversation, issues, business deals.  

If this has to be done then please require a "phone" section on the plane be set up by every airline.

Title: Rolf Sumstad
Comment:
No to voice calls on commercial flights.
I think it would degrade the experience.  I think it would add to conflicts among passengers. I think it would be another burden for cabin personel.
No, please, no.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no.  It is the one area, flying, where one can read, relax, sleep,,,

Title: Kay Nelson
Comment: Please, please do not allow cell phone use during flights.  There will never be any peace and quiet anywhere on Earth if this is allowed.  I wouldn't object to texting, but then I suppose the phone would ding everytime one is received and that would be difficult to live with as well.

Title: Sal
Comment: I would vote to not allow cell phone voice use on plane. The physical proximity to other passengers in the plane means that any conversation on the phone would disturb fellow passengers. There is no reason why a passenger cannot wait till the plane has landed to make or receive their phone calls. Even in the case of an emergency there is nothing much they can do from the air anyways. A lot of airplanes do allow Wi-Fi usage so for those desperate to be in touch with others they can always avail of email or chat services via Wifi which are less intrusive and not much  of a disturbance to fellow passengers.

Title: Maxine Jordan
Comment: please, NO to use of mobile wireless devices on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I vote NO to cellphone calls on aircrafts.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002

Thank you for providing this opportunity to express an opinion regarding cell phone usage aboard operating, in-flight aircraft.

I am advising "no" on the use of cell phones in flight. Most people talk louder and longer than necessary while using cell phones in public areas,  The background "white" noise level in a plane is already quite high, so people on phones will be even louder than they are in other public spaces. Importantly, many of us on planes are either flying for business and therefore are working (preparing for meetings, etc.), or we are enjoying a few rare hours of peace and relaxation, or we are using the time to be alone with our thoughts. Folks on cell phones will make these situations impossible. Please do not allow cell phones on planes. 
Lisa Clemens

Title: Gerald Clemens
Comment:
Please DO NOT allow cell phone calls on aircraft.

I have flown more than 1 million miles and am concerned that cell phone calls will disturb everyone near the caller.  Yet, the caller did not pay for my seat and he or she should not be able to disturb me at will. 

Frankly, even at the gate, so many phone calls in a much less confined space is very annoying, but at least I can leave my seat at the gate and move.  Once I am on the plane, I am trapped and cannot move away from someone's personal phone call noise.

Title: Debra Snyder Ringblom
Comment: Please do NOT allow voice calls on aircraft!!! I fly to get away and air transport is already hectic enough! I do not want to hear more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more and more noise, noise, voices, voices, noise, noise, voices, voices - do you get the drift!?!?! HELP! Please do NOT allow voice calls on aircraft!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO! I will not fly an airline that allow it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Picocells for Cell phones access might be considered
for a simple brief period of time during the flight ....

-  For passengers needing help with their connections, gates, loved ones - e.g.  (decent phase perhaps)
-  Medical patents, wheel chair help, Alzheimer assistance

Need a solution that respects needs of everyone including those without a voice in this forum

As time goes maybe this system gets more or less accepted  

Texting through the picocell system perhaps considered anytime.

Title: Joanne Ray
Comment: No, no, no! It would be intolerable to sit on the plane with callers talking very loudly.  Who wants to listen to peoples' personal calls?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do NOT allow cell phone calls on airplanes. Even one caller on a airplane can be disruptive to the rest of the passengers - imagine what it might be like with 20 people shouting into cell phones all on one plane. Imagine a few callers on a red-eye where it's hard enough to sleep. Think about this the next time you're stuck in the grocery check-out line with the obnoxious person behind you having a shouting match on a cell phone. At least you know you know you will be able to escape within a reasonable amount of time. Imagine being stuck on a plane with that same person. It's not worth the animosity it will ultimately create.

Title: Michael Sykes
Comment:
The use of cell phones for voice calls would have a very negative effect on the already less-than-pleasant environment of commercial flights. Use of email and texting, if permitted, would allow for sufficient communication channels for business use or essential communications while in flight. unrestricted use of voice calls would result in a major increase in noise levels as some passengers would embark upon lengthy calls out of boredom, disturbing other passengers and provoking potential altercations and additional demands on the flight crew to mediate disputes and worse.

Designation of quiet zones would be physically difficult and would probably create another class of service, with freedom of annoyance becoming an "upgrade" as aisle seats have now become. 

It truly astounds me that any serious consideration to permitting voice cell phone calls during flights is being given. Clearly I would like to register my strong opposition to such a change in the rule.

Title: William Gordon
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,

Please do whatever you possibly can to PREVENT cell phone use on an airplane. Since people generally speaking have no thought to anyone but themselves, the idea of sitting next to someone making a lengthy call can only general ill-feelings toward fellow passengers and serve as a flash-point for unnecessary conflicts. It is bad enough being dragged into a conversation without being dragged into a conversation to which you can not be a party.

Title: Harry Mort
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone conversations on airplanes.  As a frequent flier the thought of listening to someone's personal conversation at 100 decibels while trapped in a metal cigar is my personal version of hell.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm a frequent flyer and business traveler.  I would prefer not to have cell phone use allowed for voice calls on airplanes.  Already I find the planes very crowded and difficult to get any work done let alone just to be comfortable on the flight.  I typically fly during times when many business travelers are also in the air.  I believe that the quality of my flying experience will be greatly diminished by having a lot of people talking on the cell phone during the flight.  Therefore I prefer that their use not be allowed.

Title: David Myers
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Rhonda DeJean
Comment:
I know this will lead to unpleasant experiences from loud voices, disruption to all those sitting around this person who will talk on the phone and undoubtedly verbal/physical fights.

I travel by public transportation all the time and it is disruptive and people tend to start arguments.
However, public transportation is only a few dollars.  When one spends hundreds of dollars on a cramped plane with no way out until you land, the cellphone will only exacerbate the problem.

Like smoking, it will be pervasive and only upset those who are the receiving end of a loud seatmate.

Cellphone use in an airplane is a healthrisk.

Title: Gary Brown
Comment: Please, do not allow this.

Title: Erica Melief
Comment: I do not believe it is a good idea to allow phone calls on an aircraft. Flying is stressful and tense enough as it is, if you allow people to be openly obnoxious with loud phone conversations, I predict there would be a lot more mid-air fights. Additionally, businesses would likely require that their employees partake in conference calls or meetings during flight, which would be incredibly irritating for that passengers seatmates.

Title: Elle Holmes
Comment: No, please. Never, please.

Title: Ian Harris
Comment: Do not allow wireless devices to make voice calls on aircraft.  The dense packing of people into the economy sections of commercial flights already requires each passenger to be on their "best behavior."  It is not a normal social environment, and can be tolerated because all present understand that they're in the same situation, and have a degree of control over interactions with their neighbors.  Allowing voice calls will add noise, but also also breaks the tacit agreement that "we're all in this together."   Passengers adjacent to the caller will no longer have control over their immediate surroundings, leading to discomfort and stress.  The DOT should safeguard them.

Title: Saemin Kim
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

This response to the Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft ANPRM represents the interest of the Ohio State University’s international student who is currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration degree with a major in Aviation Management. The Ohio State University is one of the most well known Universities with outstanding aviation studies and has its own airport that is widely used as a GA reliever airport. Even though I am not a citizen of the US, I do qualify to participate and respond to this ANPRM since I am concerned with this rule making process and am a consumer of US and international passenger flights. Conventional wisdom says that marketplace competition is the most effective regulator of economic activity; however, there is a question as to why there are so many aviation regulations and safety recommendations. It is the FAA’s responsibility to assign, maintain, and enhance safety as its highest priority. Everyone should realize that safety is the most important factor, not competition over factors such as service options which include allowing using wireless devices while airborne. Whether or not to allow wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft is a highly controversial subject. Some people are asking the question whether using electronic devices is really dangerous or not. David Carson, an engineer with Boeing, said “It’s good news and bad news thing. Electronic devices do not cause problems in every case. And that’s good. But it’s bad in that people assume it never will” (spectrum IEEE). If anyone could predict when and how an accident will occur, there would be no accidents at all. Thus, allowing the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft should be banned for not only for the safety issues, but also for the passenger’s convenience.

Summary of Response: SaeMin Kim, an international student at the Ohio State University 

•	If the rule allows passengers to use mobile wireless devices for voice calls on board, this would have negative effects not only on safety issues, but also on passenger experience which may, overtime, reduce the profitability of the entire US commercial airline system. 
•	However, there should be an exemption on using mobile wireless devices for voice calls on board for emergencies, such as medical treatments, maintenance, and weather issues.
•	Also aircraft with operating certification of FAR Part 91K or 135, such as private jets, fractional ownership, charter flights, and non-common carriage, should be exempted from banning the use of mobile wireless devices on board. 

The remainder of this response directly addresses particular questions posed within the NPRM

In response to ANPRM Question 4: 

There should be exceptions on banning in-flight voice communications on mobile wireless devices for charter flights, air taxi, or fractional jets which are operated by private companies. Since each of the passengers owns the part of aircraft, each passenger should have authority to use in-flight communication devices and; thus, each passenger has the responsibility to use communication devices properly without interfering with the operation of the aircraft or the other 
passengers. 

In response to ANPRM Question 9: 

Business travelers in particular often need to perform job-related work while in-flight. Having a noisy traveler in the adjacent seat would negatively impact their productivity and may cause them to select alternative mode of transportation next opportunity. This would be similar to having to sit next to a crying baby. The difference is while we can’t ban babies; mobile devices can be banned or restricted. 

In response to ANPRM Question 12: 

Nothing would be more stressful and disruptive than listening to people talking on the phone for hours while on long-haul trips. The in flight experience of very few passengers will be enhanced by being subjected to hours of listening to their neighbor drone on about the inconsequential details of their day. In fact, most passengers would find such an experience very un-enjoyable. This in turn may cause some passengers to decide against flying the next time they need to travel. This decrease in passenger traffic would negatively impact the profitability of airlines which allow the use of in-flight mobile devices. 

Thank you for allowing me this opportunity to comment on this ANPRM.  I hope you find my comments helpful making this important decision concerning safety and the passenger experience.

Respectfully submitted,

Title: Mitzi Caldwell
Comment:
Tension and aggressive behavior has increased year after year on the airlines. This is documented information.

Title: Jane Curry
Comment: Absolutely NOT!  I don't want to listen to other passengers' personal or business calls.  Aside from interfering with the small island of quiet passengers may wish to surround themselves with as they read a book or try to sleep, the potential for confrontations among passengers and possible unruly behavior because of loud talking on phones would seem to be a foregone conclusion.  Passengers are often cranky enough with the everyday irritations of plane travel.  This seems like a "time bomb" likely to ignite verbal abuse at the very least and possibly worse.  Just another set of issues that the flight crew might have to deal with.  I'm a friendly person who usually engages in brief, casual greetings with seatmates while we're all settling in.  Then when we take off, I usually read a book. I, for one, would probably go the passive-aggressive route if voice calls were allowed during flights.  If someone next to me insisted on talking on the phone continually through a flight, my inclination would be to read aloud from the book I was trying to enjoy, hoping to make it impossible for them to continue. Traveling these days is stressful enough, packed planes, body scans, etc.  I can imagine ever escalating tensions between passengers who want quiet and the talkers!

Title: Timothy B.
Comment: I implore you to not allow mobile phones on flights. Many people on airplanes are there to get somewhere else, sure, but are also not very good flyers, meaning they get really nervous.  At least with no cell phones they can have a pleasant conversation, listen to their mobile music devices (with headphones), read books or magazines, play puzzle books or video games (with headphones). There are, however, periods of time when there is much ambient noise and activity in the cabin anyway, such as the first 15 minutes after take-off, and the last fifteen minutes before landing.  

Limiting calls in the cabin to that period would permit some reasonable amount of telephonic communication without disrupting what little peace passengers may get.
