Title: Anonymous
Comment:
For many years I have been a frequent business traveler.  My view of the current proposed regulations on cell phone use can be summarized as follows:  

I think that everything that is not likely to be significantly disruptive (using your laptop, watching movies or listening to things with earphones, texting, etc.) should be permitted. However talking (or listening to conversation from others not present in a way that can be overheard by other uninvolved passengers) on VOIP or cell phones or any other device, if done for a long time by anyone, will likely be quite disruptive to those passengers who are not a part of the conversations. Therefore, such communications should not be allowed, except on an emergency basis (as determined by the flight attendants) or for short periods like taxiing after landing (where it can help people deal effectively with their arrival needs, is understood to have limited duration, occurs when there is already disruption, etc.).

Specifically my response to the questions from the website are:

1. I BELIEVE IT IS UNFAIR TO OTHER PASSENGERS TO BE DISTURBED FOR POTENTIALLY LONG PERIODS OF TIME BY CONVERSATIONS WHICH THEY CANNOT AVOID.  THIS IS SIMILAR TO BEING HELD FOR LONG TIMES ON THE TARMAC, OR FOR BEING EXPOSED TO SMOKE FROM OTHER PASSENGERS' CONSUMPTION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS.

2. THE DEPARTMENT SHOULD NOT COMPLETELY REMOVE ITSELF FROM RULEMAKING ON THIS SUBJECT.  IT MAY CHOOSE TO ALLOW AIRLINES TO EXPERIMENT WITH ALLOWING VOICE COMMUNICATIONS, BUT IT SHOULD REQUIRE THE AIRLINES TO CONFINE THOSE WHO INTEND TO DO SO TO A SECTION OF THE PLANE SEPARATED FROM THE "NORMAL" SECTIONS WHERE IT IS FORBIDDEN, AND THE SECTION IN WHICH IT IS PERMITTED SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO INTRUDE ON THE SECTION WHERE IT IS FORBIDDEN-- THAT IS THE "VOICE-COMM" SECTIONS SHOULD BE SHRUNK AS MUCH AS NEEDED TO ALLOW THOSE WHO DON'T WANT TO SIT IN THAT SECTION. 

3.  ANY IN-FLIGHT VOICE COMMUNICATIONS TO/FROM OTHERS NOT WITHIN EARSHOT AND WHICH CAN BE OVERHEARD BY OTHER PASSENGERS SHOULD BE BANNED, EXCEPT FOR EMERGENCIES AND FOR THOSE LIMITED PERIODS WHICH ARE CLEARLY INTENDED TO BE OF SHORT DURATION (SUCH AS THE TAXIING PERIODS AT THE END OF THE FLIGHT)

4. IF PASSENGERS HAVE ALTERNATIVES THAT DO ALLOW A BAN, THE FLIGHT IS ADVERTISED TO ALLOW VOICE COMMUNICATION AND AGREED TO BY ALL PASSENGERS, THEN THERE SHOULD BE NO BAN.

5. THE NON-EMERGENCY USE OF ANY DEVICE IN A MODE WHICH INVOLVES FREQUENT, REPEATED, AND/OR LONG-DURATION CONVERSATIONS WITH ANYONE NOT LOCATED WITHIN EARSHOT OF THE SPEAKING PARTY SHOULD BE BANNED.  I SEE NO NEED FOR ANY FURTHER DEFINITION, AND FURTHER DEFINITION INVITES "GAMING" THE REGULATION.  

6. TEXT-TO-SPEECH TECHNOLOGY WHOSE USE RESULTS IN NEARBY UNINVOLVED PASSENGERS OVERHEARING THE CONVERSATION SHOULD BE BANNED (WITH THE EXCEPTIONS NOTED ABOVE).  USE WHICH CANNOT BE OVERHEARD SHOULD BE PERMITTED.

7. SHORT DURATION USE AT THE BEGINNING AND END OF THE FLIGHT IS NOT A SIGNIFICANT INCONVENIENCE TO PASSENGERS, AND MAY HAVE CONSIDERABLE VALUE TO A WIDE RANGE OF PASSENGERS NEEDING TO INITIATE OR TERMINATE VARIOUS ACTIVITIES CONNECTED WITH THEIR TRAVEL.  EXACTLY WHEN THESE PERIODS SHOULD STOP AND START IS NOT TOO CRITICAL, AS LONG AS THEY DON'T INTERFERE WITH THE FLIGHT CREW'S NECESSARY ACTIVITIES.

8. 

a. YES AS INDICATED IN MY EARLIER RESPONSES.

b. THE DEPARTMENT SHOULD EXEMPT THESE INDIVIDUALS, AS LONG AS THE USE BY THESE PEOPLE IS REASONABLE IN CONNECTION WITH THEIR PURPOSE FOR BEING ON THE AIRCRAFT.

9. HARMFUL-- POSSIBLE PSYCHOLOGICAL AND PHYSIOLOGICAL DISCOMFORT OR HARM TO MANY PASSENGERS DUE TO INESCAPABLE NOISE AND DISRUPTION.  BENEFICIAL-- POSSIBLE ABILITY OF SOME PASSENGERS TO TRANSACT USEFUL BUSINESS OR DEAL WITH PERSONAL MATTERS.

10. THIS COULD BE A WAY FOR AIR-LINE COMPANIES TO EVALUATE THE MERITS WITHOUT A FULL OR PERMANENT COMMITMENT.  THERE SHOULD BE A FEW-ROW SEPARATION BETWEEN VOICE-COM AND NON VOICE-COM SECTIONS.  PERHAPS A PREMIUM COULD BE CHARGED FOR VOICE=COM AND A DISCOUNT OFFERED FOR THOSE IN THE BUFFER ROWS WHO CANNOT USE VOICE-COM BUT HAVE TO PUT UP WITH THE NOISE OF THOSE NEARBY WHO CAN.  

11. SEE ABOVE SUGGESTIONS ABOUT DISCOUNT BUFFER ZONE.

12.  IN PERSON CONVERSATIONS ARE LIKELY LESS NUMEROUS (AND LIKELY QUIETER) THAN THOSE FROM VOICE-COM AND THUS CAN BE DEALT WITH BY EITHER FLIGHT ATTENDANTS, NEARBY PASSENGERS, OR BOTH. 

13. IF AIRLINES HAD SECTIONS OF SOME FLIGHTS, OR EVEN ENTIRE FLIGHTS, WHERE VOICE-CALLS ARE PERMITTED, THE MARKET COULD THEN DETERMINE THE RELATIVE BENEFITS OF ALLOWING VS BANNING.

14. SEE PREVIOUS COMMENT

15.  IT SEEMS THAT THIS MUST BE TRUE.

16.   I HAVE NOT HAD EXPERIENCE WITH THESE FOREIGN CARRIERS.  I SUSPECT THAT DIFFERENT CULTURES OF THE DIFFERENT COUNTRIES' PEOPLES (SOME MORE CONSIDERATE THAN OTHERS) MAY PRODUCE DIFFERENT REPORTED VALUE OF VOICE-COM

17.   I HAVE NOTHING ELSE TO ADD.

Title: Larry Hampel
Comment: Please do not allow cell phones to be used on passenger aircraft.  I rode city buses for many years and heard many loud annoying conversations and an occasional confrontation between the phone user and another passenger due to the loud conversation and bad language being used.  I can only imagine what it would be like on a long flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I vote no, no, NO!  Planes are too crowded and uncomfortable already.  This will add an unacceptable level of noise and way too much neighborliness.

Title: Sarah Hurst
Comment: I fly twice a week. It is barely tolerable in close, crowded quarters to listen to someone yammering nonstop until the plane takes off. Multiply that by dozens of people throughout a plane, and it is a recipe for danger: verbal confrontations, fights, retaliation. I pity the flight attendants, who will be thrust into the middle of these conflicts. If cellphone calls are permitted, in addition to the increased conflict and misery for those of us not talking on phones, chances are that more and more people will use earbuds and headphones to drown out the sound, meaning they will be much less able to hear instructions from the flight crew or pilots. That could compromise safety in the air. I urge you not to allow cellphone use while planes are in flight. Just because you can do something, doesn't mean you should.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Do not allow cell phone calls in flight. It is enough that we constantly contend with the rude idiots on the ground.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow the use of cell phones on an aircraft.  I, for one, don't want to have to put up with listening to someone's conversation.  I'm sure I'm not the only one who feels this way.  For those of us who can't afford to fly first class, sitting in such close proximity is difficult enough as it is.  Please say "No"!

Title: Mario Landeros
Comment: I am strongly against allowing voice calls on aifcraft, I dont want to be forced to hear X amount of people blabbing away while I'm trying to read or sleep.  Text is all we need.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
NO!! Please do not allow voice calls on flights!
DOT-OST-2014-0002

Title: Jane
Comment:
I have noticed that people on their cell phone while waiting in the airport to board a flight have become much more distracting. They tend to talk on their phone as if the person on the other end is not able to hear them. That means that I am part of their private conversation whether I like it or not. In an airplane, I am stuck in my seat for 30 minutes before departure until arrival at the destination. A flight can easily be a 6+ hour trip including the time after boarding but before departure.

If an obnoxious person is talking and travelers close by ask them nicely to please quiet down, things may get out of control very quickly. Airline travel is already stressful enough. Adding an annoying person close by who is talking until their battery dies is not something that I think I should have to endure, especially when I may have paid upwards of $500 for my ticket. I and other passengers should have some consideration for the right to have a quiet flight since we paid for it. Screaming kids cannot always be controlled, but no passenger should be able to inflict noise pollution on fellow passengers.

There is nothing so important that a person cannot wait until they arrive at their destination to make a cell call. I also believe that travelers will want to talk at length if calling is allowed.  Almost every airline has phones on the plane for use, but they are there if someone has an emergency that they must respond to immediately.

Please do not allow cell phone calls while in-flight as it is not fair to all the travelers who are NOT talking on a phone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow passengers on aircraft to use cellphones while in flight.  People using cellphones tend to talk very loudly and it would be disruptive to other passengers.

Title: Ivars Edens
Comment:
Flying is horrible enough without some loudmouth yakking on his phone.  We need quiet.
Thank you.

Title: Rich M.
Comment:
Flights are already noisy enough with the air rushing by, toilets flushing, PA system, service process, etc.  There is always someone who needs to rest; let them be.  People can wait.
Could we ban use by pedestrians in crosswalks, too?

Title: Jon Stephenson
Comment: Please do NOTallow phone conversations on planes. This change will make an uncomfortable experience that much more unbearable. Can't folks wait a few hours to make a call? Allow data usage but NO phone calls, please!

Title: Thomas Janzen
Comment:
I travel frequently by air.  I oppose the proposed rule change allowing cellular audio communication in flight.
1.  Safety is a significant factor.  Seating in virtually all commercial aircraft is cramped with zero privacy.  From experience we know a significant percentage of passengers using cell phones will be too loud affecting all within hearing.  Most people will endure the rudeness, but a certain significant percentage will confront the user with arguments perhaps escalating to violence.  Expecting the cabin crew to police this in an effective way is unrealistic.  In the worst case, law enforcement upon landing will give passengers no relief during the flight.
2.  Even when a cell phone user attempts moderation in communication, the generally accepted social etiquette of avoiding calls that infringe on other's privacy will break down and again call for others to endure the rudeness, even when it is at low levels.  
3.  How do you write a rule defining what level of volume, vocabulary, conversation subject matter is out of bounds, and leaving the burden on the flight crew to determine and enforce that is not realistic.
4.  With the rule, passengers who observe the rights of others have an excuse for not communicating with others - there's a rule prohibiting it.  Without the rule, conscientious passengers have no excuse and would be forced to conduct business and have other unpleasant conversations even if they didn't want to.

These are the reasons that come to mind.
Please maintain the no cell communication rule or air flight will be unendurable.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As  a frequent flier who regularly travels on domestic US air routes I believe that permitting cell phone usage during flights is a bad idea.  Frankly put, air travel nowadays is extremely stressful.  Airlines have managed passenger load levels such that few flights are less than full.  This means passengers in coach are sitting five or six abreast with little room or sense of privacy.  In essence, airline travel nowadays is generally a negative experience where one is more or less forced to sit cheek by jowl with total strangers for extended periods of time.

In such a packed environments it is easy to become annoyed with the behavior of one's fellow passengers whether it's the person nursing a cold and coughing next to you or the child behind who treats your seat back as his "kicking post".  Virtually everyone now pulls out a laptop, tablet reader, video game or iPod devise immediately upon being permitted to do so.  While most fellow passengers are generally considerate -- there's always a few who play the volume (even with headphones) at such level as to annoy those around them.

Adding the ability to make cell phone calls to this already unpleasant environment will only add further stress and discomfort to the flying experience.  While it may be true that most passengers would be considerate and judicious in their use of cell phones in flight -- it is inevitable that there will many who will make constant calls and speak loudly and insistently to the annoyance of those around them.

Besides being a frequent air traveler, I regular ride commuter rail trains in the New York City metro area.  Doing so, I have seen how it takes only a few inconsiderate passengers to make riding in a packed rush hour train a literal "hell on wheels" for those around them.  Indeed, because of this annoyance, Metro North Railroad and other commuter lines have now found it necessary to designate "quiet cars" on trains where no cell phone usage is permitted.  This workable solution for them is unavailable to airlines where everyone shares the same "car" and there's no way anyone can move away from an annoying passenger to sit somewhere else.

I cannot predict what will happen if cell phone usage is permitted during air flights.  But it is not unfathomable that in a high-stress environment such usage will ultimately, if not regularly, result in passenger-to-passenger disputes that could readily escalate into violent behavior.  Something no one wants to occur on an airplane.

Title: Jeff NiFord
Comment: Please, no. People are loud enough on their own. Now I get to listen to someone have an entire conversation next me? People already speak loudly in restaurants and parks and behave as if we want to know their business. Planes are a last refuge for quiet from these oblivious people. Just please, let them wait until they land.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO VOICE CALLS! That would be HELL!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO VOICE CALLS!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow cellphone usage during flights.  I hate to think of being trapped for many hours in close quarters, surrounded by people yelling into their phones.  It will be another reason to avoid flying.

As far as the idea of "quiet zones": please don't do that, either.   I remember the days of smoking and non-smoking sections on aircraft.  Even when you requested a seat in the non-smoking section, you could end up sitting one row from the smoking section, and breathing in a very concentrated blast of smoke.  Noise from the cellphone section would obviously bleed into the "quiet" section.

Title: Lori Holland
Comment:
My name is Lori Holland and I am an infrequent flier.  But I absolutely DETEST the idea of allowing people to make/receive phone calls on airplanes for these reasons:

1)  The flying experience has deteriorated so demonstrably that just getting there is a chore.  I have to practically disrobe at the airport.  I have to pay $25 to check my luggage.  I have to pay an extra $25 to request a window seat.  And the window seat that I do get is so frightfully uncomfortable, narrow and cramped that it would make a yogi blush.  Adding the possibility of a person near me mindlessly yapping away on the phone may just cause me to stop flying all together.  Furthermore, I can just see every airline charging us non-talkers an extra fee for the "privilege" of flying in a space where "talkers" aren't allowed.  Great!  An extra fee!  Because we don't pay enough fees.

2)  Airplane flight tends to bring out the worst in people because they are afraid; talking on the phone will be used as a psychological stress reliever.  But one person's stress relief is another person's stress inducer.  I actually enjoy flying - in spite of all the inconveniences.  I enjoy the crowded solitude of sitting quietly while travelling at 500 miles/hour.  Sometimes I watch a movie.  Usually I just listen to my iPod.  Then I fall asleep.  Cell phone talking would absolutely destroy any sense of peace, quiet and decorum many nervous - and non-nervous - flyers try to receive while floating 30,000 feet above the ground.

3)  VERY IMPORTANT:  PEOPLE ARE RUDE!  I take public transportation to work every day and it never ceases to amaze me how many people will talk - LOUDLY - for the entire 45-minute bus ride.  What are they talking about?  That girl who said that, that boy that I don't like anymore, something in Spanish, something in Portuguese, that (bad word) who owes them money, that unpaid bill, the rent, the job, the boss, etc., etc.  Now just imagine these (loud) conversations taking place 30,000 feet in the air, at midnight, on a trans-Atlantic flight.  It could cause violence.

4)  Finally, there are other options available that will achieve the same means.  Allowing people to send text messages achieves the same end result (current time conversing) without aggravating their fellow travellers.  Allowing unlimited texting is the perfect compromise between the talkers and the sleepers.

Please don't allow people to talk on cell phones on planes.  I'm under enough stress already!  I just can't take anymore.

Title: John H.
Comment: Absolutely not.  Use the east coast corridor trains as an example, there HAVE to be "quiet cars" where no cellphones are allowed.  Hard to do on a plane.  Besides, I remember the phones in the seat back that cost like 10$ a minute.  All people did was call someone to say "I'm on a plane!  Cool!"  Why bother.  People have been doing business without being able to incessantly twatter and spacebook and talk for many years, it can stay this way.  It is one of the worst ideas around, allowing voice calls. Please save us from this.

Title: Suzanne Skeeters
Comment:
I am writing to express my concern that mobile wireless devices for voice calls are NOT allowed to be used on aircraft while in flight.  I am a captain for a major U. S. airline and fly international routes.  I also commute over 2500 miles from my residence to my work place on airplanes.  I travel on airplanes A LOT, and often use that time to catch up on much-needed sleep and computer work. I would not want to be on an aircraft with 150+ people on their cell phones each time I fly.  The noise level would have great impact!

As a safety point, it would become another in the long list of regulatory rules that flight crews are required to enforce.  People have become so attached to their cell phones, distracted by their use, and so disrespectful of authority, that trying to enforce yet another rule will put additional stress on flight crews that already have many tasks and responsibilities to accomplish during a flight.  During the safety briefing, for instance, flight attendants would be required to enforce passengers to hang up their calls while the briefing is being given, or be drowned out by the noise of people making personal calls.  As it is, most passengers do not pay attention to the briefing as they are already using their portable electronic devices (PED) while the safety briefing is being performed!  I cannot fathom how also being on a voice call is going to help that situation!  Factor in an emergency situation, and passengers will now be on the phone instead of paying attention to the flight crews' instructions.   

I fully support the use of SILENT communications such as wi-fi for the use of internet email, text messaging, etc.   
I emphatically DO NOT support the use of voice calls during flight.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this subject. 

Sincerely, 

Captain Suzanne Skeeters

Title: Rose Rosenblum
Comment: Please do not allow cellphones on airplanes.  I have traveled many times on buses and trains where cell phone are allowed and this does not add to the travel experience.  I cannot imagine being trapped, yes trapped on an airplane with other passengers on their cell phones.

Title: Edith A.
Comment:
I would vote for not allowing voice calls in an aricraft.

Would be a source of pasangers disagrements and fights over a loud conversation and so on.Besides a matter of bothering the others around when someone makes a call,in flight attendants would constantly have to keep the peace between the rude ones on the phone and the bothered ones trying to read or sleep.
It is already a problem in other enviroments (like waiting room at the doctor's office) where despide the displayed signs requesting to not make calls,or keep it low......everyone is for themselves and must have that "important call".

For the safety( and comfort) of our travels hope the voice calls will not be allowed during our flights.

Title: Joe Cronin
Comment: Please do NOT allow phone calls during flight. The ability to get away from annoying, loud or personal conversations is effectively zero on an aircraft. When stuck elbow to elbow for several hours having to listen to somebody ramble on would be horrible. As a frequent flyer, I have been platinum with American Airlines for 12 years running, just the thought of this added aggravation during travel makes me cringe  uncontrollably.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Never do I want cellphones used on passenger aircraft flights.  I would find the noise of chatter utterly irritating.  Moreover, I agree with concerns expressed by flight attendants that passengers who are engaged in cellphone conversation will ignore or simply not hear their instructions.  Also, has it occurred to anyone that terrorists on the airplane could communicate with terrorists on the ground for an attack, perhaps as this aircraft is on approach or arrives at its next airport?  For these reasons, please PROTECT all in-flight passengers from the danger as well as rudeness that cellphone using passengers would cause.

Title: Joy
Comment:
I feel that allowing phone calls on airplanes would make traveling in a confined space even more unpleasant. But I also feel that there are safety concerns to consider.

Persons who are chatting on their telephones will fail to hear announcements on board. For example, if the captain warns passengers to fasten their seatbelts due to approaching turbulence, people engrossed in phone conversations will not hear the warning.

In-flight entertainment (movies and music) pause and become silent when there is an announcement on board, to ensure that everyone will hear the announcement. But if cell phone calls are allowed, I don't believe there is any way to silence those phone calls to make sure passengers hear important announcements.

The other safety issue comes from the inevitable disagreements between passengers, when loud conversations are upsetting people sitting nearby. This could lead to more fights between passengers, and could also distract stewards and stewardesses from their jobs as they have to spend their time managing disagreements between passengers.

Please ban voice calls on board aircraft. Flights will be safer and more pleasant.

Title: Gail
Comment:
I completely disagree with allowing passengers to use wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. In an enclosed environment where people are seated so closely together it is quite disruptive if a party next to you, or seated behind you is constantly on the phone, voices carry quite far in this environment and you can hear people from several rows ahead and behind. Especially during evening flights where there is a quiet environment, lights are dimmed so passengers could rest, if passengers were given the option they could be able to talk while others are resting, and no one would be able to monitor or advise passengers to lower their voices because this would be allowed. Another scenerio would be  a business passenger conducting business on their cell phone for the entire flight, and you are sitting next to them. So many times we hear infants crying and passengers complain, imagine someone talking in a loud voice the entire flight This would possible lead to altercations, and be a burden to flight crew where safety is the utmost concern for passengers by crew members. . Please do not allow this proposition be approved.

Thank You,

Gail

Title: Joel
Comment: I am strongly opposed to voice calls on mobile devices on board aircraft. It's just too confined a space for such activity. I feel it may lead to passenger altercations over the volume of those callers and thereby jeopardize the safety of the flight..

Title: Larry Krieger
Comment:
I strongly oppose the use of mobile devices for voice calls on aircraft.  The current policy has been working successfully for several years.  When we are on a plane, there is no where to go; the passenger is totally part of a "captive audience".  To imagine someone very close to me, whether talking briefly or for an extended period, it makes no difference, would upset me greatly.  I use a mobile device regularly, however I am quite willing to put up with a respite from the use of such devices on an airplane.  We are too close to others, with no where to get away to.   People can wait until the plane lands to contact love ones or business contacts!!!  Parenthetically, I would not oppose the use of mobile devices for texting while in flight.
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No, not only no but hell no.

Title: Ken L.
Comment: Cell phone use for anything OTHER than talking should be allowed.  Don't be RUDE.

Title: Joel
Comment: I am opposed to the use of voice calls via mobile devices on board aircraft.. I feel it is a definite distraction to other passengers and may lead to unwanted confrontations. Thank you for your time.

Title: anonymous
Comment: For the sake of every traveler's sanity, please do not allow this!  It is irritating enough to have to listen to people talk on their phones at the gate as well as during boarding/disembarking; it would be so much worse to have to endure this during the flight itself. No, no, no!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No, please don't allow phone calls during airplane flights.  I don't care to hear anybody's phone conversations while stuck in a small, confined space for long periods of time.  Even short flights can be annoying when someone is talking on their phone.  We need to keep flights the one place where it's relatively quiet without others' conversations.  Please keep our airplane flights quiet.

Title: RK Irwin
Comment: We as a society are not ready for this. Air rage is already an issue then compound the events that can occur when normally well mannered people are pushed to the edge by unruly people on their phone.

Title: anonymous
Comment: Allowing the use of voice cellphones would be yhe end of the last vestige of civility.Being trapped in a cigar tube,flying  greyhound bus listening to someone prattle on,mindlessly would be tantamount to ear rape. Ear Rape- the forced insertion of something against my will.My only recourse would be kimchi and sardine sandwiches, Thank you.

Title: BA Finstead
Comment: My wife and I are adamently opposed to allowing the use of cellphones on planes. In an airplane seat you are essentially trapped and would be at the mercy of someone using their cellphone with its attendant noise. Texting and/or email should be OK and should satisfy the need for emergency communication.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO, NO, NO, NO, NO !!!!  Very simple, NOOOOO!!!!!!!

Title: Andria Bronsten
Comment:
PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW CELL PHONES ON AIRPLANES. The sound of people talking all the way through a flight will add more misery to an already trying flying experience. Peace and quiet for a few hours is something all passengers need. Those who want music or movies can use headphones so as not to disturb everyone on the planes. Flight attendants and pilots need all passengers' attention during emergencies. I can think of no good reason to allow people to talk on cell phones on airplanes. At the movies, theaters ask patrons to turn cell phones off for the enjoyment of everyone around you. The same should go for airplanes.

Thank you!

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2014-03684
Comment: This is a terrible idea. It's bad enough that I have to listen to people's loud (and often inappropriate) conversations in my day-to-day life, so having to listen to them in the confined space of an airplane would be a nightmare.  Regular noise on planes is sometimes too loud (e.g., crying babies, sick people coughing, etc.), so please do not allow cellphones on planes.  Thank you.

Title: Sandy Nelson
Comment: RE:  Cell phones on aircraft.  I can't think of anything more annoying than 10 to 12 hours of 300 people talking on their cell phones at the same time!!!!!!!  It sounds like a migraine waiting to happen.  Truly, there is almost nothing that cannot wait until your flight ends.  There was a day when it just had to wait .... and we all survived.  PLEASE... no cell phones on airline flights!

Title: Margie C.
Comment: Please do NOT allow cell phone calls on airplanes. The personal space is non-existent, cell phone talkers are invariably loud and long-winded, and they tend to ignore everything going on around them while on a call. This would mean the end of being able to either work quietly on a laptop in one's seat, or being able to read a book, or being able to sleep, all of which passengers tend to need or depend upon when frequently flying.  An airplane ride is often the only chance one has in a busy schedule to decompress, having a bit of down time between events, before having to get back into the fray. Sitting next to someone who just feels like conversing and goes on and on, loudly and rudely, will NOT help anyone. Isn't it bad enough that the width of each seat is shrinking all the time, there is often an issue with bumping elbows with the person next to you (see lack of personal space), leg room is often quite minimal, esp. for tall people (even for me, and I'm short), and the hassle of flight attendants' refreshment service (can't get up while they're in the aisle, can't get around the cart, and the attendants are harried), all of which contribute to 'air rage' and irritation in passengers paying high prices for tickets. Now the FAA is considering ADDING to the number of air travel irritations (don't get me started on oversized "carry on" bags that people force into overhead bins, let alone the fees for bags!) by allowing cell phone chatter???  Surely they are KIDDING. PLEASE do NOT recommend that cell phone calls be allowed. Give us one damned break, PLEASE.

Title: Tabitha Winkler
Comment: PLEASE!  No cell phones, no calls.  It would amount to torture.  It is a horrible, bad, not good idea.  Seriously, the idea makes me want to die.  I hate flying already and having to listen to vapid conversations from all corners of the plane for hours upon hours upon hours upon hours upon hours (you get the picture) would be beyond unbearable. NO NO NO NO NO.  Can you imagine an early morning flight, let's say 5 am, and you want to sleep and the guy next to you wants to talk to his hard-of-hearing mother for six hours or something?  And then you have to listen to nothing but "conversation" about cats and schmaltz at what sounds like volume 20?  Truly disturbing.  Like nightmarish.  If this happens I think it will have results equal to when you put too many mice in a cage: they start cannibalizing each other.

Title: Sheryl Schecter
Comment:
I fly at least twice a month and love having wifi access during flights.  However, the proposal for cell phone usage on a flight is terrible.  Appropriate cell phone use (quiet voices, non-annoying ring tones, etc.)  on airlines will be difficult to enforce and require flight attendants who are there for the passenger's safety to monitor passengers cell phone behavior rather than attend to their jobs providing safety and comfort to flyers.  Please do not allow wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cell phones with voice calls on planes. It would disrupt other passengers and could lead to confrontations. Flying is stressfull enough for many people who fly. Hearing other peoples business for several hours would be terrible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am absolutely opposed to permitting voice calls on aircraft. When traveling on business, I need to concentrate on my work. When traveling for pleasure, I prefer to catch up on reading or relax by listening to music. Even if using a headset, I believe it would be impossible to tune out the babbling of scores of people engaged in individual conversations around me. When commuting by train, I sit in quiet cars. Airlines, with their already-cramped seating, can't possibly provide anything similar to this - not even a "phone booth" to accommodate a private phone conversation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not permit this to happen.  The thought of being trapped on a plane with loud mouths talking on phones is a nightmare.  I am a frequent user of public transportation and even that is torture with selfish cell phone users on short trips. 

Let's be reasonable, unless you're waiting for the call for the kidney, there is not any pressing matter that can't wait til you land.

Title: Robert
Comment: I think voice calls on aircraft should still be banned.   Imagine 300+ people on their phone at the same time in a plane.   There is no way to get away from it if you are a passenger on that plane.   I say NO voice calls on planes!   Thank you.

Title: Beth Martin
Comment: PLEASE do not allow voice calls on airplanes! Texting and other uses, yes, but not voice calls. I can think of nothing worse than being held hostage and forced to overhear someone else's cell phone conversation with no chance of escape, especially on longer-haul flights. It would be worse than a baby crying for me. I was seated next to a gentleman on a recent flight who, just as we were about to push back from the gate, got a phone call that someone he knew had died. He was seated by the window and hid his cell phone use from the flight attendants as we took off, only hanging up when he lost cell coverage. The second we were on the Tarmac he was back on the phone. It was excruciating for me to be forced to pretend that I wasn't overhearing this gentleman's shock and grief as he talked to loved ones. Do not allow cell phone calls on planes!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow cell conversations on airplanes.  The seat sizes are becoming less which means all
passengers will be closer in proximity.  People on cell phones forget how loud their voice is and how animated
they are during the conversation.  Many of us catch up on silent activities: reading, emails and work related spreadsheets 
or sleep.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no cell phones on planes. Planes are noisy places as it is, add to that louder conversation tone to offset ambient sound and flying will become even more stressful. I find conversations in the airport, which I cannot avoid hearing, often without urgency or substance. Use email, use text, no cell phones on planes.

Title: K. Hart
Comment: Flying is stressful enough without adding the annoyance of people who will invariably be obnoxious about their volume, choice of words and attitude.  People are generally trying to endure the narrow seats, cramped legroom and immediate passengers (double wides, crying babies, generally unhappy people).  Some of us try either to read, do work or watch the movie and having someone talking in close proximity is going to be horrible.  Allow texting, that's fine; but please don't make flying a worse experience then it already is.

Title: Maria Neary
Comment:
Please, please, please DO NOT allow cell phone use on planes. 
Unfortunately and unlike riding a bus, train or walking down the street, there is NO WAY to escape listening to needless and usually too loud chatter, while sitting so close to someone on an airplane.  What can possibly be so important that it can't wait a few hours?

I am a cell phone user.  It is my only phone.  I appreciate some quiet whenever possible.  

Thank you.

Title: Rita
Comment: Please, please, please, do not allow people to talk on the phone. They forget that there are other people around and talk extra loud. Plane trips are bad enough what with no leg room, reclining seats into your face and incessant annoying laughter and loud conversation from fellow passengers. Do we really need more fights? This is definitely a safety issue.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am emphatically against allowing voice calls on mobile wireless devices on aircraft!  Given the tendency to talk loudly and the uncomfortably close proximity to others on aircraft any such rule can only end with unintended consequences.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. People using these devices are usually speaking louder than normal and have a habit of talking for long periods of time. Most passengers prefer to have as much quiet time as possible to work, read or just rest and not have to listen to someone else's empty chatter or oftentimes, private business.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that voice calls on Mobile wireless devices on aircrafts would be a terrible mistake.  We will never get cell phone usage out of passenger vehicles now that it is occurring and I think once we were to allow it onboard airplanes and it didn't work it would be impossible to stop.  Anyone using a cell phone would be inconveniecing other passengers setting near them.  I think it will create a great deal of hostility among the people who are using cell phones and those who are not.  I would hate to speed an entire flight listening to someone go on and on about anything.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please don't allow cell phone conversations on planes.  It's too cramped already and will too hard to tune out half a conversation.  

Don't know if you know the science behind why hearing half a conversation is more annoying.  It's not just white noise/ chatter.  It's on-and-off noise, which is MORE distracting than a whole conversation.   

http://www.medicaldaily.com/overheard-cell-phone-conversations-are-annoying-says-science-244621  

From the article:

"Overheard cell phone calls are unavoidable, as much as you might like to tune them out. A new study confirms what you already knew - that overheard phone conversations are much more distracting than normal background chatter.

Because you can only hear one side of an overheard cell phone conversation, your attention is more easily drawn towards understanding it than it would be to a two-sided conversation - even, or especially, if you're trying to pay attention to something else.

The study was published in the journal PLOS One on March 13, by Veronica Galván and colleagues from the University of San Diego.

The researchers asked participants to complete a cognitive task that had them solve anagrams. As they performed the tasks, actors in the background staged a conversation in the background about shopping for furniture, planning a birthday party, or meeting a date at the mall.

Half of the participants only overheard one side of a cell phone conversation, and the rest overheard a conversation between two people in the same room. None of the participants were told that the real purpose of the study was to see how easily distracted they were from their tasks.
Follow Us

"This is the first study to use a realistic situation to show that overhearing a cell phone conversation is a uniquely intrusive and memorable event," said Galván in a statement.

"We were interested in studying this topic since cell phone conversations are so pervasive and could impact bystanders to those conversations at work and in other settings of everyday life."

The participants who overheard the cell phone conversation found it much more distracting than those in the other group. They also remembered more of the content of the cell phone call, and more easily recognized which words were part of the phone call.

The researchers suggest that this effect can be explained by the extra attention resources a person needs to understand a one-sided conversation.

Hearing both sides of a conversation makes it easier to understand, and thus less distracting. When you only hear one side of an overheard phone conversation, you're more likely to devote brainpower to imagining the other side- even if you would rather not.

"Not knowing where the conversation is heading is what makes cell phone calls more distracting", said Rosa Vessal, a co-author on the study.

Galván also suggests that since people tend to reveal personal information on cell phone calls, even in a public setting, it's especially difficult to ignore and more tempting to eavesdrop.

Title: Ms Tarzana

Can you even imagine sitting next to someone for hours on end while they have personal conversations or conduct business?  Please, please please---airplane travel has become unpleasant and uncomfortable enough as airlines squeeze every ounce of comfort out of travel in order to increase profit.  Please DO NOT allow cellphone calls on airplanes!!! Key-rist.

Comment: Please continue the ban on cellphones while the plane is in flight. I do not want to hear my seat mates jabbering away while I'm resting or watching a movie. Thank you.

Title: Joseph Southworth
Comment:
The use of cell phones for voice calls in the confined space of a commercial aircraft should not be allowed.  

The inability of people making those calls and to follow simple or complex instructions from the aircrew would present a serious safety hazard to fellow passengers. Comment:
Let the madness end here. 
NO CELL PHONES ON AIRPLANES!

Title: Michel Orsoni
Comment: The whole idea of allowing voice phone calls on flight is simply distressfull. What is often a nuisance in the everyday life would be quite a torture when trapped for hours in a crowed plane.

Title: Ani
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phone usage on flights. An airplane environment is very stressful to begin with. Please do not introduce a stimulus that will surely be the cause of friction between fliers. Heck, I'm afraid I'll fly off the handle myself if i am seated next to a nob-stop blabbermouth.

No cellular phones on flights!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phone calls on airplanes.  We are in too small of a space, with nowhere else to go and people speak loudly on their phones and people are inconsiderate.  I can imagine the conflicts that will arise between people on a flight regarding calls, and noise and how about content?  I don't want to hear a person's personal business or their workplace issues, etc.  Planes are one of the few places left on this planet where no one can reach us.  And that is a good thing.  Perhaps where it is quiet and you can read or take a nap or watch a movie on headphones. Please do not allow calls.  It is not imperative to do so. People can be unreachable for a bit of time.

Thank you for your consideration of my opinion.

Title: Kevin McLin
Comment: Flying has become increasingly unpleasant over the past decade or so. Enabling people to add to the noise and mayhem aboard an airplane by talking on their phones would only continue the trend. I hope the FAA will not relax its ban on in-flight cell phone calls.

Title: Stanley Trollip
Comment: Allowing cell phone calls in flight will lead to angry confrontations - because most cell phone users speak much louder than normal.  I think many travellers will bring radios or something similar to drown out the cell phone calls - then the planes will be akin to zoos.  I have no problem with people texting, as long as the alert is on low volume during night flights.

Title: Veda Ilagan
Comment:
I am in support of US DOT to propose a rule to ban voice communications on passengers’ mobile wireless devices on flights within, to and from the United States.  As a member of the traveling public, I believe the in-flight experience will be negatively impacted by allowing passengers to be able to verbally communicate on mobile wireless devices.  

Airplane cabins are a very intimate space and very often crowded.  Aircraft engine noise permeates the cabin.  Voice conversation noise on cell phones are elevated even in a quiet setting;  it will be even louder as the cell phone user will think they have to raise their voice to be heard over the phone.  Disruption of the passengers around the phone user will be inevitable, possibly leading to irritation, heightened tensions which could lead to air rage.  As well, passenger safety could be affected if phone conversation noise volume drowns out PA announcements by cabin crew.

Flight attendants will have to compete with phone conversations, which will compromise cabin safety in an emergency at worst or they will have to contend with irritated passengers on both sides of the issue which will impact the performance of their duties.

Technology is so advanced that there is really no need for voice conversations;  texting, emailing, or use of social media sites on the web are forms of communication that will not negatively impede on the peace of fellow passengers.  Banning voice calls in the aircraft cabin once the airplane doors are closed does not prohibit a passenger with a vital need to communicate from doing so as there are other technological alternatives;  banning voice calls in flight will, however, preserve cabin comfort and safety.

I urge the Department of Transportation to NOT lift the ban on use of mobile devices for in-flight voice calls.

Title: Karen Bieber
Comment: I am very opposed to people being allowed to talk on their cell phones while flying.  There is no need for someone to talk aloud - - - and loud - - - during a flight and bothering others who are trying to read, sleep, listen to a movie/music.  Many people object to having to sit near a crying baby.  Well allowing others to talk out loud on their cell phones ranks right up there in the category of NOISE and PUBLIC DISTURBANCE.

Title: Walter Chen
Comment:
Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft for the following reasons:
1) The crowded space and close proximity of the passengers would make this practice completely miserable for those who want to rest, read or simply prefer a quiet moment, being forced to listen to a loud voice calls from fellow passengers.  
2) It will also make restroom use out of whack if some passengers choose to stay in the restroom to complete their potentially loud and long voice calls with the good intention not to disturb others.
3) It will also make flight attendants' job difficulty when they're called upon to resolve the dispute between callers and disgruntled fellow passengers.

This practice may be allowed, however, if the call is extreme expensive so passengers will most likely only make short calls during emergency situations. This is the situation today as many airplanes offer voice call capabilities using phones from the back of the seats.

Nowadays, the mobile technology has allowed everyone to be connected all the times and everywhere and it's hard to find quietness in public places.  On airplanes, more and more airlines may enable Wi-Fi connection so people can go online during their flight, and therefore, VoIP calls are technically possible on some airplanes today.  Let's not make our flight experience any worse than it already is.

Title: Mark Greening
Comment:
Permitting use of mobile devices to make voice calls on aircraft would make flying on commercial airlines even more uncomfortable than it already is. Many people try to sleep or at least doze during a flight in an attempt to switch off from their cramped, unhealthy situation and their overly close proximity to other passengers. Listening to someone else’s (usually inane) conversation by phone is the last thing anyone needs.

If people want to communicate by e-mail or text then fine but trying to communicate by voice over a bad connection sitting in close proximity to 20 other people is going to be a source of annoyance to many. Currently we are allowed to use cellphones for voice calls while taxi-ing and this is fine as you know it's only going to be a brief call.

Title: N. Myers
Comment: Given the extreme close proximity of passengers to each other, I would be against allowing non-emergency phone calls while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No, No, No.  One only has to go to a movie theatre, restaurant, or even the gym, to get an idea on how many people would be inconsiderate in their use of cell phones in public.  Most cell phone users are not aware of how loud they are talking.  In certain settings one has a chance to move to another location for peace and quite, not so on a plane.

Title: Kathleen Henehan
Comment:
I travel quite extensively for work, and should the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft be approved -- I will immediately start looking for a new job that will not require airline travel.  In addition, I will likely curtail pleasure travel by air.

One result would be that a majority of travelers will start wearing noise-cancelling headphones . . . which create their own safety risks by preventing the passengers hearing any safety announcements or other important announcements.  

It's not hard to imagine what this would be like in a small contained space such as an aircraft -- even a jumbo jet.  We already know what it would be like -- just walk through a grocery store or department store, sit in a nice little sidewalk cafe, or even take a walk through the woods -- and you are inevitably assaulted by people talking loudly, shattering your own experience.      

I'm out!

Title: Anonymous

Title: Su-Jit DeSimone

It's already bad enough with kids playing videos and toys out loud, people watching videos without headphones, and more. We pay enough to be that miserable for a few hours ... why make it worse???

Title: Frank Hanrahan
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls from cell phones on airplanes.

Title: Steve Glischinski
Comment:

Title: William Schmidt
Comment:
I travel for business 3 or 4 days each week. This requires between two and four flights each week.  While I might occasionally find it personally convenient to make phone calls during the time I am on the plane, I am totally against this proposal to loosen the regulations.
It has been my experience over several years that more often than not, people making calls are either unaware or do not care that they speak in very loud voices.  In fact, in some cases if they spoke a little louder they wouldn't need their phones at all,.... their intended audience would be able to hear them no matter what the distance would be.

I am often engaged in work during my flight that involves either reading or word processing.  To be exposed to some else's overly loud conversation would be distracting to say the least.  If the conversation was to be especially long and/or loud it would prove to be annoying.

In restaurants and other public places I have approached very loud conversants to politely ask that they lower their voice.  Most of the time I am met with hostility as people seem to regard their constitutionally protected right to free speech to include the freedom to distract, annoy and irritate others.

I am afraid that on flight phone usage would lead to many confrontations as people argue this point.  Thank you

Title: F. Dobley

Title: John Hagen

PLEASE NO CELL PHONES in the sky.

Title: Janine Hardin
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on any size aircraft now or in the future. This means that passengers (except those in first class) are in each other's personal space for sometimes long periods of time.  Passengers are exposed to body odors, perfumes, halitosis, food smells, and annoying habits of those sitting in close proximity (e,g., nail biting, mouth noises, repetive involuntary movements/gestures, and drinking alcohol).  These scenarios add to the the potential of elevated anger and arguments.  There have already been incidents of violence wherein children crying has not been tolerated by certain passengers.  I have to believe that a phone conversations may have the same effect.  If voice calls are permitted on planes, it will only increase aggravation and will subject passengers to yet another annoyance and source of discomfort.  There is absolutely no advantage to allowing voice calls, except for the airlines' monetary benefit because they will likely charge passengers to use their phones while in flight.

Title: Hanna Hill
