Title: Cathy Hoch
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on flights. Sheer torture...

Title: Anne Maertz
Comment:
We've all been stuck on public transport or in a store hearing someone talk loudly and inanely on their mobile. ("Uh, yah, I'm at Target. Yeah. Uh huh.  Doritos or Cheese Puffs?" etc. etc)  What recourse will I have when I am trapped on a plane next to that person?  ("Uh, yah guess what?  I'm on a plane!  Yeah, I'm calling your from a plane.  Yeah.  Uh huh, Uh huh.  Oh.  no, no peanuts.  Nope.  Yep." etc etc etc  for 3 hours.)  

Please don't approve the use of mobile phones on planes, or at least require passengers to sit in a "phone zone" like there used to be for smokers.

in answer to the inevitable argument that businesspeople will be able to make more money if they can make phone calls on planes, here's a money-making opportunity for airlines: In Britain they have Quiet Cars on trains for those of us who don't want to listen to others' phone calls.  Consider something like on planes.  I would pay extra to sit there.

Title: Jan Rapheal
Comment: No way in hell should we have to listen to someone on a cell phone on a plane.  We pay for food, drinks, sit in tiny seats and now we have to listen to some else on the phone!  Please please do not allow this.  It will make for some crabby people - me being one of them

Title: Jamie Gordon
Comment: Thank you for taking the time to collect public comments. I am urging you to say NO to cell-phone use on airplanes. It is unnecessary and would raise the level of noise in close conditions in what is already a fairly noisy experience. I know this because I frequently travel by train for work (both Amtrak and local rail) where cell phones are not prohibited; it's a nuisance already there. Adding that additional level of noise to airplanes (which are usually cramped and louder) would be a problem.

Title: Betsy Feiker
Comment: The use of cell phones in public places has become another example of technology's downside.  A device that was designed primarily for emergencies and short-term convenience has become a mouthpiece for an increasing number of boorish louts who have nothing better to do than to air their personal business (usually at top volume) in the presence of other people.  I have observed this phenomenon with both interest and annoyance.  Why anyone would want to share his or her private business with total strangers is beyond me, but I'm becoming increasingly convinced that this behavior springs from feelings of inadequacy and insecurity along with arrogance and entitlement.  In an increasingly impersonal and technology-driven society, many people feel alienated and powerless.  So they try to find ways to feel less disconnected and more powerful.  And in a society which no longer observes (much less values) the practice of common courtesy, people have increasingly engaged in self-serving and arrogant behaviors.  It is at this point that laws need to be enacted in order to discourage (and hopefully) stop such behaviors.  Most people (even those who use cell phones in public places) respond to consequences.  Requests (verbal or written) are usually inadequate; a fine, however, is simple, clear, and easy to enforce.  It would be an effective solution to an increasingly out-of-hand problem.

Title: Vivian Ramalingam
Comment:
I believe that voice calls on aircraft should be prohibited. I do not wish to be held captive to unwanted conversations when there is no possibility of removing myself from them. It is clear that the result would be the same as cell phone conversations in the "quiet" cars on commuter trains. Regulations state that there should be no conversations in "quiet" cars, but these are regularly ignored by cell phoners who feel that the world is their living room, and the conductor is not nearby to enforce the rules. The practice in British "quiet" cars has been to loudly recite long poems into the ear of the rude offender. Unless the DOT and the FCC are willing to provide handy copies of "The Dream of Gerontius" to disaffected passengers, I think it is far more desirable to nip the abusive conduct in the bud and forbid it.
I have no objection to texting, as the present state of technology indicates that this activity would not interfere with the safe operation of the plane, at the same time allowing persons who need to be "in touch" their means to do so.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Ban cell phone use on ALL flights.

Title: Linda Shuhler
Comment: Please NO.  It is bad enough that we in economy have to deal with narrower seats and almost no leg room.  Sitting next to someone talking on a cell phone for seven or eight hours would be inhumane!  Most people speak louder on cell phones than they do on land lines, and there is nowhere for those who have to listen to escape.   It is almost impossible to read while sitting next to someone on a cell phone.  I know because I just sat next to a cell phone talker in the doctor's office.  For forty five long minutes, I heard every excruciatingly boring  detail of his broken arm while my book sat unread in my lap.  Please do not allow cell phone talking on planes.  People can text or email to their hearts' content, but no talking please.

Title: Duane Tash
Comment: No, it is a very bad idea. Individuals are already annoyed greatly with cell phones. Why subject individuals to being trapped in a plane with unruly cell phone users. It is absolutely ridiculous!

Title: J. D. Smith
Comment: I find cell phone use in public cafes and restaurants annoying. Loud users tend to drive me out. If I'm on an airliner, I have no "out." As it its, we are all subject to noisy conversations by thoughtless passengers. Cell phone use would multiply this, especially as some people think it necessary to raise their voices to be heard over the phone.

Title: Norris Williams
Comment: I do not want to have to listen to anyone talking on their cell phone while I am on the airplane.

Title: Kristin Kucera
Comment: NO NO NO! Allowing voice calls on airplanes would be HELL ON EARTH. We've done fine without them up to now, let's leave it that way. There would be no feasible way to tune out someone talking on the phone, annoying everyone around them. Unless you want escalating tension between passengers in an already stressful environment, PLEASE do not allow voice calls.

Title: Alex Horton
Comment:
NO NO NO NO!! First of all, what could possibly be happening that you need to have a voice conversation instead of just texting or e-mailing it? YOU'RE IN A TUBE 35,000 FEET IN THE AIR! WHAT CAN YOU POSSIBLY DO ABOUT IT??

Secondly, it's already cramped and loud in the cabin. Even if only 10% of the people actually use the phones during flight, that's 15-20 people (on a domestic flight) all trying to talk over engine noise, ambient noise, and now, 19 other jerks trying to do the same thing. And just imagine someone with a baby who has been having a difficult time with the flight, and after an hour of crying the baby finally settles down and falls asleep. Five minutes later some fool's phone starts playing the theme from The A-Team and wakes up the baby just so this guy can complain about his dry-cleaning bill from last week. Does anybody deserve that kind of punishment?

Finally, there are some unintended consequences. For example, when someone receives a number of phone calls in a short period of time, the recipient or those around them can commonly be heard to remark that their "phone is blowing up." Someone hearing that statement without the appropriate context could misinterpret the statement to mean something much more sinister, creating a major disturbance in flight. Imagine also the possibility of someone casually remarking as they board the plane "oh, I just know that as soon as we get in the air my phone is just going to start blowing up." Suddenly an innocent turn of phrase that this person has used probably 10 times that week has now made her guilty of a federal crime. 

Stop the insanity and ban voice calls on airplanes, and impose stiff penalties on those who would choose to ignore these rules. For example, have flight attendants warn passengers who try to make or receive calls ONE TIME. If they try it again, the attendant should be empowered to confiscate the device, through the rules the passengers agreed to upon purchasing their tickets. If a passenger refuses to turn over the device, the Air Marshall (or co-pilot if no marshall is aboard) should have the authority to physically remove the device from the passenger's possession and sequester him or her for the remainder of the flight, pending some kind of fines or other actions upon landing. If the passenger becomes combative, their actions would already fall under existing rules.

Title: Mary Farnan
Comment: I urge you to PLEASE NOT allow voice calls on aircraft.  It would be dangerous, disruptive, and cause interference to the job and responsibilities of the flight crew.  The use of cell phones in public places is a volatile enough issue without extending it to a closed in environment with no escape.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: this is a truly terrible and even dangerous idea, one guaranteed to elevate levels of anger and hostility in an already stressful environment.

Title: Patricia Manthey
Comment: I do not want cell phones next to me when I am on the plane.  I am not convinced that they are safe for take off and landings.  They are too loud and disruptive.  I would like peace and quiet.

Title: Lisa Raphals
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

As a frequent (economy class) business traveler I urge that mobile phone conversations not be allowed on aircraft.  It would add further discomfort to already passenger-unfriendly environment, and could easily lead to potentially dangerous conflict between passengers and between passengers and airline staff.  

Airline flights are already noisy and uncomfortable. There is no way for a passenger to leave if a neighbor engages in loud cell phone conversation.  Anyone trying to work, sleep, or must relax is out of luck.  Asking a fellow-passenger to stop risks conflict.  There are also issues for the well-being of children and the elderly.

An obvious option is to complain about a disruptive neighbor to airline staff.  The resulting distractions will add to airline staff workload, distraction and possibly even compromise passenger safety.

In summary, allowing ell phone calls on flights offers little benefit and much harm.  To conclude if Ariline A allows them and Airline B does not, guess which airline I will take.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I must ask that cell phone conversations continue to be outlawed on airplanes. This is to provide a basic level of decency for all who fly.

Title: Gerald Leeseberg
Comment: Absolutely not! People have little respect for others need for silence. All that yacking would drive me crazy not to mention that it would be hard to ignore the lack of any sane content in most of the calls. What if the person were to say something so nonsensical that I broke out laughing which results in the person being offended and possibly a retaliation (verbal or physical). I like to sleep on flights. Just keep people from yacking on phones so it is quiet enough that I can sleep.

Title: Donald Bell
Comment: I am firmly opposed to use of cell phones on aircraft from takeoff to landing for any reason.  There is no need to change an existing condition aboard already crowded and in close proximity to fellow ticket holders.  A ticket however does not entitle passengers to annoy everyone else.  No one currently is in any distress that phones can not be used.  I realize the airlines will want to allow the practice for it can become a new stream of income and fees.  I do not want to hear other passengers inane conversations or become part of their lives.  Too many cell phone users are oblivious of any sense of common courtesy.  Aboard aircraft now is a sanctuary compared to enduring endless chatter while waiting for a flight.  And just the rush to fire them up upon landing now is adequate communication.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please, please, do not allow people to make voice calls on commercial airplane flights.  It is bad enough getting trapped by things out of everyone's control  (i.e.screaming babies, uncontrollable children)  without being trapped within earshot of someone carrying on a loud (and it seems everyone speaks louder on a cellphone than when just conversing with a person in the seat next to them) conversation using a cellphone.  Text, people, text.
 
Thank you for this format for comments

Title: Anonymous
Comment: allowing cell phone use is a terrible idea and should not be allowed

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We already are subjected to loud cell conversations nearly everywhere, even where no cellphone use is posted in plain sight.  Some of these people obviously feel they are above the law and gabble on for long periods in loud voices regardless of signage.  The last place I want to be is cooped up in an airliner for hours with one or more of these arrogant self satisfied yakkers.  Screaming babies are like fingernails on a chalkboard but there is usually a reason.  Seat back kicking children can be dealt with.  Cell phone users think they are above the law and everyone wants to hear their side of the conversation.  In an airliner one cannot move far enough away to gain peace and quiet.

Title: Steven Leser
Comment:
I think Cell phone communications should absolutely be allowed on planes. There are a lot of annoyances when traveling on bus, train or plane. The benefits of communication, particularly in a situation when one has a family emergency at home, or urgent situation at work far outweigh the issue of annoying other passengers.

I think the rule should be that flight attendants should be able to tell passengers to turn off their phones if it is becoming a nuisance. 

A general rule prohibiting cell phone use is excessive.

Title: Jeannie
Comment: Please ban all cell phone calls on airplanes. Air travel is stressful enough (turbulence, unhappy babies, long flights, etc) without subjecting passengers to loud personal conversations or business deals. Imagine a full plane with 100 people or more talking at once! Allowing mobile phone conversations on airplanes (once the doors close until they are opened) is a very bad idea! If this regulation passes and phone conversations are allowed I will probably not be flying to my destinations opting to drive instead. Since I am handicapped, this would be a huge inconvenience for me resulting in fewer trips per year.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow unrestricted cellphone conversations on airplanes UNLESS the airplanes are willing to provide a sound-proof area for people to talk on cellphones - leaving the rest of the cabin a virtual "QUITE ZONE", a familiar concept on trains in Europe. It is so stressful to be subjected to disagreeable noise when one is incapable of removing oneself from the offending noise, which is the obvious problem on aircraft. People NEED RULES in order to behave in a respectful manner toward their fellow human beings - otherwise they are prone to provoke and push the boundaries of civility. We have all seen this again and again, and the promotion of civilized behavior on aircraft is, ultimately, a SAFETY ISSUE.

Title: K. Taylor
Comment:
I do not think it is a good idea. People with sense and consideration will not use phones even if allowed. Selfish people will and the entire plane will suffer because of the actions of a few people. 

Given that we've just had a shooting resulting from on apparent inconsiderate use of texting in a  movie theater, isn't there also the security concern that tempers my flare because of phone conversations? A plane is perhaps not a good venue for people to get into arguments.

Title: Kevin Buck
Comment: It would be a horrible idea to allow cell phone calls on airplanes. In other areas of life, if there is someone on an annoying call, you can walk away. Not an option on a flight. the close proximity to other people and not having the option of leaving the annoying user makes this an untenable idea. If airlines want to allow this, add another bathroom, make it soundproof and let folks talk there. We don't allow smoking on planes due to secondhand smoke. We should not allow cell phone conversations due to secondhand noise pollution.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls  on aircraft should not be allowed.  My reasons are: 1.  It would be very annoying to hear someone seated next to you talking on the phone all the time while one is trying to rest during a long flight. 2.  Those who talk on the phone cannot react quickly in the event of instructions from the cockpit or from the attendants for our cooperation. We are just not that gifted on multi-tasking.  3.  If everyone (550 passengers) are on the cell phones talking, the noise level would be unbearable! My suggestions is, if FCC does allow the use of mobile wireless devices for voice on aircrafts, only silent texting may be allowed, and no wireless devices allowed in the bathrooms!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002

I'm writing to ask that you please continue the ban on voice calls using mobile wireless devices on aircraft within, to, and from the United States.

I can see many potential problems with allowing people to use their phones on flights.  First, who would be qualified on a plane to decide if someone is talking too loud (or using inappropriate language among children) and being disruptive to those around them?  I think that places an unnecessary burden on flight attendants who are already stretched to the limit and whose primary concern should be keeping everyone on board safe.

Second, more people will be out of their seats during the flight, either seeking privacy for their call or because they like to pace and talk.  This will only make things more unsafe for all on board.

I think it's great that so many airlines now offer internet access while flights are in the air.  That should be enough.  I don't think very many conversations are so important that they need to be had while in the close company of so many strangers and can't either wait until landing or be conveyed via email.

I honestly don't see any positives with allowing voice calls to take place on flights.  Please keep our skies safe and quiet!

Title: Patricia Donnelly
Comment:
I do not want to see phone calls on flights when in the air. To be held captive in a crowd of people all talking would be annoying.  When you pay lots of money for a seat that you cannot change and sometimes for several hours would be terrible.

I am also afraid of what would happen if someone got so annoyed that a fight should breakout.

There is no need for someone to have to make phone calls when email and I assume texting is available.

Please do not expose captive passengers to the annoyance of a few.

Thank you,
Patricia Donnelly

Title: Peter Gray
Comment: Allowing voice calls on airliners is a terrible idea. Those using their phones will disturb other passengers and make it impossible for other passengers to get any rest. Use of mobile phones will inevitably result in conflict between passengers and even violence. Please do NOT allow use of cell phones for voice calls on board aircraft!

Title: Walton Kabler
Comment: I do not want to listen to cell phone conversations in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please please do not allow the unconstrained use of cell or wifi comm on board.

A plane is an aluminum tube that hold the radio frequency energy within it.

If 1/3 of the flyers were on the phone it would be 1) too noisy and 2)  too much EM energy.

This is no different than impacting ALL the flyers with the cigarette smoke of a fraction of the flyers.

We BANNED that. This will be a similar unhealthy situation.

Title: Peter Gray
Comment: Please do NOT allow the use of mobile phones for voice calls on aircraft! This is a terrible idea.  It will result in noisy aircraft cabins in which it is impossible to relax or sleep. Ultimately, allowing voice calls will result in conflict between passengers and even violence, which will threaten the overall safety of the flying public.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please please please no no no no!  Do not permit mobile phone voice calls.  Sheer torture for nearby passengers who have no option to remove themselves from this disruptive, annoying and stressful occurrence by self indulgent and inconsiderate yakkers.   Many people just have no clue how rude their behavior is to subject people around them to their loud and tedious conversations. 
Recovering after major surgery a few years ago, the patient with whom I shared the hospital room talked loudly and incessantly for hours on end on the phone (about her cat), making it impossible for me to get much needed rest. It was highly stressful.  As a result, I asked to be discharged the next day even though it was recommended that I stay another day or two for optimal recovery care.  As it turns out, the early discharge created another medical problem that required readmission the day after discharge.  None of this would have happened if I had not been subjected to such a intolerable environment in the first place by the clueless "roommate".

Perhaps there could be a designated small place on the plane for limited timed voice phone use (e.g. emergency conversations) but absolutely no way should they be allowed all over the plane.
Thank you for the chance to submit my view.

Title: Jeffrey Raposa
Comment: It will be terrible for passengers and crew.  Imagine sitting next to someone talking an entire flight?

Title: Johnny Hagen
Comment: I feel the use of a phone for talk communication is a terrible idea on an aircraft.  An aircraft is a small space and anyone having dialogue would be annoying to me.  I appreciate the calm of no open talk or music from a neighboring passenger.  Thanks.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I believe that allowing voice calls on aircraft would promote absolute chaos.  People are distracted enough with gaming, viewing movies, and myriad other activities while on the aircraft.  As a frequent flyer, I see people seldom give their attention to the flight attendants pre-takeoff briefs due to utilizing their electronic devices now.  The only saving grace is that it is pretty much contained to the individual.

If phone conversations are allowed....there could be a cacophany of anywhere from 50 to 200+ passengers speaking and THAT would disturb the other passengers around them as well as aurally blocking out important crew announcements during the various critical segments of the flights.  Passengers irritated by conversations of other passengers could potentially lead to increased altercations between passengers in the cabin that would lead to flights diverting for unplanned landings.

The crux of the matter is that phone conversations could lead to the disturbance of peace for the consumer that has purchased a seat on an aircraft and is subject to the multiple conversations of other passengers.

To allow cell phones on flights would be a terrible ruling.  Please continue to ban the use of cell phone on aircraft.

Title: Joanna Gilbert
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on aircrafts!  People are simply not capable of the level of courtesy needed to have cell phone usage tolerable

Title: Ross Bond
Comment:
Please do NOT allow cellular telephone voice calls to be made on commercial passenger carrying aircraft while the aircraft is in flight. On the ground while taxiing would be acceptable but not while in flight. The sheer annoyance value of inane chatter from other passengers would be excruciating in the extreme and would almost certainly lead to an uptick in passenger aggression. I pity flight attendants should such calls be permitted.

On the other hand, calls from flight crew should be permitted if the FCC determines that it is safe in technical terms to do so - there are often times when a quick call can be advantageous in operational terms - but limit this to flight crew only.

Texting while in flight (once again, if the FCC finds that this is technically acceptable) would not be an issue but voice calls certainly would.

Thank you for your consideration of my views in this matter.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: A bad idea.  Telling people they may use their cellphones in-flight will result in some feeling entitled to do so under almost any circumstance.  Allowing in-flight cellphone use will force cabin crews to police the use of cellphones (and make judgment calls on use and behavior).  Unlike on the ground, you can't walk away from someone in-flight.  Allowing in-flight cellphone use will make flying more dangerous to passengers and crew by allowing cabin behavior likely to incite "air-rage".

Title: R. Korting
Comment: Allowing use of cell phones on aircraft would be extremely disruptive to the general atmosphere on board aircraft and undoubtedly result in an increase of incidents that require the intervention of airline personnel and security officers. Flight conditions today are already stressful for most travelers and becoming more so each year. Why allow something that contributes another, perhaps the worst, stress factor in such confined places as aircraft?

Title: Henry Abarbanel
Comment:
Privacy on airplanes is not enforceable by moving away from a source of noise or irritation--such as cell phone users not respecting one's space. Communications via email should be sufficient for even the busyest business travels without inviting an audio invasion of the space of other travelers trying to read, sleep, think or whatever.

Please do not allow cell phone use on commercial aircraft in flight.

Henry Abarbanel
1110 Crest Road
Del Mar, CA 92104

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please, please do NOT allow cell phone conversations on airplanes.  I can only imagine the loud, endless, rude conversations which will ensue.  It will make flying more unpleasant than it already is.

Title: Tim Rose
Comment: I do not support the use of the voice aspects of cell phone communication.  Howevder, text and online services should be made available.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please don't allow the use of cell phones in airplanes. Crammed like canned sardines into a small metal tube I would rather not listen to anyone else's problems or inane comments. This may be public space but let's not pollute it any more than necessary for a safe flight.

Title: Keith Kleszynski
Comment:
Being in a pressurized tube for hours on end is bad enough.  I see how people react to my kids on planes so I think it is beyond reasonable that we DO NOT NEED to have cell phones used on planes.  Many people on planes like to sleep, quietly watch videos on their laptops, and read during flights.  I think people can be away from their cell phones for a few hours-it will not kill them.  I do not want to pay excessive fees, wait in long lines, and deal with the other vagaries of air travel to listen to someone blab on and on about company sales, the cute boy who sits in the back, or what so and so did last Friday night while flying.  Please do not allow cell phone calls on flights.
Thank you,
Keith Kleszynski

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Cellphone voice communications should not be allowed on airplanes.  Such communications would be extremely intrusive in the confined space of an aircraft.  DO NOT ALLOW.

Title: Peter Blomberg
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:

Flying is annoying enough these days with packed planes and little leg room.  Please do not add to the stress by allowing passengers to make and receive phone calls while in the air.  The last thing we need is some loud obnoxious salesman selling in the air or passenger trying solve a personal problem whose voices are impossible to ignore.   We need to maintain a little need a little peace and quiet in the air --- Please!

Thanks for listening and hopefully continuing the current ban.

Peter Blomberg

Title: Jeri Vargas
Comment: I am commenting on DOT-OST-2014-0002. My name is Jeri Vargas.  I believe that the policy on Cell Phone use should remain limited.  I understand that data has shown it safe to use cell phones on flights, On the other hand, it is definitely more respectful. People tend to be too loud; someone self-centered about their cell phone use in public.We have all experienced people in stores and restaurants, talking loud enough for everyone to hear; disturbing our own concentration.  By limiting cell phone use to only emailing or texting, it would preserve the modicum of personal space we all try to "enjoy" while flying.  As more seats are crammed into the cabin space, and fewer personal graces are valued and practiced by both airline staff and passengers alike, diminishing the opportunity for more stress becomes important to preserving the quality of the experience.  Rude people will continue to be rude, with airplane staff doing their best, but giving such people even more tools to be annoying with, will only make it worse. Please consider any change of policy with forethought: is it REALLY necessary to have more toys to communicate with in the air?  Isn't email access enough?  Decibel level in a confined space should be considered as an important aspect of this issue.  Let's not give sway to even more rude behavior!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please please please do NOT allow cellphone use on airplanes. Air travel is difficult enough with crying babies, crowded conditions, various odors of carried on food, inconsiderate people, carry on luggage too big to fit overhead or underseat,  etc. Please don't add to this by allowing a 'Tower of Babel' --we are captive audiences who will be forced to listen to numerous conversations at any and all times. Music and earphones and movie dialog won't be able to drown out the non-stop chatting coming from your seat partner or the loud voice behind you. And really, who wants to hear about the teenager's rant and the old man's hernia operation? 
Please spare us--if you can't get us wider seats that actually recline enough to allow sleep, at least prevent this potential disaster from happening. A man was just shot and killed in a theater for using his cellphone-- just imagine the aggression that will build up on a cramped plane with unlimited cellphone conversations and alcohol. 
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I fully support a ban on the use of cell phones etc. on flights.

Title: Ileana
Comment: Please please PLEASE do not allow cell phone conversations on an airplane.  We are literally TRAPPED up there for many many hours in the most uncomfortable seats...and now you want to subject us to 100 to 500 cell phone conversations???  I will STOP flying if it becomes any MORE unbearable!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Allowing the cell phone on air planes is the most ridiculous idea.  After the hustle to get to the airport and thru security, the some passengers would like to take a nap or listen to music or simply read. Talking on the cell phone would pierce thru the ears of the passenger sitting right next.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a terrible idea.  Please do not allow the use of phones for phone calls on the plane.

Title: Vaughn Hart
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phones on planes.  When people are on their phones in public they loose all sense of courtesy.

Title: William Powell
Comment: WHEN I TRAVEL BY AIR, I AM AIMING TO GET AWAY FROM THE NOISE OF REGULAR EVERYDAY LIFE.  I AM GREATLY OPPOSED TO HAVING TO RIDE IN A PLANE FILLED WITH PEOPLE TALKING ON THEIR CELLPHONES.  MOST HAVE NO SENSE OF MANNERS IN USING THEM, SPEAK TOO LOUDLY, AND DISTURB THOSE AROUND THEM WHO MAY WANT SOME PEACE AND QUIET.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  Stuck in your seat, there is no way to escape the invasive disruption caused by someone making a call.  Flying is unpleasant enough without the added irritation of a fellow passenger's loud conversation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am very opposed to allowing phone calls on airline flights. It would be very distracting to hear another's conversation and flights are already an unpleasant event.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I will be absolutely horrified if people are able to talk on their cell phones during a flight.  I don't want people droning on while I'm stuck there with no place to get away from it.  And what about people who want to sleep on the plane?  I also think it will cause fights and arguments between passengers.  It's a really bad idea!!!  Also, I would be reluctant to fly.

Title: Laura Hansen
Comment: Phone converstations should not be allowed. People on their cell phones tend to forget their environment and others around them. Few whisper and many talk very loudly.  It's annoying, distracting, and unnecessary.  If calls are to be allowed, there should be a separate place in the plane and calls should be emergency only.  Surprisingly, when I traveled by train in France there were signs that said no cell phone calls allowed in seating cars.  When someone's phone rang, they got up from their seat and moved to an area between cars to talk.  This was a good solution for everyone.  However, I am not sure that most people on airplanes have enough courtesy to respect other passengers.  There will be fights and flight staff will be put in danger.  I fly frequently and my worst nightmare is allowing cell phone calls.  I breath a sigh of relief when the plane door is closed and calls must be turned off!  Texting would be OK.

Title: Michael Nackley
Comment: No CELL PHONE use on Planes !!!! Bad enough we are saddled with all the extra fees from the Airlines , I refuse to sit next to a person talking for 3500mls on a cross country flight !!! We now have the term " Road Rage" , can we really expect less from the flying public when alcoholic , stress , crying babies & outrages fees all total into a new term for " Flight Rage" . This is a all around BAD idea .

Title: James Gorton
Comment: I'm fine with texts and e-mails, but NO VOICE!!

Title: Joyce Palmer
Comment: Please do not change the ruling that would allow the use of cell phones of any kind while the plane is in motion, either on the ground or in the air.  Very inconsiderate for other passengers and would cause many problems

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not permit the usage of cellular phones on aircraft.  Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please DO NOT allow cell phone conversations on airplanes!!  Cell phone callers when speaking into cell phones are typically loud and extremely invasive, disturb concentration when others are reading and prevent others from sleeping on the plane.  On an airplane, in a confined space, a traveler is unable to get away from an annoying, disturbing cell phone caller --- creating an extremely unpleasant situation for fliers who merely want a quiet atmosphere during their plane flight.

Title: Barry J. White
Comment:
I have been in the airline and travel industry since 1969 as a corporate staff member for Eastern Airlines (personnel
policy) and as an agency owner and manager (since 1974)..  Allowing voice calls by passengers on commercial aircraft
just cannot happen. NO. NO. NO!   Don't make us listen to people yacking on and on for hours on end. You might say
a two minute phone call to check on something is fine but it will not stay at that. If you want to put air marshals on every
flight to keep the peace, sure pass the measure. Otherwise, forget it.  At Eastern I handled many of the personnel related
complaints from passengers. The airlines will have to have dozens of people doing that job if you allow voice calls from
cell phones. Even texting can be annoying if they have the audible click feature on; it will drive you nuts. So please,
kill this idea now! Thanks.

Title: Diane Spargo
Comment:
Please please please do NOT allow cell phone usage on ariplanes.  Speaking as someone that rides a city bus to work, it is bad enough when someone is having a loud conversation on their cell phone then.  But on an airplane, it would be worse.  First of all, a bus ride is usually over in minutes, a plane ride is for quite a bit longer.  Secondly, it isn't as though we can just step off the plane is we cannot tolerate it.  Furthermore, the space in an airplane is so enclosed that the sounds travels.

We are already crammed into smaller seats, paying fees for things that used to be uncluded.  Please so not make use listen to cell phone conversations on top of this.

Title: Pat Arnesen
Comment: I am opposed to the use of the voice function on cell phones in airplanes. There is already enough collateral noise in a closed cabin (engine noise, voices talking, announcements, flight attendants moving about), that adding loud talking on cell phones will only add to the irritation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow passengers to speak on their phones while in flight.  If communication is absolutely necessary, a text can be sent.  While in the airport, I can physically remove myself from annoying talkers.  On the plane I have no such recourse.

Title: Bruce Albertine
Comment: Use of cell phones for voice conversation on airliners is a bad idea. The close proximity of passengers to one another means that every cell phone conversation would essentially become a group conversation, a conversation that adjacent passengers may not want to be part of. Telephone conversations should be limited to relatively private locations, even if those locations are merely pockets found in the midst of public activity. Live communication on airliners should be limited to text messaging. Please don't allow cell phone conversations on airliners unless those conversations are limited to a relatively private area somewhere on the aircraft, away from neighboring passengers.

Title: Kim Schneider
Comment:
I would like to vote that the ban on cellphone calls in flight remain in place.  I worked at a cafe for many years and quickly discovered that people have very different ideas of what they view as considerate/polite cellphone usage.  How many customers asked to move to another table because they could not carry on a conversation due to another customer's loud cellphone use at an adjacent table?  We lost count.  And volume is not the only issue.  The content of conversation is also a problem.  I recently had to move my children to another exhibit at the zoo because of the inappropriate nature of a cellphone conversation next to us.  

The point of these examples is twofold.  One, many people do not know how to regulate the volume or content of their cellphone conversations in the presence of strangers.  And two, the examples above show the need for those bothered by these conversations to move away.  The problem on an airplane is that there is no option to move away.  If you and your children get seated next to a passenger having an inappropriate conversation, you most likely are not going to be able to get up and move.   If the volume of the cellphone user is so loud that you can't sleep, you can't just move to a seat four or five rows back.  

Some may propose having separate cellphone and cellphone-free areas of the aircraft.  This would be similar to when planes had smoking and non-smoking areas.  Sound, like smoke, travels.

I believe that while allowing phone calls on flights may make some happy, in the end, the airlines will end up with far more unhappy customers.  Thank you.

Title: Roy Smith
Comment: I have trouble imagining sitting on a plane listening to 25 - 30 % of other passengers all talking on a phone. I occasionally ride a train and see people just yaking away on a phone for the entire journey because they are bored. I frequently observe people in a grocery checkout line that will not stop talking on a phone while dealing with the store clerk. Same in restaurants that will not stop using the phone when the waiter comes to take their order. OK, now let's imagine how many of these will stop and listen to an announcement by aircraft crewmembers. I foresee huge problems if this is allowed.

Title: Karen Olson
Comment: Use of cell phones should not be alloowed on aircraft.  There are many appliation available for receiving text messages over wi-fi, if someone needs to communicate with others while on a airplane.

Title: Kristin Williams
Comment:
March 26, 2014
VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION 
Department of Transportation 

Subject: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

My name is Kristin Williams and I am frequent flyer.  I believe that the DOT should not ban voice calls on flights.

Although many people have expressed concerns over courtesy, this issue could best be handled at the airline level. Once the use of voice calls is approved by the FAA and FCC the DOT’s Office of the Secretary should do the same.  

Considering this agency’s unique interest in consumer experience it may be necessary to take into account the opinions of all the publics that will be affected by this rule. As is indicated in your summary, the Association of Flight Attendants and Delta Air Lines passengers seems to overwhelmingly disagree with the idea of allowing voice calls. This is likely the most convincing reason to ban voice calls. 

That being said, banning voice calls could lead to an absurd end; voice call service would not be possible on any passenger flight in the U.S. Instead, the DOT should allow voice calls and leave the decision of whether to enable mobile communications to individual airlines.  Those airlines that choose to enable the communications through Airborne Access Systems can then choose how to regulate cellphone use during flights. Consumers would then be free to choose between airlines that have stricter regulations on cell phone use or airlines that do not allow their use at all.

Again, the DOT should not adopt a rule banning voice communications on passenger flights. The best way to accomplish this agency’s goal of serving consumers would be allowing the voice calls on flight, and affording consumers the opportunity to choose the airline that best aligns with their needs. 


Respectfully Submitted,

Kristin Williams

Title: Jeff Burke
Comment: I am for the rule to pass because, it will be a very effective defensive measure in the case that one who wants to cause harm to the passengers but needs cellular confirmation will no longer have that access. It is also very annoying when "bill from accounting" has to call his mom to come pick him up at the airport and I have to listen in to the entire conversation.

Title: John Neiswonger
Comment: Phone calls on a plane should be banned. This is because you are sitting around other people who do not want to listen to your conversation. Along with those people there are also people who are not comfortable flyers. These people are already nervous enough and may take something you say on the phone the wrong way and cause in needed havoc. "A recent survey found that prohibited electronic devices were the second most frequent cause of air rage among passengers behind alcohol…there are some people who are so annoyed by people talking loudly into their phones, that they would be just as happy if such devices were banned altogether." Says Sarah A. Downey

Title: Cameron
Comment: This needs to be put into effect for a few good reasons. First, it is disruptive to the other passengers when speaking aloud on ones cellphone. No one around you wants to hear your conversation, and they need their space. Second, there have been instances when calls cause a disturbance with communications between the airports and the airplanes which can lead to possible technical and flying problems. Electromagnetic interference can lead to serious problems such as crashing which is something that should be put into consideration when passing this. Calls can wait and are not that important, and therefore are unneeded on planes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Flyers are already subject to being treated like cattle on flights by the airlines, forcing them to be trapped having to  listen to those who would babble endlessly on a cell phone for hours seems to be cruel and unusual punishment.

Title: Steven Johnsen
Comment: I support the rule to ban of voice calls on cellular devices on aircraft because using voice calls can possibly interrupt land-based operations and can be very dangerous. Also, 81% of people and flight attendants agree talking on phones in flight should be abolished. Many people on cell phones on planes create a very disturbing and disruptive environment to other people. People on planes want silence and peace on planes. The DOT's mission is to serve the United States by ensuring a fast, safe, efficient, accessible, and convenient transportation system that meets our nations interests and enhances the quality of the American people. In order to achieve this, they must ban voice calls on planes to create a safe and peaceful environment. Permitting voice calls in an enclosed cabin space has the potential to drastically alter the publics experience. Representative Bill Shuster said "Airplane cabins are noisy, crowded and confined. Most passengers would like their flights to go by as quickly and as quietly as possible. Subjectively passengers to potentially multiple phone conversations... Would obviously diminish the comfort of any flight." The rule impacts others that fly on airplanes because they have had or will have an experience where someone will be talking on the phone next to us, and we found it to be very distractive, annoying, and disruptive.

Title: Alex Normil
Comment: I agree with this rule because as a person that flies quite a bit I would like for my plane trip to be as calming and relaxing s possible. Also, the "Association of Flight Attendants filed a comment  and replied that voice over internet or cellular broadband should be banned to reduce in-flight disruptions." As well as "Delta Air Lines also filed a comment stating that 64 percent of its passengers indicated that the ability to make phone calls in flight would have a negative impact on the onboard experience." All in all I think banning cell phone calls from flights shouldn't be allowed to avoid disturbances and other things that would make individuals flight experience bad.

Title: John Sheets
Comment: There is one issue with this mission, voice calls on the aircraft during flight. The proposed rule is trying to ban voice calls on flights. I highly agree with this. Flying is stressful enough for most flyers, so having to listen to potentially multiple people talk on their phones possobly in different languages would be completely stressful. On the other hand, I am very supportive of allowing texts, emails, facebook, etc. I think as citizens of the U.S. we have the right to use our mobile devices, respectfully. The only request that airlines should have the right to ask passengers is to not talk on their phones during the flight within the U.S. or to the U.S. No alternative, no phone calls.

Title: Stewart Haller
Comment: I support the proposed rule of banning the use of mobile wireless devices of voice calls on aircraft because the mobile wireless devices can cause harmful interference that the flight crew could encounter during flight. The passing of this rule would not only improve the protection against harmful interference for the flight crew, but it would also reduce consumer confusion, help improve administrative efficiency, and facilitate expanded access to broadband services in flight, such as Wi-Fi. Many passengers during flight, including myself would be effected by this because in the future, some studies have shown that by 2022, about 14,000 aircraft will be offering in-flight Wi-Fi. The only trade off to this proposal is the inability to use 3G or 4G in flight, which allows a wider variety of usage capabilities.

Title: Lindsey Pace
Comment:
March 26, 2014 
VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION
Department of Transportation
Attn: Laura E. Jennings, Senior Trial Attorney, Blane A. Workie, Acting Assistant General Counsel, Office of the Assistant General Counsel for Aviation Enforcement and Proceedings, U.S. Departments of Transportation. 
Subject: Comments on Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft, Regulatory Identification Number 2105-AE30 (February 24, 2014), Docket No. DOT-OST-2014-0002-0018.

I am Lindsey Pace, a first-year law student at UC Hastings. I previously lived in Washington DC but am a native Californian. As such, I have been exposed to the irritants of long trips on a plane. I believe that allowing unbridled voice calls on planes would be unfair practice to passengers but I believe that restricted voice calls would be best for both passengers and business. 
The OST derives the power to label practices unfair from 49 U.S.C. 41712 and says that an “unfair practice” is one that creates harm to customers from which they cannot reasonably escape. Although being in the tight quarters on aircraft carrier for a long period of time warrants difficulty in escaping unwanted sounds, a safe zone or earplugs can avoid the nuisance of voice calls for customers. 

By allowing recluse for customers opposed to voice calls, the OST can fascilitate the goals of business and customers. Allowing businesses to offer voice calls on flights limits puts the responsibility in their hands. Businesses and Congress are both responsive to the public. If businesses allow voice calls, angry passengers will force them to enhance or abandon the practice by way of economic impetus. Although the agency is responsible for the unfair practices of businesses, it would be unfair to ban a practice which is otherwise safe and allowable because it could create moderate discomfort. 

Respectfully submitted, 
Lindsey Pace

Title: Jim Dillion

My wife and I travel by plane several times a year.  We fly coach and generally our flights last four hours or more.  The seats on these flights are small and passengers are practically sitting on top of one another.  At times it takes the patience of a saint to deal with the behavior of some passengers who do not show common courtesy in dealing with their fellow passengers.  If airlines began to permit passengers to use wireless devices for voice calls during flights it would exacerbate the intimacy problems that already exist on todays flights.  The thought of someone sitting next to you, no more than 18 inches from your head, speaking on a cell phone is unacceptable.  Suppose you are reading a book.  How could anyone concentrate on reading while a cell phone user is speaking, again only 18 inches from your ear?  In any other environment you could walk away.  That is not an option during a flight.  Even one conversation would be an issue.  Imagine the cacaphony of multiple conversations going on simultaneously within ear shot.

Such an environment would not only result in even more discomfort for passengers, but I could forsee increasing confrontations between passengers and potentially causing physical harm.

Title: Anonymous

Title: Melissa Nebelsick

I am very opposed to the use of cell phones on aircraft!  There is absolutely no reason that we need to use our cell phones during flights!  It is one of the few places that I can be assured I won't have to be subjected to stupid conversations about someone's problem with a boyfriend, girlfriend or colleague at work, or worse, what restaurant they will be eating at when they land.  I am subjected to this "crap" on my commuter rail line all the time.  Fortunately, Metra has designated "quiet cars," but if you don't get to the train early, they are always already filled!  This type of arrangement is  not practical for a plane.

Frankly, if you allow cell phone conversations, you will be allowing people to violate my rights.  Crying children on flights give me a headache, but I understand accept this as a part of life.  However, cell phone conversations are not a "natural" part of life.  

I work in a very demanding industry and if I didn't get my calls made before the flight, it's my own fault and I should NOT have the right to subject my fellow passengers to have to listen to my issues.  Don't expect the public to be able to "police" themselves, as there is just a percentage of the population that is just plain rude and have no consideration of others.  I beg you not to allow cell phone calls on aircraft.

I would not put up with someone using a cell phone who was sitting next to me.  In all of the years of flying those those call were not necessary so why start trouble now.  The fact that passengers get out of their seats even before the plane door is open is unsettling.  Where are they going to go???  Thank You.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: no voice calls.  i do not want to be forced to hear people's very loud personal conversations.

Title: Pat Meehan
Comment: I oppose use of voice calls on aircraft.

Title: Maggie Loates

DOT-OST-2014-0002-0018

Title: Kathleen Petit

Comment: Most certainly not! The inanity of the majority of overheard phone conversations cannot be overstressed, and would probably be grounds for strangulation by the person's seatmate, not to mention anyone near attempting to sleep. Even if the (one-sided) conversation was fascinating (an extremely remote possibility), I would not wish to hear it: nay, no never. There is enough ambient noise on aircraft to make one uncomfortable, let alone howling infants or misbehaving children. Adding cell phone usage to this mix would be volatile, and certainly asking too much of everyone's store of good will. Allowing cell phone usage on planes is opening a Pandora's box of headaches and trouble for all, including the long-suffering stewardesses and stewards.

Title: Deborah
Comment: I am vehemently opposed to the use of cell phones on airplanes

Title: S. Steve Adkins
Comment:
I am commenting on DOT-OST-2014-0002.
 
Airline travel used to be elegant, comfortable and enjoyable.  In recent years, airline travel has declined to nearly the equivalent of cross-country bus travel.  Unlimited cell phone usage will complete the decline.  Often, I must use the flight time to sleep due to business schedules.  A center seat with two seat-mates on their cell phones will ensure no rest.  If I choose to read, work on business or prepare for a meeting/presentation, cell phone use by nearby passengers use would be highly distracting.  

Anecdotal examples:
1.  Cell phone rage:  On January 14 ,2014A retired policeman murdered a man texting his babysitter at a movie theater in Florida.  We cannot afford the risk that such event might occur on the enclosed space of an aircraft.
2.  In a restaurant, an old man using a cell phone turned to the teen-aged girls at the next table asking them to quiet it down so he could hear his cell phone. Will cell phone use have priority over quiet conversation on the aircraft?-
3.   "... CAN YOU HEAR ME NOW!"

I recommend that cell phone usage be allowed only under limited conditions:
- before taxiing
- while taxiing after landing
- inflight only for a short period upon announcement of a flight delay or terroristic threat
- while sitting on the tarmac awaiting unloading to call taxi, limousine service, wife, etc.

Regards,

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I support a ban on cell phone talking on aircraft except in the situation of an emergency on the plane itself. People tend to speak louder into a phone than they would in conversation. It's very distracting and usually boring to hear people's phone conversations. It disturbs those who want to read, nap, write, think quietly to themselves, etc. Texting with sound off would be okay.

Title: S. Broderick
Comment:
I am absolutely opposed to cell phone use on aircraft.  People are more often than not  loud and rude on cell phones and the aggravation of being forced to sit in close proximity to this would be unbearable.

Please be respectful of the special circumstances of being an airline passenger.  Increasingly flights are booked to capacity.  Seats are on the small side for most average Americans and it's crowded.  Often you actually have to touch someone (arms, shoulders, knees) when sitting in the middle row or in any seat next to a big person.  Having to endure the phone conversation of someone a few inches away from you is untenable - you're trapped and confined the duration of the flight with no control over the behavior of the person next to you, or near you across the isle or in front of or back of an offending cell phone user.  I've unfortunately had to endure listening to conversations (in the waiting area in the terminal) where the user had to discipline an employee on the phone - loud and emotional; I've had to listen to "thanks for last night" conversations; honey, what's for dinner; Joe I've got a great product here and you need to buy it"....ad nauseum.  I DO NOT want to hear anything - it's too close, too personal, and I have no ability to just leave.

Also bear in mind, please, that being "inconvenienced" for 1 or a couple of hours without being on the cell phone is not an unreasonable burden to bear in the interest of civil society.

Please protect the simple right to fly without going crazy.  Thank you

Title: Thom Weddle
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phones on airline flights.  Flying should be a pleasure, and this will not happen if the person in an adjoining seat is talking on his/her cell phone.

Title: Ryan Gramacy
Comment:
VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION
Department of Transportation
Attn: Laura E. Jennings and Blane A. Workie, Office of the Assistant General Counsel 
for Aviation Enforcement and Proceedings, U.S. Department of Transportation

Subject: 	
Comments on Proposed Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft 
79 Fed. Reg. 36 (February 24, 2014)		
Docket No: DOT-OST-2014-0002, 2014-03684

My name is Ryan Gramacy, and I am a law student at University of California, Hastings, College of the Law. I was recently introduced to the administrative process in my coursework, and this is my first public comment on a rulemaking. Thank you in advance for your consideration.

As a frequent traveler, I am interested in this ANPRM. In principle, I support a prohibition of disruptive PED ‘tele-conversations’ on aircraft, and believe that DOT has statutory authority to regulate such activity under 49 U.S.C. 41712. However, I am concerned that strict regulation—to the extent it will categorically prohibit tele-conversations—is unnecessary, and may foreclose more innovative solutions. Instead, if private airlines are permitted to experiment on this topic, the benefit to consumers has the potential to exceed the peace of mind of a blanket prohibition. My comments pertain specifically to DOT’s authority under 49 U.S.C. 41712 as well as questions (1) and (2) in the ANPRM.

First, I agree with DOT’s interpretation of 49 U.S.C. 41712, and the Department’s capacity to protect consumers from “unfair” practices in air travel. In promulgating the “Tarmac Delay Rule,” DOT was right to consider the harm to passengers that resulted from multiple hours waiting on the tarmac, a situation passengers could not reasonably avoid. By analogy, the potential for noise and disruption that courteous passengers would face if unregulated tele-conversations were permitted would generate a similar sense of anxiety. This is the psychological effect of unpleasant events outside one’s control or predictability—not knowing if one’s neighbor will engage in a cellphone conversation, for how long, and how obnoxious—a result that might not only lead to new ‘air rage,’ but lack of sleep, disruption of productivity, and general discomfort.

Second, in response to questions (1) and (2)  , I believe that regulation is, as yet, unnecessary. DOT notes that international airlines are already restricting conversations for the benefit of their crewmembers, and in response to market research. Given other public comments regarding the prospect of unregulated phone usage, these airlines appear to be making a independent business decisions to regulate tele-conversations. Freedom from regulation leaves open the possibility that other airlines will find niche markets (e.g., businessmen or socialites demanding phone access, or otherwise willing tolerate annoyance therefrom). These airlines may likely inspire a counter-model, reaching customers who want a reliably peaceful flight; or others airlines providing “quiet sections,” or limited tele-conversations in designated booths. My prediction is the latter model will become the norm, and airlines will compete over their innovation, marketing, execution, and ultimately, consumer satisfaction. 

There will always be demand for cellphone use, whether for emergencies, productivity, socializing, etc.. Questions remain, however, as to the extent of this demand, and how private industry will accommodate it. Moreover, the demand will likely depend on factors such as aircraft size, flight path, and hours in flight. As yet, given the relatively little information available on actual use and demand, it is not clear how DOT should proceed, or what form the public harm—if any—will take. DOT would be best to reserve its authority to regulate, and observe the industry models that develop over a trial period. Such restraint will enable DOT to promulgate rules under 49 U.S.C. 41712 which reflect the particular nature of the harms and unfair practices affecting the consumer—that is, if private industry is unwilling or unable remedy these needs independently.  

I hope the Department considers this comment in light of my shared interest in consumer welfare, and in providing the opportunity for innovative market-based solutions. As noted, I believe that DOT has statutory authority to regulate in this sector, and has aptly done so with previous rules. However, reserving this authority for a tailored solution would provide a greater public benefit, and avoid the costs of a preemptive prohibition.  

I appreciate your request for public comment, and I am grateful to have a system that is so transparent and accountable, yet efficient. Thank you again for your consideration.  


Respectfully submitted,
 
Ryan Gramacy

Title: Joan Cwi
Comment: No, nope, nah, no way, nix, non, nein, nyet!  Personal space on planes is so intruded upon already, spare us this.  Let people text, but not talk.

Title: Ted Bucholz
Comment: If cellphones are ever allowed on an aircraft that will be the last flying our family will ever do.  And that is the same feeling all my friends have.

Comment: There are already enough reasons to not fly, but allowing cell phone use would make it difficult to decide to fly.  I am retired and I used to fly quite a bit for business purposes.  I cannot imagine sitting in the center seat and having both people on either side of me on a cell phone conversation.  It's a known fact that people tend to talk louder than they need to.  General talk between passengers usually becomes a mummer. because most of them talk in a soft voice.  But a plane load of cell phone users would make a flight very uncomfortable.  Texting  would be ok, but talking would not.

Title: P. Ramos
Comment: docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002, FAA/FCT/DOT - I have recently heard that these govt agencies are considering lifting the bank on cell phone usage on US flights.  As someone who flies regularly for business, I am very opposed to this.

Title: Lydell Dupree
Comment:
PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW CELL PHONE CONVERSATIONS.
If there was a way to allow texting for those who must communicate, OK. As it is, airlines are just getting connectivity with the internet. We should see how that goes for awhile. It will allow those who must be in communication that avenue. This is still so much in it's infancy, it may resolve those who need to be in-touch with their love ones, or there not so loving ones.
But don't subject everyone else to that. We all experience enough TMO while we stand in line for anything with people who drone on about nothing, with little discretion.

I am often embarrassed, being a member of the human race, at how inconsiderate, rude, and obnoxious people can be. Many people can't figure out that carrying everything that they own onto the plane is wrong, and really bumping (crashing) into everyone as they go down the aisle. They don't realize how disruptive they have been, as they never apologize.

Sometimes, those final 10, then 5, then 1 minute to shut off their phones is already enough. To sit anywhere around those people who love to hear themselves talk, it would be way too disruptive. So please, save us from ourselves. Ever heard the statement, help me I have opened my mouth and I can't shut up!

There are many reasons why travelers look forward to a short, or long flight to chill out. Let's keep what little enjoyment there is left with flying; don't change the no cell phone policy.

Thank you very much.

Title: Walt Parker
Comment: PLEASE do not permit voice use of cell phones on planes.  IT would be annoying !!!!!   I have no problem with other uses: texting, email, web surfing etc.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I heartily disagree with having cellphone use on planes.  These environments are too small and too tense, and phone calls will put some people over the edge.  There is no escaping the individual who is not intentionally loud but too loud just the same.  One cannot just get out of seat and wander the plane to escape the noise.  We already have air rage events and allowing more cell use will add to them.

Flight attendants have enough passenger behaviors to cope with--I can see this as another item the airlines have to train their staff on--airlines have low enough profit margins that this will just add another burden.

It's interesting to watch people who open their phones the second the planes touches down and are on calls (and not retrieving overhead luggage) so they can verify their arrivals with their pick-up people.  I even find this annoying--if everyone paid attention, we could all get off the plane sooner and be in-person with the people that are being contacted on the phone.

Cell phones are allowed on Amtrak (which is much less tense and more spacious than an airplane) and that hasn't turned out well--there is always someone who has to talk too loudly, for too long, or play a loud game.  Sometimes, loudness is not a matter of the user's intentional rudeness but angering just the same.  Amtrak's "quiet car" is acceptable for trains with more than one car, but planes don't have separate sections--it's all one!

I love the story of the former Bush NSA director, Gen. Michael Hayden, saying too much on a train--and then this was reported on the nightly news.   http://news.yahoo.com/former-nsa-chief-caught-spilling-secrets-on-amtrak-212959722.html    

We used to let people smoke on planes and that wasn't such a bright idea and we had to reverse that--for physical health reason.  I think I'm old enough to say that if we do allow cell use in flight we will end up having to undo it anyway--but this time for mental health reasons!  Why waste the time?  Mobile use ... No!

Title: John Gordon
Comment:
I am a lawyer in Minneapolis, MN, who travels frequently, both for business and pleasure.  I urge the DOT not to change its rules so as to allow commercial airline passengers to use cell phones or other voice-transmitting devices.  

Traveling as a passenger on a commercial airline flight is already enough of a getting-to-know-you experience.  We are crowded in together in uncomfortably small spaces with uncertain air quality.  Being forced to listen to others' personal or business conversations on mobile phones impinges on our personal space and assaults our autonomy.  It is not dangerous or unhealthy.  It's simply unpleasant.  Very unpleasant.  It is far worse than overhearing face-to-face conversations because all of us, unsure what the other participant(s) in the conversation can or cannot hear, have a hard time modulating our volume when we are talking on cell phones.  In other words, we tend to shout.  I estimate that when two coach passengers are sitting in adjacent seats, their faces are about 18-24 inches apart.  That's way too close to someone I don't know when they are bellowing into their cell phone.

Moreover, there is no need for such oral communications.  Most younger passengers not only accept texting and emailing as adequate substitutes for voice communications, they prefer non-oral communications.  In other words, banning voice communications does not cut passengers off from the rest of the world.  It only requires them to use more modern forms of communicating, like texting.

Finally, I predict that extensive use of cell phones will reduce civility on airplanes and lead to many more altercations among passengers and between passengers and crew.

Thank you for accepting my comment.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please continue the ban on the use of cell phones on flights. Cell use would infringe on other passengers' right to quiet in a confined space

Title: Anne Newman
Comment: Plane travel is already stressful enough. As someone who rides the bus daily, I am painfully aware that people talk more loudly on cell phones and do not have any idea of their conversations' impact on the people around them. On planes, we already have people in confined spaces - often in bad moods. Adding in something that is experimentally shown to be annoying and difficult (if not impossible) to tune out can only heighten the tension. I cannot imagine any benefit to having people around me talking on their phones during flights and I can easily see a confrontation starting when someone wants someone else to quiet down or hang up and they refuse. Please keep a little bit of peace on planes!

Title: Judith Dobkin
Comment: i am against the use of cell phones during flights.   an airplane is not an office - it is a means of transportation which accommodates a large number of people of differing sensibilities to noise.  one can only image the disagreements and arguments which would break out if passengers were allowed to speak on their cell phones - & one should also consider the on-board staff who would have to referee arguments.   PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW SUCH A PRACTICE.   thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not let passengers use cell phones on aircraft. As I do not wish to hear others' discussions, it constitutes an assault on my personal hearing space and interferes in my enjoyment of the flight.  On land, I can walk away from cell phone conversations; on an aircraft, that's not possible.  Thank you.

Title: James Lemieux
Comment: I support Senator Lemar Alexander and Senator Diane Feinstein's request to the Dept. of Transportation to not allow cell phone conversations on airplanes during flight. I would go a step further and not allow cell phone conversations until passengers are off the plane and in the terminal. Being a passenger  is already a very tense and unpleasant experience for most people.  Allowing passengers to use cell phones will make a generally unpleasant experience worse.  We don't need this.  Please don't allow cell phone use on airplanes. Thank you.

Title: Colin Brown
Comment: A total ban of cell phone calls during flights is the only way to offer everyone on board a plane an enjoyable experience. Well, enjoyable as today's flights are capable of offering. If you allow bothersome phone conversations, you might as well allow smoking again. Or sex in the seats. Or drunkenness. All of these might make some people very happy, but would be a nuisance for the rest of the travelers. The freedom to a relatively peaceful flight trumps the supposed need of passengers to engage in what is most likely frivolous and loud phone conversations. In short, when it comes to phone calls in flight, it can wait.

Title: Sandy Goepfert
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on airplanes.  I enjoy the quiet time.  Most people speak louder than necessary on cellphones.  Why change a good thing!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Thank you for asking for passenger input. I believe that cell phone calls are quite disturbing in small enclosed spaces and should not be allowed to be used on planes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am saying NO, NO, NO to voice calls on Aircraft..people have plenty of time to talk before and after their flight..

Title: Aleeca Bell
Comment: Do not allow passengers to talk on their cell phones. Listening to people talk on their phones within an aircraft, no matter what time of day, would be extremely annoying.

Title: McIntyre
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002

In my opinion voice calls on an aircraft would not be a good idea. Years ago cell phone usage while flying on a plane was an issue due to wireless communications and problems that can arise out of cellular interference. Although with time, some of these problems can be minimized with more study and developments on how to control issues pertaining to tower interference, it is believed that additional problems will arise. Problems can include costs on developing such programs to block certain usage, deciding on who's usage to block, determining whether blocking is necessary at all, deciding whether technology has improved to where the same problems from in the past are still present today, whether cell usage will affect the passenger; the list can go one for days. I believe that changing rules to allow cell phone usage causes more problems than necessary. In a way it is looking at whether what is being desired outweighs the issues that will arise out of allowing what is desired. If it's going to cost more to allow cell phone usage to no benefit than it is not necessary. Besides, if you say it will be for emergency purposes only, who decides what an emergency is? Furthermore, people tend to speak louder when speaking on cell phones. An airplane is but so large and can accommodate only so many people and their desires. No one really likes to ride a subway, bus, train, or be in any confined area next to someone who has no cell phone etiquette who is talking loudly about something no one cares to hear about. Asking that person to quite down normally causes a disturbance and the last place you want to be confined where people are throwing punches at each other is on an airplane.  Besides the confinement on an airplane itself, restricts you from doing many things that you could normally do on ground transportation. If someone calls you on an airline with an emergency stating that they need you right away, there is nothing you can do (within reason) except wait until you land. For these reasons (I'm sure I can give more), I don't think voice cell phone usage is a good idea for airplanes.

Title: B. A.
Comment:
BAD IDEA..........NO CELL PHONE USE ON AIRPLANES....EXTREMELY ANNOYING TO OTHER PASSENGERS LISTENING TO OTHER PEOPLES LOUD CONVERSTIONS ABOUT THEIR LIVES ETC.....

PLEASE DONT ALLOW PEOPLE TO USE CELL PHONES ON FLIGHTS....THE WHOLE PLANE WILL BE FILLED WITH LOUD DISFUNCTIONAL CONVERSATIONS.

THANKS.

Title: Tim G.
Comment:
I suggest ruling to NOT allow voice calls on airplanes.  The call would be disruptive and disturbing the the other passengers as well as the crew. I fly for both personal and business.  

I consider the time on a plane (once on the plane) as separate "away" time where I can focus on work, reading, watching a movie, etc.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
On Amtrak, there is a "quiet" car, where no cell phones are allowed.  It is heaven.  You can sleep, you can read, you can do your work quietly and without distraction.  I took a trip where there was no "quiet" car option and had to sit for FOUR HOURS listening to the man in front of me talk nonstop on his cell phone.  It made the trip excruciating.
Please DO NOT allow cell phone usage on airplanes.  There is plenty of noise already (engines, babies, the occasional seatmate who wants to chat) without adding 200+ phone conversations to the mix.  
And for the business traveler, this is sometimes the ONLY time where we are able to be "out of reach" and it is a well-deserved (and much anticipated) respite from the constant demands of work.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: What a terrible idea.  When i get on a flight i do not want to hear someone elses conversation, i.e. jibberish when I am confined to a small living space and i applaud Delta for deep sixing the idea.

Title: Christine Vittoe
Comment: I am totally against using cell phones during a flight.  Don't let passengers suffer with listening to other people talk loudly on a cell phone about nothing.  No texting either--what's the point?

Title: Bob Rowlands
Comment: I feel that allowing talking on cell phones on airplanes would be extremely disruptive to passengers. I have no problem allowing texting or emailing as a means of communication but those mediums do not cause a verbal disruption to nearby passengers.

Title: John Vittoe
Comment:
Please don't subject airline passengers to the babbling of people on cell phones. Why can't people just read a book or sit with their thoughts for a few hours. You will force airline employees into the role of "phone police".  "Guess where I'm calling from?" will be unbearable.

No texting either.

Can you imagine trying to get some sleep on a cross crountry flight?

Title: Ann Rowlands
Comment: I do NOT want to see the allowance of talking on cell phones on planes. There are too many people who have no manners when using a cell phone. Using a phone for texting or emails is fine.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE, don't allow this! It will violate what little bit of peace and quiet passengers have on a plane. Texting would be all right but voice calls would be awful.... Please don't do this!!!!

Title: Susan Drelicharz
Comment: I fly over 50K miles per year for business and personal travel and I overwhelmingly oppose the allowing of cell phone calls by passengers on commercial jets.  Allowing in-flight calls would lead to a greater likelihood of passenger conflicts and "air rage" than you have today, and flight crews already have enough to deal with.  If people want to stay in continuous contact with someone by cell phone, they should drive rather than travel by air.

Title: Debbie Pastors
Comment: There is no place to escape from someone talking on a phone when you are in the cabin of an airplane.  No one is going to suffer great harm if s/he is unable to use a phone for speaking for the duration of a flight. If someone absolutely MUST be in communication with someone not on the flight, they can opt for text or email.  These are quiet and will not disturb others.  Given the existing stresses of travel already, we do not need to add to that stress by allowing spoken calls on airplanes.

Title: Michele Van Swol
Comment:
To allow people to make phone calls during a flight would be a horrible idea.  With people practically sitting on top of one another as it is, no one wants to be subjected to other people's conversations for an entire flight, no matter how short the flight is.  And if you put a talker next to a non-talker, people can take being annoyed for only so long and we'll need to coin a new phrase for the result: flight-rage?  air-rage?

My husband, who flies frequently for business, uses this time to catch up on work on his laptop. His time in the air is sacred, as once he lands, he's in a car driving to his location and then stuck in meetings.  

Do not change this rule.  There is no compromising on this.  Cell phones should never be used for phone calls on flights, for any reason.

Title: Reggie Marshall
Comment: Allowing use of cell phones during flight is a horrible idea.
