Flying is hard enough these days and having to listen to everyone around you's private conversations throughout the flight will just make it more unpleasant.  People can go a couple of hours without talking to anyone on their phones.  It won't kill them.

Title: Jan L.
Comment: ABSOLUTELY NOT!

Title: Peter Conover
Comment:
I'm just an average traveler, but feel very strongly that passengers should not be able to use cellular telephones while in flight, even if it has been determined that such use will not interfere with the planes safety.

In the US and throughout the world, many train companies have introduced "quiet cars" where telephones, music, and conversations above a low-level are not permitted.  Like the trains, if it were possible to separate a section of plane where those that wanted to talk could do so without disturbing those who do not, then I would have no objection.  

However, as planes are currently configured (and will likely be for the foreseeable future) such a separation is not possible - just as there was no real way to separate smokers from non-smokers, which of course led to the complete no smoking rule on aircraft.  The seating density on planes is higher than on most trains or busses - a single person's phone conversation, even if spoken in a low voice, could easily be overheard by literally dozens of surrounding passengers.  Further, the current state of travel, especially in coach class, with tight seating and competition for limited luggage storage space (even more severe since the implementation by the airlines of checked baggage fees) often leads to impatience, intolerance, and hostility between passengers who otherwise have benign personalities.  I fear that being forced to listen to a fellow passenger's unlimited phone conversations would cause even more distress than that already inherent in plane travel.

After the sometime difficult process of boarding a plane, rather than feeling cut off, I believe many of us look forward to the hours en route as a brief respite from the outside world.  With wifi capability coming to many planes, if a passenger really must communicate with the outside world, e-mail and texting is most certainly a viable, courteous, and silent option.

Title: J. Jones
Comment:
re:  DOT-OST-2014-0002
The use of cell phones (or any other current or future technology) to make voice calls while on commercial flights should be banned.  Use of cell phones (or other current or future technology) to silently send/receive texts or email could be allowed, if in-flight communication is desired.  Even if it is found that the use of a cell phone to make voice calls is not a disruption of the electronics or mechanics of the airplane, it is definitely an unfair disruption of the passenger environment on the aircraft.   "Given the cramped, close conditions in aircraft and the inability of passengers to avoid" overhearing other passengers' cell phone conversations, the consumer would be subject to a greatly diminished flight experience.

I know from my own experience that I sometime speak more loudly when on a cell phone, and I can get engaged in the phone conversation to such an extent that I do not realize how I may be impacting others in the area.  I am generally a nice person and if someone points this out to me, I apologize and get off the phone or leave the area.  However, if someone is stuck in the airplane seat in front or back of me with the seat belt light on, they may not be able to signal me to stop and I may not realize that I am being disruptive.  And I can just imagine how disruptive it would be if numerous people on the plane were all talking away on their phones!

I also know from my own experience that some people speaking loudly on their phone, perhaps fighting with their boyfriend, (sometimes even using very coarse language) can get very combative if asked to please be more quiet.  So rather than risk a confrontation, most will just leave the area.  You can walk away in the aisle of the grocery store, but there is nowhere to go in an airplane.  This will just add to the stress in the plane and may lead to confrontations between passengers and/or flight attendants.  This is not the type of flight experience that passengers or crew members should have to endure.  It would be unfair to subject consumers to this!

Title: Elaine Guillot
Comment:
I am against the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft. I feel we are already inundated with people speaking on cell phones, no matter where you go. People on cell phones seem to speak louder than people on ordinary phones, and an entire one-sided conversation can be overheard whether you want to or not.   In grocery stores, department stores, and in restaurants, one can walk away from the annoying chatting. In an airplane, this in not possible; you are stuck. While flying on an airplane, many people take the time to nap, finish a project, write,do crosswords, read, or just relax. There are many other activities in which a person can become engaged if he/she is bored. Not to mention, chatting with an amicable seatmate. 
Please, no cellphone chat on airplanes! Thank you

Title: Judith Koodin
Comment:
Allowing the use of cell phones to make telephone calls on planes will be disruptive to everyone on the aircraft with the exception of the call maker.  There are enough distractions to reading, quiet conversation and/or sleeping on planes that this will just make the flights intolerable.
I can just imagine people arguing about the loudness of their neighbors voices, the length of time they are on the phones and the disruption that they are causing.  I anticipate more arguments and more stress for flight attendants as they try to deal with unruly, angry passengers.
I hope that you will help to prevent this from happening.

Title: Anita Madison
Comment:
I am a 2 million mile flier so spend
 quite a bit of time on planes for business.  The worst thing an airline could do is to allow cell phone conversations.  Please do not allow this

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow talking on cell phones.  Allow only texting or emailing.   I've had people behind me just talking to the person next to them and they are speaking in a very loud voice. When a person speaks on a cell phone, some have the tendency to raise their voice.  Please, I want to enjoy my flight!

Title: Pat Yeakley
Comment: Flying is aggravating enough, without having a person yacking on the phone while we are trapped on a plane with him or her.. I wish they'd stop them on trains too.

Title: Jacqueline Schuster
Comment: The use of cellphones on airplanes is a terrible idea.  It would be a severe intrusion of privacy.  It would be noisy & distracting.  People can live for a period of time w/o having to use their cellphones.  Not only would calls be annoying to others, but equally annoying would be texting.  It' bad enough to put up with cell phone callers in public places such as doctor offices, retail stores, parks, etc.  On airplanes?  DEFINITELY NOT!!!!

Title: William Revelle
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to the use of cell phones on aircraft. I can think of no economic benefit to increasing the discomfort of the flying public by allowing for the use of cell phones on airplanes.  The use of email or web browsing is quite enough.  To allow individuals to talk on cell phones will inevitably lead to conflict  as people disturb their neighbors by talking on their phones  as others try to sleep or to  get work done.  

Emotional tension is high enough on flights as it is.  To unnecessarily increase the tension is a hazard to flight safety.  

There are already enough rude passengers who make the experience uncomfortable for flight attendants and the other passengers.  To allow such people the opportunity to talk on cellphones would be a terrible error.

I would rather fly next to a small child who occasionally cries than to sit next to a passenger talking on a cell phone.

Perhaps allowing cell phones in a designated area (e.g., the back of the plane) separated from the rest of the passengers would be acceptable, but that region would need to be separated by a bulk head from the rest of the passengers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am AGAINST allowing cell phone calls on airplanes above 10000 ft. The use of cell phones once a plane has landed is already annoying as everyone making a call speaks very loudly and doesn't care about bothering other passengers and to allow the use once a plane is above 10000 feet will only be a bigger inconvenience to passengers near someone making a cell phone call.  

Thankyou.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am against  the use of cell phones on planes since this would be an annoyance to fellow passengers.  Often cell phone users speak loudly into the phone to be heard.  Having a plane full of people talking on cell phones would be terrible.  There is no where to go on a plane for any peace and quiet.

Thank you for taking my opinion into consideration.

Title: Michael Scaggs
Comment: As a frequent flyer for more than 30 years, allowing in flight cell phone calls would make what is already hard to bare, even harder.  Flying is stressful enough.  No calls should be allowed save for emergencies.

Title: Phyllis
Comment: I am against allowing use of cell phones on airplanes.  People talking on cell phones in public tend to speak very loudly; they may not realize it.  We do not need to hear their conversations.  There are enough distractions and noises on cell phones.  I don't think people should be allowed to text either.  Terrorists could text each other while on a flight, putting passengers in danger.

Title: J. Lambert
Comment: Absolutely no voice calls. Text is okay.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no.  Seating is so close and I fear hearing all about my row mates, in many different languages!  How can we relax, read, listen to music or watch a movie?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I travel five or six times a year and would HATE to be subjected to a person talking on a cell phone.  Please don't allow this.

Title: Jackie Gustafson
Comment: As a frequent flier I am vehemently opposed to this. Can you imagine 50 conversations taking place on top of one another?

Title: Paul Zech - Comments
Comment: Please add me to the list of people who flight frequently (10 to 15 round trips per year, nationally and internationally) for both business and pleasure.  I have absolutely no interest in having the passengers who surround me subject me to loud an constantly annoying chatter on cellphones.  There is virtually nothing that is so important that it requires a telephone conversation while in flight.  With the allowance of emails, that is more than sufficient communications.  I do not trust the airlines to hold firm agains this blight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Opposed

Title: Janet Goldstein
Comment: NO, NO, NO! Air travel is unpleasant and noisy enough without having to listen to one's fellow passengers yakking on and on.

Title: Marty P.
Comment: Please do not allow voice. Some people just can't handle being courteous or responsible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please no phone calls on planes. Amtrak and bus passenger have long, annoying phone chats, and it's unpleasant to be around. People can survive for a few hours in a phone-free setting. Really, we can

Title: Sunshine Elkface
Comment: I DO NOT want cell phone access on planes.  It is bad enough when people use them in restaurants.  DO NOT ALLOW

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I object to allowing cellphones to be used for voice calls while flying.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Do not allow voice calls on airplanes!  The noise level would be excruciating and disruptive.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am 100% opposed to allowing persons to make cell phone calls on commercial aircraft while in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to allowing mobile wireless voice calls during flights on commercial aircraft.  Allowing voice calls would often be significantly annoying to other passengers and an invasion of their space, diminishing their ability to read, work, enjoy personal entertainment (e.g. a movie) or simply rest.  This annoyance will translate into tension between passengers, cabin personnel being asked to handle disputes, and inevitable conflicts -- all things to be avoided in the small and safety-relevant confines of an aircraft. 

The above situation exists, of course, in many public settings.  However, an aircraft is different in that effected passengers cannot leave the aircraft nor is it typically possible for them to even relocate away from the offending caller.  It is also the case that people typically speak more loudly than normal when using mobile phones in public areas due to background noise. This situation will be exacerbated during in-flight calls since background noise levels are relatively high on in-flight aircraft.  Such a situation will result in an unreasonable intrusion to all passengers within earshot of the caller.

Commercial airlines should be prohibited from allowing mobile wireless voice communications during flight. 


NOTE: The above discussion does not apply to the use of non-voice WiFi on aircraft, which will improve the passenger experience for many and not effect those choosing not to use it.

Title: Joyce White
Comment: I am a frequent flyer and do not want to see the prohibition against cell phone calls changed. Flying is stressful enough without the addition of the loud talker who wants everyone to know how important he/she is. Its bad enough having non-stop talkers sitting near you, without adding cell phone calls to the mix. However, people can text all they wish - and it would not bother me. Thank you.

Title: James Chang
Comment:
I am 100% oppose to use mobile wireless devices for voice calls on domestic and international flights. Flying is stressful and I do not want to listen to any passenger talking on their mobile devices on the plane. I fly over 150,000 miles per year and I use the quiet time on the plane to work on my laptop, read or just relax. 
Thank you for considering my opinion.
James Chang
Edina, Minnesota

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please consider not allowing cellphone use on air travel even if it is safe.  Most flights are long in duration and adjoining seat occupants cannot get up and move away from the user like on the ground.  A traveler's comfort has deteriorated (pay more for less) in recent times and this would be one more situation to add to the list.  One could argue for limiting the length of the calls (as well as the number made) but this would be one more thing flight attendants would have to deal with.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please, please do not allow voice calls on any phones during commercial flights. Air travel is already uncomfortable and stressful. I do not want the added annoyance of hearing one or more cell phone conversations during a flight. Hearing cell phone conversations during a flight would add to the uncomfortableness and stress of air travel. Please do not allow it. Thank you.

Title: Richard Olsen
Comment:
NO, please, NO!

As we were waiting, to taxi, on a flight out of LAX, my seat mate, was engaged, loudly, in conversation with his soon to be ex-wife.  Oh, God help me was all I could think, as I was being subjected, one inch away, from an angry man, as he displayed his personal life, for all to hear.   Again I say, please, no.

Title: Penny Olsen
Comment: Please do not allow the use of cell phones on airplanes.  Some passengers can be inconsiderate to the point of being rude, while using their cell phones.  For some reason, they feel compelled to speak much more loudly than they normally would. This can subject those around them to an uncomfortable situation. Please don't allow this to happen to us, especially when we are all confined in such tight quarters.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am 100% against the use of cellphones during flights.  Most people don't have commonsense when it comes to cellphone etiquette.   Please keep cellphones turned off during flights.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No do not allow.  I don't want to listen my neighbors' cellphone conversations.  Flying is not all that enjoyable.  Cellphone use would make my travel even less enjoyable.

Title: John Fechter
Comment: I am opposed to allowing mobile phones/voice calls to be used on commercial aircraft while they are in flight. Commercial aircraft are already very uncomfortable due to reduced seating distances and extremely limited space at one's feet -- because overhead storage is filled up as more people bring luggage aboard to avoid paying for checked luggage. There are no meals, only high carbohydrate snacks and whatever malodorous sandwich or dinner passengers may have purchased to bring onboard. Sulfurous egg smells, garlic, and similar odors fill the confined cabin space. And already the sound of earphones set to high volume are heard by unwilling passengers. I have been seated lately with a number of people who use their cell phones -- against rules but used none the less -- when the aircraft is in proximity to the airfield. The calls are loud and obnoxious and laced with swearing and potty language spoken loudly and sometimes in anger. If mobile phones/voice calls are allowed during the entire flight, I fear that the combination of passenger fatigue, malodorous food odors, cramped space, and frustration will boil up and turn into anger and violence when a seatmate or nearby passengers are making voice calls and cursing, swearing in anger, talking loudly to overcome ambient aircraft noise while in flight, sharing personal and intimate details not fit for public sharing; physical fights are going to break out. People will be hurt.  Please DO NOT approve or allow voice calls to be made by electronic devices while aircraft are in flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am totally against cell phone use during air flights.   PLEASE do not allow this to pass.    There is plenty of time when boarding or landing to make necessary cell phone calls.   Thanks for your consideration.

Title: Davd Lund
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment.  I am very much opposed to allowing cell phone conversations on flights.  In flight we are quite effectively 'trapped' in a small place with a lot of people, and it is to everyone's benefit to keep that as calm and quiet an atmosphere as possible.  

The aspect of these conversations that is nearly certain to be to disturbing other passengers is simple human nature - if people have any difficulty hearing the person they are speaking with, they naturally speak louder.  As you add more people in more conversations, the increased volume feeds on itself.  Walk into a busy bar just about anywhere and you'll experience this.  

If an airline felt there was sufficient demand to lose the capacity, I could see the addition of a 'phone booth'; a sound suppressed area where people could take turns making those necessary calls.  Personally I would never pay a premium to be on a flight that included such an amenity, but some may.

If the airlines felt they could manage it, I wouldn't have a problem with 'silent texting' being allowed, but this should not only prohibit voice generated texts, but also use of devices with any tone or click produced when the keys are used.  

I certainly appreciate any efforts to keep our flights calmer and quieter.

Title: Elinor Ogden
Comment: I am against the use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft. It would be an intrusion in the lives of other passengers. Some passengers may need to use the time on the flight to complete work for school or office, and the voices of people talking on the phone are distracting.  Those needing to contact people on the ground can wait until the plane  lands or use email.

Title: Norman Brenner
Comment: Allowing voice cell phone calls on aircraft is not a productive idea.  If you have ever been in a public place on the ground where cell phone calls are permitted, you will note that it is a distraction and disturbing.  Imagine, in an enclosed space like an airline cabin how disturbing all that extraneous talking would be.  I like to snooze while flying and all the chatter around would make that impossible.  I wholeheartedly vote NO for cell phone conversations on airplanes.

Title: Cynthia Orr
Comment:
I think it's a very bad idea to allow cell phones on airplanes during flights-even short ones.
People are muderously outraged by loud music, and road rage. I for one would hate to sit next to someone loudly speaking on their cell weather I am in a resturant, standing in line and especially on a plane!!!!!!!!!!
Don't Allow Cell Phones on Air Planes!!!!!!!!!!!

Title: Jay Youmans
Comment:
I can not imagine anything more disgusting than sitting within ear shot of someone blabbering away on a cell phone.  We are confined to a very small area with no chance of increasing the distance between us and the talker.  If cell phone use is permitted on aircraft the change will probably be sufficient to drive me away from flying.

For heavens sake, show some mercy on passengers who are sensitive to ambient noise.

Title: Eileen Anderson
Comment: Don`t allow cellphones in flight.  Please, it`s so annoying with everyone talking loudly. Please let me have a quiet flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: People tend to talk louder, share personal things and generally irritate people around them.  Take those factors and put them in a crowded plane and I believe you are asking for many unhappy passengers with potential for disruption, fighting, maybe violence.  I would strongly recommend against cell phone usage on planes.

Title: Jan Hacker
Comment:
NO, NO, NO don't allow use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft!!! 

I'll relate my last flight experience in support of my position. At the gate some arrogant "business person" was talking so loudly on his cell phone I could hear every word over 100 feet away. Then the mobs packed around the gate when the pre-boarding announcement was made (since the airlines don't board by row anymore) so that elderly passengers and those with small children had to fight their way through to get on the plane. When I got on the plane, all the overhead bins were full & they had to check my one bag. 

Once in my seat, packed in like a sardine, the toddler seated behind me started kicking my seat back and his parents did nothing to stop him as I requested. This continued the entire flight from Minneapolis/St. Paul to Orlando. The baby they were traveling with then started to cry and scream. Just after takeoff a man seated two seats away started eating his Subway sandwich with red onions and hot peppers which he brought on board with him. The smell was so overwhelming it made my eyes water.

And now there are proposed rules to allow cell phone use on flights??? How much more miserable can flying be made for those of us who still act civilly when flying? Many people don't act in a civil manner, with respect for others, when flying. Use of cell phones on flights will only exacerbate their bad behavior to the detriment of the rest of the flying public. 

Flight attendants have a right to be concerned about this possible change in policy. I would not hesitate to stop an intrusion on my personal audio space by an adult yakking on a cell phone within earshot of me. As a non-cellphone user on a plane I have rights to some modicum of peace during a flight. The flying public has put up with seats with less legroom, chaotic boarding procedures, first boarders taking up all the overhead space, smelly food people bring on board, screaming babies, kids kicking the back of your seat -- now there is a possibility that cell phone use is added to the mix to make a flight even more intolerable???

NO, NO, NO to cell phone use on airplanes!!! People have a right NOT to be intruded upon by others in a closed space from which they can not escape. Allowance must be made for children but not adults who think they can impose their bad behavior on others without consequence. Isn't that why smoking was banned on airplanes?? Exposing non-cellphone users to those that want to use them is similar -- the smoking ban was due to health reasons, the cell phone ban is due to the discomfort and disruption of fellow passengers enjoyment of a flight. Why should someone have to be subjected to someone's incident talking on the phone? 

Jan J. Hacker

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002 

I am against the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft because I fear I will have to listen to constant noise by other passengers who cannot detach themselves for a few hours from the people in their phone. Thank you.

Title: Dorothy Lee
Comment: I am also 100% opposed to cell phone usage on aircraft. When people generally talk on their cell phones, they become loud and oblivious to those around them.  Many of them feel entitled to their own feelings and will become defensive  when asked to stop. Who wants to listen to other people's conversations?  Who needs more trouble on planes?If this rule is passed, there will be many dissatisfied passengers and flight attendants who will have to put up with disagreements and arguments over loud and lengthy cell phone calls.  Use common sense and think of the worst things that can happen with this rule and it will.

Title: Ira Gewant
Comment:
If this bill passes, I will NEVER fly again! Also, I think you will have to train flight attendants to be fight referees.

I abhor violence, but if I was sitting next to someone talking on a cell phone, all bets are off!

I am pleased that all my doctor's offices do NOT allow these devices in their waiting rooms and for excellent reasons.

Title: Elizabeth Henderson
Comment: I am very much opposed to allowing use of cellular phones on airplanes during flights.  Passengers need to be able to hear what the captain or flight attendants or their flying companions or family are saying. This is already very difficult. Please do not make it more difficult. Thank you

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Opposing voice calls on aircraft for sure. Americans have poor manners as it is, and the majority are like unruly children when it comes to common sense. It is rude to subject others to a cell phone conversation in all places where people are gathered, including restaurants, at the gym, a doctor's waiting area and such. I can easily imagine actual fights breaking out in the air if people will be forced to sit next to someone who proceeds to hold a phone conversation.

Title: John Howell
Comment: I am opposed to the use of cell phones on airplanes. I do not want to hear my seat neighbor's loud conversation on business, personal matters or their latest sexual conquest. A few hours without cellphone connection won't be the end of the world for anyone. We can't rely on people having good etiquette in phone conversations. Let them send an email-not Skype or cell phone conversations, etc.

Title: Barbara Powell
Comment: Please do NOT allow cell phone usage on planes during flights. Loud conversations are bad enough. It is a closed space, and everyone has personal rights. If passengers MUST communicate outside the plane, let them use email or instant messages.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The ban to prohibit talking on cell phones during flight should remain in place. While the lifting of this ban may be beneficial to certain passengers, it would be a huge inconvenience to other passengers aboard. Imagine if the ban was lifted and during a 12 hour flight someone decided to talk the whole time? What if this person decided to use their speaker phone feature to have this conversation? It would also be a huge disturbance if the person using their cell phone is unable to do so with grace; thus talking loudly, even cursing. Could you imagine listening to someone's entire conversation for hours on end? In addition, there is no way that a person (i.e. flight attendant) can regulate the manner in which a passenger may talk on their cell phone. The first thing a passenger would say in response to a complaint is that their First Amendment allows them freedom of speech. When I think of flying; I think of a peaceful experience where I can relax, take a nap and simply enjoy the peace and quiet aboard. Allowing patrons to use their cell phones to make verbal phone calls during flight will only encourage other bans to be lifted; thus, challenging greatly the calming experience of a flight. 

In the event that my point wasn't clear; please do not lift the cell phone ban.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Ban cell phones!!! I dont want to spend hours listening to someone babble on about nothing

Title: Donna Smith
Comment: I vote no! I do not want to hear other's conversations on the plane. Thank you

Title: Margret Amatayakul
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002 Department of Transportation

I am a 2 million miler and urge you to NOT permit cell phone calls on planes. The airline industry and its passengers are only getting more inconsiderate with each passing day. In fact, I don't know why the airlines continue to fly planes with seats and windows. They might as well just bundle passengers up with their luggage and shove us onto cargo planes.

Title: Virginia Reardon
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone usage on planes.  It is disturbing enough to have passengers talking without having any and all those around you talking on cell phones.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not allow voice calls on flights. Texting ok but please no voice.
I fly a lot and do not want to listen to other travelers conversations.

Title: Tom Pickett
Comment:
I am writing to express my opinion on the upcoming rule to allow cellphone usage on airplanes in flight. Please DO NOT let this happen. It is bad enough sitting in a restaurant listing to someone talking on his or her cellphone. I can't begin to imagine how annoying and irritating it will be sitting next to someone who spends most of the trip talking on a cellphone. I try to sleep when I am on an airplane, but that will be impossible if the people on both sides of me are using their cellphones. Please, do not let this become law.

Sincerely,

Tom Pickett

Title: Ombretta Sdegnosa
Comment:
NO VOICE CALLS ON AIRPLANCES! It is an invitation to a nightmare for the passengers who are seated nearby. People are forced to shout to be heard in conversation on planes and will do the same on their phones . It will lead to bad feelings and arguments, possibly violence, that will have to be settled by aircraft personnel. They already have enough to do. It would certainly discourage me from flying if this were allowed. It's already so expensive and unpleasant with all the security precautions.

YES to texting! Let people keep in touch that way. It's silent.

Title: Darlene
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002  I FIRMLY and vehemently oppose allowing cell phone calls on airplanes at any time while in the air.  The thought of being trapped in a tube twelve inches from someone else's private conversation is alarming.  We cannot limit what that conversation is about, how long it lasts, or how loud it is.  We cannot avoid eavesdropping on conversations that may be offensive because we would then be subject to 'free speech' rights.  If I'm in a restaurant and the conversation is offensive, I can get up and leave.  Not so in an airplane.     Imagine sitting  within about 5 feet of EIGHT separate conversations (3x3 rows of passengers) for hours!  Imagine trying to get work done, listen to music, or trying to sleep on the plane with so many people all chatting in that confined space? Imagine how loud it could become as each increases their volume to be heard over the din of neighboring conversations.   Add that to the noise of the engines and the volume will be at levels that trigger anxiety, aggression, and auditory overload.  I sincerely believe allowing cell phone calls will also cause passengers to argue and fight with one another when one wants quiet while the other carries on a loud and intrusive conversation. I fly at least 5 or 6 times each year and cringe at the thought of being forced to endure such an overwhelming environment.  Presently, if I want to snooze or work, I merely need to let my seat mate know I'm not ready for conversation; to have his conversation forced on me would be extremely intrusive and aggravating.   PLEASE do not subject us to being trapped right next to several inconsiderate or offensive conversations for hours.   

I do not object to cell conversations once the wheels are on the ground, however, because those calls would naturally be of short duration.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Concerning DOT-OST-2014-0002. Continue the ban on use of cell phones to make voice calls on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This is a terrible idea and the airlines are asking for trouble.  I can't imagine sitting next to someone for hours in a confined space while they are having this one-way conversation.  Personally, I don't even like to get into a conversation with my seat mates.  They end up telling you their life story, which I totally have no interest in.

I hope cell phone usage will NOT be allowed on airplanes.

Title: Fran Eagon
Comment: Please do not allow cel phone use on planes.  In a small enclosed area phone conversations can be very disturbing. Have had experience with this on trains in the past.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please continue to ban cell phone use on flights. It may not be a safety concern anymore but it is a quality of life issue. It would be great to imagine a world in which people were courteous enough to not talk during the flight but that won't happen. Flying today is stressful enough without being forced to sit next to someone talking for hours on their phone.

DOT-OST-2014-0002-0018

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Only allow passengers to text message. Require ringers and alert singles be turned down to minimum levels.

Title: Sue Law
Comment:
Please do not allow cell phone voice calls on airplanes.  My argument against it would be that a person has a right to do what they want ONLY if it doesn't harm others.  In such a small enclosed space, other peoples conversations would inevitably be extremely irritating to the people around them.  Fellow passengers would have no option to get away from the noise if they found it unpleasant.  

A compromise position would be to allow text messages only.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
NO CELLPHONES, PLEASE!!!
Can you imagine sitting next to someone yakking away and times that by 150!!!  I cannot begins to imagine the grating on people's nerves, already frayed from being packed into an airplane with too small seats, no meals,but, yes you can buy alcohol and get drunk.  Who will monitor the decibel level?  Can you. Imagine the arguments among passengers who want to fall asleep next to someone who wants to gab? This is a REALLY, REALLY bad idea!

PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE , SPARE US.

Thank you,  Chicago

Title: Bonnie Goldberg
Comment: I am definitely AGAINST allowing mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.  Nothing could be more irritating and disturbing than having to listen to people talking on phones during a flight.  Texting would be acceptable, but NO VOICE.

Title: Preston Cannady, Jr.
Comment: I am against allowing cell phone conversations on airlines while in the air.  Air travel is taxing enough without those who would be using their phones continuously.

Title: Ken Gary
Comment: I fully support banning cellphone use on aircraft while in the air!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Do not allow cell phone use on airplanes when above 10,000 feet.

Title: Joschel Piquion
Comment:
My name is Joschel Piquion and I am commenting on DOT-OST-2014-0002. Allowing consumers to use their cell phones in-flight for voice communications is unacceptable. Essentially, we are in an enclosed tube flying for hours (sometimes less). Imagine 200 people talking at the same time into a metal tube. That is what it would like on an airplane. It is unfair to everyone and unsafe because words have a way of affecting even those who are not the subjects of the conversation. Texting and email is fine but the phones should be kept on vibrate. The most important thing to keep in mind is the comfort and peace of mind of every passenger on the flight. 
Personally, I do not see why I would need to be on the phone on an airplane. I'd rather let the pilot, co-pilot, and crew members focus so they can do their best at making the flight as pleasant as possible. After all, once that plane takes off, all i want is to get to my destination. That is not because I am afraid but because that is the reason I'm on the plane in the firs place. If I have to hear 200 people talking out loud on that flight, it would drive make me very upset and I am sure I'm not the only one who feels this way. Many upset passengers could, at the least, cause the airline to lose customers. The worse that could happen is up to the imagination with so many people annoyed and upset. Allowing vocal communications on such a large scale is a health risk, a threat to safety, and a disruption to the consumer.

Title: Dorothy McKee
Comment:
Absolutely no cell phone chatter on flights!!  The rudeness of those who think we want to hear every detail of their lives is unbelievable. I wish the phones were banned from the time you enter the plane until you're back in the terminal. 

NO IN-FLIGHT CALLS!!!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Regarding DOT-OST-2014-0002.  I am opposed to allowing people on aircraft to talk on cell phones.  I am adamant that it would be disruptive to other passengers who would have difficulty resting or reading or focusing on another task. On a plane one does not have the opportunity to move away from an annoying "neighbor" so please do not add to the list of discomforts (such as shrinking leg room and seat width) we must endure. I am not opposed to permitting emails or texting.

Title: Steve Lippy
Comment: My wife and I are adamantly opposed to the use of cell phones on airplanes.  It will be absolutely chaotic and so noisy if even a minority of individuals were to use them.  If they were sitting next to one another, each will be shouting in the phones to be heard.  Actually, most people tend to yell, whether it is a habit or a bad connection.  If the airlines want to accommodate the usage of cell phones, have the cell phone users all sit together and erect a soundproof wall and door between them and the rest of the cabin.   We can not fathom how noisy a plane would be if most everyone was on a phone.  How would the crew be able to communicate with the passengers over the noise of chatter?  As it is now, the speaker system is not always that great.  Would it represent a new safety issue of impeding communications?

Title: Walter Bibb
Comment: I fully support a BAN on the use of cell phones.   Flying is stressful enough without enduring listening to people shouting into a cell phone!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I have lifetime platinum status with American, and I oppose allowing phone conversations on planes.

Title: Sarah Wehren Kooiker
Comment: I fully support a ban on cell phone conversations on airplanes. With many airlines offering wireless internet connections, passengers can still remain in contact via texting and email. Allowing verbal conversations will make already-uncomfortable flights more challenging for everyone (passengers, flight attendants).

Title: Donna Wood
Comment: As someone who takes a minimum of 2 flights a week, the very thought of allowing hundreds of passengers to carry on cell phone conversations makes me cringe.  Is there seriously that great a need to be in constant contact that people cannot simply relax in peace and quiet and de-stress for a few hours?  I think you will find you will have an increased number of passenger incidents, putting peoples safety at risk if this is allowed.

Title: Robert Steffen
Comment: I think this is a terrible idea.  In fact, I would pay extra to be in the "quiet cabin" section.

Title: D. Brown
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone calls on flights.  It will be too annoying to have even one person, much less numerous people, talking away at loud volumes (people always talk louder on cell phones than normal conversation and in a noisy airplane cabin, who knows how loud they will talk).  When people talk on cell phones, they often don't realize how loud they are talking and how much it usually disturb others.  Its annoying enough now while the plane taxi to the gate.  Allow text messages or emails, but please no phone calls or anything that includes audio/voice.  Let's preserve some civility and personal space as much as possible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please, NO. Do not allow cell phone use on aircrafts, it is a terrible idea.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am totally opposed to allowing voice calls on airplanes in any circumstances.  There will be other ways to communicate if necessary (email, text) that will not be disturbing to all seated around you.  Passengers have no options to move away if someone is talk aloud.  They will be stuck in their seats and forced to hear one side of a conversation.  This would create, in my opinion, a hardship for all within hearing distance.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: NO WAY!   Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft.  We are confined in a small space and unable to leave.  It will give rise to more anger and frustration when flying.  Who wants to listen for several minutes or hours to those people who like to hear the sound of their own voice with no consideration to others?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am opposed to allowing cellphone calls to be made on airline flights.
Many individuals are not aware of how loud they are when speaking on their phones.
This would only make the flight stewards jobs more difficult to have to advise someone that they need to tone it down.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please DO NOT make me a captive to someone who will talk on the phone for the whole flight.  I can't stand to listen to some selfish person talking the duration of the flight.  This would be like torture for me.  If these people are SO important they have to be plugged in 24/7 let them quietly text if they must.

Title: Ryan Scarr
Comment: I believe that amending the existing regulations on wireless devises on airplanes is a much needed advance. The laws that currently exist are outdated due to the improvements made in cellular technology and upgrades to the laws that govern their use are greatly needed and appreciated. However there is two issues I have with the proposed law. Though I believe airlines should be able to decide and declare their own mobile device policies, I believe cell phone calls should remain illegal as well as device use during takeoffs and landings. According to a Quinnipiac University study, American air travelers of varying age groups are 2 to 1 in favor of keeping cell phone calls off of airplanes. Though people wish to be able to communicate with the outside world while in flight, most do not wish to have to put up with loud, obnoxious people chattering on phones throughout a flight.  If communication is necessary, a passenger could simply send a text message or an email.  Also, though it is known that cell phone signals themselves cannot bring down a plane, they can have an effect on the plane's equipment and the pilots. According to a recent experiment performed by Boeing, cell phone and other device signals can have an effect on plane radios.  Though they are normally a non-issue, during key times during a flight, especially takeoff and landing, when a pilot most needs to focus  it is important that nothing interfere with their job. Though the chance is minute and the impact can be small, passengers can sacrifice a few minutes without connection to ensure that their pilot's job is as easy as possible.

Title: Adrian Sahagun
Comment: I am in support of keeping the ban on voice calls. The FCC revised its proposal and is wanting to lift the ban of calling people on flights. Although the FCC can lift its ban, the Department of Transportation is ultimately the people that decide whether phone calls can happen on planes or not.  This rule still needs to be banned because it could bother people on the plane that just want peace and quiet.  The last thing that these people that are already trapped in a compact area need is for their own peace and quiet to be ruined.  AFA president Veda Shook said "As the last line of defense in our nation's aviation system, flight attendants understand the importance of maintaining a calm cabin environment, and passengers agree," (CNN.com).  I agree with the Department of Transportation when it come to banning voice calls on airplanes.   I believe that there should be an alternative method that can still allow people on the plane to communicate but without them actually talking on the phone. House Rep. Bill Shuster, (R-Pennsylvania) has a proposal that would ban in-voice calls with people but it would allow text messaging to happen. Text messaging is a better alternative because you are still able to talk to people but you are not disturbing the peace of others around you.  However, voice calls in a plane would not force the airplane companies to install special equipment.  All that airlines would have to do is just okay the proposal and then people can call others on planes.  If the ban is lifted, imagine how many people would go to the restrooms to use their phone because they have "private conversations" that they do not want other people to hear.  This could lead to problems and people on the plane becoming agitated that people are only using the restroom to talk on the phone.  I believe if the Department of Transportation bans voice calls and allows people to text or use social media then everyone will be content.

Title: Eileen Longhi
Comment: I DO NOT want to allow cell phone usage on airline flights.  It is bad enough I have to listen to loud conversations on the cell phones in restaurants, on elevators, at work and at airports waiting for flights.  I want the peace and quiet flying allows me away from those gadgets.  Listening to someone talking on the phone, usually in a loud voice probably made louder on the plane due to aircraft noise, is unacceptable to me.  There are so many other in-flight "gadgets" that people can use to occupy themselves, they don't need to talk on the phone and disturb other passengers--it is plain rude to do so!!  I agree with most of the airlines and their staff when they say NO to allowing in-flight cell phone usage.  Thank you.

Title: Ian Clark
Comment:
Reference U.S. Department of Transportation docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002:

Please!  No yakking on cell phones in the air.  It is extremely unfair for the passenger in the adjacent seat to have to listen to some stranger just inches away blathering on a cell phone.

Title: Clark Shroeder
Comment: Please NO CELL PHONE calls allowed on airplane flights. On a  plane one cannot move away from annoying self-centered cell phone conversations. This will create confrontations in the air, a dangerous situation. please do not allow cell phone usage on aircraft.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please DO NOT allow cell phone usage on airplanes!  An airplane may be the only place left in the universe where we don't have to be subjected to the loud, inane, ridiculous and non-sensical chatter of rude people who assume their importance trumps everyone else!!  It's bad enough it's on the streets, in the grocery stores, on trains -- I once had to listen to a guy for 40 minutes talk about nothing with an f-bomb thrown in about every third word (with children and parents within earshot) until I was ready to unload on him!  By the grace of God - his cell signal was lost and he was never able to get it back for the rest of the trip!  Divine intervention!! When I fly - I want quiet!  There's not enough of that in this chaotic world.  If you allow cell phone usage, I absolutely believe you will see more in flight rage between passengers!  There's a mindset with travel - even if it's for business - to have whatever flight time there is for regrouping.  It is stressful enough traveling on planes these days -- it's expensive, there are long lines for security, long wait times for delays, cancelled flights - the list goes on and on.  It's not enjoyable anymore.  It's actually surprising when you do have a flight that goes off without a hitch, leaves on time, where the attendants actually seem like they like their job and therefore treat you with some semblance of niceness (this being coach of course).  So, adding cell phone usage would just add to the stress of traveling and if it is a long flight or international - listening to someone drone on and on while you are trying to sleep again would be a big reason for possible violence between passengers.  And I know the airplane staff feel that this is like throwing gas on a raging fire!  They do not want to be in a position where they have to police people.  They already do that.  I have several friends who fly - pilots as well as attendants and they DO NOT want to see this either!!  PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW THIS!!!!

Title: Ellen Edwards
Comment: NO NO NO NO NO NO NO !!!!! Do NOT allow cell phones to be used for calls on airplanes. This change would eliminate one the very few remaining pleasant things about flying. I do not want to hear fellow travelers' instructions to their sales assistants, sweet nothings to their spouses/girl or boyfriends/children/friends, arguments, blather about what TV show they just watched, etc etc etc. Leave me my privacy and my quiet time.

Title: Jean-Luc Adam
Comment: Passengers should not be allowed to use their mobile devices for voice calls on a plane. Many people support this claim, including Association of Flight Attendants, who stated “AFA opposes any changes that would allow in-flight voice calls." The union, who represent more than 60,000 flight attendants, believe that the use of mobile devices for voice calls could cause a negative effect on aviation safety and possibly drown out other important announcements or conversations in an emergencies. In addition to being unsafe, cell phones are also a public nuisance. Because they think that the person on the other line cannot here them while talking on the phone, people tend to talk louder on mobile devices. Unlike a normal setting, on a plane, there is no escaping a loud and obnoxious person. As far as preferences go, the majority of people agree with my position. In an Associated Press GfK poll, "48 percent of Americans oppose allowing cellphones to be used for voice calls while flying; just 19 percent support it. Another 30 percent are neutral."

Title: Alex Bezdjian
Comment: I am opposed to allowing persons the ability to make voice calls on an airplane. According to a poll taken by the Huffington post, "Experienced air travelers said they would prefer that cell phone calls be forbidden by a 53 percent to 29 percent margin," (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/23/cell-phones-on-planes_n_4326238.html). Many people are annoyed by one-on-one conversations in airplanes, let alone someone else's phone conversation. So, allowing them would make travel annoying and inconvenient. Allowing text messages on a plane would be a less annoying, and equally effective means on communication on a plane that should be permissible.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow passengers on airplanes to use their cell phones mid-flight for conversations! As a business traveler, who always tries to be polite to my fellow travelers, I deal with enough rude people on each flight I take (average one a month) and allowing cell phones to be used for conversations would be awful. You have wi-fi, you can make it through a 4 hour flight without talking to someone and causing everyone around you to have to listen to your loud conversation. We all know these folks will be shouting, to talk over the common noise in the plane and to be heard over other speaking passengers. Please please please do not allow this!!

Title: Kelly
Comment: Please, no cell phone calls/conversations on airplanes.  Many people seem oblivious to how their behavior affects others in general, and especially to how disturbing the volume and length of their conversation can be.  We're all jammed in together on an airplane, and there is already enough ambient, engine, and conversational noise.  Please don't add to it!

Title: M. Thompson
Comment: Please do not allow voice calls on aircraft!!

Title: Terri Spiegel
Comment: THIS HAS GOT TO BE ONE OF THE WORST SUGGESTIONS/IDEAS/THOUGHTS I HAVE EVER HEARD IN MY ENTIRE LIFE!!!  IT'S BAD ENOUGH THAT WE'RE CRAMPED INTO A TINY SPACE FOR ANY GIVEN AMOUNT OF TIME; I JUST CANNOT POSSIBLY UNDERSTAND HOW ANYONE IN HIS/HER RIGHT MIND WOULD EVEN BEGIN TO THINK THIS IS A GOOD IDEA!!!!!!  WHY WOULD I WANT TO HEAR SOMEONE ELSE'S TELEPHONE CHATTER, ESPECIALLY IF IT'S GOING TO GET LOUD & POSSIBLY UGLY??  WHY WOULD SOMEONE ELSE WANT ME TO HEAR HIS/HER CHATTER - WHETHER IT'S PERSONAL OR PROFESSIONAL??  PLEASE DON'T DO THESE - IT'S A TERRIBLE & HORRIBLE & DESPICABLE IDEA!  THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME, TERRI SPIEGEL...

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I would like to comment regarding the use of cell phones on airlines while in flight.  I think that is a terrible idea and I hope it is never adopted.  Passengers are already squeezed together like sardines and I can't imagine being seated next to someone who is on the phone the entire way, or sitting between two people who are talking loudly on phones.  If you want to see passengers go balistic and have fights on airplanes that will do it.  People have only limited tolerance re: the boorishness of others before they lose their cool and blow their cork.  You would have a lot of disruptiions on flights that flight attendents would have to try to break up.  It could become very dangerous.  Why ask for problems when they can be avoided by not allowing the use of cell phones, etc. to be used on flights.  I can't even imagine how awful that would be so please use common sense and don't allow that.  I personally know several pilots and flights attendance and not a one that I have talked to is in favor of it.  Quite to the contrary.  I hope that I never end up on a flight where that is allowed.  It would be an awful flight.

Title: Jeff Rubin
Comment: This is the most absurd invasion of a passenger's privacy since smoking was allowed on planes. I will fly only airlines that do not allow cell-phone calls.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: please don't do this!!

Title: Margaret Hollowell
Comment: I am asking that mobile wireless devices for voice calls not be allowed on aircraft.

Title: Cheryl B.
Comment: I am strongly opposed to allowing voice phone calls on aircraft.  Most airlines are squeezing more seats into their planes making for tight quarters, especially when every seat is usually full.  There is enough stress and tension aboard a crowded aircraft as it is.  Why add a potentially volatile practice that can only increase the incidence of irritation and scorn of passengers around those on a call as well as making flight attendants' jobs more difficult.  I strongly recommend that the rules against in flight calls NOT be changed.

Title: Bernard Cohn
Comment: I think nothing is more obnoxious than being a captive to someone else's cellphone conversation in any public venue, let alone an aircraft.  It is an invitation to VIOLENCE, and I am not being facetious. I do not in my wildest Imagination see any RESPONSIBLE organ of a legislative body condoning phone calls in an aircraft to annoy everyone in such a confined space.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a terrible idea and I am opposed to it.  It is bad enough I have to hear people talking on their phones in a store or restaurant, but to have to listen to it on a plane where I cannot escape it is a frightening thought.  There is nothing so urgent that they can't send an email or wait until the plane lands. Please do not allow this.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm extremely opposed to allowing voice cell phone calls on aircraft due to the disruption this will cause with everyone shouting to talk over others in the aircraft.

Title: Kevin Butler
Comment:
As a frequent flyer (50,000-75,000 air miles per year) I am strongly opposed to cell phone use on airplanes.  After seeing the same situation on commuter rail, the disturbance to other flyers by loud conversations in a very tight cabin with no ability for passengers to move away from loud passengers and possible disruption in an emergency situation cause this opposition.  The ability to use small devices and the increasing availability of wifi aboard to stay in contact via email, chat, etc., obviate the need for voice calls in a cramped cabin.

Thanks,
Kevin Butler

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cell phone conversations on board airplanes where it is common public space.

Title: Rich Kooyenga
Comment: Please  do not allow cell phone use on airplanes. Allowing this will only cause problems for passengers and flight crew.

Title: Christine Nayman
Comment:
* The use of cell phones on a plane I feel would disturb the those sitting around the caller
* NO USE in restrooms 
* internet, video, text & audio that can be seen and heard only by the user, should be permitted.

Title: Scott Wittke
Comment: Use of cellular phone on aircraft would be obtrusive. As seating is of very close quarters and there are no partitions, sitting next to any passenger making business or personal calls would be irritating. Use of cell phones on aircraft SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Just because we can use cell phones on flights doesn't mean we should allow cell phone calls.  Anybody who has listened to people jump on their phone when arriving at the gate understands how invasive talikng on the cell phone can be.  Having to listen to other peoples conversions for a full flight will ultimately lead to a violent act taking place.  Why should I have to wear noise cancelling headphones which would eliminate the possiblility of any normal conversations between traveling companions just so another person can keep their friends up to date on their latest thoughts?  I thought that is why they invented Facebook, twitter and texting.

Also need to limit the use of Skype and any other alternative phone calling methods.

Title: Patrick
Comment:
People will be disruptive to other passengers if allowed to talk nonstop on a flight. Texting is the most that should be allowed.
Air travel is uncomfortable enough without this intrusion. Please don't allow cell phone use during flights. 
Thank you!

Title: Alan Seilhammer
Comment:
RE:  Department of Transportation;  docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002

I very much opposed the idea of allowing cell phone voice conversation to exist on passenger airlines.     I am an active business traveler.  I spend a lot of time in the domestic passenger air transit system.

Flying has moved over time from be a luxury experience to a cattle car experience.  Passengers are jammed into small  seats where people are sitting shoulder-to-shoulder.   A very unnatural environment of person space being intruded upon.   If you witness passengers on a plane, 90% of them keep to themselves and engage in various quiet activities: reading, sleeping, game playing, movie watching with headsets, etc.   They behave in a manner of not wanting to have their seat neighbor engage them and they do not want to intrude on their neighbor.     Again, it is an unnatural environment of strangers being forced to be shoulder-to-shoulder for hours.

The airlines engage in a lot of efforts to cause the passenger experience to be environmentally comfort.  The temperature is controlled.   Avoiding turbulence.    Smoking is not allowed.  Controlling unruly and inappropriate passengers.

Allowing cell phone voice conversation would create a complete violation of personal space of other neighbor passengers.   Everyone in the immediate area would be forced to have the cell phone user's dialog forced upon them.    Remember, there is always the audible drone of the planes engines.   For a person to have verbal phone conversation, they have to speak loudly which is then an accelerated intrusion. 

Cell phone use does not exist now and people's lives move along just fine.    There is no valid reason for the comfort of other passengers to be diminished by a small set of people that cannot wait a couple hours to have a "voice" communication.    Keeping in mind that today that airline passengers can log-on and send e-mails.    The technology exists to allow text conversation.    These are both communication activities that allow immediacy of conversation and  do not infringe on the comfort of others.   Having a voice conversation is not necessary and brings with it too much discomfort.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please do not approve the use of mobile wireless devices for voice phone calls on aircrafts.
Everyone's life would be miserable instantaneously and none of us would have any recourse for the duration of the flight.

No, no, no, no, no, no........................................................................................................................................................NO

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to using mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft.

Title: Antoinette
Comment: Please DO NOT allow the use of cell phones on planes!  Most people are not considerate enough to keep their conversations private.  It's bad enough when they talk too loud to a person WITH them on a plane.  It would be even worse if they have to struggle to hear/talk on a cell phone.

Title: Mary O'Toole
Comment: do not allow people to make cell phone calls on airplanes. On commuter trains, the railroads have had to identify quiet cars to keep the peace. How would you do that on airplanes.  nothing is worth the insanity of listening to one sided shouting matches. And they would be shouting over the constant din in a plane.

Title: Arnold Katz
Comment:
I think allowing people to use their Cell Phones during a flight is very wrong. Being that all passengers are VERY close to each other the "noise" would be overwhelming. I personally don't want to hear ; Business discussions, personal "business" , chit-chat and idle conversations of those who are bored.
Please do not allow this to become a rule.

Title: Linda Cassidy
Comment: Please, please no cell phone use for conversations on planes.  It is a stressful enough event, and sadly many people have little or no sense of propriety, privacy, or infringing on others' space, be it visual, audio or physical.  I beg you, please no. Texting can do what they need, if that can be allowed.  Did I beg enough? I am on my hands and knees, trust me.  Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow cellphone use on planes. It is way too distracting to have to listen to multiple peoples' phone conversations especially on long flights. It will start many arguments. People want to relax on flights and many people have anxiety already when flying, this will only add to it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not ever allow people to chat on their cell phones during a flight. I don't think there are any noise-canceling devices available that can block out the sound of 100-some people yakking at the same time about nothing in particular.

Title: Jay Baltimore
Comment:
Please do not allow voice use of a cell phone on planes while enroute; it is way too disruptive inside the cabin.

If a situation becomes an emergency, then I suggest those who need to place that call are allowed to step out onto the wing and then make their call away from the passengers. You may as well allow the smokers a place outside on the wing as well so they can just listen to cell phone talkers. Misery deserves company.

Thanks for allowing me to express myself.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am definitely against voice calls on a plane. We are in an enclosed environment with no where to go and I for one do not want to be exposed to people's conversations. Some people thrive on an audience and will speak loudly and become animated. It's not necessary, it can wait.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Big NO on voice calls on cells.  I was around when smoking was allowed on planes and it is so much nicer without that on planes.  With cells people are rude, have no idea how loud they talk, and cause tension with others in their area who may want to read, sleep, or just relax.

Even texting should have some sort of regulations.  While seating is main thing to prevent blocking and tripping when walking.

Title: Lee Ann
Comment:
Worst nightmare
Please do not pass this

Title: Marlene Wiedenbaum
Comment:
the use of cell phones for voice calls on aircraft is as objectionable and unnecessary as voice call use in any waiting room, classroom, medical office, etc., where personal space is imposed upon by another person. most of us who travel on airplanes are not in the air for business and therefore there is no urgency to conduct business in the air. besides, i suspect any business person flying, either wants to use that time to catch up on sleep or can communicate via emails with their colleagues. 
personal cell phone calls are irritating to listen to on the ground, much less in closed quarters with no escape in the air. i have been forced to witness loud and abusive arguments, lewd "romantic" ploys, disciplinary rants, grocery lists, laundry lists, and too much idle chatter by individuals i don't know and disrespectful narcissists i don't care to know. additionally, these conversations are not what any responsible parents would allow their children to hear, given a choice.
by allowing cell phone use on aircraft, the airlines would be opening themselves up to a myriad of predictable negative  situations: violence, theft, lawsuits, etc.. the consumer would of course, then be handed the bills for "cell phone police," lawyers, doctors, etc.. 
imagine all of us in the air watching our individual little tv's without earphones... try it. see if you like it.

Title: Margaret Linke
Comment:
Please do not allow the use of cell phones on airplanes.  It is so pervasive on public transportation such as trains and buses already.  To be captive for several hours having to listen to inane conversations would be unfair to the rest of the passengers.

Nothing could be that important that it can't wait till the plane lands.

Title: Denise Sears
Comment:
Please do NOT allow VOICE COMMUNICATIONS on phones on planes.

The only exception should be TEXT ONLY.

Point 1: Even 'senior seniors' know how to text now.
Point 2: Texting should allow business people, helicopter parents and Type A personalities the ability to respond to time sensitive or critical communications.
Point 3: Most people talk way too loud on cell phones in a normal setting.
The amplification within the confined setting of an airplane would be intrusive, annoying and possibly cause a new type/level of violence. The latter could be termed 'airborne rage', when other passengers (parents trying to get wired children to sleep, those with fear of flying to relax, people trying catch up on rest after a pre-dawn Departure) finally hit their limit of patience with that Type A personality seat mate's unfiltered, often overly loud phone conversations.

Title: Lorraine Blair
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002
Please do not consider allowing any cell phone talking on any flights.  Many people do not know the meaning of "inside voice" as opposed to "playground voice" volume.  Also, many people do not seem to realize that the rest of the world (or the other passengers) does not want to hear details of the speakers' love lives, medical procedures, and latest drama.  How can a passenger relax, read, or take a snooze with someone blabbing on a cell phone in the next seat?  Thank you.

Title: Liana Crawford
Comment:
I fly quite frequently, and mostly on long (overseas) trips.  PLEASE do not allow passengers to make/receive phone calls in flight!  This would be a nightmare for EVERYONE on board.  

As it is, pilots and flight attendants have trouble getting passengers to pay attention during announcements and instructions.  It would only be worse if their clients were on the phone!  

For those of us who are NOT parties to these phone conversations, we would be forced to listen to our co-travelers as they ramble on about Grandpa's prostate operation, or the disturbing medical test results they'd just received, or what that scumbag boyfriend had done NOW, or that cute little handbag they just bought or ... whatever.  

And even for these rude, self-centered, insecure folks who simply cannot live their lives without their phones attached to their ears, how much louder will they need to talk in order to be heard over the cacophony of everyone else who's just like them?

As far as the possible "solution" of forbidding cell-phone use at night, please note that for those of us who sometimes travel upwards of 20 hours in a plane to get to our destinations, any given time might be "night" for us.

In short, this is a bad idea for ALL of us--pilots, flight attendants, peace-loving passengers, and indeed ALL passengers, who depend on the DOT and the FAA to insure our safety and comfort onboard.  It's bad enough that we're at the mercy of cell-phone users every time we eat in a restaurant or go to a theatre.  PLEASE let us maintain the peace when we're flying through the air!

Title: Charles Pastors
Comment:
Voice communications on airlines, at least once the plane has pulled back from the gate should be prohibited.

An exception could be made, if the crew has announced that the flight is holding for some reason, rather than
proceeding in a normal fashion toward its turn for takeoff.

It would be a constant annoyance--much worse than the infamous "crying baby"--to be sitting next to, or in front of 
someone on the phone for some indeterminate amount of time during a flight--especially if you were trying to read,
nap, or even just relax.  The problem is made worse by the all-too-common situation that those talking on mobile
devices elevate their own voice volume well above normal levels.  In this situation, there is no escape from the
distraction/irritation.  Complaining to the flight crew would open up the possibility of retaliation--either to a crew member
responding to the complaint or to the complainer--on the part of the "offending" talking person.  That retaliation could be carried out, even after the flight, making anyone raising such a complaint uncertain of their safety, perhaps as long as they are still at the destination airport, and even longer, if they are taking public transport or a shuttle bus.

Any marginal convenience to the talker is far outweighed by these factors.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
For the following reasons, we believe that the effects of a ban on the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft would be beneficial. Allowing voice calls would constitute an unfair practice to consumers pursuant to 49 U.S.C. § 41712 and would be inconsistent with adequate air transportation pursuant to 49 U.S.C. § 41702.  Nevertheless, there is an important public interest in allowing free communication on airplanes. To balance these competing interests, we propose that cell phone use be restricted to only allow for text massaging.
First, we acknowledge the “increasing consumer interest in the expanded use of electronic devices on airplanes.”  The public is likely to view such accommodations favorably given the increasing dependence on such devices and their communicative utility. Expanded use will not only provide a welcome distraction but also help ease concerns of both passengers and their loved ones on the ground.
Many Americans, however, are concerned about voice calls on planes. Voice calls violate the consumer interest in having an enjoyable flight experience. Unlike in most other settings, on an airplane irritated passengers cannot move away from someone on their phone; they are confined to their seats. This resulting frustration would only compound the already uncomfortable experience of flying. Many passengers already have a fear of flying, and studies have indicated that aircraft noise can produce high levels of anxiety.   In-flight voice calls would only serve to exacerbate such fears and anxiety.
These concerns are reflected in polling. The Associated Press-GfK found that 48 percent of Americans oppose allowing cellphones to be used for voice calls while flying.  Frequent fliers are even more opposed to their use: 59 percent of Americans who flew once within the past year and 78 percent of Americans who flew at least four times within the past year are opposed to the use of voice calls. 
Moreover, in-flight voice calls may create a safety issue for passengers aside from the avionics-interference issues outside the scope of this comment. Listening to crew instructions can make the difference between life and death.  Talking on the phone while flight attendants give safety instructions could prevent the talker and their neighbors from taking note of vital safety information.
As a compromise, allowing texts would provide consumers with connectivity without disturbing neighbors or raising the same level of safety concerns. Most of the public prefers texting over voice calls anyway. 
If, however, voice calls are allowed, they should be subject to severe restrictions. Calls should not be operational during safety instructions, takeoff, landings, and overnight flights. And when voice calls are permitted, the FAA ought to charge or set fees for their use. The FAA could set fees to price out common use, much like High Occupancy Toll lane fees are priced to limit the number of vehicles in them.  Flight attendants should also have authority to ask a passenger to put their phone away if a passenger is being disruptive.

Title: Susanne
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0002

Hello, 

I know the inflight use of cell phones is a multi-level debate and discussion.  My strong feelings against allowing it are based on very simple reasons.  

Most passengers have either personal tablets, iPods, eReaders and phones.  In the big picture, these people make up the majority of people with headsets in their ears that are NOT listening to the inflight entertainment system.  This means that they already don't hear many PA announcements and they potentially would not hear any inflight emergency announcements in a timely manner. I notice myself that if I'm not looking around and observing what is going on while I listen to my iPod, then I can easily miss an important announcement.  

If we now add the use of voice while inflight, it will be opening up the door to even less attention being paid to your surroundings. People are off in their own worlds and they won't take responsibility for paying attention. In an emergency situation, this means potentially not knowing when to move and reacting much slower.   

Also, I am imagining the sound in the aircraft if only 1 person per row decides to talk on their phone.  It is very distracting, and most of the conversations will be of an unimportant nature.  If cell phones can be used in a true emergency, then I understand.  In an idea scenario, people would be able to discern what is an "emergency" and what is not, but unfortunately many people mistakenly think what is going on in their lives is of the utmost urgency.

If text messaging and data usage is safe, then that should be the absolute max communication options allowed during flight.  

Regards, 
Susanne

Title: Anonymous

Comment: I do not want to have cell phone calls allowed on airplanes while in the air.  It's hard enough to go to a store without hearing several loud voices talking on cell phones. I'm not even sure I want texting to be allowed, but if texting can be allowed and the voice calls can be banned, then that would be OK.

Title: Susan Osuch
Comment:
Docket number DOT-OST-2014-0002-0001 addresses  allowing voice usage (calling and receiving phone calls and engaging in conversations) inside an aircraft.  The argument has been made that modern technology is now available and could be used by passengers during flights.  But the idea that technology has been made available (in this case, voice calls on cell phones) is not a sound argument for its implementation on crowded airplanes.  Over the past decades, air travel has devolved from  an often pleasant, roomy way to get to a destination, to an aerial sardine can where most passengers are confined to cattle class(i.e "coach" or "economy" class); forced to pay for checked baggage, sit in uncomfortable, crowded seats with insufficient leg room; and on some airlines, pay extra for the privilege of sitting in most seats on the airplane.  One of the only "benefits" passengers have left is the relative peace and quiet they can expect once an airplane takes flight. From time to time, a passenger's nap, concentration, or relaxation might be disturbed by crying children, or inebriated or quarrelsome passengers; but this is not the norm.  If cell phone conversations were allowed on airplanes in flight, whether passengers chose to engage in voice calls or not,  they would suffer the disturbance of a stressful environment, not as a random occurrence, but as constant and stressful noise pollution, from the time they boarded the plane until they landed.  Being surrounded by any number of phone conversations with no means of escape is not unlike being in the center of people smoking cigarettes with no means of egress:  one suffers the unhealthful effects of stress, noise or air pollution, and inconsiderate fellow passengers.  The likelihood that a closed, crowded, already compromised environment will remain calm with the addition of multiple ongoing phone conversations is unlikely because many air travelers,  already uncomfortable, will now be more likely to lose patience and control. Flight attendants, whose primary job is to keep passengers safe, would likely be distracted when forced to arbitrate in more frequent disputes.  Their focus on safety could be interrupted to the point that it would be easier for someone with criminal intent to act when the crew was preoccupied with quelling such disruptions.It would be unsafe and unfair to consumers and crew members to impose a rule that endangers their health and safety and infringes on the right to quiet, undisturbed travel. 

 These health and safety concerns should override any need for in-air phone conversations, except in emergencies.
