Title: Johan Kala
Comment:
I support the use of cell phone on aircraft. My support is based on the following:
1. Safety. Given the fact that Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has been missing for over 14 days without trace. The ability to use cell phone in air would allow searches to pin point the location, since the cell phones would provide location information.
The events of 9/11 might have had a different outcome if cell phones were permitted to be used. Flight 93's cockpit voice recorder revealed crew and passengers tried to seize control of the flight after learning through phone calls that flights 1,77 and 175 had crashed into buildings. By allowing cell phone use, would provide one additional level of security.
2. Economic. The airlines would be free to charge a fee for anyone, who would want to use a phone while in air. This taxation of the willing would support lower fares. Airlines should be given the option to either allow or preclude the use of cell phone while airborne. It should be a business decision, not a mandate from the government.
Finally, I urge the DOT to allow the use of cell phones on aircraft and to give the choice to the airlines whether or not they would allow their use.

Title: Richard Rodriguez
Comment:
The obvious problems with using mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft are numerous.  The vast majority of travelers obviously do not want to listen to a complete strangers' (or an entire row of strangers) conversation, while sitting so close to that person, that some part of their bodies are touching each other, literally trapping the passenger into the conversation.  The obvious conversations that the public does not want to hear could include screaming domestic squabbles, family arguments, explaining photosynthesis for a school project, rambling business conference calls, phone sex, other callers talking louder than the person talking next to them, gay, lesbian, transgender, heterosexual, christian, islamic, jewish, buddhist, hindu, persons with disabilities, liberal, conservative, independent, homeless, wealthy and corporate bashing. It is a simple statistical fact that out of the almost 1 billion people traveling on commercial airliners this year (globally), a small percentage would not be able to control themselves during a phone conversation.  Just 1% of all these travelers amount to 10 million people.  I find it very conceivable that at least 1% of the human population (over the age of 16) is unable to behave in public and would be capable of such conversations during a commercial flight.

The not so obvious reason is onboard security.  By allowing mobile wireless devices for voice calls, a group of terrorists onboard any airliner could use voice calls to coordinate an attack, or possibly detonate an explosive device.  Why would the DOT make a ruling that has the potential for putting every airliner at risk?   Annoying is one thing, but deadly is 100% unacceptable.

I implore the DOT to use common sense and not allow this rule change.

Title: Wendy Sacks
Comment: Please, please do not allow voice calls on aircraft. The voice volume generally used on cell phones is too unrestrained for the confined space that exists on aircraft.

Title: Cary Milliner
Comment:
The allowing of wireless devices for voice calls on passenger aircraft is a practice that must never come into existence. With no small portion of the public already viewing modern air travel as a hassle more than an enjoyment, passengers being able to use their phones for voice calls would further diminish the flying experience for the majority of the traveling public, period. With nowhere to relocate away from the phone user as there are in other public spaces or on trains, passengers in the immediate vicinity of the passenger using his/her phone for a voice conversation are forced to listen to the conversation in its entirety. With some passengers already having a complete and utter disregard for their surroundings and fellow passengers, a voice conversation could have the potential to go on for far too long and at a volume that is inappropriate for the environment (i.e. and airplane). I have been in an airplane cabin before where a passenger on the opposite side of the aisle from me carried on a conversation for at least 25 minutes at a louder-than-necessary volume during the entire boarding process, and fellow passengers around me were noticeably annoyed, as was I. I simply cannot fathom having to deal with someone (or multiple people) using their phones during flight, where conversations could stretch on for much longer. Title: Brad
Comment:
Please do not allow voice call cell phone use on airlines. I do not work for an airline but I am an ATP rated career pilot and a frequent flyer on the airlines. 
The golden age of aviation is over. Passengers no longer marvel at the wonder of flight, showing deference and respect to the flight crews, while wearing suits and ties. These days, the simple act of listening to the preflight briefing while keeping your pajamas on seems to be a bridge too far. And we've all seen, in headlines and in person, how difficult it has been for the flight attendants to get passengers to shut off their beloved electronic devices after door closure.
The point is, there is a pervasive indifference toward civility in our culture, and when it comes to cell phones, people are aggresively setting new standards of indecency. This lack of basic courtesy is annoying enough when in a situation you can soon leave, like a fast food establishment, or the movie theatre. In an airplane, however, there is nowhere to escape. We are all locked in this aluminum tube at 34,000 feet with no policing authority to help determine what is acceptable and what is not. So if you introduce this opportunity for unacceptable behavior into an environment that is not built to withstand it, you would be inviting air rage incidents on an unprecedented scale. This is why the flight attendants and pilots unions have been opposed to this from the start. They are on the front lines, and regularly witness this metastasizing plague of disregard for common courtesy. Thank you for considering my comments.

Title: Gabby Pecora
Comment:
To make it clear, this proposal does not allow cellular usage on board an aircraft; it proposes the discretion of the individual airline companies to make that decision for flights and aircrafts. Therefore, this gives the consumer various options of choosing an airline of one's liking. A person may think making a phone call is convenient, while others find it disruptive for those around.

Personally, my main concern with allowing anyone to make a phone call is safety for all passengers. I believe if allowing mobile broadband waves to be in use while in flight, there is no immediate harm in the navigational airwaves for the aircraft. My worry is more about what is said on the other line than the actual call being made. Think of a telephone call being made to a passenger on flight an airborne plane, the news from this could be devastating. Whatever the call informs the passenger, she freaks and the mental breakdown brings her more anxiety being on a plane. The other guests, the stewardess, the staff is unable to control the woman from being completely irate in a matter of minutes and there's nothing to do in the meantime but constrain her with force. The plane is in an uproar and now has a woman detained from another disruption. This is obviously worst-case scenario with a phone call being made while in flight but it's not far from the point I'm trying to make: there are ways to avoid harmful situations, or even situations where passengers take advantage of the system.

The position the DOT has taken brings more of an option to consumers by choosing an airline, as I have previously stated. Thus customizing a passenger's flight experience, with or without cell phones, could promote customer loyalty. The prices in flights have inflated dramatically after the national security hype post-9/11 and this is one way to creatively push more sales for favored airlines.

Title: Stephanie L.
Comment: Do not regulate the use of cell phones for voice calls on airplanes. The comfort and pleasure of passengers is the business of the airline company. They can design rules that best address the wants and desires of customers (either to enjoy the near-silence of jet engines, babies crying, pilot announcements, and passengers talking to each other; or to be permitted to make needed phone calls). Airlines might choose to limit or ban voice calls, or to announce to passengers that loud and lengthy calls will disturb other passengers and should be avoided. The government does not currently regulate other ways in which passengers might be noisy and annoying on planes. To my knowledge, the government does not currently regulate other sorts of polite behavior on planes, nor does it regulate cell phone usage on other modes of transportation.  This is not an area the government has a responsibility to deal with.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the use of voice calls on planes.  Particularly with the wide availability of data service in-flight and on the ground, which allows silent non-disruptive communication such as texting and emails, there is no need for in-flight calls.  Furthermore, most airlines generally allow voice calls once the plane has landed, allowing those few passengers who might prefer or need to make a voice call to arrange for ground transportation, etc., to do so during the usually ample time being landing and the time a passenger clears baggage claim and is ready for pick-up.  We live in a world where consumers are constantly wired, and we see the eroding of social courtesies on a daily basis -- texting and walking without looking where one is going, not turning off beeping video games during public transit, loud calls in public with incessant chatter.  Typically a request to a phone use to pay attention or turn down sound is met with rolling eyes or snappish comments (and seriously, I'm in my 30s, so please don't attribute my attitude to me being old and crochety).  Planes are too confined, passengers too tense and frankly phone users too inconsiderate to allow in-flight use.  I actually think voice calls would significantly raise the possibility of passengers getting into a heated argument that requires the intervention or attention of either flight attendants or other passengers, and that is both dangerous and distracting.  Security, safety and comfort for all should continue to be the mantra of our airborne transportation system, and voice calls are incompatible with each of those objectives. Thank you for your time.

Title: Kelly Bengtson
Comment: Road projects in Minnesota are being blocked by US Army Corp 404 permitting review process.  These projects are reconstruction of existing road in an existing road corridor with minimal impacts to wetlands.  In fact many of the wetlands the Corp is looking at were man made and exist in the road ditches that were built several years ago.  These roads now need to be reconstructed to meet updated safety standards and it is taking one to two years or more to obtain a permit. This is insane red tape and has recently surfaced.  In the past only projects built with Federal money had an issues, but now even projects built with State or local money are being derailed.

Title: Mark Little
Comment: Many of the Federal Transit Administration policies and regulations are excessively burdensome on small urban transit agencies with small staffs (under 50 buses). Programs such as Title VI, Equal Employment Opportunity, Triennial Review etc.., seem to be in the category as “one size fits all”. In addition, soon there will be a new requirement “Security and Emergency Preparedness Plan (SEPP)” which appears to be designed for larger transit agencies but the requirements will apply to all. I would suggest that a scaled-down SEPP would be appropriate for smaller systems.  All of the above mentioned programs (with the exception of the SEPP) have been in place for several years, but more and more components/requirements have been added over time. It is to the point where small transit systems are forced to add staff only to remain in compliance at a time when funding has decreased or remained stagnant. These funds could be better used for what they were intended for, providing a much needed service, public transit.

Title: Glen Glover
Comment: In the past if you were "Off Duty" the time counted the same as sleeper time in your over all 14 on duty. I understand that two hours wasn't enough time to get out of the truck and go some where to get rest but if you are off for 4 or more hours, it should not count against your 14 hours. Currently a driver who drives 2.5 hours in the morning is off for 9 hours and then drives for 3 hours in the evening is illegal, while another driver can spend 14 hours straight divided between on duty and driving time and is 100% legal.

Title: Les Whiddon
Comment: Increase the minimum weight threshold for commercial vehicle classification from 10,000 # to 15,000 #.  Modern vehicles are much safer and this size vehicle is not currently roadside inspected to any degree anyway.  This change would save companies that have small trucks a lot of money, without affecting public safety, and allow enforcement resources to be concentrated on larger trucks.

Title: Michael Day
Comment:
There are 2 things that absolutely destroy productivity in the trucking industry. 

The first one is the time that drivers are required to spend at shippers and receivers docks, which often runs into hours, and is often unpaid time to the carrier or driver. A shipper or receiver should be allowed 2 hours to complete their tasks of loading or unloading a truck. Beyond that there should be mandatory reimbursement to the carrier for detention, for any hour or part thereof that exceeds the 2 hour limit. This one little regulation would significantly improve every carriers productivity. It needs to be addressed.

The other item is the split sleeper berth regulation. Trucking is a 24/7 occupation. A driver may have pick ups or deliveries scheduled for any hour of the day or night. Under the old sleeper berth regulations, the 10 hours spent in the berth could be split in any fashion, and stop the 14 hour clock, as long as neither period was less than 2 hours. This rule was very effective in helping a driver adjust his sleeping schedule to his work schedule. It also helped drivers avoid gridlock in major metropolitan areas by allowing them to stop for a few hours, without penalty, prior to entering the city, to let the gridlock dissipate. Another big advantage to the old rule is that if a driver was sleepy during the day, he or she could stop and take a nap, without penalty, resulting in a better rested, and safer driver.

Under the new rule, only a period of 8 or more hours in the berth stops the 14 hour clock. That effectively takes away the drivers ability to sync his sleep schedule and work schedule, resulting in significant inefficiency. Drivers may also be forced to violate the hos rules, based solely the inability to sync them with the scheduling demands made by his or her companies dispatchers. 

Also drivers are now reluctant to take a break during the 14 hour window because they lose some of their productive time for the day. Where a driver may have stopped for a couple hour nap under the old rule, he or she will now continue to drive sleepy, to keep from losing any time on the 14 hour clock. A driver should have the flexibility to nap or sleep anytime their body is calling for it, without penalty.

Another adverse effect of the same rule: Under the old rule, a driver approaching a metropolitan area like Atlanta, near rush hour, might stop just outside the city and rest for a few hours to let the gridlock dissipate. Not only did that help the drivers efficiency by keeping him out of the gridlock, it helped the traffic conditions in the city because his truck was not in the middle of it. Under the new rule, the driver cannot do that without penalty to his productivity, because the 14 hour clock continues to run. So instead of stopping for a few hours, the driver will continue on into the gridlock and just hope for the best. 

While the new sleeper berth rule was made with good intentions, the adverse effects on productivity and safety have been significant. It needs to be changed back to the way it was.

Title: Karen Hill
Comment:
If we can allow our public servants - police, fire, medical personel - to work double shifts & extended hours in service to the public, our private employees should be given the similar consideration for their "single shift" of 14-hours. Is it any less important for our doctors or police to have less than the required amount of rest each day?

FMCSA should stop trying to micro-manage a drivers day by regulating rest breaks, hours of sleep, consecutive 1 am to 5 am etc. I believe we can agree that we want everyone home safe at the end of any day. Allow the truckdriver to plan the safest periods of their 14-hour workday to drive through metropolitan areas. Current regulations are forcing trucks through these areas during rush hour traffic or other periods when it is clearly less safe to operate there.

Title: James Harvey
Comment:
I have 20 years in various aspects of the transportation industry, all of which have been governed by the FMCSRs.  My lastest period of the last 12 years has been in driver training and CDL testing.  Many times while teaching new drivers, the question arises concerning aspects of the Hours-of-Service regulations.  Particularly the provisions of §395.1(b)(2).

§395.1(b)(2) Emergency conditions. In case of any emergency, a driver may complete his/her run without being in violation of the provisions of the regulations in this part, if such run reasonably could have been completed absent the emergency.

There is nothing specified anywhere in the FMCSR which defines what actually constitutes an "emergency" allowing broad interpretation by some, including drivers, motor carrier compliance officers and company safety officers.  

Recommend that a concise definition be included in §395.2.

Title: Dean Bayouth
Comment: I suggest a board of Industry professionals to review all new and existing regulations. It should consist of 20% from small trucking companies and their expenses paid for. There are many question marks that need to be clarified. Small trucking companies have been under attack by D.O.T and large companies for some time. Small trucking company owners have a wide range of knowledge of the trucking industry, while larger companies have departmentalized there staff. More workshops in more area's would be helpful.

Title: Timothy Howard
Comment:
1- Please consider specialized exceptions for weight requirements pertaining to Auto-Haulers.  Auto Haulers are designed to hold 10 vehicles, as long as size permits.  Often times a car carrier will be over weight even only hauling 9 units.  The "puzzle" of loading a car carrier means the weight will always be different due to the variety of automobiles, and how they are loaded to fit safely on the truck.  
2- Please consider changing the 168 hours for a reset to 120=5 days.  The major issue I encounter when auditing logs seems to be a driver reseting over the weekend from Sat. evening until Monday morning.  The following week because of schedule changes, the driver needs to leave out on Sunday.  The driver had Friday night off to Sunday morning but no valid reset.  The 1-5 AM is provision should still stand.  5 days before another reset should be more than adequate to curb the abuse of the pre-July reset rules.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
In answer to your request for feedback regarding the 34-hour restart rule, please see below for what we have experienced at Ed Thayer Inc as we have had to adapt to this new ruling:

 

 

1)   There has been a significant cost to us due to lost loads, equipment efficiency, and driver pay

 

2)   Dispatch has had to request fewer loads from shippers due to the restrictions as of July 1st of this year on our drivers

 

3)   Drivers pay has suffered as they have gone from six loads to five loads every two weeks, which equates to a lost revenue of approximately 1,600 miles per month

 

4)   Drivers have to wait until 5:00a.m to start their runs, putting them in some of the busiest traffic periods of a day through Hartford, Connecticut and New York City, which causes late deliveries and extensive on-duty hours

Title: Cindy Fletcher
Comment: Revise the 34-hour restart AFTER 168 hours.  When someone is off work they are off work.  If a driver is off for 34 hours; he's off 34 hours.

Title: Steven Brown
Comment:
Several Comments about this process:
1.  Conduct listening sessions and possibly webinars, tailoring some for specific operations administrations such as the Federal Transit Administration who we deal with the most.
2.  DOT should request input focused on specific operating administrations regarding large savings potential.
3.  FTA should make it easier to move funding from one item to another in annual grant programs to allow local agencies to respond faster and more effectively to changing environments.  The whole RTIP process is cumbersome and antiquated, requiring local agencies to often identify new technologies that they desire to use, only to have the market develop new and better solutions while the RTIP and funding process is cumbersome and moves very slowly.

Title: Joe Fannon
Comment: DOT needs to make and enforce fair labor laws for the transportation industry, especially drivers, like the rest of the American workers. This can be easily done by passing the electronic log mandate which will enable trucks and drivers to efficiently be tracked. Most drivers already are making less than minimum wage if you would take in consideration of the actual hours they invest in a week and an overtime rate after forty hours a week. Not many people are expected to work 70 hours in eight days or fourteen each day, as drivers are. Take into consideration they have to hunt for places to park, eat, and perform personal hygiene combined with the risk of performing the most safety crucial function in the industry, they should be fairly compensated. This would also help remove the fatigue factor of drivers being pushed, or them pushing themselves to earn more money by driving illegally outside of the of eleven hours limit, which DOT enforces.

Title: Guy Payne
Comment:
The voluminous regulations concerning the transportation industry, in particular the trucking industry, has created a state of confusion with operators attempting to comply. Spending many hours trying to comprehend regulations while simultaniously having to manage or operate their fleet on a daily basis creates a sense of compunction .  Many regulations are addressed in an overlapping, or inferance style causing one to spend hours "piecing" together the whole intent of the regulation.  This overly complex system of regulations causes compliance failures.  

I would like to see the regulations re-written in such a manner that would be inclusive of extraneous or referenced applicable material that directly effects the application and compliance behavior. Thus, enabling operators to easily locate and read a comprehensive rule making compliance more amicable and sensible. 

Retiring those regulations that are redundant or no longer relevant, due to technological advances, would ease the "man-hours" expended by operators to maintain compliance and reporting requirements. The reduction in funding regulatory interpreters would have a positive financial impact on the operators and ensure better compliance. 

Thank You.

Title: Patty Schaub
Comment: Please be advised, after over 35 years in the transportation industry, I find it curious that a panel of "experts" would decide it better for tractor trailer drivers to only reset once a week.  Wouldn't one think it more be more beneficial for drivers to reset "more" often and get more rest than only resetting once a week with less rest.  There is no "common sense" to this decision.   Customers and the industry is suffering from such a rediculous ruling.

Title: Mark Luxzcz
Comment:
Since 2008, the Delaware Department of Transportation (DelDOT) has repeatedly and consistently urged the Federal Highway Administration to eliminate compliance dates from the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD).  This is documented through our response to the following federal dockets:  FHWA-2007-28977, FHWA-2010-0159, and FHWA-2012-0118.  Much of our response to this request for comments is quoted from our previous submissions to FHWA.

DelDOT firmly believes that states and local agencies should have flexibility in compliance with the federal MUTCD. Adherence to strict compliance dates to ensure the continuation of our federal transportation funds will undoubtedly draw away scarce resources from other transportation improvement projects, including our federally mandated Strategic Highway Safety Plan. We acknowledge the need to approach traffic safety in a proactive and uniform manner, which appears to be the underlying intent of FHWA’s significant modifications to the federal MUTCD, including the adoption of new compliance dates. However, we believe the proper way to address highway safety is through a data-driven, programmatic process and not with strict compliance periods for modifications to specific traffic control devices.

DelDOT agrees with FHWA that it is important to be proactive with regard to the management of traffic control devices to improve safety for the traveling public.  However, we believe that states and local agencies should be free to manage our respective transportation systems.  Without the federal compliance mandate, we can choose at the state/local level how best to use our limited resources, based on local traffic and safety data, including data gathered as part of the federally mandated Strategic Highway Safety Plan.  This may include bringing certain statewide traffic control devices into compliance with the MUTCD sooner, or may include many other safety/operational upgrades not directly related to these compliance dates.  Although it is difficult to quantify, it is possible that the effort to comply with the MUTCD compliance dates could adversely affect safety as a result of diverting limited resources away from other, more critical safety initiatives with documented safety problems.

To quote from the Federal Docket No. FHWA-2010-0159:  “In general, the FHWA has intended that target compliance dates coincide with the useful service life of the devices that would need to be replaced to meet any new requirements, thus minimizing economic and logistical impacts on highway agencies.”  This statement completely misses the point that any MUTCD compliance date forces local agencies to develop programs to address those compliance date issues, including efforts related to study, inventory, prioritization, design, funding, and construction.  The elimination of all compliance dates would be consistent with Executive Order 13563.

In January 2014, the National Committee on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (NCUTCD) adopted the “20-Year Vision and Strategic Plan for the MUTCD.”  One of the recommendations of that plan is as follows:

“The MUTCD should not include compliance dates associated with the addition of or changes to MUTCD content. Where the implementation of new or revised MUTCD content should be accelerated, the establishment of specific deadlines for meeting MUTCD criteria should be established through memorandum or other administrative procedures.  Basis for recommendation: Placing compliance dates in the MUTCD creates legal requirements that cannot be adjusted without initiating rulemaking. Establishing implementation deadlines using procedures other than inclusion in the MUTCD provide flexibility for agencies to work with FHWA to best meet road user needs.”

In summary, DelDOT is opposed to any compliance dates in the MUTCD.  The inherently limited time, personal, and financial resources required to meet any compliance date will be better and more cost effectively utilized by state and local agencies in working on the study, engineering, and implementation of locally important matters, such as those identified through the federally-mandated Strategic Highway Safety Program.

This response does not address the specific questions posed in the docket regarding how the federal DOT should go about the second round of retrospective review under Executive Order 13563.  DelDOT may or may not comment specifically on those questions.  However, we wanted to take this opportunity to again raise this specific concern related to the MUTCD.

Title: Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection)
Organization Name: Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection)
Comment:
Dear Docket Clerk:

These comments are submitted on behalf of the Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection). County Connection operates fixed route and paratransit service within central Contra Costa County in the suburban San Francisco area. Our service area is over 200 sq. miles with a population of over 500,000. We provide over five million transit trips annually on a combined annual operating budget of just over 35 million dollars. 

I am writing to provide comments on the Office of the Secretary of Transportation (OST) request for comments on the Next Phase of the Regulatory Review of Existing Department of Transportation (DOT) Regulations, published February 27, 2014 at 79 FR 11051.

OST has offered a number of options for managing this review process, including simply
asking for specific rules in need of review, focusing on a list identified by DOT in 2011, focusing on
a specific operating administration, or focusing on cross-cutting rules. We do not believe any of
these options are mutually exclusive and that all have merit, based on a wide range of factors.
There are specific rules that, standing alone, are unduly restrictive and cause the regulated
community to expend excessive time and money to achieve compliance. DOT should seek
recommendations on these specific rules to be reviewed.
The 56 rules cited in the Federal Register should be explained in greater detail. The reference
to Attachment 2 of the Department’s 2011 final plan leads to a reprint of a routine Section 610 notice
and does not clearly specify which of the rules the Department identified as having potential savings.
Once clarified, we would encourage OST to seek additional information from the public and use that
information to prioritize its list.
Since the impact of rules is often cumulative, OST should pursue a modal review to ascertain
the overall regulatory burden on the regulated community and specifically to identify those areas
where differing rules require the same or similar information to be processed and presented in
different ways. This review should not be limited to existing rules, but also those being developed.
Similarly, OST should focus on cross-cutting issues to eliminate unnecessary costs and
confusion. Buy America, with many differing interpretations of compliance, should be an immediate
focus. While the underlying statutes may differ, the differences are exacerbated in widely divergent
regulatory schemes and practices within the Department. Moreover, projects that draw funding from
more than one modal administration require clear guidance on what rule applies. As the Federal
Transit Administration crafts its safety program, OST must ensure that the program can reasonably
co-exist with the Federal Railroad Administration’s program to avoid duplicative, counter-productive
efforts.
Within this exercise, OST should also look to the various Circulars and other guidance
documents that have become de facto rules through practice, oversight, and other modal
administration actions. While an underlying regulation may be benign, the interpretation and
enforcement of the rule is often cumbersome. We have found that review processes have tended,
over time, to enlarge regulatory requirements through the threat of adverse findings and these de
facto rules carry the same potential for wasting time and money as formal regulations.
Finally, the Department should examine its rulemaking processes. Delay and uncertainty in
the regulatory process only compound the ill effects noted above. As an example, OST proposed
changes to its regulations related to services for people with disabilities in 2006. Over eight years
later, the proposals are still pending. Federal courts in multiple circuits have found them
unenforceable before they are finalized, yet they are regularly enforced through adverse review
findings. This leads to confusion for agencies providing the services, the passengers dependent on
the services, and the state and local governments responsible for funding the services.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Rick Ramacier
General Manager
County Connection 
2477 Arnold Industrial Way
Concord, CA 94520
925-680-2050

Title: Don Jewell
Comment:
The DOT comments are actually a bit misleading as they infer this is an early or pre-operational deployment of CNAV messages and that is a bit of a misnomer. Under the original guidelines CNAV signals would have been broadcast back in 2003 but events prevailed to prevent that from happening. However, and this is an update to the numbers in the original Federal Register Notice, there are currently 12 GPS SVs on orbit capable of broadcasting civilian L2C CNAV signals and military code or MNAV messages. Additionally there are five GPS satellites (IIFs) on orbit capable of broadcasting L5 safety of life signals for DOT.
	Frankly the DOT objects to these signals being broadcast now for, in my humble opinion, very nebulous reasons, and the USAF is working hard to and has, again in my opinion, negated all of the DOTs concerns. Currently GPS is the reigning PNT Gold Standard. In order to maintain that status and indeed to continually exceed the capabilities of any of the current or planned PNT systems in existence today, the GPS needs these new signals. I predict CNAV and MNAV messaging capabilities will revolutionize the way PNT signals are utilized. These new signals bring about a capability heretofore unknown in the PNT arena; each CNAV and MNAV signal has the ability to broadcast 256 separate and definable messages to users globally. With 12 CNAV satellites on orbit today, global accessibility tests have shown that for the majority of users this means at least one CNAV SV in view at all times and you only need one CNAV SV in view to take advantage of the messaging capabilities. So the sooner the better I say - just imagine the possibilities.

IS-GPS-705 contains both 1) incorrect GNSS ID bit assignments and 2) and missing the L5 ellipticity values.  The absence of this information may create design issues by providing incorrect requirements to reciever manufacturers.

Title: John Lavrakas
Comment:
Benefits. Benefits to users include:
1.	Users and manufacturers have early insight into operational signal structure and data transitions.
2.	Users are able to test out performance improvement for their applications.
3.	Manufacturers are able to check out receiver performance using the new signals.

Risks.
1.	Risk: Users who are unaware of Air Force intent to use for test purposes will use the signals operationally. This is how their equipment is designed, and this is in compliance with the interface specifications. Many such users are unaware of the technology they use; they just hook up the box and get excellent positioning and timing.
a.	Impact: Limited Impact. Only a small set of users would be affected, and none of these involves safety of life. Some of the applications are real-time, such as open pit mining, roadway grading, and precision agriculture. If undetected signal anomalies were to occur on CNAV signals, there could be significant economic impact since receivers would continue to operate using the anomalous signal. For digging and grading applications, this would result in the added expense of correcting the errors and having to do the work over. 
b.	Likelihood: Likely. Most receivers are single frequency using L1 C/A, so this would only affect the users who purchase high end equipment that track the new civil signals to improve accuracy and are used in realtime applications. Note that GNSS receiver manufacturers design their equipment to conform to GPS Interface Specifications which say that it is ok to use a healthy signal. They do not design their equipment to handle the case that “signal is healthy” could also mean “use at your own risk”.
2.	Risk: An anomaly occurs and is not addressed quickly, resulting in users being exposed to an aberrant signal. 
a.	Likelihood: Highly Likely. This condition persists until OCX is operational, assumed to take place as late as 2019; thus the risk will exist for about five years. While significant anomalies could occur as often as 3 times a year and last for up to six hours, the actual occurrence is on the order of once per year. Assuming there are five years until OCX with monitoring, It is reasonable to assume there will be several significant anomalies that will occur without monitoring conducted using the baseline OCS.
b.	Impact: Limited to Significant. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, the effect could be significant. Because many precision realtime civil applications today do not involve safety of life, the systems do not perform integrity checks, and thus are unable to reject aberrant signals. 
Issues.
1.	Testing on the CNAV message is incomplete. In 2013, significant tests were conducted in concert with the civils on a portion of CNAV messages and problems were identified. No further tests are proposed as far as I know on either the rest of the CNAV messages or on verifying the fixes for the first set of problems, so it is reasonable to assume that without further testing to confirm compliance, more issues involving non-compliance will appear.
2.	The operational protocols for health settings on legacy and CNAV navigation messages have not been worked out and published. Because of this, there will be ambiguity and varying implementations in user equipment. While the interface specifications provide the format and content of health settings in the messages, they are not define the operational management of the health indicators. GPS receivers and users are heavily affected by health settings, both in continuity of service and in timely response to anomalies. A documented operational management description for health settings is needed describing when and how each of the health indicators will be set. 
3.	Another issue to consider is whether the U.S. Government loses any legal protections if it intentionally misinterprets a setting in the publicly available interface specifications, namely declaring that the setting “Signal Health to Signal OK” also means the signal "should be employed at the users' own risk”. Although the U.S. Government would have not declared the signals operational, such a position still would be not in compliance with published interface specifications.
 
Appropriate timeline.
If the decision is made to go ahead with broadcasting pre-operational CNAV messages, the following steps are recommended:
1.	Test CNAV in close cooperation with civil community. This means not only for the Air Force to run tests and report the results, but to let the civil community to run tests using their own equipment and under representative conditions for civil applications. This should be done in 2014 and as soon as possible.
2.	Develop an operational protocol for the CNAV signals in cooperation with the civil agencies. Publicly document how health settings will be handled. This should be done in 2014 and as soon as possible.

Further detail including examples are provided in the attached file.

Title: Trimble Navigation Limited
Comment: The attached document contains the comments of Trimble Navigation, Ltd., on the DOT Notice: Global Positioning System Pre-Operational Civil Navigation Message Continuous Broadcast,  Docket: DOT-OST-2014-0028

Title: Ed Baron
Comment: Our preference would have been to see these signals start broadcasting when the first L2C/L5 capable system was launched.  You are years late so the sooner the better.  Receiver developers need access to the live signals to start testing their incorporation into products.  We see very little risk in broadcasting pre-operational CNAV messages.  They use the same clocks and broadcast the same data on different channels and the existing signals provide ground truth for comparison.  Broadcast of this data will give the user community the opportunity to compare the quality of these signals and help build solutions that might be less impacted by interference.  This is a much better situation than the late 1980s when we only had a few satellites on-orbit and we did not have a full constellation of operating satellites with validated signals for comparison.

Title: Fahd Arshad
Comment: The transparency in fees and especially promoting one airline over another is great. Third party aggregators were already doing this because it leads to great user experience and much lower frustration levels. Kudos.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
We as consumers need a SIMPLE and CONSISTENT means to compare airline fares.  The Airlines have so many ways to create and change fairs today, The same seat can sell for $99 or $1099 or any where between based upon demand and when it is being sole and to whom it is being sold to. Examples a seat being sold 6 months in advance may be discounted to $99, the same seat to a business traveler may go for $800 and the same seat to business the day of travel may go for $1099.

Why do we need to have a base price then add taxes/fees?  It should be just like the Gas station the price you see is the price you pay.  There should be a simple "laundry list" (the same for each Airline)  with ticket price (including taxes and fees) baggage fee, headset fee, meal fee, drink fee, Premium seat fee,  etc... and a grand total at the bottom.  Then we could compare prices between Airlines based upon price and schedule.

This proposal to separate the taxes and fees, I believe, give the airlines an even greater advantage in confusing the customer.  I have seen prices already that have taxes and fees removed that show a flight for $500 and when you go to book it the taxes and fees are over $500 more raising the total price to well over $1000, that's an additional 100+% (these were for international flights).

Title: M.P. Donahue
Comment:
I am in favor of enhanced transparency for the consumer. How else can one compare apples to apples when we are purchasing a product like air travel?
I see no downside to this for any honest company.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: airline fees should list the total cost of ticket, price, taxes, baggage fees and any other fees related to using the ticket.

Title: J. McGettigan
Comment: I support all of the components of this proposed regulation. Hidden or "undisclosed" fees keep popping up throughout the entire process of purchasing an airline ticket, checking in for the flight, and checking bags. I've been bumped from flights for not purchasing a seat, even though I paid for the ticket and the website did not indicate that a passenger MUST purchase a seat separately. Many airline websites will indicate that "seat assignments are not available" at the time you buy the ticket, and indicate that there are numerous seats available. Then as the day of travel approaches and the website shows fewer seats available, it becomes clear that the passenger MUST purchase a seat rather than risk not having one.

Title: C. S.
Comment: I agree with the need to increase transparency concerning ancillary fees in the airline industry. As an international traveler I have often been unhappily surprised at some of the added expenses that airlines charge. Personally rank the airline industry together with used car salesmen in degree of sleeziness. The more regulation the better.

Title: Eric Key
Comment: The true cost of travel should be front and center in any advertising of airline fares.  If there is a fee for checked baggage or any other service that should also be posted where it is obvious to anyone reading the advertisements.

Title: Therisa Rogers
Comment:
I am a US Citizen living abroad, and I use Internet aggregators to buy tickets to visit my parents in the USA.  Sometimes, it's difficult to understand and compare prices, when one considers fees to checked or even carry-on luggage, taxes, etc.  I also wonder if certain airlines are being promoted, not because they actually offer the best fare or schedule.

Please adopt rules to clarify the fees and to consider Internet aggregators as ticket agents.  It would save time for me and for other citizens, residents, and visitors.

Title: Joseph Powers
Comment: I think it's a great to make airlines provide information on the entire cost of a flight, including all fees, taxes and other costs to be borne by the traveler. It would be bestif that total was thethe most prominent, and first, number that the consumer would see.  However, I acknowledge that some costs, such as seat selection, might be difficult to manage in that way.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am in FAVOR of this rule. Glad to see a regulation siding with citizens.

Title: Keith Scipps
Comment:
There should be consistent industry-wide regulations regarding baggage fees. Allowing each airline to make up their own rules is ridiculous. 

Each passenger should get one checked bag for free (as long as it conforms to size and weight regulations), as well as one carry on and one personal item. After that each bag should be charged $10.00 not $25.00. The airlines would still make plenty of money, but they would be charging fees for EXCESS BAGGAGE, not the necessities of travel.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am in FAVOR of this rule. Glad to see a regulation siding with citizens.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am in FAVOR of this rule. Glad to see a regulation siding with citizens.

Title: Thomas Baca
Comment:
The US Airline fee structures border on Extortion. Change fees, cancellation, baggage and seat fees. They are free to change any of your itinerary without regard to your needs as a consumer. If you try to change, delay or cancel a trip you are charged hundreds of dollars. You have lost your free will or your money in any case.

Reregulate this industry that has lost it's way. It is run like a payday loan company.

The itinerary on my upcoming United trip has changed 3 times since I booked it. They did not give me anything back. You even have to pay a fee in addition to fare to upgrade to Business class for medical reasons.

Title: Thomas Baca
Comment:
The US Airline fee structures border on Extortion. Change fees, cancellation, baggage and seat fees. They are free to change any of your itinerary without regard to your needs as a consumer. If you try to change, delay or cancel a trip you are charged hundreds of dollars. You have lost your free will or your money in any case.

Title: John Fasoldt
Comment: Kill the Transparency Act.  It is too opaque

Title: Mark
Comment: Do something for the little guy for a change....Force airlines to advertise prices that include ALL TAXES AND FEES. How else can we compare apples to apples...Thanks

Title: Ron Gosswiller
Comment:
How about a vastly new idea: Advertized flight cost is all you pay, nothing more. 
You know the concept—"truth in advertizing." Yes I realize honesty is a bygone concept, along with honest representation.

Yes I realize legislators have their corporate contributors to look after, after all, they are the only "citizens" who are actually represented.

Title: Shukree Tilghman
Comment: We need to maintain and create greater transparency in airline prices. As a frequent traveler, it is maddening to get hit with hidden fare rule charges, baggage, seats, television, internet, and a host of other dumb charges, all increasing at a higher rate than any of our wages.

Title: Cathleen Merenda
Comment: please make flying costs for consumers as clear as possible, spirit airlines took us for a financial ride this weekend and it was too late to change flights, consumers need complete transparency for airline fees and fares

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
All fees to consumers for airline travel should be posted, upfront, clearly and transparently.  No fine print and no weasel
clauses.

Title: Jeff Williams
Comment:
Dear DOT,

As a weekly traveler I very much want to have easier to read and evaluate the cost of my travel, not the opposite.

The poor business traveler gets so much abuse from the system, yet pays the higher percent of the costs, as short notices force last minute purchases.

The least your governmental agency can do is mandate concise and accurate information for the public to evaluate, not concealment and slight of hand like many of these companies want to practice. Just ask anyone who has traveled for over 30 years how much things have degraded and you will certainly get an earful.

Thank you,

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It is imperative to know the "all-in" true cost of a flight - all associated costs.  Full disclosure is essential. Government rules are needed to protect the public from incomplete information.  All costs must be shown.  And all key performance metrics too,

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Transparency now.

Title: Kirsten S.
Comment:
Yes, please make it mandatory to disclose ALL fees upfront, including baggage fees, seat selection fees, etc.  It is too hard for the consumer to make an informed choice when the airlines hide their fees.  The price advertised should at the very least be the price, including taxes, at least 1 checked bag (as airline trips are for TRAVEL) and any other fees necessary to procure a seat on the plane.

Additionally, please include such websites as Kayak, Expedia, Orbitz, etc. in these regulations.

This is an overdue regulation!

Title: Andrew Giammarco
Comment: At a time when more and more fees are being charges to consumers for basic services, it is important that airlines post those fees upfront when advertising fairs so that consumers can make an informed decision about their purchase. This is and important rule that should be imposed by the DOT.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This whole idea sucks.  The public should have transparency in all airline transactions

Title: Robert Thornhil
Comment: Airline fares and charges have become so changeable and confusing that consumers have an almost impossible task to determine what they are paying for.These regulations are essential for consumers who do not want to be exploited and overcharged for travel.

Title: Suzanne Gittleman
Comment: Please protect consumers.  This "regulation" does not benefit them.

Title: Madelyn Weiss
Comment: I am someone who does not fly often, but when I do, I often find the process of selecting flights and finding the best fare daunting at best, even with all the on line services out there supposedly helping you do just that.  Having all the fees, besides the base fare, laid out, and knowing the relationship between the booking service I'm looking at and the airlines would make finding a good deal much easier.  I, therefore, support the current rule.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please protect consumers.  Vote against this; it is anything but transparent.

Title: Matt Nadler
Comment: When I chose an airline for a flight, I should be permitted to understand ALL of the charges I'd be subjected to, including change penalties.  Purchasing a ticket comes with a contract.  The conditions of that contract must be fully disclosed and easily found.  Otherwise, the airlines, and the government that permits selective disclosure, is committing a form of fraud.  It's time for our representatives to consider the people, and not the airline lobbyists

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please protect consumers.

Title: Mark White
Comment: Bravo!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Everything should have a price tag, and then there should be a total at the end.  Just like in the grocery store.  Why is that so hard?  The airlines know all these numbers.  Consumers deserve to know them too.

Title: Steven Heydemann
Comment: Please take whatever measures are needed to provide consumers with complete and accurate information about the costs of air travel.  Please do not permit Congress to pass legislation that would make it easier for airlines to obscure the true costs of travel.  The regulations proposed here are badly needed, a welcome improvement.

Title: Rock Miller
Comment: I think airlines should disclose all fees and taxes so you can get an idea of the actual price of flying somewhere. Especially since airlines charge for baggage, legroom, and other stuff you might not think of at first. The cost of flying into one airport instead of another is also relevant. There is no excuse for concealing any of this.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please make ALL fees, costs, taxes, rules and regs in airline tickets transparent and easily understood BEFORE one buys the ticket - so, for instance, put in if they charge extra for seats, for checking in one bag, for getting food - etc. etc.  Make airlines list ALL fees and costs just like a restaurant menu.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I have two concerns regarding the considered regulations. First, there is no documentation of how the estimated costs were derived. Surely this has to be provided so there can be a substantive and transparent debate about the policy? Or are we to accept on faith that the figures are the best derived possible? I find the extent of the costs hard to fathom given that the regulation is asking airlines to do nothing other than include some information which is already available digitally with other information which is already available digitally. This can be easily integrated into the existing purchasing systems, why are the costs so high? Second, if there are no significant costs incurred by airlines, why is there opposition to a proposed regulation which would do nothing more than give consumers price information to allow them to make a sound consumer decision? Has the cost-savings to consumers not having to spend time looking up all the competing information worth calculating as well?

Title: Richard Lachmann
Comment: I hope you approve the rule as written. Ordinary citizens don't have time to scrutinize the various possible add-ons to base ticket prices. Airlines have the resources to hire experts at fooling and outwitting customers. These rules diminish airlines’ unfair advantage. The rules also are family friendly. Ordinary consumers have busy lives: working, caring for children and elderly parents, cooking; cleaning. Whenever we have to invest time and effort to decipher and compare complex price formulas we lose time we could devote to family. It is either overpay or spend time. Your rule makes it possible for us to pay a fair price without having to devote hours to figuring out deceptive and confusing airline prices.

Title: Etienne Wenger-Trayner
Comment: All the surprising fees are simply maddening for the consumer. I was so grateful when regulations forced all airlines to include taxes in their quoted prices. Upfront transparency is essential. I don't understand why the airlines are opposing this when it is so clear that they make their customers mad and in fact when transparency does not hurt their business as long as everyone is playing by the same rules. When businesses cannot see what is good for them, regulations need to help.

Title: Robert Cushman
Comment: The proposed regulations are a sham and should be carefully evaluated and rejected in favor of consumer protection.  The idea that this regulation would use the word "transparency" in its effort to deceive the flying public is an outrage.  The newly proposed department of transportation regulations for more information and real transparency which would include all fees associated with a given flight is the honest way to go.

Title: Robert Cushman
Comment: Please reject this new regulatory sham.  We need more transparency, not less.  The flying public needs to know all fees associated with any given flight.  Anything less is dishonest.

Title: Alan Onnen
Comment: This is an amazingly bad idea. I want to know how much I'm going to have to pay... Period. Fees; taxes; the whole works. That's transparency.  In fact, the opposite of what you're doing here should be law: car ads should have to include tax, delivery fees, etc. Ads for anything costing more than $20 should have to give the best estimate of total consumer costs.

Title: Jim Whitehead
Comment: Providing more information to consumers helps us make the right choice.  How can anyone legitimately say we should not know how much our plane ticket will cost?  Please enact this regulation.

Title: Kristina Kus
Comment: I strongly support this proposed rule.  Honesty in pricing should be instinctual, however, as airlines find new ways to hide the true price of their services,  a rule forbidding such practices is necessary to protect consumers.   I am willing to pay the necessary amount, but I want to know exactly how much I'll be paying and where every dollar goes,  particularly as services are no longer all-inclusive.

Title: A. Custer
Comment: I 100% support making ancillary fees more transparent from the beginning of the search stage. I have found it so frustrating in the past to be given one price, only to discover the true price when all sorts of taxes and extras are suddenly tacked on. I applaud the DOT's efforts in this matter.

Title: Rollie Smith
Comment:
I really cannot express how much I think the airlines MUST show the FULL price including bag fees, and any other services for which they now charge. I have on several occasion bought tickets only to find out at the airport about checked bag fees and other "not so optional" services. This situation is a complete disgrace. It is difficult to find the information if you don't know where or how to look. Even if you know how and where to look the language is often unclear. Now that some carriers are charging for carry on bad this situation will only get worse.

The FULL price with ALL fees, even the "optional items" should be shown on the main flight selection page. This should apply to both the airline web pages as well as third party sites such as Orbitz or Travelocity.   

Again I cannot express how strongly I feel the airlines should be made to be as transparent as humanly possible.

Title: Ralph Carabetta
Comment: PLEASE pass this proposal in its entirety and resist efforts by the airlines and "pro-business" lobby to keep us flying blind.  It is the right thing to do.

Title: Carville G. Bevans, III
Comment:
Comment on DOT-OST-2014-0056

I am an American citizen living and working in Germany over the last decade an a half, and I have found it increasingly difficult to obtain up-front and clear pricing and conditions information with passanger airlines when I book intercontinental flights between Europe and the USA.

I fully endorse Transportation Secretary Foxx’s comments about ‘knowledge is power” for consumers.  In today’s age of rapidly found information on personal computers, the airlines and all parties offering airline ticket sales should be compelled to clearly state the bottom line when it comes to price.

One further comment on the format of the publicly available Air Travel Consumer Report - this should be augmented by an easy to use website that graphically and simply summarizes the airlines track record over the past few years so consumers can get up-to-date information before making final decisions to book airline tickets.

Title: Hank Roden
Comment: "Oh, the price I cited for the car did not include the price of seats or a trunk."  Does that make sense?  What the airlines and their agents are doing is lying about the cost. That simple. Lying.    Thank you for the proposal, I hope you can withstand the corruptive  influence of members of congress.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Yes, please ratify this !  I prefer no. 2 as is, not the alternate.  I have no opinion about other alternates.

I would also like to see a regulation that prohibits airlines from changing flight numbers and schedules so they can reset on-time performance to 100%.

Thank you.

Title: Monroe Sheppard
Comment:
These fees, the costs involved, should not be any sort of last minute, end of the process barely revealed part of booking travel. Getting it up front earlier, clearly shown will be a great help to all and will help to avoid confusion and passenger upset.

Putting true numbers out on what an airline actually flies, to where and how many is also a great bit of information long past due. 

Please approve and get these rules out into the marketplace.

Thanks you

Title: Kathe Stevens
Comment: I recently purchased complicated, multi-city tickets on American Airlines. I chose American after using third-party sites to narrow my choices to the lowest fare. After I decided to fly American, I went to its website (where the advertised fare was indeed available), chose the flights, and then got to seat assignments, I discovered there were no "available," i.e., free, seats left. I didn't want to add to the price of my airline ticket but faced with the idea of starting the process over again (and don't forget, sometimes consumers are flying to take care of sick or dying friends or relatives, or visiting a troubled child, or taking their turn at caregiving for an aged parent, any assortment of travel that is already disheartening to arrange), I chose to pay the extra fee. I believe all fees should be transparent in order to make an informed decision. Thank you.

Title: Peter H.
Comment: This is an excellent idea. More clarity, information and transparency is always better for any market. It also appears that proper analysis was done with respect to the impact on smaller entities and they are exempt from certain provisions.

Title: Jeanne Miller
Comment:
I am favor of this regulation.  I'll offer a very good example on how undisclosed ancillary fees have directly affected me as a consumer.  My husband's uncle died and I had to find 3 round trip tickets from Omaha, NE to Myrtle Beach, SC, with less than a week's notice.  I ended up choosing to drive to and fly out of Kansas City, MO to save $200 per ticket.  The published airfare was $x.  I started the booking process and went to the next-to-last screen to select seats.  The seating chart said that every seat was UN-available - unless I paid $25 per each of the 3 legs for each of the 3 tickets, adding a total of $150 to each of the 3 tickets.  This allowed me to choose "Economy Plus" seats, which according to the phone representative, were the only seats available for purchase.  The flights were from MCI to ORD, ORD to ATL, ATL to FLO (where we rented a car and drove the rest of the way).  The MCI to ORD and ATL to FLO routes designate the first few front rows as "Economy Plus", but there are no distinctions in seat width or pitch on those regional jets.  (One regional jet had the airline name "Air Wisconsin" still painted on the side of the jet!)  The flight from ORD to ATL did have a dedicated Economy Comfort section, with the better seats.  

The only reason I chose to pay the extra $150 was that my father-in-law needed a little extra help in flying and by choosing seats, I could offer that extra help to him.  It was not necessary that all three of us needed to sit together, and the small size of the regional jets didn't require that someone be with my father-in-law.  But the booking process required that all 3 of us pay the extra fee, for every leg of the flight, whether there was a benefit there or not.
 
Had I been better informed of this at the start of the booking process, I would have chosen a more direct flight, directly from Omaha to Myrtle Beach, rather than trying to "save" $200 per ticket by driving to Kansas City from Omaha and then from Florence to Myrtle Beach, since the "savings" turned out to be $50 per ticket for the flights.  

I purchased my tickets on US Airways, which code-shared United Airlines flights to create the itinerary.  Neither US Airways or United were the real carriers on the two regional jet segments - their name was not on the equipment, but only on the ticket.  Delta would have been a far better choice - if only I'd known all the options at the beginning of the booking process.

Thank you for proposing this regulation.  This example is only the most egregious one in the last two years.

Title: Carl Davis
Comment: I support full disclosure of the entire cost of an airline ticket.  This is an obvious basic consumer right that is long over due.

Title: Frederick Langhorst
Comment: More transparency in the reporting of total travel costs is an improvement.  I urge adoption of this measure as a way to give the consumer more information in selection of travel options.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am in favor of the proposed regulations. In order for two parties to enter into a positive economic transaction, both parties need to have sufficient information to make a decision on whether the transaction is good for them. While the government should not regulate prices, it should regulate disclosure so consumers can make informed decisions. This creates "win, win" economic transactions which build wealth in the economy. Hiding these fees creates the opportunity for "win, lose" transactions which at best create no wealth and at worst destroy wealth. Full disclosure of fees is both reasonable and necessary for a properly functioning economy.

Title: Lynn Saxton
Comment: I would like to see fees presented in a clear and concise manner similar to the Schumer box for credit cards, with the requirement that all airlines must use this format.

Title: Randall Clark
Comment: As a frequent flyer with almost 3 million miles (on my preferred airline; some miles on other airlines as well), I have watched the unbundling craze develop.  This industry has taken this basic marketing idea to extremes.  If the hotel industry followed the airline lead, they would provide you only a room and bathroom.  Sheets, pillows, towels, toiletries, phone, TV, would all be extra.  This is why the airlines are unique and should be treated as such: they alone have stripped their service totally bare.  Furthermore, there need to be regulations to cover refunds for baggage lost or damaged.  Their lost/ damaged baggage  procedures developed years ago when baggage service was free (in the ticket price).  I think they should provide a full refund of baggage charges if the bag it not provided to the consumer within 24 hours and pay a 50% penalty if the baggage is not returned within 48 hours.  Despite these comments I am a real fan of what the airlines do. They generally deliver excellent service to an enormous consumer base, but they need to be held fully accountable for the unbundling.

Title: Rick Horan
Comment:
1.)	Why should the airlines have to include government mandated taxes and fees in their rates?  Think about it, hotels, department stores, bus companies, rental cars, and virtually every other business are not required to include theses costs into their advertised prices? 

2.)	The government doesn’t have a very good record of truth in advertising.  Let’s take its gambling monopoly for example.  The Lotto ads scream you can win $20 million! But wait, that’s before you lose about half to taxes and collect the other half over 20 years.  If you want it all at once that’s at a much lower payout.

3.)	As far as regulating seat pre-assignment fees and baggage fees, so what?  The airlines have simply adopted to the model of keeping rates low for the basic flight and charge people for the extras, including food.  What’s wrong with that.  Let’s face it, the airline business if very risky and many of them fail.  When that happens we all lose.

4.)	On time performance?  Let that policy be driven by competition too.  The ones who have better records will use that information at the expense of those who do not.

5.)	Here’s another idea for accessing the data.  The FAA, knows when every flight in the country departs.  Let them share this data online so enterprising people can correlate this information with the airline schedules.  Problem solved.

6.)	Mandated disclosure of mishandled baggage rates?  These are still private businesses and should not be forced to disclose this information any more than FedEx or UPS.  The internet is a very effective way for millions of passengers to share information, both positive and negative.  If an airline is losing luggage at an unacceptable rate they will be paying the price in lost business.

7.)	Regarding trying to regulate bias in travel Web sites, can we first ask that the owners, editors, writers, broadcasters, etc. in the media disclose their own political leanings so that readers/viewers can factor that bias out of their reporting?

8.)	It would be great if Congress was as transparent as it wants the airlines to be. 

If Congress really wants to make the cost of flying transparent, then let’s make the government responsible for publicizing the taxes and fees it mandates and stop trying to pretend that the airlines are somehow responsible for them.

Title: Gerald Astorino
Comment:
The airlines are getting away with too much.  Recently, US Airways "removed" me from my FIRST CLASS reservation and could not put me back on that flight (overbooked).  The only available flight was the next day and had to personally expense a night in a Hotel, which they will not reimburse me for.  They continue to use sneaky excuses, such as (1 minute) schedule changes to justify a change in itinerary and only offer a "refund" if the rebooked flight is unacceptable......funny how it only works one way (advantage - Airlines).  For those who take a schedule vacation and also book (non-refundable)
hotels, this seems to be a scam for which the public has no rights.   Let's do something about their abuse!  Thank you

Title: Kimberly Rotter
Comment: On third party sites, like Expedia or Travelocity, all potential fees should be disclosed while comparison shopping. Currently, they only show the fees for checked luggage. I also want to know - before selecting a ticket - whether there's a fee to sit with my travel companions (particularly when purchased together), whether there's a fee to select a seat in advance, a fee for carry-on bags, a fee for a boarding pass, a fee for making changes to the ticket, and so on.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Great idea to require apples to apples all in fare comparisons - a good example of the govt. working FOR consumers/constiuents.  Thanks.

Title: Juancho
Comment: Airlines, trains, ferries and busses should disclose all fees involved in the fare being shopped/purchased including the ancillary fees, surcharges, fees, taxes and government charges. The cost of the services onboard, luggage checked, carry on and seat reservations fees need to be disclosed up front and itemized through the entire process. So that if I byt two tickets round trip from point A to point B, the fare, fees, taxes, services are all added up and also itemized during the booking and shopping process. This should apply to all modes of transportation; airplane, train, ferry, ship, bus, taxi and car or bike rentals.

Title: Roman Radomysksky
Comment:
Thank you for moving towards more transparency!  

I would like to see the flight/fare search engines (and airline's own websites) require that you enter number of bags, any elite status(es) with carrier(s) and seat preferences at the same time as entering the date(s) of travel and the origin and destination information to produce a comparable prices across all the available options.  

I am also excited to see a step towards less "bait-and-switch" practices with code-shares or contract carriers.  It seems unfair advertising, in my view, if I buy a ticket on "Delta" (because I truly enjoy the carrier's service and aircraft features/amenities) but then find myself flying another carrier (or feeder) because the two carriers agreed to partner.  It is great and convenient for the airlines but as a customer, I am sold one thing and received another.  

Also, other (travel) services that generally come with a myriad of "disguised" fees are car rentals and hotels.  The taxes, including local "occupancy" taxes, surcharges, amenities and "resort" fees can vary dramatically and are generally unknown until I check out and see the bill.  It's almost never a pleasant surprise.

 Thank you very much, you are doing the right thing!

Title: Robert B. Magness
Comment:
I am in favor of the airlines industry disclosing ALL fees upfront to the consumer. The ludicrous assertion by the airline trade association that the "proposal overreaches and limits how free markets work" shows that they have no concept of what a free market means. It DOES NOT mean deception. It DOES NOT mean trickery. Obviously there is an inability to think at the higher echelons of the airline industry or they would not require such intervention. I applaud the DOT for stating the obvious and I lament the unethical practices of the decision makers in the industry, where ethics here means simply doing what is the greatest good for all involved.
Sincerely,
Robert B. Magness
825 Harbor Oak Lane
Clearwater, Florida 33756

Title: Anonymous
Comment: All fees should be stated clearly, and exceptions and special circumstances explained in a way that can be clearly understod even by tens and old people. Costs should be noted for any/all services.

Title: Lawrence Moore
Comment: I support this rule. Transparency is long overdue. All fees & taxes should be shown in the ticket price. The idea that fees/taxes are added on after the customer has researched a buy and the deal is struck is inane.

Title: Jeff Kahn
Comment:
Yes, this rule is needed.  I recently was surprised to learn that my wife and I had paid more than $2,000 for airfare to Africa on British Airways only to learn that we had to pay $39 each to reserve any seat whatsoever on each leg of the flight.  Total extra charge was $390.  I would not have chosen British Airways had I know the real price at the time I made my purchase.

This is dishonest.   Make aviation an honest business.  Please.

Title: Jeff Kahn
Comment:
Yes, this rule is needed.  I recently was surprised to learn that my wife and I had paid more than $2,000 for airfare to Africa on British Airways only to learn that we had to pay $39 each to reserve any seat whatsoever on each leg of the flight.  Total extra charge was $390.  I would not have chosen British Airways had I know the real price at the time I made my purchase.

This is dishonest.   Make aviation an honest business.  Please.

Title: Sandra K.
Comment:
There's no question that consumers are being seriously nickeled and dimed to death by the airlines, (the absolute worst offender right now being Spirit Airline) to the point that other industries are taking their cue from the airlines, charging for as many ancillary services as they can get away with. Everyone also seems to have forgotten that the airlines were de-regulated (and therefore consumer protection stripped) under late President Ronald Regan. The flying public has become fair game. Where is Consumer Protection when you need them?

I'd also like to mention that, in the past, getting pillows and blankets and meals were not 'free' once you purchased a ticket, but were covered in the cost of the ticket.  True, flying overall was less expensive overall, and no one tried to snooker the public with what has become petty 'excise taxes' couched as individual costs.

Title: Aviva Williams
Comment:
I am strongly in favor of the proposal to require airline ancillary fees to be clearly disclosed at the time of booking. Today, airlines are charging passengers a la carte for things that ought to be included in the base fare.  Such as selecting a seat.  (And can one realistically be expected to travel for more than a day or two without a full-size suitcase?)  For anyone who cannot afford first class, airline service has become a race to the bottom.

Having all the fees clearly identified at time of booking will help us consumers determine the true cost of our travel.  Please implement this rule as quickly as possible.

In a similar vein, can the DOT look into a cap for ticket change fees?  In the age of the computers, it does not cost an airline $200 to switch a passenger to a different flight.  It probably costs $0 since human interaction is not even required.  Airlines charge these fees because they can.  I believe that all these exorbitant fees are detrimental to our modern society, in which families and friends are spread across the country and need affordable travel.

Title: Mike Howe
Comment: I fully support the rules as proposed.

Title: A. Adams
Comment: The only effective way for for consumers to make informed decisions regarding travel plans is to require that all fees be clearly delineated and available for review at the START of the booking/purchasing process - not at the end after all billing data has been entered and the choice to back out is more complicated. This detailed pricing data will strengthen, not weaken the competitive marketplace.  Since major carriers have proven over time that they are not willing to self regulate and offer this to their passengers, the DOT does have a legitimate role to play in protecting the American consumer from false and/or misleading advertising.  Please protect consumers and approve this regulation.

Title: Chris
Comment:
I highly support this move! The airlines have been using prices schemes for years to hide fees that we consumers have had to pay for. I still remember decades ago when the price of a ticket included the flight, a non cramped seat, 2 carryon bags, 2 stowed bags, drink of your choice, snack, meal (if applicable), and a smile. Now we're just paying for the ability to be tolerated and possibly arriving at your destination on time. Anything more will have to be paid for in fees.

The airlines complain that this move will hurt the "free-market" in which they hold their business. But I posit that this move will allow consumers a better idea of which company to trust, thereby increasing loyalty, and which company to move away from, due to their fees. This move would not be against a "free-market" move but much more in-line with it.

Title: Susan
Comment:
I am in favor of these regulations requiring airlines to disclose upfront the cost of basic ancillary services (such as checked bags, carry-on items, seat selection).  This is needed for consumers to be able to accurately compare costs when selecting air travel.

I am also in favor of expanding the airlines covered by these regulations  (from 1% to .5%).  Smaller regional airlines should have to follow similar rules as the bigger guys.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It's necessary to enact laws to protect the consumer. Ironic misstatement of transparency.

Title: Carrie Devorah
Comment:
The issue of Airlines is not Ancillary Fees nor of Consumer Protection issues at this point. The issue of Airlines is of Government interference in what is no longer a reality of TOO BIG TO FAIL but rather too big too succeed.
