I will be writing a more complete piece on this, specifically the merger of United and Continental Airways being the anatomy of what goes wrong when government intervenes going for bottom lines rather than, as I experience first hand, a clash of airline cultures.

It was mindblowing that one could see on my recent flight the stark difference between the United Airlines employees and the employees from Continental.

It was mind blowing to see how foreign regulators are to what goes on in the belly of the beast, so to speak, where the passenger and airline intersect. A culture survives only when it does not cannabalize its own, as the airline industry is doing to its passengers.

My piece I will be writing then posting to my site THE CENTER FOR COPYRIGHT INTEGRITY www.centerforcopyrightintegrity.com will trail the experience of customers departing DC to Newark, some staying, some connecting. That was in fact not the case.

Our plane was hit on the runway by a tug truck, hard enough the plane shook threatening to go over, hard enough to require, eventually, all passengers to deplane. Luggage remained on board for those passengers preferring to avoid lines at carousels. Sort of. Luggage for three passengers making noise was removed. Crew failed miserably at connecting to passengers. Those staying in Newark or nearby were ok to wait. Those catching connecting flights were misled as to connecting to flights. Again, I will detail this in the article that will post to my ezine- www.centerforcopyrightintegrity.com

Alot was learned. The flight staff in DC failed in Customer relations. Passengers were mismanaged. Rolling terminals should have been brought in ASAP to get Connecting passengers to other flights as not to miss connections abroad. Some destinations have only one flight a day. Ground crew with anxiety in crisis should have been yanked ASAP. 

This is for starters. On record is that a plane filled with passengers feared safety when the plane was hit on the ground. NOT on the record is that United Airlines reported the flight problem as an Airtraffic Controller issue. It was not. The plane was hit by a truck. There is a penalty for filing fraudulent papers. This penalty must be followed through with against United.

Passengers learned from crew how unhappy United employees are with their current CEO. Hate would be a kind word after seeing how pained good employees are to having to do a bad job they feel does not reflect them.

To capsulize what will be detailed in the piece I will write and will be illustrated with printouts from emails and some pics, it seems United is gambling as to who will complain demanding customer respect and who will not.

Multiple emails were received from United Airlines "updating" on the plane departure. Crew were guaranteeing connecting flights would be caught they were not. There was no effort to bring courtesy water or food to passengers who were refused being put on connecting flights but were put back on the plane, eventually, sitting in heat without water until eventually the plane could find a slot to take off.

Oh, yes, the plane had to be looked at before it could take off. THE mechanic was called. No, not A mechanic was called but THE mechanic was called. He had other issues to adress before he could get to this United Airlines plane to vet it airworthy. Passengers connecting to other flights missed their flights. There was no outreach to passengers of any courtesy sort. IF passengers complained they were led to customer service reps to rebook new flights. This was in and around 10+ at night. 

By the time re-bookings were done, IF passengers complained they were offered a hotel voucher. IF passengers complained they were starved, by this point, they were given a $7 food voucher. Ever buy a coffee in the airport? 7 bucks does not go very far. Customers were told United's CEO orders is that food vouchers and hotel vouchers are for disabled, old and kids, not for other customers. The United reps all said, 'we wish we could do more.' Not with the CEO they currently have.

Of note now, is the bag on the plane scam that takes place. Any bag that cannot be put overhead and is deplaned, goes under the plane FOR FREE, unfair in flights where passengers are penalized for bags sent below. Penalize & charge passengers that want express access carrying bags on board. Let passengers storing bags below go for free. 

Do I expect to see United last too long in the airs? In a culture where cheap flights are sought, mmm, for a bit. Long term? Not at all. People may be cheap but not stupid learning more about the culture of airlines through the conduit of the Internet. Remember, give me about a week for me to write my complete illustrated piece... TOO BIG TO SUCCEED

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am all for complete disclosure of airline fees.  How else can one find the best value for a flight?

Title: Rosemary Anton
Comment: Please require that all information about air fares include ALL additional fees, taxes, costs, etc.   That kind of transparency is essential for consumers when we are trying to compare air travel option.

Title: J. G. Welch
Comment: Every airline should be required to post each and every ancillary fee associated with passage on that carrier.  For a carrier argue against such disclosure is ridiculous.  Each fee imposed (advance seat assignment, carry-on, printed ticket, extra leg room, baggage charge, et al) is a part of the fare that airline charges the passenger to get them from point A to point B.  Those fees have to be considered in total so the consumer can make an informed choice between one carrier or another.

Title: Milli Hoffman-Patrick
Comment: I support this proposal.  All airlines should have to disclose each fee that will be charged in connection with purchasing a ticket, including all checked bag, carry on bag and seat assignment fees.  The purchasing public has the right to know exactly what it will cost to travel on an airline.

Title: Brian Pape
Comment: I think this is a brilliant proposal and whole heartedly support it.  Do NOT let the airlines and their minions scuttle or substantially change the proposed rule. It is extremely frustrating trying to compare fares and buy the cheapest ticket.  The proposed rules will make life easier for consumers.

Title: Kathryn Soderberg
Comment:
I am SICK of airlines!! They are crooked and deceitful and frankly DOT, I don't know that I have any confidence that you will  be able to reel them in!!! Once you try to implement some new policies and sanctions, they will lawyer up and claim that they are being treating unfairly! Like so many other industries they live on GREED!!! I am sickened by them and have refused to fly anywhere in the last 3 years. I won't play their game. I either drive or take the train and sit back and enjoy the ride. 

These fees are sneaky and frankly dishonest!!! They know it, their sales reps know it, everyone knows it. First it was luggage, so people in order to save funds pared down to one small carry on bag!! Oh no!!!  the airlines aren't making their projected profit so, now they charge for carry ons. They charge for everything they can think of. 

Frankly, we should boycott them!!!! I will only fly if I absolutely have to and at this point, I will FED EX/UPS my luggage. They are greedy thieves!!!

Title: Lance J. Konover
Comment: It is very important that all fees be disclosed ahead of time to ticket buyers, so that they may make an informed comparison between different airlines, which have widely differing policies. If an unsophisticated customer makes that choice without that information, they may well end up paying half again or more than the ticket price to check luggage. The free market principle requires that the customer be able to make an informed choice, and any and all information that affects this choice should be available.

Title: Paul Vignoli, Jr.
Comment: Consumers should be informed of all charges when booking travel when fare is displayed/advertised.

Title: Joe Jelson
Comment: This regulation is one of the very few rules favorable to the citizens of the US, and needs to be enacted.

Title: Nicholas Neild
Comment:
I have a story about hidden fees when dealing with the airline industry that may help this cause:
My wife and I bought a flight through Kayak on Dec. 17th, 2013, set to fly out from San Diego on Feb. 23rd via United and their international partner Lufthansa to Prague, Czech Republic so that we could celebrate our wedding with her family on April 4th. Unfortunately, on the morning of Feb. 2nd, 2014 we got a call from my wife's mom notifying us that her youngest brother, 14 years old, had committed suicide and the funeral had been set for 2/8/14. We had no idea he had been suffering from severe depression related to difficulties in coping with his sexuality. Of course we were shocked, stricken with grief and afraid that we would miss the funeral. We called United to ask them what could be done, and how much it would cost to change our flight to an earlier one. The lady we spoke to said that we would be responsible for the cost in the change in airfare and that the fee would be $300 per person, but that we could expect to get $250 per person back if we file for a refund with the death certificate. I told her $100 was definitely affordable and thanked her and United for being so compassionate, flexible and understanding. She then asked when we would like to leave, and we said that we had to be there by Friday 2/7/14 at the latest if we were going to make it to the funeral. She told us she found a flight that left on 2/6 and arrived on 2/7. I talked it over with my wife, and we agreed $100 was well worth the change of flights and I gave her my credit card information. She told me that credit card (my Capital One CC) wasn’t working, so I then gave her my Priceline Rewards Visa which worked. We were then in a frenzy to wrap up what we had planned on doing for the next few weeks in the next couple days. I checked my email at 1am 2/6/14 (the morning of our flight) when I was forwarding my itinerary to my dad. That’s when I noticed that there was an additional charge of $519.96 for me and $519.96 for my wife beyond the two $300 charges that we discussed. I was never told these figures over the phone, nor did I agree to pay for them. Consequently, the lady had charged my Capital One card for the $600, and the Priceline Card for the $1039.92. Again, I was not under the impression that both cards were even being used. After countless hours waiting on hold and over a month waiting for a reply from customer service, we were able to get the two charges of $250 back as promised, but were given the cold shoulder about the two $519.96 charges. I told them I would no longer shop with United and left them with a few suggestions that you may wish to include in your docket:

1. Customer service representatives should always tell their customers the total charges they are agreeing to pay. 
2. Customer service representatives should not say a credit card isn't working, and then still charge money on it. They should clearly explain how much money is being charged on each credit card. 
3. Customer service representatives should be trained to be very clear and honest with customers suffering from shock and grief. It would even be nice to have a special customer service representative that is skilled at talking with customers suffering from grief and have customers who fit that criteria forwarded to them. 
4. Customer service representatives should be given more latitude in helping customers come to a fair resolution of conflicts without being bound by red tape. 
5. Customer service representatives shouldn't be a minimum of a 20 minute hold away. 
6. Customers should receive a response to a written dispute in a timely manner.
7. Customer service representatives should have accurate and stable feedback on what to do when their customers are experiencing a dispute and not to give conflicting information. 
8. Customer service representatives should listen to their customers instead of reading a script.

Unfortunately, that isn’t even the end of the story. When we got to the airport in Prague for our return flight, we were told that the specific airline partner that United contracts with only allows 8 kilograms for the total weight for the personal item and carry-on luggage because their airplane is so small. Since our checked luggage was already close to the maximum weight (from wedding presents), we couldn’t put the things in our carry-on into our checked luggage and were forced to pay an additional 80 euro to check one of our carry-on bags. This is another hidden fee that you should be aware of. These types of fees should be clearly explained when purchasing the original airfare from Kayak, United or whoever sells the ticket so it reflects all potentially hidden fees. In the end, we were charged close to $1200 more than what we ever had anticipated, which has created a tremendous financial hardship for me and my wife during an already difficult time in our lives (getting married, starting a life together and losing her brother).

Title: David Oakeson
Comment:
I am thankful for this proposed regulation and nearly plead with the DOT to proceed with the full disclosure requirement.  Airline pricing is now partially hidden and sneaky, and it is difficult to find out the true cost of flying from point A to point B with a checked bag, a carry on, and an assigned seat.  Finding the cost with adjacent assigned seats, e.g. a family, is even harder.  Some airlines, e.g. Spirit. Allegient, and to a growing extent, Frontier, are difficult to find out the total cost without beginning the purchase process of submitting personal information and possibly payment information.  I inquired Spirit once the cost of an assigned seat on a specific route, and they were very elusive, saying somewhere between $1 and $99 per passenger.

The regulations are not burdensome.  All passengers request is honest pricing.  We buy a book, TV, appliance, etc., and we see a price.  We try to buy an airplane ticket, and maybe it costs us an extra $200-300 with baggage fees, carry-on fees, and increasingly assigned seat fees.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The proposal to give travel agents more information and make ticket agents more transparent sounds fine, but the bottom line is that many consumers now buy airline tickets directly from the airline. Are you calling the airline's website a "ticket agent"? If not, the proposal has no relevance to my airline ticket-buying experience. If so, then the bottom line for me as a consumer is to know what I'm getting into when I click "Purchase ticket." 

Information that would be especially useful if on the same purchase web page so the true price of a flight can be computed:

"Any change will cost $350"
"All checked bags $100 per bag" 
"No gratis food service./No food available for purchase.
"The extra $75 for this seat does not buy a larger seat, only more legroom"
"No carry-on luggage allowed that does not fit under the seat." 

And so on. 

Make them reveal everything.

Title: Lea Bowers
Comment: I think the DOT's proposed transparency with airlines and airfare is a wonderful and long overdue thing!

Title: Gajendranathan Ramanathan
Comment: Let the airlines tell the whole truth to the customers, don't change the current pricing system.

Title: Boola Lomuscio
Comment: Travelers should not be blindsided by fees and charges when arriving at their point of departure. All costs should be available when first making a reservation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Sad that government has to be involved but some airlines "hidden" fees have made the market deceitful, destroying the opportunity for healthy competition, luckily there are a couple of airlines that have not lowered them self to this practice.

Title: John McCoy
Comment: The more transparency, the better.  If you wade through the ticket information, get ready to reserve and pay, then find out that the ticket will cost you more than the initially advertised price, you have to start all over again looking for a less deceptive fare.  I am for the proposed rule.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airline fares should include total cost of transportation including baggage fees and "carry on" fees, if any, taxes, added cost of seat assignment and any other charge so that the traveler knows exactly what the cost of air travel will be from point of departure to final destination, excluding food and beverages. Anything else is just plain deceitful. It would be similar to paying the advertised price of gasoline and then told of an additional charge for use of the pump.  MAKE IT SO NOW!!

Title: Paul Sullivan
Comment: I am in full support of the need for airlines to disclose up-front any charges in addition to the air fare, specifically but not limited to, the baggage handling charges.  I want to know how much the real cost of a particular fight is BEFORE I book it.

Title: Charlotte Barnes
Comment:
DOT  docket # DOT-OST-2014-0056

    With the astronomical increase in air fares it is only fair ( and competitive ) that airlines be required to itemize all the "add-ons" to a basic fare.  The advertised fare should reflect the total "out - the -door" cost of a ticket INCLUDING all taxes and associated fees.  Other optional items/services should be presented as a "menu" from which the traveler may choose - including the price for such items.

Title: Carey
Comment: Airlines are masters is bait & switch tactics & have us at their mercy.  They change schedules, relegate us to cramped and ergonomically horrendous seating, charge us more to sit in a seat with more leg room or on an aisle, tack on fees for every little change and basically screw us because they can. While this proposal may not solve all the issues it is a start. PLEASE listen to the consumers and not the industry lobbyists.

Title: Joseph Mignogna
Comment: Purchasing an airline "ticket" is clearly purchasing a service and not a product. There are multiple components to a "ticket" over and above a printed card or piece of paper verifying your name, flight #, date of departure, and itinerary (departure and arrival airports). An airline "ticket" is not a boarding pass. Airfare is but one component, and others include baggage fees, sales tax, airport and other taxes or fees, seat assignment, food and beverages, use of toilet, use of overhead compartment, etc. Definitions are critical to ensure consistency for both airlines and consumers. Should we expect to see automatically assigned "service gratuities?" Perhaps 10% for a morning flight, 15% for mid-day, and 30% for late day or evening split between pilots and cabin crew? Un-popping charges for soft drinks? Pay toilets? Air vents rented by the minute? The trend toward unbundling is a clear and egregious scam by the airline industry to mislead consumers, businesses, and travel agents. It's not complicated. Require airlines (sorry they can't regulate themselves) to display clear and simple "fairs" comparable between all carriers without unbundling any costs that the consumer cannot control, then add a menu of optional items (food and beverages, seat upgrades, baggage, etc.).

Title: P. Brody
Comment: Please, please, remember that many travelers are not wealthy and need full information on costs and options in order to choose the flights and airlines that best serve their needs and their budgets.  Please . . .

Title: George Mirsadshanow
Comment: We need the airlines to be up front with all the prices of a flight and not nickel and dimes us to death

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please protect the consumer in deciding not to allow airlines to obfuscate the true price of airfares.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I feel it is important and necessary to the flying public to know what the total cost of a ticket.  Please do not let the airlines get away with less than full transparency.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am very much in favor of full disclosure of all fees, taxes and tariffs associated with the purchase of an airline ticket.

Title: Ben Broughton
Comment:
It is about time.  Pass the rules.

Similar rules should be proposed to require lodging and car rentals to advertise a total price including taxes, in room safe, internet access, local calls, airport fees, collision insurance, etc.

Title: George Mirsadshanow
Comment: You ticket should include 2 bags, taxes , food or snacks.  There should be no hidden fees.  Lets stoop the rip off by Airlines

Title: Griselda Sutton
Comment: I wholeheartedly support the proposal requiring airlines telling customers upfront the total cost of an airline ticket.  I also support anyone selling tickets to show this information.  Nowadays computers make such information readily available for little or no cost.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Re: Department of Transportation proposed rule DOT-OST-2014-0056, I am in total support.  Airlines should be required to post/list all fares and associated fees in the process of the consumer purchasing air travel.  Airlines are currently taking advantage of the consumer as they list low fares then when the consumer makes the actual purchase, they find that they must pay additional for items such as a seat on an already nearly full flight.  

I have no issue with an airline pricing their flights based on supply and demand, but the price quoted via online, email or print for a particular itinerary/city should include all known fees prior to purchase.

Title: Wayne Kolb
Comment: I cannot imagine why any airline feels it is acceptable to obscure the charges for airline tickets unless it is simply GREED.  The only possible explanation, in my opinion, is to extract as much money as possible from their passengers by obfuscating charges.  PLEASE set regulations for a "standard disclosure among" ALL airlines.  If any of them wish to add additional information that should be allowed; however, each airline should be mandated to disclose the exact same charges - in the exact same format - as a starting point.

Title: Anne Kinzel
Comment: The regulations should address consumer concerns by requiring the carriers to define an "airline ticket" as including two-checked bags, one carry-on and advance seat selection, access to free bathrooms, and free water on board.

Title: Mary
Comment:
If we expect transparency from our government's overseeing federal spending, then we should accept no less transparency from private corporations that are the beneficiaries of our public largess. We the People, should know the total and final cost of all transactions made when purchasing transportation of any corporation that is granted subsidies from government tax revenue. We the People should should have the the influence to control this transparency, not the airline industry.

As the Boomer Generation continues to age up, so might their acumen to recognize constant changes relating to flying. I have witnessed the trials of fliers as they navigate their easy through check-in, TSA screening, and baggage handing. The fact that hidden fees suddenly emerge is unsettling at best and potentially humiliating. All consumers should know up front all the costs of flight.

Title: AZ Contirbutor
Comment:
All merchants who provide services to the public need to be forthright and honest with their pricing, including airlines.

The airlines are bringing in new monies and doing much better financially thanks to all the new "fees",   

What is NOT acceptable is disguising tickets at a competitive price only to learn that all "fees" had not been disclosed.

Full Disclosure is the way to go.

Title: LaRae Markle
Comment: All of these additional fees are rediculous.  Allegiant has gone so fas as to tell me twice my credit card was denied/because I would not pay a seat fee.  During the time it took for them to approve my card they increrased the fare $25.00 per ticket so they got their fee in another manner.  I will never fly Allegiant again.  I honestly expect the next fee to be a charge for the restroom.  Please stop these fees!!!!!

Title: Judy Fair
Comment: Quoted airline prices should include your choice of any available seat on the plane except first class, one small carry-on and a purse, a light snack or beverage on short flights or meal on long flights, a blanket or pillow if requested, and of course, access to the bathroom.  Taxes and fees should be included in the price quoted.  it would be nice to allow one checked bag per person free.  I think the large carry-ons should be banned.  Basically this is pretty much what I get from my chosen airline at this time.

Title: Margaret Brauer
Comment: Airline ticket prices should include fees for one checked baggage and one carry-on of a certain size with wheels!  To compare prices under the current situation one has to read each airline's policy to determine what the true, total cost of flying with that company. Senior citizens should be able to wheel their carryon (required medications,  camera, ipad or computer, etc).

Title: Craig Bryce
Comment: i think airlines should include all fees, taxes and one checked bag in the price of it ticket . it would make all the airlines equal.

Title: Tom Jolly
Comment: Please make airlines and all others provide 100% transparency for air fare price quotes. We need to be able to compare apples to apple.

Title: J. Clayton Baum
Comment: As a consumer, I request that you retain the requirement of including all taxes and mandatory fees in the ticket price.  Other fees, such as checked and carry on luggage, change itinerary, seat selection, do not need to be included in the base price as long as they are clearly indicated on the same page as the ticket prices. This would better allow the consumer to choose which options they prefer.  If possible, I will always fly Southwest Airlines, because they do not charge to change your itinerary or for checked baggage.

Title: Donna Klamm
Comment: I think the airlines should be accountable to the public in reporting ALL fees for flights. This includes 1st & 2nd checked bag, carry-on bag, taxes, advance seat assignments, and miscellaneous charges. For individuals on a fixed income this is extremely important. Frankly, I think it outrageous that the airlines are making over a billion dollars in checked baggage fees alone.  Please make all airline fees open to public viewing when making reservations.

Title: H. Dunster
Comment: THE RULES AND REGULATIONS NEED TO BE CHANGED. BE HONEST ABOUT THE REAL PRICES OF AIRLINE TICKETS. WHAT THEY ARE ALLOWING, AND NOT ALLOWING. SPELL IT OUT. MAKE AIRLINE TICKETS TO INCLUDE ALL TAXES AND FEES, BUT DETAIL THEM SEPARATELY, SO IT CAN BE IDENTIFIED. IT IS WRONG TO CHARGE ALL THESE CHARGES, KEEP UP ALL THE FEES, COLLECT ALL THE PROFITS, AND STILL KEEP UP THE HIGH PRICES ON TICKETS. TO CHARGE FOR SEATS, BOARDING EARLY, BAGGAGE, CHANGE FLIGHTS, NO FOOD, POOR SERVICE, UNCLEAN SEATS, TRAY TABLES, POOR AND UNSANITARY AIR FILTERS, CROWDING UPON BOARDING, POOR BAGGAGE HANDLING, DELAYS, NO VIABLE REASONS, AND THEN BLAME IT ON WEATHER. MOST TIMES WHEN I CHECKED THE ARRIVING CITY, NO PROBLEMS WITH WEATHER, NO DELAYS REPORTED, AND YET WE ARE TOLD THAT THE DELAY WAS DUE TO WEATHER. THIS AVOIDS THEIR ON TIME REPORTING, PAYING CUSTOMERS FOR THEIR DELAYS AND CAUSING HAVOC WITH THEIR PERSONAL BUSINESS COMMITMENTS. WITH THE AIRLINES MERGING, SERVICE DECLINING, COMPETITION, AND CUSTOMERS MORE DISGUSTED WITH HOW THEY ARE TREATED. CONFIDENCE AND LOYALTY WITH BUSINESS TRAVELERS IS DECLINING, AIRLINES WILL CONTINUE TO FIND THAT CUSTOMERS WILL CONTINUE TO BE MORE SELECTIVE IN WHOM THEY WILL PURCHASE THEIR TICKETS FROM, WHAT THEY WILL RECEIVE, AND WHERE THEY WILL SPEND THEIR COMPANIES MONEY OR THEIR OWN. REDUCING PERKS, SERVICES, AMENITIES, AND PRIVILEGES THAT WERE ONCE AWARDED TO GOOD CUSTOMERS IS THE BEGINNING OF THE END. WHAT WILL IT TAKE FOR THE AIRLINE INDUSTRY TO WAKE UP, AND THE GOVERNMENT TO SPEAK UP ON BEHALF OF THE PUBLIC AND DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT. DO NOT BE INTIMIDATED BY THE AIRLINES, WE HAVE SEEN THEM COME AND GO, AND THAT WILL CONTINUE TO HAPPEN IF SOMETHING ISN'T DONE NOW.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a frequent international flyer, I'm more closely reminded of what air travel used to be like. The domestic airlines in this country will continue to dissect their fees to the point of introducing seats with 3" of padding and others with no padding creating yet another revenue stream. They are unrelenting in pursuit of growing profits through manipulation and quiet meetings of collaboration driven by greed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: All airlines should be required to display airfares to include checked baggage, a carry on item and seat selection!

Title: Bryan Everett
Comment: I think the total cost of the ticket should be displayed before purchase. Broken down and listed before purchase should be the cost of the ticket including all taxes and government fees, a free seat assignment with an option to upgrade with no pressure stating that if you do not buy advance seat assignment your party will be seperated, one piece of free luggage with in weight limits as almost all passengers will need one type of luggage whether it be a full suitcase or a carryon. That way it is easy to compare apples to apples when viewing air fare prices. Another area of great concern is the wide variations in the way that frequent flier miles are marketed and delivered to consumers. These are a major headache for consumers that vary greatly from each airline with all kinds of different rules, restrictions, and additional charges.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I think that the initial fares should have every charge listed.  This way there will be no unpleasant surprises.  Because to the current fare structure, we fly as little as possible.

Title: Chloe Powell
Comment:
I would appreciate it if the airlines would be honest and clear in the case of the advertised fare to include all taxes and mandatory fees. One should be able to assume that when you book a  flight the cost stated should include the trip,
as well as a seat assignment, baggage fees, whether checked or carry on, as well as access to a bathroom.  I am
weary of feeling duped each time I am required to purchase an airline ticket!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Just tell me the exact price. Include what you think are extras; what I think are necessities. Like a cruise line, your prices should be cheaper as take off time approaches, not the other way around.

Title: Gail Sattler
Comment: All fare quotes should show everything that is included in the price. Southwest Airlines does it right! Fare includes tax and airport fees and nothing else will surprise the passenger when they arrive at the airport. If there are options, they should be listed at the same place the fare is listed - such as early check-in, extra or overweight baggage, seats/fares for children, charges for flight changes, etc. Extras are getting ridiculous!  Baggage check, one fee if you do it online, one fee if you do it at the airport, one fee if you carry it on board, one fee if you put it in the overhead.  Checking in, one fee if you do it on the phone, one fee if you do It online, one fee if you do it at the ticket counter, and fees for printing your boarding pass, or having it online or ?  Then there are also fees if you want or need to talk to a person on the phone. Some airlines are charging for window and aisle seats!  Spirit Airlines is the antithesis of what all this should be. Either include everything in the fare, or make a comprehensive list that people can choose from. Make the menu clear and people will be much happier and not have to feel like they are being abused. Fortunately, I get to use Southwest Airlines for where I need to go!

Title: Donna Boerma
Comment: My husband and I vigorously support all efforts to compel airline transparency in pricing. We believe that all fees, etc., should be defined and included in the original purchase. We also believe that separate fees for seats, baggage, food services, etc., have become not only outrageous but also insidiously underhanded. We would most definitely choose to fly open and honest airlines such as JetBlue and Southwest if they were available to us for our itineraries.

Title: Richard Pfeffer
Comment: I strongly support the proposed rule to require airlines to make all their fees transparent up front and to quote ticket prices including checked and carry-on luggage, booking fees, taxes, seat assignments etc,

Title: Marilyn Kohl
Comment: Consumers should be told the entire cost of a flight at the time they seek information about a ticket and should be able to  compare total costs among airlines, which have been conning travelers long enough.  I fully support the proposed rule.

Title: Bill Hartman
Comment: This disclosure rule is needed. I believe the airlines need to make a profit after years of financial problems. However, profit should not be made by duping the public. If airlines want to post a basic fare, taxes and associated fees should be included. As for add-ons, there is no IT reason preventing an available options menu to be shown for ticket buyers to calculate the added cost. It's obvious airlines are fearful truthfulness about the total cost will cause travelers to seek other modes of transportation. If so, they need to find ways to be competitive other than through chicanery.

Title: George Henzler
Comment: Airline ticket must be defined and include basics, seat selection, carry on baggage, certainly all taxes and fees.  The consumer should be able to compare ticket prices for what they are buying.

Title: Gloria Graf
Comment: I definitely support this legislation.  The airline industry is like a runaway train.  Who knows what they will charge for next? The new rules do nothing to prevent additional charges, but at least the airlines would have to be up front about them.  I do not think that the airlines care one thin dime about the customer.  Their attitude seems to be that if we don't like it, don't fly; but the truth is that in this day and age if we have to get between point A and point B in a reasonable amount of time we have to fly.  Personally, I would like to see rapid rail.  Many of my friends and neighbors have said that if we had rapid rail, they would ditch the airlines completely.  Why not have the competition?  I don't expect the airlines to run in the red. I do wonder though whether high gas prices was the only reason that they were failing before.  Could it be the outrageous salaries and benefits of top management also contributed to their losses?  Also, they seem to compensate employees from ground agents to the top with several free flights a year I worked with a person back in the 1980's who told me she had several free flights a year for the rest of her life..(she was laid off from her job as a boarding flight desk job)   She was only in her late thirty's at the time.  Multiply that thousands of times over plus inflation.  I retired from the telephone company, but I don't get free telephone service and I worked over thirty years both in craft and management positions.  I get a $15 discount - that's it.  Perhaps these types of perks should be investigated and made public so we can see where all this new found money is going.

Title: Thomas White
Comment:
It's about time the government take some action to provide the treveling public the true cost of an airline ticket.  The traveling public has no idea of the total charges of a ticket until they get to check-in.  the airlines have hidden these extra charges far too long.

Pass legislation now to correct these rip-offs.

Title: Marie Persons
Comment:
I am pro government regulations on the airlines industry!  One in particular, Spirit, sneaks in so many fees that by the time you click your cost have doubled for an 'inexpensive ' airline ticket.  

Please, don't give up the fight, we need to hold them accountable, we need a price to be a price and not the beginning,  We all wish we wouldn't have to do this, but if the airlines industry had their way, they would charge us for walking up the ramp to the plane.

Keep up the good work.  Don't let them be deceptive.   Call the airline industry on they misleading tactics.

Title: James Jones
Comment:
I have been flying weekly since August 1974 so you can say I am a seasoned traveler.  Many years ago I began flying Southwest Airlines exclusively because they seem to be the only airlines that cares about its passengers and they have never lied to or misled me.  I believe all airlines should be required to reveal and include all fees in the cost of the ticket so that travelers know the true cost of the flight.  Flying as much as I do I am aware of the hidden fees so I can truly compare costs. The hidden fee situation has gotten out of hand; pay extra for a bag, pay extra for a certain seat, pay for food and drink while on the flight.  The last time I had to fly on American the flight attendants were selling head sets, snacks, drinks; it was like being in a flea market.

Bottom line, the practice is deceitful and dishonest and abuses the traveling public.  If all airlines had to reveal all fees and what they do and do not provide, the public would have a true picture of which airlines are in fact the less expensive.  I ask you to force airlines to practice full disclosure when it comes to charges and fees.

Title: Darwin Walls
Comment: FULL DISCLOSURE OF OF PRICING ELEMENTS SHOULD BE MANDATED FOR AIRLINE FARES

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We support the the above proposed rule for transparency of Airline Fees.  My husband and I are in our 60's, and we find the current rates confusing.  We will not be flying until this comsumer protection issue is passed.

Title: Tom Fullerton
Comment: I am a frequent flyer for pleasure-Iam tired of the airlines not being fully honest on the cost of buying a ticket and what they will provide for that price.  I support your rule changes.  Thank you.

Title: Judy Huffstutter
Comment:
I paid $160 for a ticket and ended up paying $265. I think the add on's  are out of line.

Judy Huffstutter

Title: Jerrold Petterson
Comment:
As a shopper has no way to guess what taxes and fees might be added on to a base fare, surely the airlines and other sites offering help to shoppers can provide this information, either broken down or as a sum total. Baggage fees vary so much from carrier to carrier that an easy to read explanation should be provided. Advance seating choice seems so obvious for families traveling that I wonder that any carrier doesn't offer it. Some carriers do a pretty good job now. Let's not go backwards to a less informed time. 

I don't buy the argument that stores and food vendors don't have to quote charge, tax, and total. Most residents of the states know what their sales tax is. Hotels often omit the resort charges that are almost always mandatory; that is not right either. 

Too much information would be better than too little when purchasing an airline ticket.

Title: Gordon Hagewood
Comment: I absolutely support full disclosure of all costs associated with airline travel. Only then can consumers make a valid cost comparison and make an informed choice.

Title: Mike Lefkowitz
Comment: It's hard enough to make a reservation. We should at least know exactly what we are going to be charged for - the final service.  What other service or product (other than health care) are we left in such a mystery until we are too far into the process to back out.

Title: Jamey Aebersold
Comment:
I travel a lot and when I'm looking to book a flight, I want to see ALL the prices for my trip. Please don't let the Airline Lobby hide my costs! Thank you,
Jamey Aebersold

Title: Anonymous
Comment: "Ticket" implies all required fees and should be required to do so. A list of options would be useful in planning a trip. I have all but stopped flying because of cost confusion and multiple restrictions.

Title: James Sellers
Comment: No question, quoted airfares should include all costs, including taxes and fees. Consumers need this information to know the true cost of the flight, which for many people makes a great difference in whether they can travel. Travelers ought not to be hit with fees to which they had no idea they would be subject.

Title: Koren Taylor
Comment: Airlines must be required to reveal all fees and taxes to customers as they research flights so that consumers may make informed choices. Airlines must also describe all items and services that are included in a ticket price so that consumers will know what they are being charged for. For example, state how how many bags and carry-on are allowed. Lastly a payment should secure an actual seat on a flight, not just a reservation.

Title: Lewis Martin
Comment:
Transparency should be the law for all industries in the US.  The American consumer is being "BAMBOOZLED" by "Corporate America" to include the federal government (Department of Veteran Affairs).  Transparency should be exact not allowing figures that are close to the optimal amount.  The classic example is the food industry's labeling.  Nonfat doesn't mean no fat, it means almost no fat.  There is enough profit in America for everyone to do business honestly.  Why must industry make victims out of consumers for the sake of profit and why is our federal government complicit in this act?  The fat cats in congress are in the back pockets of industry and the wealthy.  They pass laws that are beneficial to the corporate world.
 
The airline industry makes billions on bogus fees.  They cram us in seats with no leg room or any semblance of comfort.  They cancel flights, overbook, force passengers to wait for hours on sweltering tarmacs, charge for changing your itinerary  and  arrive late to their destinations without any consequence. Transparency is the least that should happen considering all of the underhanded business dealings these corporate giants are engaged in on a daily basis.  If the consumer has to pay these bogus prices then the airlines should refund money for lost luggage, late arrivals and cancellations, late departures etc., tit for tat the same way they are nickel and dimming the consumer.

Title: Ilsabe Urban
Comment: I think the proposed changes sound like a great idea and would save me much time when booking a flight.

Title: Henry Guthrie
Comment:
Re:  POSSIBLE LEGISLATION DISALLOWING GOUGING AND HIDDEN FEES BY AIRLINES

Dear Decision-makers at the US Transportation Department:

I am an eighty-five year-old economist and Internationalist (semi-retired, but sill a domestic and international air traveller) who commenced flying (DC-3s and later DC-4s) in the mid-1950s when flying was a fun-adventure and passengers were treated with respect and not treated as cash cows to be nefariously and systematically fleeced. 

 Since that time I have logging over one million miles with Pan Am/Delta, well over half that with British Air and untold hundreds of thousands with American Airlines and Lan Chile.  

In the last two decades, I have watched with dismay most airlines' abandonment of (1) calculating the cost of an economy, a business or a first-class seat from point A to point B, (2) adding an amount to equal a fair and reasonable profit and overhead (and, sometimes a temporary surcharge to cover the wildly fluctuating cost jet fuel) ... and (3) openly and transparently posting the cost for those wishing to make a straightforward comparison with other carriers for the same trip.

And I watched with equal dismay (combined with no small amount of frustration and anger) as all airlines commenced making it ever more difficult to make use of frequent-flyer miles accumulated as the result of ongoing, loyalty.  As I am sure you are aware, today, making use of frequent-flyer miles with most airlines is beyond challenging. 

Notwithstanding my concern over the growth of our government in Washington, it is my opinion that (most) airlines have joined hands in a price-gouging campaign that must be stopped–and, it appears the only way to make that happen is via legislation. 

Clearly, you can not legislate friendliness, cordiality and politeness toward passengers by air carriers.  Nor, can you dictate what amount of profit and overhead airlines add to the cost of an economy, business or first-class ticket.  However, it is my earnest hope that whatever legislation you consider proposing as law puts an end to nickel-and-diming and fuzzy math used by airlines in the process of squeezing passengers. 

Additionally, it is my hope that you analyze the less-than-fair policies used by airlines regarding the near impossibility of making use of "rewards" accumulated by frequent fliers. 

Very sincerely, 

Henry S. (Tex) Guthrie
5507 E. Hillery Dr. 
Scottsdale, AZ 85254
602 569 7778 home
602 616 3334 cell
texg23@q.com

PS  I respectfully urge you to locate, read—and heed—a recent column written by Christopher Elliott (Special for USA TODAY) entitled "What Comes With an Airline Ticket"?  I pray you will agree that Elliott;s thoughts express the opinion of all American voters who travel by air (with the likely exception of the price-gouging airline executives whose unwelcome "stick-it-to-em," bizarre pricing and frequent-flyer-redemption policies have allowed them to rake in billions ... all legally).  Until reading this highly topical, succinct and well-written article, I was unaware that these geniusus and the well-paid lobbyists now seek to harvest even more from passengers with their underhanded schemes. I believe I speak for many when I express my trust that your agency will bring the airline industry back to some form of normalcy.

Title: Kathryn Stearrett
Comment:
Most travelers in my opinion would like to have the price of ticket include the seat ( does not have to be assigned unless it is first clas), taxes and the airport fee, the first bag (50lbs at least) and one 21" carry on bag (30-to 40lbs), computer and handbag, and at least a beverage (non-alcholic) with the option to carry on a lunch/snack item. The first baggage fee I think is unreasonable as most people are traveling for vacation and some have children. Fees for sporting equipment should a flat fee such as $25 or $35 and not a fee of $50. I would rather a flat fee for the ticket and list the restrictions and not have a SURPRISE WHEN ARRIVING AT THE AIRPORT.

LAST MINUTE FEES ARE UPSETTING TO THE  CUSTOMER AND REALLY CAN BE CONSIDERED RUDE ON THE AIRLINES PART.

Title: Rose Evans
Comment:
The airlines should have no option other than to first quote the entire fare price, and then break it down for the consumers prior to booking, so they have a clear picture of what they are paying for.

My strong feeling is that there should NEVER be a charge for either checked or ( even worse ), carry-on bags. A suitcase or carry-on is a prerequisite of any sort of travel, so when did some idiot come up with the idea of making extra millions by charging for an essential item?? We have become (almost) resigned to the elimination of any food or snacks on board, but the addition charges which we must endure, such as the right to sit with your family members, are ridiculous!

 I'm in favor of boycotting travel on those airlines which add on all of the above, and more, and limiting air travel to those who do not- Jet Blue and Southwest.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We support proposed rulemaking that each airline ticket purchased guarantees traveler 2 checked bags, one carry-on item, advance seat selection (which means a whole seat not 1/2 a seat because of an oversized adjacent passenger), access to a bathroom and bottled water.

Title: Bill
Comment: I recently flew from Phoenix to Chicago and paid almost three hundred dollars for two seats with extra leg room and then found out that those same seats were only forty dollars the next day when I checked in for my boarding pass. The airlines are gouging the people like myself that require extra leg room. These seats should require advanced notice of the rates at time of ticket sales compared to the day of check in.

Title: Sandra Carbotti
Comment: I'm all for transparency ..............it helps we the consumers make an informed decision if we are forced have to fly an airline other than Southwest, which I always fly if possible, because they don't have those stupid add-on fees.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please put all the fees into the price of the ticket.  So senseless not to and helps people to plan their expenses.  It is just a way to keep ripping the people off by not having all the charges included.  All the extra charges for leg room, exit rows, etc, are just out of hand.  It certainly isn't a feel good feeling to fly any more.

Title: Megan
Comment:
This bill will essentially allow airlines to advertise a price that is not available (because it is not possible to purchase a ticket without the mandatory fees.)  That makes no sense.  Since all tickets are subject to these additional expenses, they should be plainly outlined at the start.  Currently, some airlines do break down the price showing the cost of fees clearly (Southwest comes to mind).  This bill cannot benefit consumers;  it will only benefit the airlines (and of course the members of Congress who will be rewarded by same for supporting it). 

If you want to help consumers, require all airlines to adhere to the same definition of what a ticket is (e.g. a reserved seat, and one piece of carryon luggage).

Title: Gary Renick
Comment:
I appreciate DOT's efforts. I am generally supportive of the proposals. However, I have a suggested addition for disclosures of change fees.

With respect to section 399.80(p), I am less concerned about the ticket agents than the air carriers themselves who impose many of the policies and fees which the ticket agents are obliged to enforce.  

Specifically, from my personal experience, it is a common practice for air carriers to adjust their schedules over the course of time (e.g., 3-12 months) AFTER a passenger has already purchased a ticket.  The passenger can be adversely impacted by shortened connections (connecting flight, cruise). despite having already planned for what seemed to be sufficient contingencies.

In such cases, a passenger only has a limited right to change or cancel his/her reservation based on a "single" change by the air carrier within a few days after notice of the change.  The passenger neither has any rights nor is entitled to any compensation when an air carrier chooses to change the schedule multiple times.  The air carrier has no mutuality of obligation while the passenger is subject to exorbitant change fees.  The air carriers to have the authority to change schedules and impact customers travel at will without regard to the cumulative effect on the customers and without compensation.  

I personally have had two recent occurrences where the air carrier has changed its schedule a minimum of three times - individually being a half hour here or an hour there  When the changes are accumulated, though, the changes in schedule can be in excess of 2 hours with no monetary consequence to the air carrier. In one case, my schedule changed in excess of 3 hours with a connecting flight.

Since air carriers can impose such exorbitant change fees (e.g., up to $200), passengers should have some renumeration for an airlines change in schedules, including a cumulative change. Alternatively, air carriers should be obligated to disclose their change fee policy, including a right to cancel or fare adjustment equal to the airline's current change fee policy.  If the air carrier changes, its schedule multiple times over the course of the passenger's reservation, then the passenger should have the right to change the schedule without being subject to a change fee up through the day of actual travel or cumulative credit adjustments, at the discretion of the passenger.

Section 399.80(p) and/or other appropriate sections should be modified to disclose the air carrier's policies, the air carrier's obligations and the passenger's rights if an air carrier "changes" a flight in excess of [15] minutes for a single change or in excess of [60] minutes for cumulative, multiple changes since the reservation was originally made.  Consideration should be given as to whether air carriers should be required to waive any change fees through the actual date of departure if the air carrier changed the schedule more than [once] since the passenger's original reservation.

[Excerpt of pertinent Proposed Regulation]
"§ 399.80
Unfair and deceptive practices of ticket agents.
It is the policy of the Department to regard the practices enumerated in paragraphs (a) through (m) of this section by a ticket agent of any size and the practices enumerated in paragraphs (o) through (r) of this section by a ticket agent that sells air transportation and has annual revenue of $100 million or more as an unfair or deceptive practice or unfair method of competition:
* * * * *
(p) Failure to disclose cancellation policies applicable to a consumer's selected flights, the aircraft's seating configuration, and lavatory availability on the aircraft on its Web site, and upon request, from the telephone reservations staff.

In summary and respectfully, the proposed regulations should require further disclosure of the air carriers policies, the air carrier's obligations and the passenger's rights with respect to change fees."

Thank you for this opportunity to comment and DOT's commitment for transparency in travel fees and passengers' rights.

Respectfully submitted,

Gary Renick

Title: Karen Meyer
Comment: I am strongly in favor of more transparency in airline fees.  I remember when everything was included in an airline ticket, so no wondering about this.  Airlines have gradually changed everything about ticketing fees. Since this has crept upon the public, it has not been regulated.  Full disclosure is important and should be implemented.

Title: Watts
Comment: As a airline traveler, I am very tired of being nickel-and-dimed by the airlines.  This proposal is not acceptable and should not be allowed to be enacted.  The full cost of any airline ticket should be displayed so the consumer really knows what it is going to cost to travel by air.  I am very opposed in allowing airlines to distort the true.  This should not be implemented.

Title: Howard Depietri
Comment:
This  is a Rule that needs to be pushed through. The airlines are creating a situation where it is impossible to determine
the true airfare. It is false advertising and very deceptive in its present form. It promotes a feeling of distrust.

Title: Carolyn Andrews
Comment: Charging for restroom access should be strictly illegal, for medical reasons if nothing else. Access to drinking water, the same. This is a closed system; there are no alternatives. The list of potential fees should be clearly posted on the airline website. Sites that post comparative ticket pricing should post ticket prices that include the same bundle of features. Since they have proved themselves to be untrustworthy, they should have to apply to create any more new fees.

Title: James Thompson
Comment:
Taxes on air fares should be prominently displayed for all airline ticket prices.  How else will the consumer understand the fees the federal and state governments are collecting in addition to the hidden fees of the airlines?

Air fares should include making your reservation, seat selection, one checked bag and one carry-on bag for each passenger and any accommodations for special needs passengers.  They could charge extra for meals or beverages if they liked, but should be limited to extra charges only for first class or business class seating.  All coach seats should be the same price.

The rules should also allow airline and itinerary changes for the same departure and destination points with no extra fees.

Title: Milbrey Raney
Comment:
The airline industry and their lobbyists are out of control. I can't believe they have the nerve to present to Congress "Airline TRANSPARENCY Bill of 2014", when their intent is to continue their subterfuge of raising prices on everything that isn't nailed down!  Their argument is spurios that hotels and rental car agencies don't have to show how they sell their products.   The last thing consumers need is more fees in our tickets. I think its false advertising to  advertise a ticket price without showing taxes, mandatory fees, etc. Do they think we consumers are dumb?
We hope the DOT will have the fortitude to pass and enforce this new rule, insist  that a ticket include two checked bags, one carry bag, and advanced seat selection. This needs to be shown at the time that prices are being compared.
I applaud other parts in the rule, such as regional airlines having to account for their arrival times, amount of times bags are mishandled, etc.
Sincerely, Milbrey S Raney

Title: Zoe Kulakowski
Comment:
The consumer has lost much during deregulation of the airlines.  I fully support the Federal government's definition of an airline ticket purchase includes 2 checked bags, one carry-on item, and advance seat selection (all with no additional charges). This will permit transparency in true ticket pricing and prevent the surprise of add-on fees afterward.

This regulation is long over due and I hope it goes into effect quickly.

Title: Nancy Cadet
Comment: I support the disclosure of all fees and taxes in airline ticket prices . This is a good protection  for consumers. Information helps us make better choices .

Title: Robin Rowan
Comment:
I feel I'm a fairly savvy consumer--I read labels, I read fine print before I sign anything, and I NEVER agree to donate to a cause over the phone. So is hiding the real cost of air travel like not putting the price of drinks or dessert on a restaurant menu? And if I'm booking online, who do I ask about these hidden fees prior to entering my credit card number? I stopped flying years ago because of just such fraudulent practices and now just drive everywhere, but circumstances have created a time crunch with urgent family matters, causing me to have to book flights at the last minute and pay whatever outrageous charges and fares the airlines are charging. What really sticks in my craw is that everyone seems to be going along with it.
There should be an outcry so loud and so long that even thick-headed, hard-of-hearing Congress gets the message. It needs to be changed, it needs to be transparent, but mostly, some of the ridiculous fees just need to go away and never come back!

Title: Robert Carder
Comment: All airlines and ticket agents should be required to disclose basic ancillary services associated with the air transportation consumers are buying or considering buying. Flying is stressful enough without fee surprises.

Title: Jim Schrempf
Comment: This is one of the first government initiatives that I actually agree with.  The airlines continue to gouge Americans with excessive fees for baggage, seats, boarding, etc..  I am a frequent flier and this has gotten out of hand.  Their latest ploy is to assign a middle seat in the back of the plane, and charging $29-$89 if you want to change seats to an aisle or window.  To avoid baggage charges, customers are now trying to bring on large bags to the plane, causing space issues and extending boarding and deplaning times.  For a recent trip, their were extra charges for baggage, seating, boarding priority, and even carryon bags.  The flight rate was not even close to the end charge and makes it very difficult to compare prices when purchasing.  Lets finally do something good for the people and make the airlines be more transparent with the total cost.  A ticket should include at least one checked bag, one carry-on bag, and certainly the choice of a seat (non-middle).

Title: Robert Monod
Comment:
The comments below apply to part 7 of the proposed rule, "Disclosure That Not All Carriers are Marketed and Identification of Carriers Marketed on Ticket Agent Web sites".... and to a section of part 1, titled "Clarifying the Definition of “Ticket Agent”", specifically the question asking "Should carriers be prohibited from imposing restrictions on ticket agents that prevent agents from including a carrier's schedules, fares, rules, or availability info in an integrated display?"

Carriers SHOULD be prohibited from imposing such restrictions for any ticket agent.  In addition, as long as airlines are allowed to keep display/sales restrictions in place for any agent, then agents SHOULD NOT have to disclose to consumers whether or not options on other carriers may exist.    

This is due to for several reasons as follows:

Currently, some airlines do not allow any or all agents to display fares to the public, even though the airline doesn't compensate the ticket agent for any bookings, nor does the agent request commission.  For example, Southwest (WN) historically hasn't allowed any agent to book fares online.  In addition, Delta (DL) allows Priceline, Expedia, Orbitz, & Travelocity to display fares, but has stopped the 2nd tier of ticket agents in terms of volume to display DL's fares as of 3 yrs ago.  This includes agents such as CheapOAir.com, LasVegas.com, BookIt.com, Onetravel.com, etc... Unlike WN, which does not allow any agent to book its fares online, DL is now cherry-picking the agents that it chooses to allow to display and book fares, presumably based on contract or volume of business.  Most agents would gladly display/book fares from these 2 airlines if permitted to do such, as most agents earn income from the commissions on associated hotel bookings.  Why should these agents have to disclose that other airlines may be available on each web search and suffer the loss of business each time a consumer reads the disclosure and searches elsewhere?  The agents would gladly display all fares/itineraries if allowed to by the airlines.  Keep in mind that DL was one of the 1st airlines that eliminated commissions for most US travel agents more than 10 yrs ago and with the few exceptions, or special contracted situations, 0 commission on the air portion of an itinerary is now standard for most agents.  

I agree it is a disservice to the consumer who prefers to use one of the 2nd tier agents to not have all fares/itineraries displayed.  However, airlines that are not displayed are at a disadvantage due to their own business decision, and not the agent's decision.  If a consumer chooses to book on AA over DL via a 3rd party due to DL's decision to remove fares from the 3rd party, then it is DL who has created the disservice to the consumer, not the agent.  

Using a comparison example, if I want to buy a "Widget", and there are exactly 10 companies that make Widgets, I can go to any store I choose to buy a widget.  If 2 companies that produce "Widgets" decide not to supply the product to the store that I choose, I am limited to purchase one of the 8 Widgets from other companies.  Even though all Widgets are at various prices, and have various qualities, should the store be required to display a sign that states "There may be other companies that produce Widgets not carried by this store".  In my opinion, the answer to this question is not only "NO", but it is absurd to regulate such signage.     

In addition, there are many airports where DL has a monopoly on air service, which means that any consumer who prefers to use one of the websites that have been shunned by Delta who is looking for an itinerary to and/or from one of the airports where Delta is the only carrier cannot book thru their preferred agent.  These airports include, but are not limited to DHN, ABY, AGS, BQK, CSG, VLD, PIH, TWF, APN, ESC, IMT, PLN, CIU, BJI, BRD, HIB, INL, GTR, BTM, EKO, GFK, ABR, CDC, RHI.

Please note that while DL receives federal subsidies for many of the cities listed due to the Essential Air Service program, their actions toward agents' ticketing abilities limit interstate commerce, as the agents that DL chooses to discriminate against have customers residing in all states.  In addition to the previous airports listed, there are numerous airports where DL is 1 of 2 carriers that operate.  At these airports, due to DL's actions, agents are relegated to only displaying 1 carrier due to DL's decision, not the agent's.     

In summary I am questioning the fact as to why should an agent who wishes to display a certain carrier's fares, but is prohibited from doing so by the carrier, have to market that some fares may not be displayed, and thus drive away business?  In these cases, I would assume the agent wishes to keep the consumer as their customer, and wants to offer all carriers' fares, even if this means that the consumer chooses an airline for which the online ticket agent is not compensated by the airline.

Title: David Harry
Comment:
A ticket price should include all taxes and mandatory fees. 

It should also include one carry on and one checked bag. Put the checked bag back in the ticket price even though it will mean extra for me. My status allows for 3 free checked bags, but it has caused people to create un safe conditions in the cabin.

Title: David Evans
Comment: I fully support the essence of this regulation but don't pretend to understand the details effecting third parties.

Title: Mike P.
Comment:
I have read that “The Department remains of the view that as carriers continue to unbundle services that used to be included in the price of air transportation, passengers need to be protected from hidden and deceptive fees and allowed to price shop for air transportation in an effective manner.  However, we lack sufficient data to be able to quantify the extent of this problem for consumers.” The Department then requests comment from consumers.
The dilemma need not be pointed toward the consumer. The Department should be looking at the financial results for the carriers that show why the unbundling has occurred. Airlines have become more profitable! It has been reported that airlines earned more than $2.8 billion in ticket change fees alone in 2013. How many more billion were earned on other fees? A good deal of this income is because they have deliberately decided to confuse consumers, taking advantage of many individuals and families that are not flying every day. Revenue is clearly the only reason why they unbundled and why they will continue to be deceptive unless stopped by regulation!  The airlines complain about paying higher fees to the GDS firms but clearly continue to drain every cent possible from their customers.
Since the department lacks sufficient data to protect the consumer, the department should err on the side of caution and simply change the rule so that all fees must already be included in the price being offered to the consumer. That goes for the airlines, GDS firms and all others! Let them make a buck honestly not by duping their clientele! Why do we need so much complication? Just take a step back in time.
In lieu of my simplified approach, Proposal #1 that requires carriers to disclose fee information for basic ancillary services to all ticket agents to which a carrier provides its fare information, including GDSs, should be implemented.

Title: Larry Holmes
Comment: Please require all Airlines To Quote Ticket prices with ALL FEES and TAXES included. This will make it easier for all consumers to make informed decisions!! With All Airlines Quotes having to include the same.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This is a great idea and it should be implemented with no changes to the proposed rule(s).

The following are additional requests to the DoT to consider adding to the rule(s):

- Airlines to disclose differences between "premium economy" and normal economy seats along with the price option for this upgrade. In some instances, there was no perceptible change in seat pitch or comfort.

Title: Richard Albright
Comment: There is no excuse for the airlines to not to be honest about what it will cost to buy a ticket to make a trip without paying extra for things that are required to make the trip. Bait and switch has been around a long time, but there is no way it should be sanctioned or excused by our regulatory agencies. When airlines were deregulated, we were promised more competition and better service at better prices. Like many other promises, exactly the opposite has happened. The 1% are up to their usual tricks-- charge more for less.  They can't honestly claim it will cost them more to tell the truth about airfares. It has to cost them more to separate all the charges when they can charge one price to get on the plane, have a seat, and not have to hassle with all the people who don't want to pay to for checking luggage and try to cram it in the overhead bins.

Title: James Bussell
Comment: This rule is a bad for the Consumer. Vote NO!.

Title: Michael Thomas
Comment: Please have your baggage rule define several bag size and weight varieties.  Airlines could say their fee includes which size bags.  Both checked and carryon.  Try to find an amalgam of what is currently the "standards".  Something like the tire ratings  A,B,C  etc.

Title: John Hogle
Comment:
I am completely opposed to this rule, as it will:

1. Enable the airlines to mislead the public as to the true total cost of airfares without us having to dig around a lot to find all the fees and taxes.
2. It will enable the airlines to shuffle in new and higher fees for items in addition to the basic cost of the flight.

John Hogle

Title: Ferdinand Delrosario
Comment: We purchased 3 tickets online for United Airlines to fly from LAX to MNL on March 31, 2014 and back on April 27. We have been flying all over the world and have always been allowed 2 luggages per person.  We were rudely suprised at the LAX United counter when checking in that we had to pay $100 each because we each had 1 extra luggage.  We told them that nobody told us or emailed us about the restriction and the standard answer was that it 's disclosed in their website. Since we could not leave our extra luggages with anyone, we had no choice but the pay $300 to bring our luggages. And worst of all, since we could not abandon our expensive luggages in the Philippines we again had to pay $200 for the flight back to the US (our son ditched his luggage). I requested United for a refund of our extra baggage fees but they curtly responded that we should have known but it's so hard to know of this when it's buried in their website. Pricing should automatically have included the baggage price which the proposed regulation is supposed to address.

Title: Don Tendick
Comment:
I totally agree on the proposed new regulations. I travel a lot and can afford the costs, but do not like hidden or other fees that now are a significant portion of the overall fee of the seat you are now purchasing. String fees are just what the airlines want to falsely get an incorrect advantage over other airline seats. Something similar to baiting a customer in a low fare then adding services without the ability to assess the true cost by comparison. I support this rule 100%. Time for all to know the true cost of a seat on a flight and to compare for quality and value for all of us. 
Thank You. 
Don Tendick

Title: Sandra Schwartz
Comment:
Imagine this scenario ordering coffee at Starbucks.®
He: Hi and welcome to Starbucks. What can I get you?
Me: I have a loyalty card and received an email about the sale on a coffee for $3.00. So I would like some.
He: Well, the special is for a small coffee, although we do have other sizes priced accordingly. 
If you want a small, that will be $3.00 plus $1.00 extra for the cup if you need something to put it into.
If you want sugar, that will be 50 cents extra.
If you want a sugar substitute, that will be 75 cents extra.
If you want skim milk, that will be 50 cents extra.
If you half n half, that will be 75 cents.
If you want cream, that will be $1.00 extra.
If you want it hot, that will be $1.00 extra.
If you want it cold, that will be $1.00 extra plus 50 cents more for ice.
Stirrers are 25 cents extra. A lid is 25 cents extra.
Plus taxes of 7% and a 20% tip for the server, your small iced coffee with cream, sugar substitute, a stirrer and lid will be $7.25 plus taxes of 7% and a 20% tip for the server, which brings it to $8.73. 
If you order by phone, there is an additional charge of $1.00 or $9.73
If you order in person, the charge is 50 cents or $9.23
If you pay by cash, there is a surcharge of 25 cents or $9.98
If you pay by credit or debit card, there is a surcharge of 5% of the total bill to cover the cost of running it through the credit card machine or an additional 44 cents. 
Thank you for shopping at Starbucks® and have a good day.
What is the difference between this scenario and buying a ticket on an airplane?

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I support protection of the consumers with your new airfare rules. We used to fly at least 4 x yearly for vacations. We  have had lots of financial surprises with all the add ons for basics as we fly. We now only vacation in places we can get to by driving- even if we take 3 days to get there! 
The uncomfortable seats, lack of cleanliness, surly baggage folks, late arrival times, missed connections, having to pack food supplies to name a few things have make flying more of a chore than a convenience.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I fully support proposed changes to provide "bottom line" pricing to the consumer  before the purchase decision.  And that display of ancillary fees should be in a simple-to-understand format to allow the consumer to easily compare fares between carriers.

Title: Gay Wayland
Comment: As a person who flew over 160,000 miles in 2013, and who has million mile status with a heritage airline, I completely agree with transparency. Passengers are confused when they can no longer move to empty seats and flight attendants have been forced to become cashiers and police, watching for passenger movement then rushing to charge the passenger - they are no longer there for our safety, they are there to collect more fees. I think even beyond the fees, it drives what the airlines want which is loyalty since once you have status you won't be paying those fees, the stickiness to keep you has been created. The people who really get hurt by this are those who aren't flying on business and who fly so infrequently that they have no awareness of the fees until they hit the airport - which is why it needs to be transparent.

Title: Kenneth Bryant
Comment: Airlines should NOT be allowed to quote an artificially low price! I want to know precisely how much the product will cost.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airline ancillary fees should be clearly stated and displayed in the price of a ticket, showing the cost of 2 pieces of checked luggage and 1 carryon with an assigned seat, which would be typical for a person going on vacation.  This is required for an apples-to-apples comparison of ticket prices between different airlines.  Consumer protection is of the utmost priority here and we the people insist our government put the interests of its citizens above those of any business.

Title: Patrick Higgins
Comment: Please look at enforcing transparency on the Airline Ticket Price debacle. As a consumer it is now impossible to discover what the meaning of a Ticket is in airline pricing. You buy a Ticket but then you may have to pay, for carry ons, checked luggage, Foot room, any food or drink etc. This is unconscionable pricing and needs help from a regulation demanding that all airlines price tickets on a level playing field. Now, I understand the question is can they quote prices without the taxes and fees. This is the crux of the problem....in order to compare the price of a ticket, the tickets need to be apples to apples. the obfuscation of pricing by the airlines is intentional and created to avoid the comparison that all consumers want.

Title: Elaine Barlas
Comment:
I am strongly in favor of the proposed regulations,  as purchasers of any goods or services should know at the outset of investigating a purchase what  the total cost will be.  Our economy is based, at least theoretically, on the concept of open competition.  Therefore, sellers should be prepared -- and required -- to provide potential buyers with all information regarding the goods or services they offer and their full cost. As this is currently not the case when buying airline tickets, the proposed regulation would go a long way toward ensuring that airline ticket buyers will have the information we need to evaluate competing offers before making a choice. 

I do urge you to revise the proposed language that reads, "Currently, some consumers may be unable to understand the true cost of travel..."   As written, it implies the "inability" to know the true cost lies with the consumer's inability to "understand" that cost.  This is patently untrue.  The consumer's inability to "understand" the cost is caused by the failure of some sellers to provide complete information upfront to the consumer.   

Thank you.

Title: Judy Standley
Comment: I appreciated the way airlines have to disclose their "hidden" fees and support including baggage fees as well. I use a budget payment for my utilities because I don't like surprises, and resent the policies the airlines have for "nickle and diming" us to death!

Title: Kevin Foley
Comment:
I want an airline ticket price as quoted to include a carry on bag, a checked bag, and a seat reservation made in advance as well as checking in at the airport--all in the basic price. Anything less is ridiculous and deceitful. Airlines have been taking advantage of the public in too many ways for too long and the government has not only allowed it but even encouraged it. It is time for this to stop, come to a screeching halt, in fact.

Of course, decent customer service is also severely lacking, but i suppose you can't regulate that.

Title: A. Williams
Comment:
Let's stop assisting the airlines from duping the public.  I want clear info about what a ticket costs with taxes and fees included, don't change this simple clear rule.  They are making huge profits from the unsuspecting public with their "additional fees".
Vote this change down.

Title: Fred Carney
Comment: I am opposed to the Airfare Transparency Bill of 2014.  It is already difficult enough to determine what I am paying for.  Allowing airlines to advertise fees which do not include taxes and other unexpected fees will make it worse for us travelers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It is imperative that the consumer be advised about all and any ancillary fees when purchasing an airline ticket.  This is particularly important when purchasing a non-refundable ticket.  The airlines now operate in a "buyer beware" environment which should be changed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Yes, it would be helpful to know to cost of whatever one could purchase.  Sandbagging customers is not my idea of a good business practice.

Title: Robert Kane
Comment:
Airlines have been fooling passengers long enough with their fees.

Not only when buying a revenue ticket but with award tickets also. When is a free ticket free...... NEVER!

Their "change" fee have also become robbery, they should be back at $25, nevermind these 100, 150 or 200 change fees which sometimes make the ticket we purchased WORTHLESS.


We are going to get to a point that US Airlines ask for our help in the form of a bailout. I for one use international carriers whenever I can. It will be like why GM needed help while most people bought Toyotas, Hondas, BMW and Hyundais!!!
