Please do something about these fees and how they are hidden to protect the average guy that doesn't have a team of lawyers or Lobbyist on their side

Title: Christoph W. Aurich
Comment:
I would like to express my opinion abut airline rules and practices, because I am traveling, worldwide, often more than 50% of the time.   Airlines are now practicing an unethical "Deceive the Public" marketing policy and it ought to be stopped. They also engage in promoting class-generation to the detriment of those who have to travel in economy.  They ought to have one-class flights, where every seat has a little more leg room for the benefit of all, mainly on less then three hour domestic or inter-national flights.  I also realize that this would be a hard sale.

They ought to go back to the old way of charging a fair price for them to make a profit, but to buy a ticket these days really has little or no meaning, when only considering the ticket price.  In fact, a ticket price means actually nothing any more.

Also,  too many passengers are allowed too many bags to be brought on board.

Sincerely,
Christoph W. Aurich

Title: Bernard Berman
Comment: Please implement this new rule.  I believe that it is outrageous that most airlines do not disclose all of the costs that they are going to charge for purchasing a ticket.  It is important that I, or any other consumer, know what full cost of any service I purchase, BEFORE completing that purchase.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please standardize what is being purchased with a ticket between airlines, it doesn't have to include everything, I just want to know what I'm getting before I pay for it.

Title: Kathleen Beaulieu
Comment:
The stated purpose of this act is to "enhance protections" for air travelers. Yet every article I read says the fine print in this act protects the airlines and their profits. When the ink dries on a "Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees" Act, any reasonable person should be able to easily find and comprehend every possible fee, extraneous or otherwise, that will be included in their final payment. That should be the measure of its success: that regular, reasonable people can figure out the full and total cost without jumping through hoops of fire and web pages of fine print. 
Don't bury a real intention of obfuscating consumers behind titles with "transparency" and promises of "protections" if you're really passing legislation to appease the airlines.

Title: John G.
Comment: The title of this rule couldn't be farther from the truth.  This proposal sounds like the airlines wrote it.  Transparency should make it easier for a person travelling to know what their final cost will be, not have to figure it out as they travel, and get charged "new" fees for services that are part of the accepted service now.  I shouldn't have to approach the airline industry like I was buying a used car from somebody in a sweaty tee shirt.  If they have nicer planes or a better class service, advertise that against their price for travel.  Don't "seperate" out the "services" with a fee for each part of the travel process.  The next thing on the ticket will be tire and break wear fees for landings at higher elevation airports because the plane has to work harder to stop.  Being more creative about how I'm charged to get somewhere only makes the industry as a whole less attractive as a method of transportation.  As a rule, I have begun driving over flying for trips under 400 miles.  Is this how the industry wants to go?

Title: Byron Somers
Comment: At no time in history has communication been so readily available [USPS, telephone (land line, satellite, and/or cell), e-mail, computers, newspaper, magazine, etc.].  It seems counter to the fruits of these technologies that consumers would be limited in receiving all available information when purchasing an airline ticket.  The only way to make an informed decision is to have all of the information.

Title: Mari Hartmann - Comments
Comment:
I think this a great rule that prevents any supplier of expensive goods or services to disclose full costs.  Cars, homes, etc. all have their fees disclosed upfront and airlines should also be required to disclose their full costs at time of advertisement.  Airlines are trying to nickel and dime travelers with changing and hidden fees, while holding consumers to a rigid schedule, with the ability to cancel flights at anytime, and penalizing consumers for consumer initiated changes.
Make airlines disclose the travelers full cost.

Title: Camaleta Roseman
Comment:
All airlines booking systems should include a menu of services and cost, consumers need to know what to expect. 
Airfares should be compared apples to apples we do not need to be nickel-and-dimed by fees

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We need consumer protection.

Title: Roland Phelps
Comment:
Sir/Madame:

The airline flying public needs a clear and fully understandable ticket pricing system before a passenger purchases a flight ticket that allows a purchaser to compare airline prices.  One other comment is the purchase of an airline ticket automatically should ensure the purchaser a seat without any doubt, and preferably a selected seat. No one who has purchased an airline ticket should be informed when arriving at the airport his ticket price did not include a seat. Also, when a larger plane is switched to a smaller one, passengers should have the option to select their seat if possible. Flight changes should not cancel out passengers seat selection. Regards,
RSP

Title: M. V.
Comment: force airlines to allow your first bag checked to be free. 2nd bag $35.00. this new rule will eliminate so many carry on bags at security checkpoint and filling up the overheads onboard during boarding.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0056

The proposed rule should be adopted.  Airlines and agents should be required to disclose all taxes and fees, including but not limited to, baggage charges, seating regulations, fees for changes, and accurate schedule information.

Also consider regulating change fees which can become prohibitive.

Title: Paul Higgins
Comment:
Having spent close to the Million Miles flown, on many different airlines and countries, I would like to make the following comments.
Travel is difficult enough without having to concern oneself about 'add-ons", fees and other charges after you have made your bookings. It is ludercrious that one has to juggle cash or cards to pick up unforseen charges that are being levied by the different airlines when checking in.

All fees/taxes//charges for different airports, baggage, foods, entertainment etc., so one knows that they are completely covered when the booking is made.  Flyers can then book-in at the airport, travel & exit the other end without hasels and more stress. Isn't that what all the airlines say/said?
" Welcome aboard & enjoy the flight"

Also,.
insist on NO to in flight use of cell phones. Who wants to listen to someone else's endless and mindless crap during a flight. What a nightmare! Let them call on  Landing - period! The world will still be there to meet them. If this is to be allowed then you must insist that a 'phone booth' is installed next to the 'loo's if they just can't wait to let all their buddies know where they are at. PLAH-EESSSSSS!
Make it so, thank you. PH

Title: Paul Lubell
Comment: This action is long overdue and should include GDS's.  The definition of "basic ancillary services" will provide a common baseline for comparing prices.  A consumer can subtract the fees for checked baggage if that service is not desired.

Title: Bruce Tepper
Comment: Please require that information about air fares include ALL additional fees, costs, and taxes.  Consumers should be informed of ALL charges when booking travel.  There should be NO surprises or hidden charges.  Thank you for generating DOT-OST-2014-0056.

Title: Mike Cefalo
Comment: Stop the airlines from nickel and diming the Americam publicwith the fairs they publish..they should tell the public what they are getting for their money...you would like to know.

Title: James Karlovich
Comment:
I certainly feel tricked by the airline when I'm charged a bag fee only to arrive at the gate to hear an announcement to the effect that the flight is full, overhead space is limited, and volunteers may check their carry-on bag for no charge. In my opinion, there should be a refund offer when such disparate treatment is given.

I understand the airlines are arguing for "transperancy" of pricing. They seem all in favor of splitting out taxes and regulatory fees but I don't think they will be willing to disclose the wide range of fares that passengers are charged for sitting in the same class of service on the same flight. 

I also feel that change fees are excessive and should merit some regulatory attention.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: No "nickel-and-diming" by airlines. Please ensure every ticket is transparent and reflects all charges (fees).

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am against the rule forcing airlines, travel agencies, and similar entities to track the prices for the myriad of fees and services across a huge array of individual airlines. This expensive proposal adds complexity to an already convoluted and fragile regulatory environment in which airlines and related entities have to operate. This also adds a burden on the Department of Transportation, and therefore on taxpayers, to track and react to yet another dimension of the quickly evolving global airline industry - in which I believe the DOT already has a heavy presence. It is not the responsibility of a rigid, slow-to-react, taxpayer-funded regulatory agency to dictate pricing models for widely varying airlines and related entities within a vibrant and competitive industry. 

I also believe that the DOT overestimates its own importance, proposing rules with real costs in order to micromanage pricing on behalf of consumers that voluntarily participate in transactions with this industry. If a consumer is deeply and truly unhappy with the pricing model of their chosen airline, they can simply choose not to fly with that airline again. If enough consumers are unhappy, the airline will correct its actions much more quickly and nimbly than the DOT could ever hope to. As a taxpayer, I ask that you do not spend my taxpayer dollars to legislate, monitor, and enforce rules that consumers are not asking for. While some industry practices are not inherently self-regulated via market forces, this is not one of them, nor is it impactful enough for a taxpayer-funded agency to take notice.

I am a software engineer in the banking industry and a moderately frequent flyer. My perspective comes from first-hand experience of the real costs and headaches of implementing and maintaining the technology needed to comply with similar types of rules. These costs must be paid somehow, and are reflected in higher prices for typical consumers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While I like the definition of a travel ticket and what the fare should include. I would also like to see the regulators clamp down on the airlines for charging ridiculous change fees for tickets. Not only will a person be charged $200 for making the change they will also be charged the higher fee for the seat if applicable, adding insult to injury they tack on a $25 process fee. IT does not cost the airlines to change a ticket. They have already made money on the purchase of the ticket. 

You all have clamped down on the banks for their fees it is well over due that you do the same to the airlines.

Title: Garry Everett
Comment: As a frequent airline traveller allowing the airlines to advertise fares while omitting the all taxes and mandatory fees  to further market unbelievable bargains is taking it too far.

Title: Steve Balog
Comment: Full support for defining basic ticket that includes all applicable taxes and fees: and carry on,  and 1 or 2 checked bags, bathroom usage,  and seat assignment if offered.   Only in this way can one compare not only between airlines,  but between  airlines and other modes of travel including no travel.  If airline then wants to offer discounts from this basic by eliminating item(s) that should be allowed .

Title: Mitchell Martin
Comment:
This new or revised Rule especially needs to be applied to Spirit, Southwest, and Allegiant Airlines (but be applied to all Airlines and middleman Agents/Resellers), which have gone crazy in adding hidden fees for 1st and 2nd Bags checked, carry-on Items checked, seat Reservations in advance, and other hidden fees such as Fuel cost, made-up Gov Fees, etc! They should have no right to hide any fees/charges from their total price for an Airline Reservation posted cost or charge!  Spirit also has a policy to require any refunds to be only a Credit for only 90 days, but then does not allow you to use that Credit online for any upgrades or other charges added later before the Flight??  The Rule should require all Airlines to provide an online way to use such Credits, or to refund the Credit if they don't!  Don't water down these requirements or accept any deal that would allow them to avoid disclosing all fees and charges in their ticket price (or at least providing an upfront list or breakout of such charges)

Thanks for your help as Airlines are taking huge advantage of the flying public and the current loopholes in the Rule!!

Title: Stephen Wilcoxon
Comment: Airlines should definitely be forced to play fair and report prices including fees for basic things that used to be included in tickets (seat selection, checked bags (at least 1), carry-on bags, etc).  Mandatory fees and taxes should also be required to be given as part of the price (contrary to the bill the airlines are trying to get through Congress).  Airlines are reporting huge profits - there is no need for them to deceive the consumer or nickel-and-dime them.

Title: Rob Vaughn
Comment: all fees should be included in an airline fare, with no hidden fees. thank you

Title: V. Jordan Tanner
Comment:
Airlines are misleading the public by advertising fares that do NOT include checked baggage, food, taxes.   Now Delta awards frequent flyer miles according to how much ticket cost and NOT on the miles traveled.   

Those of us that can't afford business class seats have no leg room ( I'm over 6'2") and it is torture to travel a long distance in seats meant for a person 5 '2" tall.

Air travel is now a terrible way to get to a destination.   Certainly "half the fun is getting there"  NO longer applies to airline travel.   

Airlines are raking in the $billions and the public is getting poor service, high extra fees and cramped seating.

Airlines need to better regulated and treat economy customers with more respect and lower fares.

Title: Francis Komola
Comment:
Thank you for recommending this proposed rule.

The most important aspect of this rule regarding ancillary fees for me concerns the cost of advanced  seat assignments  labeled "extra legroom or economy plus".

A significant amount of personal information has to be provided to United Airlines, for example, before the total cost of the flight is available to customers like me.

I welcome these regulations and again appreciate your attempts to correct this consumer protection problem.

Title: Charles Catania
Comment: Thank you very much for this regulation.  This is what the public needs.  The airlines Industry are taking advantage of the paying public and this will make our interaction so much easier and we will know our price up-front rather then continue through a long process for a $39 ticket which is actually amounts to $87 dollars.

Title: James Maher
Comment: I believe that the airline should be required to show "true pricing transparency" and be required to show ALL of the costs associated with a ticket. This includes their base price, any taxes, regulatory fees, and add on fees for baggage and any fuel surcharges so that the consumer can compare the true cost of a ticket between carriers.

Title: Arlene Versaw
Comment:
As a government agency, your responsibility is to protect the public. Airlines are beholden to the dollar and shareholders. We need you to protect us from
businesses hiding fees and taking advantage of the public.  We have the right to make informed decisions. Relaxing transparency rules precludes our being able to do so.

Title: Business Travel Coalition
Comment:
BTC Applauds U.S. DOT Airline Consumer Protection Efforts

Business Travel Coalition welcomes the U.S. Department of Transportation’s (DOT) publishing of a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking regarding new airline consumer protections. Consumers will benefit from greater price transparency by the Department’s proposal to require airlines to provide real-time pricing of core ancillary services (e.g., for checked bags) wherever they sell their tickets. However, DOT must require that ancillary fee information is disseminated to travel agents in an efficient manner that is truly usable by agents and we urge the agency to ensure that consumers can purchase these services from travel agents at the same time as an airline ticket.

The more consumers trust a shopping and purchasing process the more likely it is that they will buy more products and services more often. Over the long term, providing strong consumer protections will increase competition, create market efficiencies, encourage innovation, expand markets, increase sales and satisfy customers. These are outcomes that benefit all stakeholders in any industry as well as society in general.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I think the nickel-and-diming us passengers on every flight is ridiculous. When you book you ticket and see the fare it looks good until they add all the other fees, sometimes it adds up to almost another $100.00 dollars to the ticket price.

THE FARE QUOTED SHOULD INCLUDE EVERYTHING - NO CHARGING FOR LUGGAGE, CARRY-ON BAGS, SEAT ASSIGNMENTS, ETC!!!!

Title: Judith Reitman
Comment: Require that information about air fares include ALL additional fees, costs, and taxes. Consumers should be informed of ALL charges when booking travel...Also first bag should be free, and second bag charge not over $35. Crackdown on carry ons which when large and heavy hold up boarding and are just an way to avoid checking what should be baggage.”

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airline passengers should know ALL costs BEFORE they purchase their tickets.  A drop-down menu would work, giving options:  e.g., carry-ons, checked, etc costs.  The purchaser could then add the options that applied to them--and get a final cost.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The airlines should be required to publish all fees related to their fares.  This should include the fees to change a ticket.  And the fee to change a ticket should be regulated.  Delta charges $200 + fare difference to change a ticket regardless of the original ticket price.  $200 is ridiculous.  Delta is not losing money if I change my ticket and pay the fare difference - I'm still traveling with them.  The ticket change fee is a way for them to legally gouge customers.

Title: Robert Plato
Comment: I would  like to share with you my latest experience with United Airlines, which was a new experience with my long time veteran travel agent. I booked a round trip ticket to Brisbane Australia with Air New Zealand, which is a partner of United, so I could get United Rewards Miles. After completing the trip April 14, 2014. United inform me the 6500 mile leg between Auckland & LAX didn't qualify for rewards even though LAX to Auckland did. there was no advanced notice, before I booked, another good example of Airline deregulation

Title: Kay Holloman
Comment:
Require that information about air fares include ALL additional fees, costs, and taxes. Consumers should be informed of ALL charges when booking travel. 
Allow first bag free, and second bag charge not over $35. Also, limit others with large carry ons if they are checking a bag

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please require that information about air fares include ALL additional fees, costs, and taxes. Consumers should be informed of ALL charges when booking travel...”

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that the cost of air transportation should be all inclusive of all parts of the service of transporting passengers in airplanes from one airport to another. If that has to be done by listing the breakdown of included & optional parts of this service, then so it should be. A simple list of services & the cost of each all on one page with each identified as included in the basic service or optional to be purchased separately above the basic cost would be the easiest for consumers to understand. And all airlines should use the same terminology for the services.

Title: J.R. Gimblet
Comment: Airlines should provide a COMPLETE price for the services they offer - including documentation on things like change fees and baggage fees.  Customers should not face cost surprises while they are traveling and have little recourse.

Title: Cynthia Washburn
Comment:
I am a private citizen that travels via air frequently to visit family in multiple states.

I strongly support option #1 to makes these rules applicable to all outlets.

I strongly support protecting consumers by having all add-on fees visible and clear.

I dispute the costs of adding this disclosure because the airlines can save these costs by including baggage and other fees in their standard price - they have the option to save the costs.  Since at least one airline, Southwest, has been able to do well without the nickel/dime fees, then the other airlines should have considered the disclosure costs in their decision to unbundle fares.

Title: James Grossman
Comment:
I am a frequent flier.  And I most strongly support tighter regulation of airline advertising.  It seems to me that Sen. Robert Menendez's "Real Transparency in Airfares Act" is the right way to go with this.  The airlines are constantly misleading the public with their ads.

Yes, other industries are permitted to advertise pretax prices.  But that doesn't mean it's OK.

Title: Steven Folino
Comment: I believe that it is in the best interest of the consumer that airlines should be required to advertise all-inclusive prices.  Those prices should include all REQUIRED taxes and fees.  Only those fees that the consumer has no option to pay should ne included.  A disclaimer should be required that lists optional fees should be required.  Such as: "Rate does not include additional, optional fees for baggage, preferred seat assignment or early boarding."

Title: Thomas Hilton
Comment:
It is increasingly difficult to comparison shop for tickets, even within the same air carrier, because of hidden fees.  Assertions by the industry that not reporting taxes (including landing fees and other local airport taxes and costs) will make ticket purchases more "transparent," is nonsense.  It wastes my time to make an on-line purchase for say, $200 only to find at the time of charging my credit card the price has jumped to over $300.  Why??? Well, you want a reserved seat so you are not bumped, right?  Ku-ching goes the virtual cash register.  You want to bring a suitcase? Ku-ching again.  You want 2 more inches of legroom? Ku-ching.  You want a refundable ticket in case of emergency cancellation? Ku-ching. If Congress relents on the requirement to include taxes, ku-ching, ku-ching, ku-ching!  

Please help return sanity to purchasing an airline ticket by requiring that all "normal" costs be stated to include taxes, baggage fees, etc. 

Finally, keep in mind that the hassle of flying is becoming a growing burden on the public with long lines for check-ins, TSA screening, and flight delays.  In a growing number of cases it is just as fast to drive or take the train.  In 1999, I enjoyed platinum FF status on two airlines in the same year.  In the past three years, I have stopped flying if the trip is under 800 miles.  If things do not improve, the  air carriers will lose more business from folks like myself.  It is in the industry's interest to be forthright about ticket costs.

Title: Matthew Wiecek
Comment:
Regulatory Identification Number: 2105-AE31

To whomever it may concern,

A free market depends on both parties having adequate information to make decisions. This is an absolute must if the market is to function properly. Unfortunately, certain airlines have taken it upon themselves to undermine this market. Certain airlines have started to exclude taxes and fees, and then even begin to exclude things that citizens believe to be standard, such as checked bag fees.

This is a major problem as it means that responsible airlines that provide the full price to their customers get pushed out of the market. Irresponsible companies, meanwhile, convince customers to purchase their under-priced tickets, only to hit them with fees later on. This is exactly what government is for, to ensure a properly functioning and well regulated market where both sides can make well informed decisions. If airlines are required to disclose all fees then citizens will have the information necessary to make a well-informed choice. 

I urge the Department of Transportation to adopt the proposed rule and ensure that the airline market is not undermined by companies that fool their customers. Without this rule it may well be possible that the most successful airline will not be the one with best service or lowest cost, but the one that is best at hiding its various fees and slicing up the cost of a ticket into a plethora of fees to be paid at the airport. Do not let the market be undermined, adopt the proposed rule.

Sincerely,

Matthew Wiecek

Title: Joe Morguess
Comment: Knowing baggage costs well in advance of booking or airport arrival and Any prepayment discounts available , would give consumers clearer choices immediately prior to confirming purchase, and could prevent additional surprise baggage charges at drop off or the gate.

Title: Doug Tallinger
Comment: Please ensure the airlines expose all fees to potential customers.  I support this regulation.

Title: Gordon Loader
Comment: Make all advertised airfares, and purchasing of airfares include all taxes and fees, clearly available at ALL TIMES, including prior to purchase,  during  purchasing, and prior to completing purchasing.  Clearly clarify prior to commitment to purchase a ticket fees and prices for luggage, meals, etc.

Title: George W. Sickler
Comment:
Hi, thanks for asking.  Two things:

2)  I was surprised that, when it came to seat selection, it now costs extra for a tall person (I'm 6-foot-2) to get essential legroom.  For me, it's not a luxury.  It's essential.

Regards,

George W. Sickler

Title: Oscar Gonzalez
Comment:
I believe what the carriers are doing amounts to legal false advertising. Their so-called "transparent airfares act of 2014" is anything but transparent. It would allow them to post fares online that are much lower than what the customer will be paying at checkout. 

I suggest that the act shows a complete breakdown at checkout of what the customer is paying. That would be the true transparent way of showing the customer what he/she is paying for.

Please do not allow the airlines a say-so in this. Their incessant greed along with the rest of corporate America continues to spiral out of control and is an insult to Americans.

Title: Laurie Norton
Comment: Airlines should have to list all applicable taxes separately, along with their basic price.  Consumers should NOT have to hunt for the information or take chances that taxes are comparable between flights...

Title: Richard York
Comment: I think airline ticket price info should include all mandated taxes & fees as a minimum.  Then the airline should be required to include an itemized list of all fees for any service that may be charged by the airline.

Title: Thomas Bauer
Comment: I believe that all airlines should have first bag checked free and then, if they are going to charge for subsequent luggage, price must be included in cost of airline ticket.  In addition, all other "sneaky" fees must be included when ticket price is quoted.

Title: Elizabeth Pierson
Comment: If the airlines are interested in trying to define transparency in such a way that the consumer is able to see how much the taxes are, the consumer should be provided transparency in what the consumer what the consumer wants and needs transparency, which is the overall cost of the ticket with a place to sit, put your purse, and, optionally, check a bag.  If the airlines think additional information, such as the breakdown of taxes, is relevant to the consumer, they are free to provide it, but what they should be required to provide is the information the consumer needs to make a meaningful choice.

Title: Ken Hart
Comment:
Airlines should have to disclose the actual and full cost of a ticket.  There is a trend for airlines to tack on additional fees 'after' the completion of a ticket purchase transaction; such as baggage, seat assignment and carry-on bags.  This is nothing like sales tax the airlines are using as a defense.  Additional government and airline fees can number over a dozen and are constantly changing and can vary from one location to another.

It's in the interest of the public for full disclosure of taxes, fees, etc.  It's insane that a few dozen airlines can override the wishes and needs of the public and argue for need to deceive and mislead by obfuscating the true cost of travel.

Title: Art Kosatka
Comment:
I think I am most offended by the A4A line that the rule would probably “further increase airline expense, and force airlines to pass on the additional costs to customers in the form of higher fares or reduced levels of air service.”  While I suspect there are probably some finer points elsewhere in the rule that I’m missing:

•	These are not “additional” costs, they are the same costs you are already charging, but under a different name
•	Thus, they are not “higher fares”; they are the same total amount as before.  A rose by any other name….
•	It would likely be less administrative cost by not having the extra bookkeeping processes
•	There is no “reduced level of service” – that plane will still fly the same route, with the same amount of my money… or you wouldn’t be in that market in the first place.

Here’s a wild idea:  advertise  “Total cost – Yes, Really..   No Added Fees Ever.”  Use the extra $65 the other guys are charging you, when you get to the hotel bar in Maui.    I’d appreciate the honesty… and the competition would follow pretty quickly.

Title: Byron Hood
Comment:
This type of regulation is long-overdue. Airlines have found it all too easy to add hidden fees and charges, only to spring them on customers at the last minute. This is a deceptive business practice and has no place in a system that is already confusing enough to travelers. The DOT should define what a standard airline ticket entails, and require airlines to advertise the full price of that ticket, including any additional fees that might be charged for services within that definition.

Airlines may argue that in a free marketplace, they should be permitted to advertise their lowest base fare, and then charge additional fees for the services not provided by that base fare. This argument contains two fatal flaws, however. 

First, airlines are not specific about what services a customer is purchasing for that "base fare", so they cannot be held accountable for price and/or fee changes. In any other context, the concept of paying hundreds or thousands of dollars, months in advance, for a service that is not in the slightest guaranteed, would be considered ridiculous. For instance, a customer may purchase a $100 ticket in January for a flight in April with the understanding, based on the (often rather confusing) information made available by the carrier, that he/she is entitled to bring one carry-on aboard as part of the price. The airline, however, could institute a $25 carry-on bag fee in March, and then charge that customer for his/her carry-on, despite the fact that he/she was led to believe that the full price of travel was $100 (not $125). This is highly deceptive and violates the principle behind truth-in-advertising laws.

Second, the marketplace is not as free as airlines might suggest. Travelers do not have the flexibility to change their plans at a moment's notice and switch airlines if the first airline decides to institute fees that travelers might find unreasonable. Furthermore, many airlines charge hefty cancellation fees - often more than the original cost of the ticket - and thus customers are forced to pay other unanticipated and unadvertised fees. For instance, given the choice between a $25 carry-on fee or a $250 cancellation fee (plus the inconvenience and cost of booking another ticket), the vast majority of customers have little choice but the former (even if it did not exist at the time the ticket was purchased).

The solution to these problems is to codify a minimum definition of what must be included in a ticket price. This way, airlines cannot surprise customers with what effectively constitutes a price increase, at a time where customers do not have the power to resist or decline the unwanted cost. Airlines may still charge additional fees for services outside of the minimum definition, but would be liable for severe penalties for changing the price of those basic services - as they so often do today.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Real transparency would provide for an itemized price for all tickets: 1. fare; 2. tax; 3. carry-on; 3. one bag, two bags, etc.;4. food price; and 5. drink price.  Some items could be provided by clicking on a link but it should all be there for the consumer to review if he/she wishes.

Title: Jeff M.
Comment: Seems to me this is a pissing match as to who can force the other to do something.  The Airlines need to provide the costs for ALL the add ons, bags, taxes, services etc and the Government needs to allow the airlines to prominently show the taxes that are being tacked on to each ticket, especially since the taxes on an airline ticket are as high as tobacco and liquor which are taxed heavily to discourage use.  Here's a thought, lower the taxes on the tickets and have the prices broken down so people know what they are paying for and then totaled at the bottom.   It would be nice to see these two entities work together to solve these issues.  Also it would be nice to have all the taxes we've paid for the last 50 years actually be used to update and upgrade the ATC system and airports to something more befitting the 21st Century.  There have been hundreds of billions of taxes collected with little to show.  We are still using 50's technology in the ATC system and that is unacceptable.

Title: C. Bergmark
Comment: Please require airlines to allow customers to transfer tickets to someone else prior to checkin. The current policy is unreasonable, especially as airline tickets are usually not refundable, or the charges are so high, customers simply lose ther money if they have to cancel a flight.

Title: Priscilla Bauer
Comment: The airlines should be regulated like they were in the 70's and before.  They charge for food that is just okay but not really good.  They charge for luggage that use to be included in the price of the ticket. (they damage or ruin you luggage and do nothing to replace or repair it properly). If they were as good as they used to be we wouldn't mind paying for extra luggage (after the 2nd piece or there food.  But to pay for blankets & pillows when you are flying 10 hours or more is not a very good business practice.  The customer should come first.  They cram us in a small place and then do nothing to help us remain in good spirit.  Charging more for the tickets could be an answer, however, it seems they charge much more for the tickets and then add more on for other things just to make more money, so that they can merge with other airlines to simply put there competition out of business.  Example:  American Airlines buys U S Air and there (AA) ticket prices go sky high.  However the service don't go up is goes down.  Is this a Really good policy?  I think not.  Maybe giving a discount to seniors and the handicapped would be nice also.

Title: JC Naber
Comment: Airlines and Congress have some nerve naming their brand of legislation TRANSPARENT! I want to know that I am comparing apples to apples and NOT apples to watermelons or apricots or dirigibles. DOT -- Please continue to fight for us consumers. Thank you!

Title: Tatiana Marquez
Comment: Reliable information is an important factor when making purchasing decisions, if not all decisions in everyday life. It is in the consumers benefit to be able to compare apples to apples when deciding which airline ticket to buy. I understand that different airports must add different charges to their tickets based on local and regional taxes. It would help consumers to know the difference taxes added on to tickets based on these geographical differences. However, must importantly for the consumer we would like to know the total cost of an airline ticket once all fees and taxes have been tagged on to our purchase. Please keep on trying to make sure consumers have the most relevant information made available to them before purchases are made. I encourage and support the DOT efforts to mandate airlines to only advertise prices that include both the fare and all corresponding taxes associated with the purchase.

Title: Alex Tray
Comment:
It would be nice if information included what was available for extra purchase and what was included.

It also feels like, with checked bags, that those who buck the system get rewarded, while people who follow the rules have to pay an extra tab.  For example, checking in a bag at the front costs 50 dollars round trip.  But people who carry it to the terminal and volunteer to give up their carry on space and check their bags in, get to do it for free.  While I understand that there should be incentive to volunteer, it just feels dishonest to do this intentionally while others have to suck it up.

Title: L. De Vito
Comment: I have recently gone through the process of buying airline tickets. I was dismayed and discouraged by the complexity involved when trying to compare prices. The fee disclosures are mercurial, especially when using a third party booking service. It took at least 5 hours of laborious, tedious processes and even then I was not confident that I had all the information I really needed. Sure enough, I did not. The seat assignments made on the booking agency website was fictional and I had to make a phone call to the airline to purchase the now deemed add-on feature of what used to be customary; i.e. assigned seats. The current situation is a consumer nightmare.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Strongly support legislation that requires greater transparency and accountability from airlines re: fees and costs to consumers. Please pass this legislation! Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airlines must disclose the full price of a ticket before customers get to the purchase point, whether this is through an online site or a travel agent. It is unfair to make customers wait until they choose all of their flights to find out the true cost of the tickets.

Title: Nick
Comment: I don't really care about the advertising, because I always use orbitz, or another search website to compare prices. As long as those sites keep consistent, it's fine, because an educated consumer never belives the airline advertisement anyway..

Title: Robert Gramm
Comment: This proposed rule is a common sense one and should have been instituted long ago. To be able to compare airline pricing, it is necessary to have available the ancillary fees that the traveler will pay. For too long, these have been hidden and then the traveler is surprised at the counter when checking in. I support the rule as it brings transparency to the market place and helps ensure the traveling public can make a fair determination when booking airline tickets.

Title: Martin Weinberger
Comment: I am in support of a standard definition of a ticket that would include airfare and all fees and taxes. I am opposed to airline industry backed position that would allow only the fare portion of a ticket to be advertised.  This approach is contrary to the idea of true transparency, anticonsumer in its effect and formulated to further disadvantage consumers vis a vis the power of the remaining airlines.  When I purchase an airline ticket I want to see what it will cost me and what is included in the price.  If the seller of the ticket chooses to provide a breakdown of how the fare is calculated, that option would not be precluded by the proposal under consideration.  What the airline industry wants to do reminds me of an old George Carlin routine where he assumes the role of a sportscaster reporting baseball scores.  He says now a partial score - Philadelphia 3.  The airlines want to give us an analogous partial cost.  Please do not allow them to do so.

Title: John Samuelson
Comment: I fly 8 to 10 times a year. I want the cost of a flight, advertised by the airline, to be the total charged to me on my credit card statement.

Title: Gene
Comment: Please don't let the airlines get away with hidden fees. Also, letting them post prices without the taxes would be permitting deception.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a human reasoning researcher, I know the kinds of underhanded tricks that advertisers play.  What consumers need is simple, clear information at a glance to help them make rational decisions.  Regarding prices, that means knowing the total cost for their trip, with whatever luggage they intend to bring, for each available airline.  In one table, at a glance.

Importantly, rules regarding fares and fees should not only apply to airlines, but to all air travel booking sites.  From personal experience, I know these travel sites to be some of the worst offenders.

Title: Elizabeth Kotz
Comment:
Like most Americans, I strongly oppose the proposed (and deeply misnamed) "Transparent Airfares Act" of 2014, which would allow airlines to advertise just the "base fee," without taxes. 

Consumers pay the base fee WITH taxes -- and those taxes make up a significant portion of the cost of any plane tickets. 

Allowing airlines to advertise just the "base price" would be allowing them to do false advertising. 

So please listen to the American public, and not the A4A and other airline industry trade groups. 

The Full Fare Advertising Rule, implemented by the U.S. Department of Transportation in 2012, was a good move. Don't change it to allow airlines to do bait-and-switch advertising.

Title: Patricia Levitan
Comment: As a consumer usually on a budget, I want to know exactly what the cost of my travel will be.  I support disclosing all costs down to the penny of any flight I take.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Include the taxes in the full price of the ticket. Also, include an additional note about how much baggage fees are per bag when listing the price of the fare. (For example: $205 roundtrip, including taxes, plus $25/checked bag)

Title: Jonathan Proudfoot
Comment:
Price should absolutely include all taxes etc, in addition there must be a standard specification regarding what you get for the fee.
You should get a seat No, carry on  bag and handbag, and drink for the quoted fee.
I do feel that the customer needs to understand about airport taxes, BUT the airlines only have themselves to blame for these being unclear!
Try checking on a flight to London Heathrow, though you may see similar prices from each airline, the tax shown can vary wildly so I have no confidence in the airlines plying fair if allowed to separate air fare and tax element!
"Transparency" means the paying customer not feeling conned when making a purchase by then finding that he will need extras to actually make the trip once already having paid up.
Airlines like that we book direct on line, rather than using agents that add cost to them, so they must be responsible for clarity to the public.

Title: Marius Voitek-Berger
Comment: I am a vivid consumer who travels a lot.  When I need to purchase a flight ticket, I can never determine what my real expenditures will be (budget).  I’m so disappointed that this form of advertising is promoted all over across our continent, but in Europe too (I’m European, natively).  I have been attracted by the airlines with initially thought affordable prices, but in the long run as I was flighting throughout the airports, I’ve encountered so many other unexpected fees (baggages, meal,...).  I’m so sick and tired of this.  I hope that our US Government will get us out of this impact, and we can once and for all say:  "This is how much you have to consider taking out of your pocket; for real!".  This applies also to restaurants, general shoppings, car rental, house rental, and so on.  Could we once and for all get a real price to include all these fees?  Thank you!

Title: Steven Hall
Comment: I was one click away from booking the flight my family had planned to use to take our vacation.  Then, I noticed that a baggage fee was not included in the price.  I started looking into it, and these fees, as best I could tell, could cost over 50% of the ticket the price.  Emphasis on "best I could tell" because the information was unclear, hard to find, and completely defeated my efforts to compare fares.  I gave up and we've decided to drive and not fly this year.  As a consumer, I want to know how much I am going to have to pay to travel by air.  I am less concerned about the inclusions of taxes, but the closer the quoted price is the final price, the better.  The airline industry is doing its self a disservice in opposing measures that promote greater transparency and accuracy of quote airfares.  Until I know what I am paying UP FRONT, I won't be able to compare airfares, and when I can't compare (or the process is incredibly complex and difficult), I won't fly.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Consumers need to know exactly how much their airfare will cost. We don't go to grocery stores, pick up a can of soup at one price, and arrive at checkout to learn that there's a 5-cent can charge, a 3-cent soup surcharge and a 10-cent "you've carried this around the store for more than 15 minutes" charge. It's outrageous that consumers have to fight to get the accurate price of airfares so we can at least compare them, apples to apples, in an industry with increasingly fewer options as airlines merge.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I can no longer afford to fly as ticket prices are going up due to fees..this means no visiting family around the country. My parents are travel agents and this has also affected their tour company, causing them to have to add on a service fee to compensate for the rising cost of air fare. Honestly, I don't mind the one bag limit or the weight restriction for bags, but the fact that southwest makes you buy two tickets if your overweight or that you now pay for basic comfort, like a drink, on all airlines is ridiculous given the outrageous cost you have to pay. While the costs go up, the seat gets smaller and comfort gets stripped away. For that, I would rather drive.

Title: David Salzberg
Comment:
This resolution is critically required.   When I book an trip,  I have to search for the fees to figure out the best deal.  And the information is often buried until you go to check in.  As an example, lets say I am traveling for a $200 round trip fair, but I require 2 bags.  I typically fly United, and would end up paying $75 in bag fees.  By comparison, Southwest might advertise the ticket a $210, but the bags are free.  Under this circumstance, United is actually $65 dollars more than Southwest.


The only reason to keep the regulations as is is to allow the airlines to bury profit making activities until after the (usually non-refundable) ticket is purchased.

Title: Andrew Rodriquez
Comment:
I have flown over a million miles as a business traveller over the past 25 years, on Southwest, Delta, Continental, United, Northwest, and others.

Please require all airlines to offer standardized service and be more teasparmnt in their pricing.   It is already bad enough that they have ministure monopolies on a per-route basis (e.g. $800 direct routes of 400 miles,that cost more than $200 multi-leg routes thst travel 600 miles).  When you add in these kooky pricing models on top of that, it is hard to know what you are really getting for your money until you get it.

It would be very nice if
1) everyone had the same classes of service
2) those classes of service described equipment and inclusions (e.g. Coach turboprop with one checked bag)
3) everyone had the same pricing structure for add-ons

Thank you.

Title: C. Thurman
Comment: Let's get rid of the old "bait and switch" once and for all. I'm intelligent - I have a PhD, for cryin' out loud - but it sure would be better to see all the airfare costs up front. I'm am all for changes that would uncover the hidden charges, standardizing and simplifying the process of purchasing an airline ticket for consumers.

Title: Cynthia Dyer
Comment:
I am for complete transparency. Airlines should be required to advertize the total charge for a seat on a plane, including all taxes and fees. After one selects a fare, at that time the various taxes and fees should be itemized, so the taxes aren't hidden.

Everything that is included in the initial fare should be transparent as well, either standardized among the carriers or, if not, then spelled out clearly from the beginning.

Service providers must be made to treat their consumers honestly and respectfully, since they apparently resist doing so voluntarily.

Title: Sam Lane
Comment: Completely in favor of the proposed rules.  It’s about time that airlines were required to reveal the true price of their commodity.

Title: Damian Pokoj
Comment: I believe that as citizen of this country I should be able to see total cost of the ticket - including any taxes and fees.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I think taxes and fees SHOULD be included in advertised prices.  If the airline is so worried about the consumer knowing what they are paying for (ticket vs taxes) they have the ability to make that abundantly clear on their website and in the checkout process.

Title: Denise L.
Comment: I want the ticket price to include all taxes and fees. I don't mind fees for checked bags - let those who bring a lot pay their share of the extra gas. Carryon shouldn't be charged.

Title: Pat Engel
Comment: Airline pricing has gone completely out of whack.  Passengers need to know when they book exactly how much the fare is; no added fees later.  Would you buy anything else without knowing the exact cost up front?  I used to enjoy flying, but rarely do anymore, and this is one of the big reasons why.

Title: S. Feldman
Comment: I absolutely believe that airlines should be required to provide information on all fares, taxes and fees in all advertising, and that all airline websites, travel websites and travel agencies should be required to provide this information as a part of the basic ticket cost information during the time a customer is doing cost comparisons, etc. Who can travel without any luggage? What are you supposed to do, mail your clothes and toothpaste? Obviously fees for checking luggage are now a part of the cost of the flight, regardless of how the airlines try to couch them. In many cases the numerous fees are the lion's share of the total cost of the flight. Sins of omission in advertising may be harder for people to spot, that does not make them less deceitful, and it does not make the practice of omitting the information while advertising rock-bottom ticket prices less predatory.

Title: Jeff Bineham
Comment:
There should be a standard definition of a ticket and that definition should include taxes. While it's true that other institutions do not have to advertise taxes (restaurant prices, for example) the amount of those taxes are generally known by those who frequent the institutions. Taxes on airline tickets vary across states and and airports, so the only way the consumer can compare prices is for the taxes to be stated up front.

Airlines should also be required to include as clearly stated supplementary information any fees charged by the airline or the airports for baggage.

Title: Jack McBroom
Comment: My understanding is that the airlines have separated the so-called 'fees' from the 'fares' because the airlines are not required to pay taxes on 'fees' collected whereas fares are.  If this is true, the airlines are using this as a method to evade taxation.

Title: Klaus Schuller
Comment: I strongly support the new rules, and indeed would argue that they don't go far enough.  Consumers need to be protected from misleading price advertising, and be able to compare true inclusive fares at a glance.  If we truly believe in a free market economy and competition, then we need to be able to compare apples to apples and find the best value.  Any other practice is deceptive on its face, and designed only to confer unfair advantage on to one provider over another.

Title: Lynne Anderson
Comment:
This is a no-brainer.  I am so tired of airlines playing with their fees.  

I recently tried to buy two tickets overseas.  The price for two said $3700.  I clicked buy.  The website came back that those tickets were no longer available, the price was now $4400.  I stopped, search again on other website and found the same schedule offered for $4100.  I clicked buy.  The website came back that the price was no longer available, it was now $4700.

We are entering an era where we are no longer free enterprise.   Free enterprise is where businesses compete.  Congress seems bent on allowing merger after merger until only 2-4 big businesses exist in a line of business and they don't compete, they spent all of their time trying to reduce competition and increase prices.

The current airline ticket arrangement is a joke.

I am very much in favor of requiring the airlines to show the entire amount that a person will pay for a flight.  There is really no other alternative if we are actually going to be fair and not just cater to the few big oligopolies.

Title: Nancy Curtis
Comment: Please require that the consumer receive complete information about all fees right at the beginning of an inquiry and that fare aggregation sites be required to disclose which airlines they favor over others.  It would be more helpful if there were a federal "exchange" online of airfares with all this information which would aggregate it and make it easily searchable for every consumer, cutting out the middle man.

Title: Allen Grew
Comment:
Pass/implement DOT-OST-2014-0056 (Proposed Rule: Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues).

Allen G. Grew
6 Howe Terrace
Methuen MA 01844-3221

Title: Steven Munger
Comment: These changes are critical if consumers are to be able to make fully informed decisions about airline ticket purchases. I am a regular flyer for both business and personal reasons. I fully support them.

Title: Nancy Thornburn
Comment: It has been wonderful being able to see the TOTAL cost of an airline ticket, which includes the taxes.  Don't let this slide backwards.  I applaud your efforts to also include any additional charges that might be added, such as baggage, meals, etc.  The airlines are trying to take us backwards by hiding additional costs and making tickets appear less expensive.  We pay what we pay and we need to know upfront if we can afford that flight.

Title: James Gray
Comment: I wholeheartedly agree that transparency is a must in regard to airline advertising. What has essentially been bait and switch tactics is absurd. There are now so many added on costs the consumer has no idea what they are buying. For those that argue other industries do not have the same restrictive requirements I would respond that other industries do not have a half dozen or more additional charges tacked on to their fees.

Title: Margaret Appleton
Comment: I support forcing airlines to include taxes in advertised pricing.  That allows true comparison. It should always include a seat assignment.  Fees for everything not included clearly listed

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a frequent traveler, I fully support transparent disclosure of airline ticket costs, taxes, and fees. Often the full cost of travel is obscured by lack of disclosure of fees, creating an uneven playing field for consumers. The current fees charged by airlines for everything from luggage to food to movies, creates an experience that is fraught with hidden fees. 

Please support full disclosure of ALL costs of airline travel. 

Thank you.

Title: Fred Schachat
Comment: Fairness in advertising requires that both taxes and ancillary fees be listed at the time of purchase.  Taxes are an intrinsic part of an airfare; they cannot be avoided. Listing them makes it possible to accurately assess the true ticket cost.  Ancillary fees need to be listed because more and more accepted services of a common carrier are being converted to fees for service fees,  and they are an ever increasing proportion of ticket costs.  Moreover,  if these fees are not included, competition is hindered: airlines that provide for services such as checked bags, and even a bag of peanuts, are out at a disadvantage.

Title: Alexander Thompson
Comment: I would like to voice my strong support of the Transparency Act and its requirement that the full fare be advertised. It would be extremely useful to know what the ticket price is paying for and could potentially work out in the airline's favor. Recently I was on an American Airlines flight from New York to LA, a 7.5 hour direct flight, and there was no food provided, no peanuts or pretzels, except what was available for purchase. If I've paid $650 for a ticket and I'm going to be on a plane for more than 4 hours it seems fair to hope for a small complimentary snack, and if I knew, for instance, that a ticket on Delta was slightly more expensive but included a meal I would be willing to pay more to have the cost of the meal wrapped up in the ticket. I know meals aren't your primary focus, but I do support the basic premise of the bill and I appreciate your work to help inform and empower the consumer.

Title: Connie Mahoney
Comment: Buying an airline ticket is like playing a shell game. In addition to transparency of pricing in advertising, they should be forced to CLEARLY list their flights by cost on their websites. As it is, they pretend that you can shop by cost, but once you choose a price and go to buy the ticket you are suddenly forced to wade through ALL of the flight options again and decide based on flight time. Then you wait to find out how much it costs. The final cost is NEVER the low cost you initially chose. They purposely confuse and change the routes until you forget where you were going in the first place. Eventually you just click and pray that you made the right choice. And that's when they start hitting you with the "added" costs. No other industry gets away with this subterfuge...AND the airlines have the right to keep your money even if they don't provide the service. The whole thing is a racket. I don't fly anymore if I can help it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The regulations as written are excellent.  I would include an option to forbid animals onboard for those who are allergic to dogs and cats. This would be similar to when airlines serve alternate snacks when those with peanut allergies are onboard.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
1) First of all, why are these fees even allowed or tolerated? This should not be the new standard for air travel. 
2) Airline charges & fees should be 100% transparent to the consumer up front - including ALL taxes that go to TSA and to initiatives unrelated to the air travel.  
2) Airlines have threatened that any potential rule change will incase costs that they will have to "pass along to the consumer"  -    Airlines should be required to itemize and prove how and in what ways the rule change will incase their costs and an INDEPENDENT body should decide whether it's appropriate to pass these costs along to the consumer.
3)  Ban preferential ranking of carrier flights 
4)  Message to the A4A:  The USG does not currently tell other industries how to sell their products b/c those industries have not crossed the line that has been crossed by the airline industry.  All industry is driven by profit only and requires check & balance from time to time.

Title: Keith Williams
Comment: One price for one comprehensive ticket, please.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: When looking for fares,the total cost should show up. We do not want added fees and charges and taxes and "junk" fees added in the end to increase the cost. The airlines are taking us for a ride. No pun intended.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please force Airlines to disclose all taxes and fees as part of the cost of a ticket.

Title: Leslie McCormick
Comment:
I would like to vigorously express my support for clarity in airfare pricing by including taxes and any fees determined to be part of a "standard ticket" in any price quotes under the DOT's proposed rule:  Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues.

The bill in congress ridiculously and  hypocritically titled "Transparent Airfares Act of 2014" does a disservice to consumers and in the long run can only harm the airlines' reputations (which they really don't understand).

Title: C.C.
Comment: Why not advertise the TOTAL cost (including taxes) with an asterisk listing the amount in taxes.  I know it can be done, because there's almost always an asterisk as a disclaimer for every great price.

Title: Christopher Castelli
Comment: I support additional protections that require airlines and ticket agents to disclose at all points of sale the fees for certain basic ancillary services associated with the air transportation consumers are buying or considering buying.  As a customer I am discouraged by the time spent trying to compare airfares in order to find the "real" cost of a prospective trip.  In turn, I find myself flying less and looking for alternative means of transportation.

Title: Sandra Glass
Comment: When I shop online for an airline ticket amongst various sites I want to compare apples to apples, and I want to know what  my full and final cost will be before I go to the checkout and purchase.  I want to know upfront what are the various parts making up the total cost and finally, total cost of that airline ticket. Full fare Government regulations should protect the public. The public has a right to consumer protection!

Title: Zachary Ansley
Comment:
Which Republican in the House of Representative sponsored the bill that favors airline industry business and profits over consumers?

Even an idiot can see the airlines want to use deceptive price advertisement to "bait" consumers and then "switch" the prices by adding on expensive fares for seat selections, carry on luggage, food, taxes, airport fee, etc.  Bait and Switch -- isn't there a law against that advertisement practice ALREADY??  You know damn well noboby can't fly without a seat and you surely are going to need a few pair of fresh drawers, slacks, skirts, etc. when you get to where you're going.  BAIT 'N SWITCH!!  CALL IT WHAT IT IS.  USE IT AS YOUR TAGLINE.

I have to give it to industries and republican politicians. They know that most American citizens are too ignorant about legislation and that they will ultimately win in making the people pay to ensure that the RICH CONTINUE TO GET RICHER -- THAT IS UNTIL THEY DIE AND GO STRAIGHT TO HELL.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airlines that clearly state what I will pay, in total, and define clearly whst that includes will get my business.  I value upfront, frank snd honest. Airlines that play games with the facts will annoy the consumer and, judging from my own point of view,  will lose business.

Title: Meghan Kennedy Justice
Comment: I support Senator Robert Menendez's Real Transparence in Airfares Act.  Advertised airline prices SHOULD include all fees and taxes so that a reasonable comparison can be made among different airlines and so that it is possible for the consumer to determine exactly what they will be paying (and paying for) when they purchase a ticket.

Title: Anne Fuller
Comment:
On a third party site, I'm cautious about believing that the price quoted will be my cost.  When on the airline site or watching an ad from an airline, I want to see the cost (I support the definition of basic ancillary services.

The airline can't sell me a ticket without the airport fee, so the price needs to include that fee.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Please continue to push for greater transparency in airfares.  Hidden taxes and fees are very difficult to know ahead of time, given the complexity of the various airlines, baggage, taxes, fees, meals, etc.  I travel a lot for business and I would like to see an 'apples to apples' ticket price required, where every airline is required to show prices that include: a seat, a checked bag, a carry-on bag, a nonalcoholic beverage, and a small snack.  These items could be increased to include a larger snack, headphones and a second nonalcoholic beverage on flights of 4+ hours.  Finally, long haul flights should also include a number of meals corresponding to the time spent on the plane (one every four hours) a pillow, and a blanket.

Any attempt by the airlines to propose that consumers want "bare" fares, so they can be knowledgeable (and appalled) when their $250 ticket balloons to $300, is like saying that I want my grocery store to stop showing vegetable prices that include shipping costs, so that I could have the "opportunity" to more fully understand the global agricultural system.  

I applaud your current efforts, and encourage you to do even more to assist consumers.

Title: Jenni R.
Comment:
The price of an airline ticket should include a seat assignment and a carry-on bag plus a personal item. If the price of the fair doesn't include a seat assignment, what does that even mean? Are you not guaranteed a seat at all? Maybe there is a standard definition of it, but my mother didn't understand what it meant when she flew to visit me two weeks ago, and she paid the extra $9 for a seat assignment out of fear that she might end up bumped from the flight because she didn't have a seat assignment. 
If the airline advertises a fair, I think it's ok for them to list the base price separately, but they should also have to list the taxes and fees in the same size font in the same visual field (e.g., $59 + $15 in taxes and fees, not $59 and then have the taxes and fees listed in small print at the bottom of the page). If it's impossible to regulate to this level of detail, then they should have to include the taxes and fees in the price they advertise. I understand the airline's argument that other industries don't have to do this, but other industries aren't charging us fees for a seat assignment or to bring another bag with us--so if the airlines are going to nickle and dime what is pretty much a captive audience (we have no choice but to fly some places), our government has the right to regulate them differently on our behalf.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe it is criminal the way the airlines are currently allowed to falsely advertise "low" fares to lure in customers, when, in the end, the fares are significantly higher.  There should be a standard by which customers will know that the advertised price ALWAYS, at a minimum, includes fare, all taxes, seat assignment upon purchase, carry on luggage and at least one checked bag.  Otherwise, it is too difficult and confusing to compare prices between airlines and even days and times when booking.

Title: Susan Henoch
Comment: I often fly between NYC airports and Milwaukee, Denver and Albuquerque, among other places in the US and internationally. The changes in fares and fees is constant. I often rely on Southwest Airlines domestically, as they are the only company that still allows free baggage and flexibility in changing dates without a penalty. However, it is difficult to find a consistently low fare or even the same route from one month to another these days, as there seems to be constant turmoil in the formula, most often with rising prices for more limited flight choices and longer flying times. For my upcoming flight to Albuquerque, I am taking a 6:00 AM Amtrak train ($51) to Baltimore to catch a 9:45 AM nonstop flight ($206), since this is the best route for the lowest cost and shortest flying time--even though I'm nearer four major airports. Flying in this country is becoming prohibitively expensive and unpleasant. It makes me wish for a system of fast trains throughout the United States! (But that's another conversation, isn't it?!) Anything you can do to force airlines to tell the truth, whether about fares or anything else related to consumer safety and convenience, would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

Title: Vincent Dunlap
Comment: This regulation is clearly needed to make comparison shopping easier.  The airlines need to learn to advertise in an open and honest way to consumers.  Afterall, everyone hates flying, so why make it worse?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I agree that it would be a great service to consumers to provide a system of equal comparisons between actual costs of airline travel. If airlines have nothing to hide they will be behind such a move to transparency. If not, then we have further evidence that there is, indeed, something "rotten" in the current system-- and it isn't in the traveler's interest! Please continue to fight the good fight of consumers' rights. After all, without us the airlines would be out of work.

Title: Simone
Comment:
I think carriers must make known all taxes and fees. It is very frustrating to consumers not know how much things cost. Besides,it is very difficult to compare total prices without that information. If 
carries weren't so sneak with their charges,this legislation would not be necessary. However, carriers got used to hide fees and taxes for years and now they want to continue to be able to false advertise and steal our money with hidden fees and taxes. I am sick and tired of feeling like I am being robbed everytime I buy a ticket. Consumer protection and education is the key since carriers want to be dishonest with consumers.

Title: Melissa
Comment: Thank you for coming up with this bill. I think it's unfair and extremely sneaky for airlines to not be upfront about the total cost of a ticket, and any surcharges that may apply. In Europe, prices are almost always shown with tax (even in restaurants!) so it would simply bring us in line with the rest of the civilized, pro-consumer world.

Title: Steven Maynard
Comment:
Please don't fall for the airline industries Orwellian claim that Less Is More - It is VERY helpful that the pricing includes the taxes and fees.  It is NOT comparable to seeing a meal advertised for $9.99 - I can count on 8% tax and 15% tip there - with airfares, who knows what the final cost will be?  

And the extra fees?  Who knows what they are as well? I say put it ALL out front and force MORE upfront and uniform disclosure, not hidden fees that you are coerced to pay when you get to the airport.

I fly a lot, and I have been much happier since the taxes were included. I would like to fee MORE disclosure.

Title: Alan Root
Comment:
C'mon... get serious! Flyers want a bottom line cost for each airline ticket to go from point A to point B including all out-of-my-pocket add ons. Airlines may eventually be shunned by boycott behavior that slowly escalates -- particularly by corporate America and vacationers. When fuel prices go up, a fare increase may be justified. but when they go down, so should the price of tickets. Again... get serious!

Alan Root
ar1932@gmail.com

Title: John Neal
Comment:
I absolutely 100% support these new rules that would require upfront displaying of total possible fees, reporting requirements for smaller airlines, and so on... This is in addition to the displaying of fares with their taxes included. I don't agree with the airlines argument that it will result in higher fares, as the customer is actually likley to end up paying less overall with these new requirements in the end. 
I'm a frequent flyer
Thanks
J. Neal

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please require airlines to include taxes and fees in the price they post upfront for plane tickets. The advertised price for fares needs to be representative of the final cost when the consumer goes to pay.

Title: Louise Goodman
Comment:
When purchasing a ticket one needs to compare apples to oranges NOT apples to lemons.  
1.  Charge for carry-ons - NO
2.  Charge for 1 checked bag -NO
3.  Include all taxes and airport fees - YES
4.  Include your seat - isn't that what you are paying for?
5.  Include polite, helpful cabin help - YES
6.  Offer routes that do not go 180* in the opposite direction in order to reach destination- YES

Title: Darrell Hoerter
Comment: I believe the airlines should have to disclose, up front, the fare, the taxes and the fees, separately AND in total.  This entitlement idea that things can be hidden from consumers must stop.  And make the fines 10 times what they currently are.

Title: Allison Simmons
Comment:
The advertised prices should reflect ALL taxes and fees and the "standard" should be established to include one carry on, one checked bag of a certain weight and meals and beverages depending on the flight length. Taxes and fees should be broken down in a list of all costs BEFORE final purchase. 
This way the airlines cannot advertise prices that are false and the government taxes and fees are clearly presented to the consumer. 

Establishing the standard might be time consuming but it's necessary for consumer protection and fair competition between retailers. Allowing airlines to charge a fee for every service will eventually undermine consumer confidence in the industry and make oversight a total mess.

 -A. Simmons of NY, frequent flyer

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I believe that the whole airline industry has gone overboard.
If weight is important, then they should charge overweight people more for their tickets.  
Why is more weight ok for first class passengers? Just because you are rich you can carry more weight?
It is misleading to assert that weight is the factor in charging baggage fees. 
So, let's put people and their luggage on a scale and charge accordingly... I think that would at least be more fair.

Transparency is essential.  Yes spell out the price of ticket, fees, baggage, meals etc. all up front and let the passenger decide which airline to fly.
Also they should show the rating of the airline - stars, just like restaurants or other establishments on Yelp.  Travelers are not idiots.  We need information in order to make decisions that suit our pockets and our desires.
Regulations are essential in this out of control capitalistic system.  It is a fallacy to believe that companies will regulate themselves... we all saw what happened to the banks and the economy when we allowed that to happen.  They simply don't give a foot about people. It is all about their PROFITS.  We need to regulate and make them follow the rules.  Their tendency is to band together and screw us all by becoming monopolies.  We need to unite to make them tow the line.  After all without passengers they would go bust. ..... but...

Title: Neil B.
Comment:
Airlines tack on so many ancillary "mandatory" fees and local governments tack on so many additional taxes that if we can't see them, how are we supposed to make a fair price comparison?
For instance, flying from Denver to Prague. The ticket may be the same, but if you connect London the price might be $100 more because of taxes vs connecting in New York. How can I be an informed consumer if I can't see those charges right up front?

Title: Stuart Frederich-Smith
Comment: I strongly support your efforts to increase transparency in air travel costs, particularly by defining a reasonable minimum requirement for what a 'ticket' means. Keep up the good work.

Title: Anonynous
Comment:
Earlier this year I booked a flight with spirit airlines. The flight had a base fee of 30$. While I knew there would be taxes and fees I had no idea how expensive it would be. I thought the full price would be around 80-90$, but it actually ended up being the same price as the Southwest flight I had been considering. Had I known the full price I would have flown southwest without hesitation due to many of their benefits, free flight changes and baggage. I tried to change the time of my flight with spirit, but if you cancel or change your flight you get none of your money back. All of the hidden fees that spirit had absolutely turned me off and I will NEVER fly spirit again. Had they put a more realistic price on their website I would have had no problem, but at every turn there were more fees and taxes and fees, totaling about 75$. 
So even if this does not pass, I would recommend airlines adopt a more transparent full ticket price that shows a breakdown of taxes and fees at the end. You may fool the consumer once, but you may also lose all of their future business. I will never trust spirit due to the way they advertised their ticket vs the real price and I will certainly never spend another dollar to benefit that company.

Title: Kate Clark
Comment: Make the airlines show you exactly everything you have to pay for a ticket - the price, the fees and the taxes.

Title: Robert Flowers
Comment: YES to requiring airlines to disclose the full cost of a ticket, including all fees and taxes.  The industry statement:  "Airlines argue that other industries are allowed to advertise basic prices without spelling out the additional costs. For example, you can see a meal advertised for $9.99 on a billboard, even though you'll end up paying more once you add the tax and tip." (NPR) is just industry doublespeak to confuse and confound consumers so they can gouge and get away with it. Using the industry statement above as an example, I know, or can I find out easily, the taxes on my $9.99 meal and I make the decision to tip or not. Not so with airline fees and airport, etc. taxes.   So their argument doesn't get off the ground. Make the industry tell the truth, and when they don't, nail 'em.  A paltry $25K fine for telling a lie to the public is nothing to the industry!  Make a fine big enough to count as a deterrent.  Thanks for the chance to comment.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: When airlines have a clear menu with itemized options & prices to go with them, then they can whine about posting tax as part of their advertised fares, not before.  Airlines aren't restaurants, and the experience is vastly different.  When I know I will get personal individualized service, whether I'm footing the tab for not-so-complimentary peanuts in 1st class, or non-existent leg room in economy, is when I might be ok with them playing transparency price games....  not before....

Title: Eric DeWeese
Comment: Advertised airfares should include all fees, taxes, assigned seat, carry-on. & one checked bag.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I want FULL transparency in cost -- which means an airline has to state base fare, taxes, and fees.

While you're at it, how about forcing rental car companies to do the same?

Title: James Campbell
