Comment: I support full information of all things payable by customer in air travel, listing ticket price, taxes, fees, and additional services.  The boiler plate language of "other fees may apply is no longer acceptable in the information age.  Thank you

Title: Evan
Comment: The required display of the actual cost is clearly a win; this is one of the biggest things wrong with air travel (although false advertising is hardly limited to air travel). I'd put the benefit at well over a cent per passenger.

Title: D. Fulton
Comment:
Please pass strong regulations governing accurate and full display of air fares. A recent trip for me and my husband was expensive in the first place - and then there were baggage fees, fees for all food (not even peanuts, for goodness sake, and it was a long flight!),  and if we'd wanted any sort of legroom, more fees.

I understand that the airline industry is asking to be allowed to publish "base" fares - no taxes and no fees included. Cable providers do this, and its maddening! How can you know what you are buying if you don't know the true price? 

It's impossible to compare prices if taxes and fees aren't included in published fares. Please help consumers spend their dollars in an informed way!

Title: Gloribel Rivas
Comment: I think taxes should be included because they vary and are widely unpredictable in most cases. The argument that meals can be sold without taxes included in the advertised prices is bogus. I can do that math in my head and figure out how much I will be paying. However, in an ideal world, all prices wouldbe advertised with tax included.

Title: Erin McGann
Comment: I am for requiring airlines to advertise fares with fees and taxes- they can write Seat $100, taxes and fees $50 total $150 but I want to know what it is I am paying! I also want to have  standard base purchase so you know what you add ons will be- i.e. all tickets include a seat assignment and a carry on. It doesn't matter to me WHAT the base definition is, it matters to me if I am all of a sudden paying an extra $100 at the airport so I can sit in a seat and bring on a bag.

Title: Joseph Ficht
Comment: I support the proposed DOT rule.

Title: Mary Cairns
Comment: I believe strongly that advertised airfares should include taxes & any additional charges. baggage should also be listed upfront. One of the reasons that I prefer to use Southwest airlines is that all added fees are included and baggage is not extra.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please require airlines to include and and all taxes as well as any carry on luggage in their fee structure. It is important as a consumer to know what we are paying and to not getting nickel and dimed to death.

Title: Kelly Reddy-Best
Comment: I would like to know exactly how much my ticket cost up front.  I would like to be able to carry on a bag and be able to check a bag without any extra charges.

Title: Ruth Shaver
Comment: The "Transparent Airfare Act of 2014" needs to be passed because taxes and fees are a predictable and known (on a federal and state/airport authority basis) part of the cost of flying, the same way that federal highway and state transportation taxes are included in the cost of a gallon of gasoline because those are part of the cost of flying. I would argue that taxes should be included in ALL advertising except that national chains—restaurants, clothing stores, general retailers, etc.—would find doing so cost prohibitive due to the sheer number of tax collecting authorities each operates within. This is the red herring which must be avoided when discussing the appropriate advertising information for airfare.

Title: Derrick Williams
Comment:
I am in support of these additional rules on airlines.  Ever since the 2012 ticket/taxes rule change, it has been a blessing in comparing airline tickets better.  I use to waste so much time going through trying to find the best price by adding up all the taxes and fees.  I do that a lot less now, because I usually only fly a few certain airlines because I know they wont hurt me with a bunch of additional fees.  The rest of the airlines like to hide all of these additional fees for everything making it extremely hard to find out what a true cost of a ticket is through other airlines.   I wish more industries could be this way where you know the true cost of an advertised item.

Thanks.

Title: R. Wong
Comment:
As an American consumer, I believe that the proposed airline rules would be beneficial, and necessary to maintain both consumer safety, and a healthy competitive environment. 

It is necessary for me as a consumer to understand the true cost of travel while searching for airfares, including being able to easily understand fees for checked bags and other common or essential services and amenities, in order to make real comparisons while shopping for airline tickets. It would be preferable for this information to be reported and shown standardized data formats in order for computer APIs to be built from the information, but requiring airlines to publish the true cost of travel is a big step in the right direction. It is important personal budgeting, timeliness, and fairness to understand the true cost of travel before starting the purchasing process with an airline. 

While I endorse and support the proposal, I would ask that DOT take steps to mitigate unforeseen problems. For instance, by requiring airlines to reveal fees for a carry-on item and advance seat assignment, airlines that do not currently charge fees for those services may find it easier or in their interest to charge more for those services because of the reporting requirements.

Title: Theofilos Rafaelidys
Comment: Taxes and any extra fees ought to be part of the advertised price, so we can compare apples to apples .

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Consumers are sick and tired of the parlor games that businesses play with regard to smoke and mirrors advertising prices and actual "gotcha" pricing. This practice should be eliminated across the U.S. in ALL Industries period!

Title: Al Aliment
Comment: I am all for any improvement in the airline ticket buying process. I'm tired of having to look for "Mouse Print" with all the extra fees I may have to pay. Tired of finding the final price I have to pay is not the one advertised. With this upgrade travelers can see everything they need to make the best ticket purchase decision. Requiring online travel agencies to adopt consumer protection policies would be another major upgrade. Too much finger pointing, no one wanting to take responsibility and fix the problem. Lets get this passed, in place, and make traveling better for everyone.

Title: Jill
Comment: I would like to see airlines required to list the FULL COST of the ticket they are offering.  Just as the price of a gallon of gas includes many taxes but is advertised as a simple, easy-to-compare price, so should airline tickets.  Food is a matter of choice and seems it's not needed to be included in the price, but I believe the price should include a minimum of one piece of luggage (there seem to be industry-standard size and weight definitions).  If you are flying, you are by definition going a reasonable far distance and should be staying long enough to require a change of clothes and to brush your teeth!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a long overdue overhaul. Airlines routinely mislead customers about their rights and skirt their responsibilities. It is much needed for a fair playing field.

Title: William Clark
Comment:
Airline ticket prices should be totally transparent.  I believe the best way to accomplish this is with a standardized, itemized ticket showing the line item costs of basic fare, seat assignment, meals, taxes, airport fees, baggage fees, etc.  Any items which are optional should be noted as such.  At the bottom of the list, in LARGE print should be the sum of all the required costs, fees, and taxes, etc. along with the total cost of any selected options, and finally the grand total.


I think DOT should also look into the use of computer algorithms used to sell tickets based on the number of views, etc.  It is frustrating that ticket prices for the same route and same airline will change in a matter of minutes as you hunt for the best price. It doesn't seem right that the exact same ticket can have a variety of prices depending on how long you search for it.

Thank you

Title: R. Hill
Comment:
This regulations are long overdue and not nearly strong enough.  Airline pricing and selling policies are immoral and outrageous.  How can a traveler making an informed choice about a flight when ancillary fees for fundamental aspects of the flight have obscenely large prices affixed to them?  

You should also include regulations prohibiting the adjusting of prices for a specific person based on cookies and/or data obtained from data-mining done by the airline.  Adjusting prices for a person based on their search history, previous websites visited, or frequency of previous or planned future travel must be prohibited. 

Stronger regulations are required for a industry interested in providing the most minimal possible service while extracting the most possible cash.  Anyone who has flown an international airline knows that U.S. airlines offer inferior service more expensively than their peers.

Don't let the airlines water these regulations down.  Consumers should receive this basic protections and guarantees that they are seeing all possible information and options when they are trying to book flights.

Title: Gina Hylton
Comment: I agree 100% that quoted airfare should include all taxes and fees. When I book a flight, I want the bottom-line price.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The airlines are out of control.  They need to advertise the full price and something needs to be done about all the extra fees.  It is outrageous!  We pay more and get less all in the name of profit for a few.

Title: Tony Haliwell
Comment:
It is only fair that I have the price of the complete package.  I know how much the gasoline costs when I go to the pump. I know how much my Amtrak ticket will cost when I book it.  I know how much my hotel will cost when I book it. Why shouldn't you quote me what the total price is for my travel including taxes and fees, baggage cost, and the base fare. 

I can understand the restaurant and retail argument, but airlines are not restaurants and are not retail stores--they are transportation. All forms of transportation quote our the fees+taxes+base fare. Airlines should be required to do the same.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I haven't flown a US air carrier since 1986, and do not plan on ever doing so again until the airlines stop cheating passengers, which includes withholding all information pertinent to the actual cost of flying on one of their planes. The industry behaves outrageously.

Title: Bettina Barbier
Comment:
Airlines should have to state the full price of the ticket including fees and taxes in their ads and website, and on the pricing websites. If they want to they can break it down right there in that display space, thus providing the "transparency" they claim to value, but I want to see the whole price while making my buying decisions. 

By attempting to divorce the base ticket price from fees and taxes, they are removing transparency from the process. Such fractured and incomplete pricing will just confuse the issue and break the functionality of all the sites that find the lowest prices. 

It seems clear that the airlines would like to muddy the waters and make finding a ticket a longer and more difficult process. By showing lower than realistic pricing they create expectations and desires in their potential customer base, and create an artificial psychological "need" to buy a particular product. This "need" would tend to influence the buyer to discount additional fees and taxes, because they now have a desire that wants to be gratified, and there is now an incentive to gloss over the additional cost in the final decision process. What I see here is a somewhat underhanded anti-consumer move that would make things harder for everyone.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
As a traveler, I would appreciate knowing in advance what additional fees (taxes, baggage fees, etc.) before I purchase my ticket. My budget is limited, and I need to be able to make an informed choice about whether I can afford to fly a particular airline or to a particular airport. For instance, my mom is equidistant between Hartford and Providence. Knowing prices in advance lets me choose between the two airports and plan my trip. 

I heard that the airlines were comparing their situation to other business where tax and tips aren't included. Frankly I think that is ridiculous. But as long as we're addressing that, I think that all businesses should include tax in their prices
Every other country in the world does. But unless we have regulations to force business to include tax in their prices, no one will do it. It will make the prices of those who do seem inflated compared to those who don't. Thus we need regulation. Please don't lift those regulations from the airlines.

Title: Joseph Bernstein
Comment: Bravo, DOT! It is high time that the real cost of air travel is available to consumers at the point of purchase. After all, an air ticket that does not include basic fees, such as seat assignment and luggage conveyance is not a real commodity. No one wants to buy a unicorn instead of a realistic air ticket.

Title: Patricia Bickley
Comment: Please do what you can to ensure we know the full cost of a ticket based on fees. My recent trip to Jamaica for a wedding cost me an extra two hundred dollars due to Spirit Airlines' exorbitant baggage fees. I never would have bought that ticket had I known about those fees and I've never flown Spirit since.

Title: Mohan Paul
Comment:
As a citizen, I am in favor of this rule.  It doesn't have to be expensive as some have suggested.  The airlines already have these broken out per ticket, since they are charging these costs per ticket and so can show them easily to consumers.  I am a software engineer and I know how easy it is to implement.  IT does not have to expensive, in fact such information is available to the executives of these airlines thru big data and business intelligence software.

Good information is essential in free markets.  Airlines prefer not to have to show these items because then they will have to compete on price.  Today they can hide all these costs and spring it on the consumer when they are at the airport and have chance to an alternative flight.

These rules should over time help to reduce fare for consumers and I would argue that in a free market that is what should happen.  Congress should support free market policies and the need for transparency and better information for consumers and citizens.

Title: Matilda Larson
Comment: I think it's important for airline carriers to disclose the full cost passengers will pay when purchasing a ticket for a flight.  Otherwise airfare advertisements will market deceptively low-priced tickets and mislead customers.

Title: Bernard Clark
Comment:
I think it's very important that travellers are able to see the maximum amount of information at the initial ticket purchasing stage, so we have the best chance of making the most informed decision. It's tough enough booking already, and become very much more so with premiums for booking particular seats, lounges, baggage, and boarding priorities. Fine that we are given these choices, but they must be clearly shown at booking stage. And any changes should not just allow a refund, but some kind of additional premium to the passenger, say $50 and upwards. After all, if we change our itinerary we normally get charged - and what's good for the goose.......
Transparency is good for business, and especially good for good businesses. Or to put it another way, hidden charges and obscuring stuff is what crook and criminals do.

Bernard Clark --- London and North Carolina

Title: Thomas Fralich
Comment: I travel frequently, and still I'm sometimes tricked by hidden fees in airline ticketing. This has become worse recently, with Frontier, Spirit, Allegiant, and other "low cost" carriers adopting the model of fees for everything. I support legislation which would allow travelers to compare fares directly, without having to do extra research to identify the hidden fees for seat selection, check bags, carry-on bags, etc. The airlines should be required to publish "standard fares" which are directly comparable by consumers.

Title: Lorraine Kelman
Comment: I support the Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection issues bill.  Fares are misleading and improvement is needed.  I am also opposed to baggage and other fees, and would support a bill to either remove them or include the fees clearly in advertising.

Title: Kimberly Levinson
Comment: Please DO institute these rules. I went looking for a coach flight to the Caribbean, checking several islands, and saw what looked like a great deal: $400! But when I clicked on it there were $500 in fees attached! We need to know that up front, not be sandbagged by it at checkout.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We should know the entire price up front including taxes and extra fees altogether when considering purchasing a ticket. It makes it easier and fairer to compare airline prices. Being able to hide all the extra fees misleading to the comsumer. Further, when you buy a product from a store or restaurant, you know the amount of the tax and can factor it in. There are no other hidden fees, and a tax on a product that costs $9.99 is the same in any store in that state.  Airlines want to keep people in the dark about costs, but to no end except their profits and to the detriment of consumers.

Title: Steve Brown
Comment: As one who often flies, I endorse the ideas behind "Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues".  I am especially interested in the full disclosure of the various fees that go into determining the total cost to fly from point  A to point B.

Title: Phil Stigall
Comment: Yes.  Yes.  Yes.

Title: April Kemp
Comment: As I was reading I saw the bit about the $9.99 meal at a diner that is actually more. It is ok for them to advertise that because I am aware of how much the tax is in my state at a diner. I do not know what the tax is in my state at an airport for a ticket  or any other for that matter. it is not general public knowledge where as the state rate at a diner is.

Title: S. Jahangeer
Comment: I strongly support efforts to compel All airlines (local and international) to fully reveal All charges (including basic fares and any and all additional fees, taxes, surcharges, ) from the very beginning of a air-ticket booking process.  There is too much deception in airfares already and the hidden fees, surcharges, taxes, etc.  add up to a significant increase in the airfares as currently initially displayed while booking air travel.  It is criminal on the part of airlines to force passengers to travel like sardines in a can without coughing up substantially additional dollars for carrying their luggage, a comfortable seat, food and water, etc.  They make one wish for the days before airline deregulation when airline travel was simpler.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am a citizen of the U.S. and approve heartily of the DOT requiring more airline transparency in the upfront disclosure of all fees and taxes and costs associated with airline tickets.  I fly regularly on trips within the U.S. and abroad and find it ever more difficult to understand the pricing of the various airlines and would like to be able to "comparison shop" like a good consumer. One has to have clarity from the airlines first in order to do that. Just like any other product or service, airline ticket prices should be clearly laid out and explained to the potential consumer BEFORE purchase. None of us should be SURPRISED as to what we are paying for and how much we are paying after the fact.

Title: Eric Doerfler
Comment: I strongly support regs that would make shopping for air fares easier!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Consumers are entitled to know all fees involved in buying an airline ticket.  
All other industries show fees up front before a product is bought. 
Would you buy a home without knowing all fees at closing?
Would you buy a car without knowing all taxes and fees for upgrades included?
Do you buy clothing without knowing the tax involved?
Do you buy products on line without knowing tax and shipping and handling?
NO to all of the above.  
We need to stand up and be heard.  We are entitled to ALL fees, taxes, etc. involved when purchasing an airline ticket!!!!!

Title: Margaret Adams
Comment: I would LOVE to see how much an airfare ticket would cost with applicable taxes and fees.  I hate having to guess-timate the taxes and luggage fees.  On more than one occasion, I have had to pull cash or use my emergency credit card to cover the cost of unexpected luggage fees.  Frankly, leaving Texas is a chore and it would be nice to get more information so that i can plan a little better.

Title: Robert Mann
Comment:
An example of why airline airfare-only comparisons have become meaningless for both booking and quarterly financial reporting purposes:

http://www.hopper.com/flights/tools/feecalc/index.html?origin=JFK&destination=LAX&bags=1&fees=carry_on&fees=you_choose&fees=big#.U4ywv3JdVS8

[page print image attached as pdf]

As an air travel consumer, I endorse DOT's approach to the booking resolution (leveling the playing field across all distribution channels), and as an airline industry analyst I would like to see complete, transparent and consistent reporting of fees mandated in DOT quarterly financial reporting.

Title: Mark Dion
Comment: Customers should have all of the information available to make decisions.  Individuals and businesses have to make decisions about budgets when preparing for travel, whether for a family vacation or an international business conference.  When carriers bury the fees, taxes, amenities, not to mention food or beverage fees, it causes hardships for travellers.  Infrequent travellers are especially subject to problems.  It is impossible for the average consumer to know about local, regional, or federal, taxes and fees.  The airlines pass those on to the consumer, and we should know we are being charged and taxed, and how much.  All transactions should be itemized and explained, we need to know which items are under the airlines' control and which fees are not. When I comarison shop for items online I have to include shipping handling and tax charges, the airlines should be held to similar standards.

Title: Mark
Comment:
I fully agree with the proposed rule and think it way past time that the DoT has finally started to support the rights of the tax payers that have been continually misled by airline corporations about pricing over the last decade. The most important fact is that the information required should be easily and readily available for a consumer and not buried in some website requiring multiple clicks to unearth it. 
Which is what exactly the airlines will do if they are allowed to get away with with spurious arguments and general obfuscation about why they don't want the rule or how it will harm the consumer. They simply don't want the rule because passengers will finally know upfront what the total product costs and will finally be able to compare prices between airlines easily.  There is absolutely no reason that this is not achievable given the advances in software over the last 5 years.

Title: Lance Smith
Comment: I am in favor of this change. Government imposed fees on airfares is extreme and it isn't the fault of the airlines that these fees are being imposed. Allowing the airlines to advertise their actual prices brings more visibility to the portion of the ticket being charged in government regulated fees. If these fees are appropriate/fair, there should be no reason that the government should have a problem with it. Consumers will find out what the total charge for a ticket is prior to actually purchasing the ticket.

Title: Ruth McDiarmid
Comment: Thank you for proposing this very valuable set of rules. I am a retired person who makes about 6-7 personal round trips a year, about 1/3 foreign. I search carefully to find the best fare -- a combination of price and length of flight. Because of all the ancillary charges the airlines now apply, it is almost impossible to find what the actual fare will be. I strongly hope the transparency of airline ancillary fees rule is implemented.

Title: Christine McIsaac
Comment:
I strongly support airlines having to show/advertise the full fare cost of an airplane ticket.  

Consumers should not be surprised by fees and taxes, after seeing a smaller "fare" price.  That is a deceptive practice.  A fare price is not the cost to fly.  We are all aware that after 9/11, consumers have to pay a security fee.  Further, there is not a set amount that a consumer could easily add to the cost to determine the full fare price.  This was an argument the airlines used- that a restaurant may only advertise that the meal costs $9.99.  However, consumers know the sales tax amount.  And not may flights can be had for $9.99.  Consumers do not know all the additional fees of an airline ticket.  We do not know what the airlines intend to charge this week for baggage.  We do not know if there are special fees for the airport.  Consumers should be able to make decisions on the full fare.  Airlines have the option to break out the fare during a purchase so consumers are better informed of the actual costs to fly.  However, I do not see where airlines ever show the cost of baggage.  That usually entails a person scouring their website for the fee.  And really, how many people fly without a bag these days?  Not many.  Please do not allow airlines to try to confuse consumers with a potential price.  

Please continue the practice of requiring airlines to advertise the full fare cost.  It is most fare to consumers.  And that is who the government should be looking out for.  Thank you for your consideration.  Have a good day.

Title: Jack Spiers
Comment: I wish to strongly urge adoption of the proposed Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues regulation.  Without this regulation it is nearly impossible for consumers to know what the final cost of a ticket will be when searching for fees, and encourages deceptive advertising practices by the airlines.  Full fare ticket advertising revealing all taxes and fees should be mandatory at all points of sale.  It is time for full transparency in air fare advertising and an end to the shell games and lax customer service standards of the airlines.

Title: Paul Anderson
Comment: I am supporting the proposed legislation. The current pricing used by many US airlines is, because of the hidden nature of ancillary fees for common and previously free services, anti competitive in that it makes comparison shopping extremely difficult at best and impossible at worst. All airlines should be require to post any additional pricing for common services not included in the base fare (baggage, carry ons, entertainment, food/beverage, early boarding, etc.) prominently and in close proximity to the base fares on their web pages and in advertising.

Title: John O'Connell
Comment:
As a frequent domestic and international traveler, I strongly support the proposed rule.  While I am usually able to determine the total cost of my flights, it often takes much searching and careful examination of obscure documents to insure that unexpected charges will not appear on my credit card bills.  This wastes my valuable time and causes considerable stress when I am making family reservations. In particular it will be very valuable to be able to compare among air lines the total fares with the same amenities of baggage, meals, and preassigned seats.

I could express my frustration with airlines that use only words and no actions associated with customer service.  However, I will merely say I am pleased that my government is taking this initiative and hope that it will continue to keep customers as the highest priority.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I love how airfares now (mostly) show the full fare. Please don't let airline take this away.

Title: Melissa Yorks
Comment:
As a customer in a store or online I know exactly how much something will cost from the beginning and do not find out after I've bought it how much it will cost.  Airlines should not be able to say your ticket will cost only $150 and then after you buy it say oh by the way it will cost you $30 more in taxes and fees, $50 to check a bag, $25 to bring a bag on board, $ 20 if you wish to reserve a seat and we no longer provide food, even on cross-country flights.  When I'm comparing costs 
I need to know what the costs really are.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I consider myself to be a fairly intelligent person with a good eye for detail and fine print.  However, it still feels like a crap shoot when it comes time to buy a plane ticket.  It's like walking into a car dealership and sitting down with the sales manager wondering if you can get out with a price that's close to what you thought you agreed to when you sat down in the first place.  I HATE the thought of adding regulations to business but now that I hear that airlines want to do away with reporting taxes and fees up front, I say bring it on.  There should be transparency in the purchase.  I don't agree that a checked bag should be included with every ticket, but I do think that a carry-on or two should be allowed to allow for everyone who is going to hand carry their laptop or an overnight bag or a diaper bag with them.  If folks want or need to check baggage, so be it--but price it clearly and fairly with decent weight restrictions, etc.  

If they want to charge for snacks or blankets or movies, that's fine too.  Just be straight up about it. Seat assignments costing extra?  I think that's a rip-off and a time waster, but again, clear and up front and it's fine.  Just let me make a knowledgeable choice about it.   Whether it's rumor or reality, charging for things like using the restroom is a flat-out no in my mind. What next? Insert a quarter to get your oxygen mask to drop down in an emergency?  

Last, in terms of agents and search engines, I agree that it should be transparent about which carriers a company represents.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: ALL FEES AND FARES SHOULD BE ADVERTISED TO THE CONSUMER, YOU CANNOT COMPARE A 9.99 MEAL WHICH I WOULD ONLY PAY 5-10% SALES TAX ON TO AIR FARE. AIR FARE IS MUCH MORE COMPLEX WITH ADDITIONAL FEES, TAXES, AND THE BASE FARE. THIS DRIVES UP THE COST FROM AN ADVERTISED 59.99 TO ALMOST 300.00 DOLLARS.

Title: Meili Price
Comment: Advertising tickets without including the taxes is misleading to the consumers. Airplane tickets will often include significant tax add ons, and as a consumer I want to see that price included in advertising. This saves me time when comparing between airlines and avoids nasty surprises during check out or at the airport. Airlines who support having the best customer service should opt to include taxes in the advertised price. If they really care about keeping our business, let them be honest and upfront. That's how you keep customers for life.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please ensure all taxes and fees are included in the price, that has the be the bare minimum. Seat assigbment and carry on luggage should be assumed in the price as well. Who travels without luggage?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please stop the airlines from hiding the hidden fees and taxes. treat it as an ala carte menu so folks can see what they are ordering UP FRONT. Do not let the airlines push back with the flimsy excuse of airfare vs. taxes. It is all money out of my pocket--it's not as though I can go only 1/2 way to my destination!

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Offer to show the fare as a pie chart where each segment is broken down by fare, fee, and tax.  Much like a layout of how investment funds are show.

The public moans over ancillary fees but showing the tax rate may spark a better debate on how their tax dollars are benefitting aviation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Transparency about what we are being charged and why should be the basics of our costs. I feel like I am held hostage to airlines and it makes traveling an even bigger pain. It also makes it hard to reconnect when prices are constantly rising without any definitive reason.

Title: Frank Thornburgh
Comment:
All airline price quotes must include a standard list of fees and taxes of all kinds.
In my opinion all airline ticket prices should be based on the person's weight plus their bags weight on a scale at the ticket counter.

Title: Carole Kerr
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0056

I feel strongly that consumers should know up front what all charges for an airline ticket will be.  No hidden charges!  I think we need the Transparency of Airline Fees and other Consumer Protection Issues desperately.  The airlines are not being fair with their nickel-and -diming.

Title: Christina
Comment: I'm tired of going back and forth to derermine the actual price of flights. I don't understand why airlines feel better customer service is tied to showcasing the lowest possible price, even if it's false. Good customer service begins with clear information, smooth interactions (not going back and forth to learn pricing) and trustworthy companies.

Title: Marc Hurwitz
Comment:
Many products are allowed to state their price separate from taxes, and even have additional fees separate from the base price (e.g., cars). There are pros and cons to this:

Pros: shows the true cost allocated to different sources; informs consumers

Cons: reduces the ability of the free market to do its job, using price and features as a mechanism for choice

One has to balance the pros and cons in each and every case. For example, when you go to a restaurant you know that taxes and extra fees (tips, for example) are standard. Therefore, it is possible to compare prices and you end up getting the best of both, i.e., transparency and a free market.

When an industry purposefully complicates billing to disrupt the free market, that tears at the fabric of our economy. Imagine, for example, walking into a grocery store and each product had a price. However, when you go the checkout a 'shipping' fee was added to your box of cereal (and it is different for each cereal), and a container fee, and a cart fee, and a markup for the wholesaler fee, and… you get the picture. The point of separating items is to clarify the situation, not obfuscate it. If this bill is allowed through, it sends a clear message to other industries that they are not allowed to weaken an important aspect of our market. 

The argument used by airline associations, i.e., that others do the same, is valid. But the slippery slope only really starts to function when you actually accept it and apply the unusual case to the usual. Better to stop it here, and look at other places (such as telecom) that also egregiously work to harm consumers.

I realize I'm not an American. But being from Canada, many of the flights I take are across the border and your pricing policies have a dramatic effect on what I see, and how I purchase.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I would like to see the base price then the taxes state, local and national.
I would like to see exactly what the airline charges for the seat
baggage, carry on luggage, food, any extra fees.  The airline are hitting the consumer with so many extra fees--that air travel is crazy.

Title: Steven Lembark
Comment:
I travel frequently enough  to be Platinum on American. I firmly believe that fare advertising should describe the final price paid for any ticket. I realize that variations on fees between customers will make any number approximate, but the basic numbers will be available. The ideal solution would require airline ticket price, total taxes and fixed fees, and any additional luggage, carry-on, or seat selection fees be shown in same-size font along with any total suggested by the airline - if airlines believe that showing the bases fare is more accurate fine, but show the rest with a total.

One option might be regulating on-line and print media differently. It is much easier to show breakdowns in HTML content than on a margin add in the local paper.

Title: Michael Tamburrino
Comment: I believe thebottom line cost of a ticket should be displayed. The airlines can still display the taxes and fees to make their point by added them to the ticket price displayed.

Title: Ellen Walford
Comment: The advertised price should include fare, taxes and any additional fees for carry ons and 1 piece of checked luggage. The fact that they don't is really a misrepresentation of the cost of the travel.

Title: Charles Burton
Comment:
As a frequent air traveler, I am ABSOLUTELY IN ACCORD with the idea of including all the fees, taxes, etc., in any quoted or advertised airfare prices.  The "bait and switch" tactics the airlines are presently using are dishonest and lack integrity. 

If you want to help consumers, PLEASE make sure that all advertised and quoted prices are standardized to include things such as a carry-on bag, snacks, checked baggage, etc.  

And if an airline wants to advertise or quote a rate withOUT those things, they need to be forced to put the difference in large print, prominently displayed as a special "Discounted Economy No-Frills" rate, so consumers can choose wisely.

Title: Francisco Navarro
Comment: I am supporting the idea of knowing ALL the fees and what I paid for so I can make a better consumer decision. In order of free market to function we need transparency in the contract that we sign with the air lines of responsibilities and duties.

Title: George Johnson
Comment: I strongly support transparency of information regarding airline tickets.

Title: James Wood
Comment: The total cost (fees and taxes) should be upfront and be part of the advertised price.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: People want to know how much an airline ticket costs, and what it includes and doesn't include BEFORE we buy a ticket.  No one wants to find out a seat or a carry on bag costs extra after purchasing.  That's ridiculous.

Title: Steven Hutchison
Comment:
It seems the airline industry has embraced the notion that stripping down the advertised airfare to the base fare without all those messy local, state and federal taxes, not to mention all the optional costs of taking along luggage or ensuring a specific seat or a carry-on bag helps consumers better know the cost of a ticket.  What are they smoking? 

The DOT must require fares to be universally defined [e.g. guaranteed seat [not a specific seat], one carry-on bag of specific size and weight, two pieces of luggage of specific size and weight] and to include all local, state and federal taxes. That way, consumers can compare prices in the marketplace without having to sleuth the details of fees, taxes, and specific provisions of the basic fare to make a reasoned comparison. If airlines are worried that consumers won't know the level of taxation in the ticket if that amount is added to the basic fare, they can, and I believe several do, itemize the tax amounts on the ticket and/or boarding pass [this is all computer-based and simple to do]. Luring consumers through the turn-style with a luridly low basic fare, and then smacking them with a torrent of additional taxes and fees once committed, is plain deception.

Let the market be free and competitive, but let the market be fair, and let the consumers compare prices that are "apples to apples" without the 'gotchas' of unmentioned fees and taxes.

Title: Alison Brown
Comment:
I consider the expansion of regulations regarding ticket agents' disclosure to meta-search websites a good thing for consumers.  
The disclosure of code-sharing would be good because a lot of confusion arises for consumers when one thinks one is flying one airline and they have no records about it, because one is actually on a code share with another.  Indeed the seamless flow of information between airlines participating in code-shares leaves a great deal to be desired in the 21st century.
Information about the contractual relations of a ticket sales entity with specific carriers should indeed be disclosed so that the consumer is alerted to the possibility that other carriers could also be explored for more favorable conditions.
The possibility to hold an offered fare for 24 hours would be beneficial to consumers (to allow for further research) and not unreasonably penalize ticket agents or airlines.
It is absolutely necessary that ALL costs associated with a trip be disclosed when a ticket is offered for sale.  The airlines protest that taxes and fees vary widely around the globe and hence should not be disclosed.  But to have the consumer bear the burden of discovering the differences, which the airlines know in advance, is an unreasonable demand on their part. This information is standard in the EU and will cause the airlines no trouble to provide in the USA.
I would greet the codification of a standard flight package including airfare, taxes, fees, seat, carry-on baggage, hygiene amenities (i.e. - WCs).  That should be the basic minimum in every package sold. Detailed information about checked luggage, meals, entertainment, arrangements for children and infants as well as handicapped individuals (which according to ADA, must be without extra charge) should be available at the point of sale, so that a comfortable trip can be tailored to the needs of each traveler without financial surprises.

Title: John Fechter
Comment: Yes. I strongly support the DOT proposed rule on Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees.  The proposed rule would give consumers the information needed to make apples to apples comparisons between vendors. The airlines put consumers into an impossible situation to wait until check-in to inform consumers of the total, bottom line cost they must pay. By waiting until check-in to announce total costs, the airlines make it extraordinarily difficult for consumers to back out and seek alternative vendors, because the ticket-purchaser has already made logistical commitments to present themselves at the counter, their cars are already parked in parking lots or taxi/shuttle expenses already paid and those vehicles long gone. Please proceed to make the airlines publish total fees and a menu of additional fees that will be presented upon check-in.

Title: Stefanie Cragun
Comment: When I am traveling, I have a budget. I want to know exactly what I will be paying. Adding on fees and taxes after the fact causes me to go over budget. I want to compare and get the best price. I need to know what fees I will be paying. An airline with a higher fare but lower fees might be a better choice. I can't make that determination unless the airlines spell out all fares and fees. That is transparency. I have a right to know what I am buying and what that includes.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The airfare should list everything that is included and what is optional. The passenger should be told what each option costs whenever an option is offered to them . . . whether prior to or in-flight.

Title: Matthew Kirkland
Comment: Displaying all fees as part of the ticket price levels the playing field and makes it much easier for consumers to compare apples to apples.  I strongly support this rules change.

Title: James Strader
Comment: I trust that DOT will in fact pursue regulating airfares demanding that the airlines provide full disclosure about what is included in the cost of an airline ticket (taxes, seat assignment, meals, baggage, etc). The airlines are "hiding" fees as well as excessively charging customers for services that should be included in the airfare. Moreover, airlines, especially "low fare" airlines are not being transparent in what customers are and are not receiving when purchasing a ticket online.   It is time to return to pre-2012 guidelines for transparent airline ticket costs.

Title: J. L.
Comment: Airlines should absolutely be required to display taxes and fees with their fares.  The comparison with restaurant prices is ridiculous, because airfares are much much higher priced.  Also, people who live in a certain area will know what the taxes are in their area, but air travel necessarily involves _going to a different place_ where the taxes and fees are likely to be different.

Title: Jack
Comment:
The public good should take precedence over the airline's privilege to operate their business as they want. To this effect I feel that the purchasing public must be provided the total cost for their prospective itinerary. Said total cost should be broken down clearly and in one location and not spread out over a number of pages. Preference should be given to have said costs appear on the first page of the web site of the airline with which the customer is transacting.

This exhibition of detailed costs should be required of all information and ticketing providers. The airlines etc. are free to determine how to book those costs incurred for including this process. The costs could easily be considered good will.

The process of purchasing an air ticket should be developed with a view of a client ranging from an average 18 yo, public school educated individual to a senior citizen. In other words, idiot proof and not plagued by intentional or unintentional gaffes frustrating and discouraging the consumer.

The airlines should be required to make their profits from the main reason for their existence and that is transporting the public from point A to point B. They should not be allowed to profit from scumbag capitalism.

Title: Nancy D'Arcy
Comment: Airlines should be required to continue to show ticket prices with all taxes and fees included. In addition, any fees for luggage should be stated along with the ticket price. All people, with the exception of airline and airport employees, should have to go through the same screening lines. It is unfair that people can pay an extra fee for prescreening and then be allowed to go through special abbreviated lines.

Title: Sallie Sharp
Comment: I support transparency for ancillary fees.  Consumers have the right to know what something costs before purchasing it.

Title: Judith Lawlee
Comment:
I am so annoyed by all these fees tacked on to airfares that I have limited the # of trips I take per year to 3. I can't tell you how many times I have checked out airfares on websites,and with the taxes, fees, fuel and state taxes the fare is often over 25. - 30% of the fare!
So I just stay more local and do trips in New England more often.
Would travel more if all these fees which increased when the economy began to have trouble, were more reasonable. They were supposed to be temporary increases - instead they are excessive and continue to grow, so that the traveling public has to absorb these unnecessary increases, and greed of the airline industry - just look at there profits and where they Re coming from, just disgusting. Where is the U S Consumer Affairs support on this one?

Title: Arthur Albrecht
Comment: Adopt all of the proposed regulations as soon as possible. The air travel industry should provide all users of the system with complete price information at all stages of a ticket purchase, and they should provide as much information as may be useful to their customers about their operations.

Title: Bettina Barbier
Comment:
Airlines should have to state the full price of the ticket including ALL fees and taxes in their ads and website, and on the pricing websites. If they want to they can break it down right there in that display space, thus providing the "transparency" they claim to value, but I want to see the whole price while making my buying decisions. 

By attempting to divorce the base ticket price from fees and taxes, they are removing transparency from the process. Such fractured and incomplete pricing will just confuse the issue and break the functionality of all the sites that find the lowest prices. 

Additionally, I am told that repeatedly searching for a fare for a particular route can increase the price of the ticket - that there are algorithms that detect more popular searches and jack up the prices of those tickets. So not having all the information at hand the first time around can cost consumers more. 

It seems clear that the airlines would like to muddy the waters and make finding a ticket a longer, more difficult, and more expensive process. By showing lower than realistic pricing they create expectations and desires in their potential customer base, and create an artificial psychological "need" to buy a particular product. This "need" would tend to influence the buyer to be less deterred by additional fees, taxes, and price increases, because they now have a desire that wants to be gratified, providing an incentive to gloss over the additional cost in the final decision process. What I see here is a somewhat underhanded anti-consumer move that would make things harder for everyone.

Title: Gayle Harlow
Comment:
I feel the airlines have been given carte blanc to do whatever they want, and what they want is ridiculous.  Flying on an airplane  has always necessitated a suit case.  To charge extra for that makes no sense.  Now they are talking about carryons and aisle seats - there is no end in sight.  Will we next have to pay to use the restroom?  Please put an end to this madness.  If they need to charge for handling our baggage, have it included  in the ticket price.  A carryon should not cost extra, as now everyone wants to bring one to try and save money.  Will I have to pay for my purse next?   What about a family with small children who needs to bring all the baby "stuff".? 
Thanks for you attention, and please help!
Gayle Harlow

Title: Di Quynn Reno
Comment: I agree that all airlines fees need to be stated when receiving a quote before purchasing tickets. Transparency please! In the true sense of the word.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: "Transparency in Airfares Act" - if an act has that name, it ought to provide easy and transparent view into competitors prices, including all possible fees, so consumers can make good decisions

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Please do not back down on the airlines! The have very non-transparent billing and they have lousy customer service. Fairs shown should be for the cost of the seat, one carry on bag plus small purse or computer, 2 pieces of checked luggage and any other fees as well as taxes for a one way ticket (not a return ticket costs split in 2) or a return ticket (again, not just the one way part of a return ticket). It should also make the time frame that the ticket is available for clear, any advance purchase necessary, and how many tickets are available at this price (they can't have one ticket at a really low advertised price but no one else can get it at that price.)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I support the DOT in making and maintaining transparency in the cost of airline tickets. It is very important to consumers to clearly be able to compare prices with other airlines before purchasing a ticket. To not continue including all taxes in the cost of an airline ticket would be unfair and goes against the progress DOT has made in keeping fees transparent. People are still struggling to make ends meet economically and this would be important for those who are keeping close eyes on their checking accounts, while wanting to maintain their ability to fly.

Title: Harlan Kanoa Sheppard
Comment:
Dear DOT,

I wholeheartedly support the spirit of the proposed rule. The aviation industry indulges in wanton abuses of consumers wherever possible.

This has been evidence to me by the fuel surcharges and continual desire to itemize every remaining aspect of a commercial airline flight into a line item purchase. I do not mind paying for a flight, but I do detest the manner in which this occurs.

I welcome a sense of continuity and consistency, which the proposed rule appears to provide. If I had a fair and objective notion of how often an air carrier lost luggage or overbooked flights, I would likely travel by air more. I say this because I would be able to prepare in a fair and reasonable manner. Perhaps the dispatch of my luggage by means of USPS if I found that an air carrier was reliable in all aspects save their luggage handling.

As it stands, air travel is a chore. An uncomfortable means to an end. I welcome and applaud the efforts by the Department of Transportation.

Sincerely,
Harlan Kanoa N Sheppard

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Require airlines to advertise honestly, showing the actual cost of a ticket including taxes and fees. List the Congresspeople and Senators who vote for the proposed bill.

Title: R. Sharma
Comment:
As a citizen, I am in favor of this rule. It doesn't have to be expensive as some have suggested. The airlines already have these broken out per ticket, since they are charging these costs per ticket and so can show them easily to consumers. 

Good information is essential in free markets. Airlines prefer not to have to show these items because then they will have to compete on price. Today they can hide all these costs and spring it on the consumer when they are at the airport and have chance to an alternative flight.

These rules should over time help to reduce fare for consumers and I would argue that in a free market that is what should happen. Congress should support free market policies and the need for transparency and better information for consumers and citizens.

Title: Cynthia Robbins
Comment: I think airline fares should be completely transparent.  I want to know what I'm paying for.  When you have a dinner out, the price does not include tax and tip and yet all consumers know that there will be tax and tip, both of which can be figured out ahead of time if you know what you are going to eat.  Airlines used to charge for checked bags, now they charge for carry-on too.  So that should be part of the ticket.  Anything that is a standard charge should be part of the ticket price.

Title: Dennis Hesselbarth
Comment: Free markets are only free when consumers have the facts they need to make their free decisions. To try to obscure costs so it's difficult to compare fares is anticompetitive. The proposed transparency rules should be adopted.

Title: Michael  Middlebrooks
Comment:
When I fill up my car with gasoline, I realize there are federal and state taxes included in the price of each gallon.  In fact, there is a little sticker on the pump that tells me so.  And, although the tax rate may vary from state to state, I can effectively compare the final cost by looking at the advertised or displayed price.  (The additional .9 cent add-on still annoys me, though.)

If someone wants to show how much of the total cost of an airfare is due to taxes, it could be accomplished by listing the fare as "$289, including $63 in taxes and fees".  That accomplishes the obvious aim of the Republican bill of raising taxpayer ire, while still allowing the consumer to compare prices without the use of a calculator and a law library. 

Excluding taxes from the listed airfare is anything but transparent and would further erode consumers' ability to make informed purchase decisions.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: DOT-OST-2014-0056 I support this regulation, as it will make comparison shopping better, inherently urging airlines to provide a better product. I think that the requirement for smaller airlines to provide some of the details required, may be overkill, but defer to USG and airlines to figure that out. The airline industry has evidently argued that no other industry is thus regulated, but I submit that no other industry receives the kinds of subsidies that American flag carriers do via the Fly America Act. If we were willing to repeal that, I'd be a bit more willing to buy into their argument; however, as stands they are a heavily subsidized industry that is providing a less and less reliable product without full disclosure to consumers. This rule will greatly help in at least the last part - full disclosure, and hopefully encourage better products. Flying consistently overseas, if it were not for Fly America, I'd never fly another U.S. flag carrier - their service is awful relative to other airlines. Separately, if you added cost for meals to the required costs, knowing that it is not necessarily set, but at least including that it is not served, despite regulations requiring them after four hours flight time.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Make a standard ticket, or even a set of standard tickets that includes all airline and government fees and extra charges but taxes shouldn't have to be included in the advertised price as general taxes apply to all good and services, not just the airline industry.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Keep the regulations as they are.  I want the advertised price to include all taxes and fees.

Title: Jill
Comment:
I support the department's new airfare rules.  As many other have commented, consumers should have a clear and complete price before having to commit.  Those airlines that don't want to do that can throw themselves upon the mercy of the marketplace as more people buy with those they can trust.  It should be common sense to the businesses that customers don't like surprises and surprises lead to grumbling and unhappy customers and eventual loss of customers.
Please pass these rules and if other industries who are hiding fees on consumers complain, then make fair rules for them too.
Since the changes in advertising fares went into effect a few years ago, the airfare buying has improved greatly on basic fares.  This should not be allowed to be changed.  Customers should also have the expectation of being able to bring a suitcase with them.  All fares should be laid out so they are understandable and can be compared apples to apples.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This rule proposing FULL DISCLOSURE by airlines is and absolute necessity if customers are to be able to have HONEST FARES quoted to them.  All airlines should be required to comply, not just larger ones.  

Having done in-depth studies of the airline industries at various times in my career, I find that the cost/benefit analysis by DOT is absolutely sloppy and deplorable.  Any recent MBA/Statistics graduate would be able to provide greater information on the financial benefits to flyers than all of the N/As that appear.  It would be in the billions of dollars.  Also in the summary table of Monetized Costs and Monetized Benefits it would be very helpful if the dollar quantities would be given.  Is this millions?  Hundreds of millions?  Billions?  Every properly prepared income statement and balance sheet that I've ever looked at tells me the number of $zeros I should be adding.

Having worked with OMB for a number of years, all I can add is that allowing this type of sloppiness to be published tells me that the quality of gov't analysts has seriously deteriorated for this to get by both DOT and OMB.

Title: Richard Benator
Comment:
I favor that an  airline ticket should include

a.  an assigned seat for each ticket, though I am OK with premium seating excluded.  
b. one piece of check luggage
c. two carry on - one for beneath your seat and one above.
d. knowledge of taxes and fees with the total price before purchase

Recently I was disappointed to find that getting a regular coach non premium assigned seat was going to cost me extra.  I was stunned as I was traveling with someone and just getting the two of us, a seat side by side, was going to cost me extra.

Time and time again I find that the airline gate agent will request that passengers relinquish their overhead carryon bag because they do not have enough space in the overhead bins. Having so many individuals go through TSA screening with these carryon bags slows the entire process down.  It would be better to allow at least one bag to be included with your ticket at no extra charge, this would, in all likely hood, reduce this request by the gate agent.  Having to carry this bag to the plane and then relinquish it, is a big waste of time and energy for all.  

At a minimum my ticket should include an assigned seat and one piece of checked luggage.  

Then I venture that carryon luggage would not stress the system so much

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This is a great idea and can only help consumers.  I honestly wish all prices for everything would be listed with an "out of the door price".

Title: Patricia Hunter
Comment: I think that taxes and fees should continue to be included in the prices that airlines advertise.  It makes it easier to budget the cost of the flight before committing to a particular airline and date of travel.  I would like to see a standard definition of a seat. It would make it easier to compare airlines and would limit an airlines ability to include fees after a ticket has already been purchased.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Airlines should have to:

1) Provide an itemized cost to consumers so they can see what they're paying for in terms of fees and taxes.  These include: fuel, admin costs, taxes, individual prices for each carry on and checked bag, meals and drinks on board, first to board, etc.

2) Customers should be assigned a total weight allowance including all baggage and their own weight (ex. 250 pounds total) with perhaps more allowance for men than women based on gender differences.  Prices for weight would go up incrementally per pound over the allowance. With the high cost of fuel there is no reason why thinner customers should have to foot the bill for those who are heavier.  Aside from fairness in pricing, this regulation could give everyone a financial incentive to maintain a healthy, less costly weight.

Title: Joe Fischer
Comment: I rather like having all taxes and fees included in the price of the ticket.  That way I don't have to remember how much more it costs me to fly into and out of different airports.  It is bad enough that i have to read the fine print for baggage fees and carry a credit card if i want a soda... they keep finding ways to wring out profits on the backs of their passengers and we need some rules in place that protect us the consumers.

Title: Marion Velenzuela
Comment: I would like to know the full price of a ticket so as to save time spent on searching for airfares within my budget.

Title: Thomas Kelly
Comment: Since most airlines have demonstrated that they intend to deceive consumers by misrepresenting the actual cost of flying, I support the proposal to codify what is included in a ticket and clearly indicate exactly the real total cost to fly.

Title: Lee Madison
Comment: Airline ticket pricing should be standardized so that the advertised price can be compared between airlines. The price should include all charges, fees, and taxes so customers can make informed choices when buying tickets.

Title: Bill Hough
Comment: I support any rules that make it easier to calculate the total cost of a flight which is what the customer is actually interested in. A few years ago, airlines started low-balling the fare but tacking on fees for basically everything. This is dishonest advertising and should be stopped. Failing that, full disclosure should be regulated by DOT. And the customer should not have to plow through pages of incomprehensible legaleze on a web site to know what the total cost will be. Airlines do this because it makes it difficult to comparison-shop.

Title: Elna Hunter
Comment:
Dear Sir,

This comment pertains only to the issue of "transparent" airline ticket prices.  

I fully support your proposed rule changes!  The current airline practice of hiding fees from the consumer amounts to bait and switch.  It is so frustrating to purchase an airline ticket that I do everything I can to avoid flying, even if the alternatives cost more.  Spending a couple of hours on the computer trying to find out what a ticket costs, and ending up in tears with frustration, is not worth it.  My husband and I choose the train or our car.  Forget flying!  

Please adopt these rule changes.  They would be a wonderful improvement from the current shyster-techniques allowed.

Title: Ann Gipalo
Comment: Airfares should include ALL fees and taxes and assume each person will have at LEAST 1 small carryon bag - either a purse or a briefcase. For total flight lengths OVER 2 hours I think one CHECKED bag per person should also be assumed and included in the price. Additional carryon or checked bags OVER the ones described above can be charged for by weight/size.

Title: Maarten Albarda
Comment: I am a CT based very frequent global traveler, and have been so for the last 23 years. I think all the recommendations in this document make an awful lot of sense and I wholeheartedly support their adoption and implementation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that airfares should be clear and inclusive of what is included--a reserved seat assignment, a carry on bag for no extra fee, at least one free piece of checked luggage included.  All taxes, extra fees for extra luggage, overweight luggage fees, meals, and change fees must also be stated clearly.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It is completely unfair for airlines to advertise fares that we will never see. I fully support the new regulations.  We should know exactly what we are paying for; their argument that restaurants and other industries can do it is invalid because the taxes do not change which makes it easier to calculate your bill and the tip is based on the consumer's choice (tip is not mandatory like fees and taxes).  Advertise exactly what we will be charged. And CUT LUGGAGE FEES!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The advertised or stated costs should include all costs to include tax fees baggage.

Title: John Buchan
Comment: Advertised airfares should include all fees. The excise tax, PFCs, etc. have to be paid, no matter the actual fare basis is. The airlines are just trying to take advantage of passengers general lack of knowledge of airfares and fees. Remember, very few Americans use travel agents, so they have no professional guidance. Furthermore, airlines advertised fares should include anything that is mandatory to fly. For example, seat reservation fees. Reserving any open seat, should not cost extra. Charging for carry-on bags is another nuisance fee and is purely a revenue generation fee. Most travellers carry a minimum of a handbag and/or a computer bag. I hope the Federal Government realizes that the faith of Americans in our government, to make fair regulations, is also at stake here.

Title: Mario Zdybel
Comment:
I wholeheartedly support this legislation. Of course all "scheduled" air carriers/air taxi operators should have to report delays. Further, regional carriers that supply regional flying to legacy carriers under a codeshare agreement should have this information reported or posted two fold. For example, SkyWest Airlines overall ontime dependability will be one measure, however, when they operate flights for UA, there should be a breakdown of flights operated by legacy UA as well as their regional partners, therefore the SkyWest data would further be used to solidify UA's overall ontime dependability. I feel that is fair since regional carriers' contracts have stipulations for ontime dependability, and if necessary, the legacy carrier may exert pressure or make changes within its power to mitigate these delays. For example, if SkyWest has a heavy departure bank at ORD where they may have 20 aircraft departing within a 20 min period, UA may decide to split that bank up, thus relieving the pressure on their own ramp/passenger service employees, the ramp tower as well as air traffic control.

As far as tickets are concerned, I have always believed that additional fees should be disclosed at time of booking. LCCs as well as their European counterparts, which I understand the DOT doesn't exert any oversight to, have been charging for crazy necessities such as boarding passes, if you don't print these at home yourself. If you have a ticket to fly, you should never have to pay for a boarding pass, as you're required to have one to proceed through the TSA checkpoint. I believe the DOT should, if in their power, also guarantee some necessities that should not be charged fees for. Definitely no fees for boarding passes. When examining ancillary fees, I know for a fact, a carrier will charge a change fee, for example, of $50 for a rebooking/ticket exchange. On top of that fee, they will charge $10 more as a document issuance fee. That $10 fee is now intolerable. How can you charge a fee in order to pay another fee? If you're charging the $50 fee, there should only be that fee. Again, something that should be banned. All baggage, seat selection and meal information should be published on a summary page before a ticket purchase is finalized. If people don't read it, that's their fault, but at least it was fair game since the information was presented ahead of time. Finally, fare aggregator sites that may not encompass all available options, should indicate that. For example, if Travelocity doesn't offer Southwest Airlines or Jetblue fares, it should have a blanket statement that other carriers may exist who aren't sold through this channel. It's up to the traveling public if they would like to continue searching for options. Further, the checkout page that's shown before a ticket purchase is finalized should be standardized. Just like we went to standardized forms for and rules for mortgage closings, it may aid in providing the same level of opportunity to the consumer. You will probably have other comments that help you determine what should be included on such a page/form, but it would be a start to keeping them honest.

Title: Jim Estner
Comment:
Section 399.88 is working perfectly fine. In the DOT Notice, it notes that "the Enforcement Office has investigated a 
number of incidents where passengers complained that airlines or ticket agents would not honor tickets that had been paid for in full because the sellers of the air transportation erroneously let them book flights for less than the actual value".

What is "less than actual value"? What is the actual value and how is it determined and who determines it? How did the DOT determine this statement to be true? Furthermore, if the airlines can allow someone to book a flight, and then follow it up with a confirmation, why should they be then able to claim it was "less than the actual value" and cancel the ticket?

399.88 is perfectly reasonable as is. First, the airline should be careful (as any company or individual should) about what fares/offers it is posting and even if it is not careful in what it offers, it shouldn't send out a confirmation if it isn't truly confirming what is it offering. 399.88 gives customers sound and valid protections by 399.88 in its current form and further, the airline is protected in two stages as well given that 399.88 allows an airline to cancel after purchase (but before confirmation). Why weaken the consumer protections when the airlines already have two opportunities to avoid whatever issue this is. If airlines can claim "less than actual value", what good is any ticket purchased. Further, does a blog post or a message board that calls a sale fare a mistake or "below value" make it so? This is a very slippery slope.

I urge the DOT to keep 399.88 as is written. Airlines are earning record profits and mistakes seem few and far between. There is no urgent or compelling reason to attack consumer protections so that the airlines can be negligent in their business practice. As noted, the protections for both airline and consumer are already sound and reasonable. If the airline doesn't want to sell a certain ticket - they shouldn't sell it. And if an airline sells a ticket by mistake - they shouldn't confirm it. It is as simple as that.

Sincerely, 
Jim Estner

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I'm opposed to changes to handling of so called "mistake fares". Airfare pricing appears totally irrational to the average consumer. A flight from A-B-C and back will often cost half of what A-B costs. Prices are frequently advertised at low rates and then fees are added on to create the illusion of a deal. Additionally, when a customer makes a mistake (date off by a day) and notices it 25 hours later the airline gets to keep their money (all reasonably priced fares are non-refundable) and charge an extortionate change fee to correct it (hundreds of dollars, often more than the ticket is worth). Why should the airline get to force cancel the contract without penalty?, you speak of bad actors but the average airline is far closer to a bad actor in most transactions than the consumer.

Title: Jack Torrey
Comment:
With regards to the section regarding determining when someone is purchasing a 'mistake' fare and whether DOT should require them to be honored, how can DOT distinguish between just a low fare which is good for consumers and a 'mistake' fare without implicitly setting minimum prices for fares?  

Is DOT in the business of determining minimum prices for each and every route originating or terminating in the United States?  I do not believe that is within DOT's purview under any relevant legislation since deregulation of airfares several decades ago.  And since minimum fares on a route by route basis are not in DOT's purview, by what standard would DOT judge the difference between a low and a 'mistake' fare?  More importantly, how would a consumer be expected to know whether what air travel providers are voluntarily publishing as their prices are real or could be changed per the airlines' wishes?

The average consumer needs DOT's protection as currently provided by the requirements to publish a clear all-in price and to honor it.  No one makes an airline publish a 'mistake' fare.  If airlines get to pick and choose when to honor prices, or the DOT implicitly maintains minimum prices for them, it is the consumer that DOT is supposed to protect who loses.  The same consumer who relied on having purchased a low fare to make other travel arrangements that have non-refundable prices.  The same consumer who is slapped with huge change fees most of the time if they change their mind about having accepted a fare, with no opportunity to say "Oops, 'mistake' purchase!"

Title: Nic Guaqueta
Comment: Regarding the "mistake fares", please be advised that most of the time, even for advanced consumers, there is no way to know if it is indeed a mistake or a good sale. It is important to highlight, that some of those so called "mistake fares" occur because the fare structure is very complex, but that is a choice that each airline makes and they should be held accountable for their choice. For example airlines like Delta or United will have more mistakes, than Southwest which has a simpler fare structure. Finally, it is important to highlight that mistakes on fares can go both ways, not only to passengers advantage.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: In the issue of mistake fares. Mistakes go both way.  As a consumer, if I booked a wrong date, I'm stuck.  Airlines make billions in hidden surcharges such as fuel, bags, seat assignments, and early check-in to name a few.  DOT please protect consumers and not the airlines.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Southwest Airlines has a low fare calculator on their website which states a lowest fare for each day of the month between two destinations.  When you select which day you want to fly, another web page comes up with all the detailed flight information for the flights between those destinations like times, stops, cost, etc.  

The issue is many times you can't find the low fare from the low fare calculator in the detailed flight information as they are always higher which I believe is false advertising.  A SWA supervisor indicated that the low fare calculator is not updated in realtime and she could not tell me when or the frequency that it is updated.

This is a false advertising and a bait and switch tactic.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The longer I get to actually ponder the implications of this, this absolutely reeks of collusion and Antitrust. You can not possibly have a standard price for things and then claim when someone purchases the item below what you consider to be the standard price without some form of collusion on pricing and inherently inferentially ANTITRUST.

You can’t possibly say that XYZ route should cost a minimum of ABC and anyone who buys it below that figure “should have known” that this fare was a mistake without inherently participating in collusion to set minimum prices in a market. Free markets do not operate that way. Free markets are free for sellers to offer their product at an asking price and buyers are free to either accept or deny their offer. When a seller makes an offer that after a buyer purchases it they deem to have been too low, it is expressly against all good logic and valid legal interpretation to then allow that party to simply nullify their commitment because they have now deemed their initial offer to be in error.

That would be like someone listing a home for sale with a realtor. And then when a party purchased the home, showing up at closing claiming well I never meant to offer it for that price. I was mistaken. Or like an auto dealer publishing in the paper a unit for 10,000 and then when someone showed up cash in hand, the dealer then saying well we meant to say it was 12,000.

Incorrect, and yes people try this stuff all the time but the BUYER Is not responsible for the publishing of the offer, THE SELLER Is. All offers in terms of how much the fare costs are solely within the discretion and control of the SELLER. If the buyer accepts the seller’s offer, it’s simple contract. The Seller is obliged to follow through with the agreement.

There is absolutely no bad faith involved in this in any way whatsoever. No one has intentionally gone into the seller’s system and forced them to publish a low offer. No one has defrauded or deceived the seller of anything in order to get their products under false pretense. Airlines are free to force people to buy tickets with no refund and recourse and consumers are not permitted to seek the lowest fare. Absurd

This is the most repugnant nonsense I’ve seen in print in the past 10-15 years and we’ve been forced to live through a heck of a whole lot especially since 2008.

Title: Wayne Garcia
Comment: The airline industry used to have an all-in-one ticket price that enabled consumers to compare fares and make informed travel decisions.  The industry has changed, and the ticket price is now just one component of the total cost of air travel.  The industry has consolidated and is now dominated by three legacy airlines, who want to make it difficult for consumers to compare the total cost of air travel and make informed travel decisions.  Essentially, they want to sell tickets based on deception, a legalized bait-and-switch system, because it will inhibit competition.  Imagine how difficult it would be for consumers to compare air fares if they cannot determine the total cost without being forced to go through all of the steps necessary to purchase a ticket!  The proposed rule is sensible and fair.
