The industry trade association has not provided any valid argument or produced any evidence supporting its opposition to the rule, other than to engage in the 'scare' tactic of saying that it might increase costs.

Title: Ken Adams
Comment:
Airlines have published such an array of fares and have conducted such irrational pricing promotions that it has become completely impossible for a consumer to apply common sense in order to determine if a fare was intentional or a mistake. Currently, 11 legacy carriers offer a $3 fare from OSL to FLL. Is that a mistake? Is it a consorted industry wide effort to destroy an new competitor?
On another route to Europe most airlines offered a $186 fare. LX offered a fare of $1860. Was that a mistake? 
The point is that the logic and rationale that go into an airfare is incomprehensible to the average consumer. And, a consumer should not have to comprehend WHY an airline offered a certain fare. It unfairly shifts the burden from the corporation to the consumer to seek to understand what was mindset, intend and strategy by the airline. Airlines publish 1000+ of fares per day  with wildly variying fare rules to maximize their profitability. And that is perfectly okay. However, if that leads to complications, confusion and the publication of mistake fares, the airlines need to be held accountable for that, not the consumer. The airlines could just publish one fare for NYC-LHR, but they choose not to. Today, LX offers eighty (80) different coach class fares from NYC-LHR. Some business class fares are less than a coach class fare. Is that a mistake? It cannot be the consumers responsibility to ensure that the airline meant to publish that fare. 
Mistake fares, exceptionally low fares or just great fares MUST be honored by the airlines. Airlines should not be able to pick and choose which fare they will honor in the end. Airlines have the choice of simplifying their revenue management systems or increase their checks and balances to ensure only fares are published that the airlines intended to be published.

Regarding your clarification of "within, to or from the USA". It is very apparent to me that if I fly FRA-DFW-MEX, that I am flying TO the USA and then on to Mexico. That is evidenced by the simply fact that all US immigration, custom etc laws and rules apply to me. Mexico has no problem with travellers bringing in meat or fruit. Try telling the US Customs officer to not worry about the 10 oranges and 4 steaks since I am going to Mexico next. If the flight touches US soil, DOT rules should apply. Airlines should not get a free pass to skirt the law because of the amount of time a traveller spends in the USA. FAA rules apply to all flights into the USA, even if that plane leaves for another country afterwards. It is a slipperly slope when you try to carve out that certain itineraries do not apply to DOT protection because the passenger spends less than 24 hours in the USA. There is simply no logical basis for that argument, other than it allows airlines to skirt their responsibility.

Title: Deborah Freeman
Comment: I support this legislation.  Airline fees are totally out of control and consumers need to be protected from these confusing and misleading pricing mechanisms.  Please pass this proposal.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airline ticket prices should be required by law to include:  the round-trip price of the ticket, any and all baggage fees, and all taxes and airport fees.  There should never be an additional fee for using the restroom on an airplane.  After all, we are pretty much stuck with the available facilities when we board an aircraft.  The addition of baggage fees feels like highway roberry.   After all, are we expected to travel somewhere for a week with only what we can fit into our pockets?

Title: Helen Ross
Comment: I am appalled at the fees that airlines area charging these days. With mergers like U.S Air & American the monopoly is leaving consumers with huge losses. My husband & I paid $800 to fly from Miami to Nashville. We had to change our outbound flight due to illness & their change fee for one way was $200 per person. We lost $400 plus they wanted to charge the ticket difference. The government needs to regulate airline fees & protect consumers. This is unacceptable.

Title: Kenny Wood
Comment: Historically, airline fares included ALL services--baggage, meals, passenger's choice of seat, etc. Because the airlines have chosen to "unbundle" air fares (plus the assorted taxes, fuel fees, etc), it has become very difficult for passengers to discern in advance the exact total they will be paying for a seat often until they are into the actual booking process. And the airlines clearly seek to avoid "standardization" in displaying their fares. This makes airfare comparisons difficult and time-consuming. Standardization of current database technology should easily allow the public to make exact dollar-for-dollar comparisons for airfares between the various carriers. Any legislation that allows airlines to confuse (rather than CLARIFY and SIMPLIFY) airfares to the public is irresponsible. Legislation that promotes the free market and makes the 700-odd million annual U.S. airfare transactions transparent is the only responsible approach for legislation.

Title: Timothy Niblett
Comment: I support this rule change and I think that airlines should be required to include their fees and all other costs in the price of the ticket.

Title: RedTail Shark
Comment:
Re: mistaken fares.  The concept of consumers being responsible in any way for airline pricing, or being expected to adjudicate INTENT on behalf of the seller, is ridiculous and contrary to the principles of consumer protection in the US.  

Merchants are not entitled under consumer protection law to revisit their own published prices after products have been sold and to void the sale and repossess the product at some indeterminate time after sale.  Imagine what would happen if a store promoted iPads, sold them, then later claimed the sales were void because their own sticker price was now considered "too low" by the same management that originally set those prices, and the merchant then repossessed the items forcibly.  

This is exactly why consumer protection laws exist and the intent of the 14.CFR 399.88a regulation, to provide similar protection for consumers of air travel, is to be lauded.  It makes air travel more consistent with other forms of consumer protection. 

We, the consumers, are held to account for terms and conditions when buying tickets and we are not authorized to decide after purchase that the price was too high and to void the ticket, obtain a full refund, and then begin again.  We recognize and accept these conditions and the carriers do too, by implementing differential pricing for changeable tickets.  If such changeability has market value, and the carriers expect their conditions to be respected and enforced, then why should consumers be treated differently?

Also, the idea of any free speech activity being measured or taken into account as determinative of "good" or "bad" faith is despicable.  It violates the principles behind the First Amendment and should have no place in agency rulemaking in the United States.  What is this - Switzerland, or a fascist thought-speech control regime?

This concern smells of airline lobbying/pressure behind the scenes.   

The 24 hour rule does need to be clarified and seems reasonable to make the definition of "air travel to/from/within" the United States clearer for consumers and air carriers.

The mess in Canada with respect to a so-called mistake fare, where the Canadian Transportation Agency backtracked on an earlier enforcement decision for seven complainants and then ruled against more than eighty further complainants on the same issue shows what happens when carriers lobby governments and where definitions are unclear and can be influenced by commercial pressure.

Sellers of air transportation are in full control of their pricing and distribution channels.  Why the DoT invokes a problematic concept of "bad faith" is disturbing and will undermine all rulemaking of this type.  But, if "bad faith" is to be raised, let's address the bad faith of those who set prices, sell product, and then renege on it.  This conduct is more clearly "bad faith" than those who purchase the offered product and should be regulated - which it currently is, by the 399.88a ruling as it stands.

The DoT is to be congratulated on taking this seriously in the first instance, as shown by recent FOIA-released correspondence regarding recent fares from RGN and the predictable responses of airline legal and corporate representatives protesting the ruling.

A doctrine of absolute liability for published fares is critical.  It maintains incentives for carriers to monitor and manage their own product pricing without relying on a government agency to bail them out from what they can later call their own "mistakes" and prevents arbitrary renegings that undermine market and contract reliability.  Any fare that is published and purchased is a valid fare and should be treated and protected as such.  Any change that undermines this principle will be opposed by consumers.  Copy to Congressional representative.

KB
bestinclassredtailshark@gmail.com

Title: David Boufford
Comment: I am very much in favor of being able to see in advance all the fees that I may incur when booking an airline ticket and in knowing exactly what a ticket will cost in total before I make a purchase.

Title: Shankar Lakhavani
Comment: I have traveled frequently by air for work and pleasure for the past 20+ years; and one of the frustrating issues is the manner in which the airline industry has redefined what I as a consumer pays for an airline ticket. The airline industry has slowly stripped out my ability to check a bag, reserve a seat and even carry a bag on board from the base fare that they charge. Now the airline industry wants to create a very opaque process so that as a consumer I know less about the ‘product’ that I am getting starting with the true cost of travel before purchasing a ticket. Further as a consumer I need to know the quality metrics and statistics such as: on-time performance, over sales, bumping off a reserved flight, mishandled baggage rates, etc. The airlines should be given a grade as the Health Department does for Restaurants in many cities.

Title: John Buchan
Comment:
Addition to previous comment.

Under no circumstances should any airline be able to cancel tickets booked by consumers on so-called "mistake fares". The airlines send their fares and rules to the Airline Tariff Publishing Company. ATPCO distributes the fares to all sellers of airline tickets. There are checks and balances, in both airlines and ATPCO to prevent mistakes from happening. But, mistakes still happen frequently. The airlines are ultimately responsible for auditing their own fares. To label "blogs" as bad actors and then to further label consumers as acting in "bad faith", is gross misrepresentation. When a consumer makes a mistake in purchasing an airline ticket, he/she has to pay all kinds of penalties for the error. To release airlines from providing transportation to a consumer who purchased the ticket in "good faith", is giving all the power in the marketplace to the airlines. Consumer advice is always that "the buyers should be wary", but airlines need to be wary of their possible errors, as well.

Title: John Drake
Comment: A ticket should be a ticket for all aspects of the trip from purchase to arrival at the curb at destination.  It should not be simply "a reservation to pay more",  All fees should be bundled into to price as used to be done.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am in support of the proposed regulations. It is frustrating, confusing, and dishonest for many of the airlines to advertise/offer/quote one fare, which is then inflated with all of their hidden fees when it comes time to purchase your ticket.  If I am quoted a fare of $250, then that is the fare I expect to pay, not one with undisclosed fees that raise it significantly.

Title: Tim Tanis
Comment:
After reading the NPRM on this topic I would like to make some recommendations.

1) Regarding #5 Customer Service Commitments: a) These should be expanded to airlines as well as defined by the 0.5% of domestic scheduled passenger revenue threshold as these requirements would equally impact both Ticketing Agents and Carriers. b) The definition of a "prompt refund" should be specifically less than 7 calendar days for all Carriers and Ticket Agents that sell/provide flights that depart from or arrive within the US and less than 14 calendar days for exclusively international flights. c) In coordination with item proposed rule #1, I believe that the DOT should also include a provision that if the Carrier or Ticketing Agent fails to honor the commitment of any paid Ancillary Fee they are required to refund the passenger based upon the "prompt refund" definition. This would include if a paid first checked bag is delayed more than 2 hours in its delivery to a customer.

My view point of this comes from the fact that I about two years ago needed to book a last minute ticket in economy on a US carrier. The fare was refundable and I needed that flexibility because I was waiting to hear back from a friend on a medical issue. The carrier debited by credit card immediately, then about two hours later my friend contacted me back and said my travel wasn't immediately required and it took them almost three calendar weeks to refund my credit card.

I have read too many friends on Facebook that have posted that they paid the carrier's Ancillary Fee for a bag and then the carrier "lost" the bag in transit. In most cases, from what I have heard, the airlines refuse to refund the passengers for the service they offered when something happens this is unfair when baggage delivery should be a core competency of an airline and they exchange cash to act as a delivery service.

2) Regarding #9 Post-Purchase Price Increases: a) I would expand this to also include a prohibition from increasing the price for preferred seating and any services provided for free or included in the price of the fare. Seating, baggage and other commitments the airlines have promised are core services that consumers expect to remain the same once a ticket is purchased.

3) Also Regarding #9: Airlines and their agents have complete control over the pricing of tickets and how they are distributed to consumers, the fare rules and all conditions that consumers must agree to (with no negotiation). Compared to the number of fares posted mistakes are genuinely rare. Most of the airlines that errors impacts are extremely large organizations that can afford to put in sound audit and invest in IT systems/tools that would help prevent issues. In this case, the DOT should let the free market with the current consumer protections act as an incentive to the airlines, GDS's and ticketing agents to improve their processes and systems.

3) Also Regarding #9: I agree that all forms of travel should be included as some airlines offer continuing service via code shares on trains and cruises. However, I very much disagree with the additional inclusion that a time period of a connection or stopover that is "24 hours or longer". The United States is unique in that we require all passengers of transportation to clear customs and immigration. Therefore, it is complete possible and something that I have used to leave London in the morning, schedule a meeting in New York for the afternoon and then have a connecting flight to South America on the same ticket the next morning because the airlines allow a 24 hours "connection" so that I can spend almost a full day in the US. Depending on how the fare basis codes work out the LHR-JFK and JFK-EZE could be completely separate fares and for convenience of both the airline and myself I have those flights on one ticket number. By adding the "24 hour" words to this rule the DOT is limiting the protection of a ticket where I very clearly have to enter the United States, have one or multiple segments that could have me passing through the United States several times, and creates complexity around a very simple concept at its core. If a ticket is issued and a passenger travels within, to or from the United States any and all carriers and travel agents must honor fare of that booked itinerary.

As an example last year I booked one ticket GIG-DFW-CDG-JFK / surface break & one week stay / LAX-NRT-DFW-CDG-JFK-EZE. The ticket had multiple fare components. Without a straight forward rule, "air transportation within, to, or from the United States" how would I know what parts of the ticket the Ticketing Agent or Carrier could change?

Comment: Yes. Please. Did I say PLEASE?  Thank you!  Did I say thank you? THANK YOU VERY MUCH!!!!

Title: Paul Muntjan
Comment: I travel a lot and the extremely deceptive practices of the airlines and travel agencies is very much anti-consumer.  We need your help here in balancing the unfair and unethical practices of the airline industry.  You have my full support in this regard!

Title: Joan Horn
Comment: I'm one of the millions of US consumers who want the airlines to show basic fees upfront and at the time the fare is displayed.  To be quoted a fare by an airline or travel site, and then have it "surprise" you will additional fees, is ridiculous.  The airlines are difficult enough to navigate with the different boarding, seating, baggage, meals, by nickel & diming of the consumers, it will be almost impossible to find a flight and compare the final price.  Upfront fares & fees will at least help us, as consumers, be able to compare and choose wisely over the airlines and allow competitive fares without hiding the final fares until the fare is actually "bought". Title: Ella Hurrell
Comment:
Please ensure that all prices are disclosed in such a way that full price comparisons may be made by the consumer when investigating flight fares/costs. This should be in a standard way so direct comparisons are easy to make.

Thank you.

Title: Ruth Christie
Comment: I strongly approve of the proposed regulations to make the airfares more honest & easier to compare.

Title: Michael OMalley
Comment: The airlines have obviously been using fare smoke to hide true final fares. The airlines deserve to make a decent profit and should charge accordingly - but the huge divergence in their own fares (on an hourly basis in many cases) does more than suggest smoke. There is no reason they can not list the fees and taxes as part of a final fare figure. This eliminates one of their prime arguments.

Title: Diane Rhodes
Comment:
I absolutely HATE buying an airline ticket, simply because I never know what I am actually going to pay until the end, because of all the hidden fees and additional costs that are tacked on.  It is virtually impossible to compare apples to apples in looking for the best deal.  I have longed for an airline which will simply list fare + luggage fee + seat fee (if any) + taxes + any other costs = total cost of your ticket.  But such a pricing is not currently available, and it certainly should be.  It is especially disgusting to get to the airport to check in, and only THEN discover you aren't finished paying yet!

I believe ALL airlines should be REQUIRED to give the TOTAL cost you will have to pay when quoting a ticket price.  And all of that information should be on a single page, so it can all be seen at once.

I am also astonished that any airline would charge for carry-ons (of a reasonable size).  If your suitcase should get lost (and yes, Virginia, that does happen), should you have to arrive at your destination without so much as a toothbrush, or else have to pay an additional $25, $50, or even more to take that toothbrush aboard the plane as a carry-on?

The Airfare Transparency Bill is anything but, if it allows the airlines to "hide" even more of the actual cost of our tickets. Please, DOT, be the government agency that for once gives the consumer a break and allows us to know what we're getting when we look at it on-line!

Title: Albert Panko
Comment:
As a frequent traveler, I resent the fact that I must scour airline web sites to figure out the total cost of an airline ticket.  I believe that the hidden fees should be included in the advertised flight price, including one checked bag and one carry-on bag.  It is ridiculous that consumers should have to pay separately for  a seat assignment, one checked bag (50 lbs or less) and one carry-on. 

Please do not allow the airlines to continue this blatant scheme to collect more fees income.  Please require them to put it in the price, or at least display all ancillary charges up front.  Some airlines do not show all their fees until you have entered all your flying information.   That is absurd.

Thank you.

Title: Marilyn Muller
Comment: NO hidden fees by airlines. When we buy a ticket, price should include all taxes, all fees, my seat, cost if any of carry on bag. This is the only fair and decent way to proceed. We put up with enough from airlines as it is such as being offered disgusting food at exorbitant prices, being herded into narrow, uncomfortable spaces like so much cattle. I long ago learned to pack a bagel and an apple in my purse so as not to have to eat airplane food.

Title: Aaron Danner
Comment: Section 399.88(a) should not be modified. Airlines seldom make "mistake fares" and the current practice of forcing them to honour such fares is the reason why they seldom make mistakes to start with. If this consumer protection is loosened, then it will encourage airlines to void legally purchased tickets if they later discover that they could have charged more. Fares are complicated enough as it is, and it is nearly impossible to anyone to dub a fare as a mistake, given the plethora of deals offered by airlines that are genuine. Airlines charge customers hefty fees when customers make mistakes in purchasing tickets, so why shouldn't the reverse be true? Contracts have to be honoured in both directions.

Title: Timothy Ngo
Comment:
As a US frequent flyer, I appreciated the DOT's efforts to be fair and balanced to both sides: the airlines and the passengers.  However, revising Section 399.88 to allow the airlines more leeway in dealing with what they consider "mistake fares" sounds like a terrible idea--a disservice to American consumers of air transportation.  When passengers make mistakes in their fare booking, they are penalized.  Carriers impose hefty charges when passengers change their minds with regards to travel dates and routing.  And carriers always have the upper hand, even in the case of incredibly low fares.  Information on booking classes, which is not always available at the time of purchase, is extremely complicated and varies from one airline to another.  Sometimes the airlines or travel agencies (both online and offline) do not even let passengers know the precise fare booking class before they actually make the purchase.  With seemingly low fares, carriers can impose most severe restrictions on changes.  They may not award full mileage either.  Whatever a passenger may gain in terms of fare discount, he or she may lose in terms of restriction and mileage.  This is asymmetrical information advantage.  Yet it is the current system we are all operating under.

Now if the Department decides to loosen the restrictions on the part of the airlines and allow them to freely cancel "mistake fare" based on their determination that the fare has been purchased in "bad faith," the already not-so-level playing field will be further tilted towards favoring the airlines.  When an airline decides that it could sell a fare for much higher than it did due to unexpectedly high market demand, it could freely cancel the transaction after determining that the consumer might have got the information from an online posting and therefore knew in advance what they were getting into--a "bad faith" attempt.  It will be then the passengers' burden to prove that they did not.  This is extremely unfair and unenforceable and will weaken consumer's protection.

In addition, in today's bewildering air fare market, how would an average consumer be able to know if the low fare is mistaken or real?  Many airlines routinely advertise free fares while charging a hefty sum for taxes and fees.  It would be an extreme and unreasonable burden for the consumers know the difference.

The so-called mistake fares are exceedingly rare.  Have the airlines submitted to the Department credible data on actual loss of revenues due to mistake fares?  If they do, would the Department make these data available to the public for examination?  Until such data is available, there are no compelling arguments to weaken consumer protection under Section 399.88.  Airlines are required to honor their end of the contract, just like millions of passengers are once the transactions are completed.  I just don't see how revising Section 399.88 would benefit the consumers or reducing risks for the airlines.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airline ticket prices must include all  fees and taxes ,cost of baggage and a reserved seat.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I would like airline fares to be compared fairly, easily, and quickly: the bottom line on all fares should include all items necessary to board a plane and take a seat. Taxes and any other service fees should be included; no "after purchase" add-ons; nothing to raise the cost to get on a plane and fly.

While airlines are busy figuring out how to add optional services (aka more dollars), I'm left unable to compare the cost to get from one city to another on X, Y, or Z.

Thank you for returning the airline industry to its previous complete and understandable pricing standards.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Airline behavior is becoming progressively less civilized. Regulation is recommended. 
Fee structure should be made transparent so that travelers can make a reasonable comparison. 
Any traveler who is left stranded in an airport should be paid $10,000 minimum. 
Large airlines operate as monopolies in restraint of trade. Such monopolies and ogilopolies should be broken up.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: While consumer experience declines, fees continue to rise. Protect American consumers by ensuring that airlines disclose the full cost of air travel. Keep airlines from further re-defining what a "ticket" is so that Americans will be able to spend their hard-earned money more wisely.

Title: Jerri
Comment:
Please define what is included in an air travel ticket; be sure to include at the least a seat assignment (or place in the boarding queue ala Southwest Airlines), a personal and secondary carry-on bag, and reasonable (or better yet no) checked-baggage fees.  And make a rule that any additional costs show up in the initial quotes consumers are given by the airlines, travel agents and on-line booking services.
  As of now, those airlines which aggressively unbundle such as Spirit Airlines always show up at the top of competitive price quotes but when the bare minimum requirements are included they are as expensive, if not more so, than other airlines.  This effectively is consumer deception if not outright fraud.

Put a stop to this madness!

Comment: against

Title: William
Comment: I believe airlines SHOULD have to disclose all related consumer fees for check baggage, carry-on items, seat assignments, and other fees.

Title: Walter Slazyk
Comment:
Dir Sir or Madam:

At a minimum, advertised and offered fares for all transportation mean should include all mandatory fees and taxes.  This includes airport fees, federal, state and local taxes, plus any other charge that the traveler must pay to be moved from point A to point B.

  Walt Slazyk

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
It can be very difficult for consumers to calculate the full cost of airline travel from point A to point B and to compare that cost among carriers because airlines have different definitions of what is included in a "ticket."  Does the ticket price include checked baggage, carry-on baggage, meals, seat assignment.  In addition, different carriers charge different fees for these "optional" items. (Is the first checked bag free or $25.00 or $35.00 or more?)  It would be much easier for consumers to calculate their costs and compare prices if all tickets were required to include the same standardized list of items and services.  

I suggest that the standardized ticket price include all of the following: 1) the cost of transportation from point to point; 2) all required taxes and fees; 3) one checked bag; 4) one carry-on bag; 5) one carry-on personal item; and 5) advance seat assignment.  

The costs for additional optional services (such as meals, priority boarding, seats with extra legroom, etc.) should be clearly displayed, and consumers should be able to select any of these options that they desire.

Title: Susan Absher
Comment:
As a retiree who flies several times a year domestically and internationally, I support the proposed transparency in airline fees set forward by DOT.  I plan my own independent travel, and it is very difficult for the consumer to compare prices among competing airlines when fares and fees are displayed so differently.  Just last week, I didn't realize how much the taxes were on an airline ticket until I had entered my payment information.  Also, I didn't know until after I completed the purchase that the fare category I selected does not allow me to select my seat until just before the overnight flight.  And, if you've ever tried to book a fare on Spirit Airlines you know just how misleading their fare quotes are. 
Please stick to your guns and finalize these rules with the protections consumers need and deserve.
Thank you (as a former EPA employee who developed regulations, I know just how tough your job is!)

Title: Camille Nicholson
Comment: I am whole-heartedly in favor of these new proposals. This is something that is way overdue. I hope these new rules are adopted.

Title: Laura Nelson
Comment: This rule is incredibly important for protecting consumers. Please keep the requirement to show fees in addition to the base fare. If at all possible, airline tickets should include all taxes and fees, so consumers can know the full price of the flight as we search for flights.

Title: Farris - Comments
Comment: The airlines need to stop nickel-and diming the consumers.  It is obvious they are looking for wiley ways to milk consumers of more money by making it difficult and misleading to understand airfares.  Go JetBlue and Southwest who include checked bags into their airfares.

Title: Steven Tiefel
Comment: Airline ticket fees should be clear and understandable without any attempt by the airline to hide the cost of taxes and fees.  Ideally a ticket price would include a seat assignment, checked bags and a carry on bag/item.  If the cost of checking a bag must be separated out it should be done in a clear and understandable manner.  Charging for a carry on items is ridiculous.

Title: Robert Walker
Comment:
First of all, I fully support standardizing the airline product. There is little effective competition in the airline industry at this point, with the American government having allowed the entire industry to merge into--effectively--3 major US airlines. The public has no leverage anymore, airlines can do more or less whatever they want and they have been doing so.

This regulation is a good first step, but doesn't entirely solve the problem. There have been "incredible shrinking bag sizes" at major airlines as recently as last week. It's not particularly meaningful to require that a checked bag be included if the bag can be 2 inches in total size and weigh one ounce. Most recently, allowable carry-on bag sizes have shrunk. As a starting point, I would like the DOT to define a standardized allowable size and weight, both more generous than the current new 9" maximum dimensions which seem designed to force everyone to either buy new carry-on luggage or pay massive fines.

Another problem is that airlines charge so much for extra bags that it's often much cheaper to buy a second seat and use the baggage allowance from that. However, airlines won't actually allow you to do this. When you consider that a single overweight extra bag checked on a United international flight can cost $600, this violates the basic principle of fair dealing. It is a huge problem for musicians like me who must travel with musical equipment and are given no choice but to either pay these ludicrous fees. I have had to turn down performances abroad because of unaffordable bag fees, even though a second ticket would have been affordable.

Finally, I would like to propose that the checked baggage allowance should be one bag on domestic flights, and two bags on international flights as was previously offered by all major airlines. Such limited airline baggage allowances are harming the US economy by discouraging foreign visitors from shopping here and this needs to stop immediately.

Title: Emily Aldredge
Comment: I prefer to base my airline comparison search on the final cost, instead of hiding the costs until the end of the individual ticket purchase. We already have enough surprise costs with added fees for baggage, food, seats, etc. I wish the airlines would roll these costs back into the overall ticket price, as they once did, so that travelers can plan better with having all costs, upfront.

Title: John Carleton
Comment: This is seriously needed for better transparency in the true costs of airline travel.

Title: William Harris
Comment: We need this to be able to tell the real cost and comparison of airline tickets.

Title: Sandy Husmann
Comment: All pricing and scheduling information should be available to a consumer searching for travel information online.

Title: David Edwards
Comment: good idea... they should tell consumers the entire cost

Title: Lawrence Reinholt
Comment: I want to know if their is fair bias!  And in reality, there shouldn't be.

Title: Richard Phillips
Comment: I, LIKE THE MAJORITY OF AMERICAN CONSUMERS WANT TRUE TRANSPARENCY IN AIRLINE TICKET PRICES WHEN ATTEMPTING TO PURCHASE TICKETS ONLINE.  THERE ARE TOO MANY HIDDEN FEES THAT ARE BEING ADDED TO "QUOTED" TICKET PRICES THAT NEED TO BE CLEARLY STATED WHEN CONSUMERS SEARCH FOR THE BEST AIRLINE TICKET PRICES.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This year I was looking at airfares for a trip.  I found that kayak.com had different fares for the same flight when I viewed them simultaneously (on two different devices)  I also found that depending on the location I was viewing the fares that there was a difference.  I would like to be able to feel that I was looking at an objective price quote, i.e. that it was a set price at that point in time.  I also noticed that the price became higher the more times I viewed the flights.

Title: Amanda Kachur
Comment:
Thank you for soliciting public comment on airline fees.  I am in favor of including all mandatory costs, such as airline fees and taxes, in a single base price with an additional listing of common ancillary fees (i.e., checked and carry-on luggage).  The base fare (including tax) plus ancillary fees should be displayed in the same place.  Only then can comparison shopping be done in a reasonable amount of time.  Allowing airlines to advertise only their fee without tax and ancillary fees would be a nightmare for the consumer.  

It is also important to clearly list the operating airline on code share flights, and list the airlines that the ticketing agent represents.  

Thank you.

Title: Chris Hansen
Comment:
Any rational person would prefer to have as much information available when making a purchase, whether it be gasoline for the car, a suit of clothes, furniture for the new baby, or an airline ticket.

The airlines and online ticketing companies have the relevant information between and have the ability to display all that is needed.

Spurious statements from the industry and some politicians that no one else includes taxes in the final price just need to go to their closest gasoline station.  The full price is posted for all to see and allows the consumer to make the choice of going elsewhere if they want. 

Airline ticket prices deserve no less.

Title: Deb
Comment: Please pass this rule.  It's very unfair that I, as a consumer, don't even know exactly what I'm paying for.  Gone are the days when you bought a plane ticket, it included two baggages, carry-on's, a meal, drink, and a reserved seat.  Now, it's maybe I'll get a free drink, maybe I'll get some sort of food, maybe I'll have to check my carry on, etc.  I'd travel more, if I knew the price up front.  Airlines are constantly trying to "trick" us into buying their fares.  I'm spending too much time, checking one site after another to find the full cost of a fare.  Now, hotels are starting to do the same thing.  What they're doing is making travel such a chore instead of an exciting experience.  Remember, the more I spend on airlines because of all the nickel and diming, the less I have to spend at the locations.  I'm sure the destinations should be concerned about that too.

Title: Patricia Olderr
Comment: All charges should be enumerated from the beginning.  There should be nothing hidden from the consumer.  This should include baggage fees, taxes, and any other charge beyond the price of the airline ticket.

Title: C. Shuman
Comment: The traveling public should be able to easily see all fees and compare fares and fees.  We should not have to search out costs or buy blind.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Respectfully request that the DOT NOT kowtow to the airlines and/or their lobbyists to allow the way fares are displayed to be changed from the CURRENT requirement.  If anything, the carriers should be required to continue to display the complete and full fare INCLUDING the required taxes and/or fees (as they do now) as well as wording that additional fees will be changed for baggage and every other bloody thing with a link that will then display those additional charges.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I have traveled on major airlines numerous times over the past year, and never found it difficult to determine what additional fees there were beyond the fare and attendant government-imposed taxes and fees. The baggage, upgrade and other options have all been easily found and readily explained when I sought them, and nothing was charged without my knowledge and approval.The more difficult items to determine were how much tax and what cost the additional government fees added to the base fare. Perhaps that is what needs to be more clearly disclosed - how much the government gets from each ticket I purchase.

Really, this is unnecessary and intrusive. Haven't the airlines been regulated enough? If this is consistent with free market economics, then demand the same transparency from cable and wireless providers. And lets not forget electricity providers, certainly a much more "essential" service to our consumer economy. When was the last time you opened an electric bill and had any relevant information regarding the true cost of the Kwh being provided.

Enough! Let this industry alone. No further ridiculous and onerous disclosures for airlines.

Title: Douglas Meyer
Comment: I would like the FULL price to be disclosed when purchasing airline tickets ! No one cares what the airlines get, they only care about what they PAY. If I pay for a flight and then get to the gate and have to pay more, I feel cheated, no matter the reason !

Title: Robert North
Comment: I normally travel by air 2-3 times per year and have found the current methodology of separate fees for everything to be very frustrating and confusing.  It is almost impossible in some cases to know what the final cost of a flight is going to be until after it has been booked and even then there may still be fees that remain unknown until checking in for a flight.  I strongly support display of full costs up-front in order to do valid apple-to-apple comparisons.  As a consumer I would find that to be far more valuable than the current practice.  I am strongly in favor of this proposal.

Title: Barbara Royal
Comment:
The current trend to 'unbundle' various charges by the airlines has become totally absurd!  It's time to go back to some basics - the ticket should include checking 1 bag, and carrying on 2 bags that are not to exceed certain size regulations. And those regulations need to be enforced. No more huge duffles or suitcases that belong in cargo! 

Also - no more fees to reserve your seat ahead of time, and no extra fee for certain seats. 

And ticket prices ought to reflect miles flown. How on earth can they justify more for a direct one-way flight than a 2-stop round-trip? 

AND - it's totally wrong that people sitting next to each other can be paying such widely varying prices. A simple discount for early booking is one thing...  but we also know that when booking online, they track what I search on, and if I don't buy the first time, then when I come back even a short time later, they up the price!

Do we even want to get into the shrinking size of seats? and loss of leg room between rows? I know - that's not about transparency, just about providing a comfortable travel experience!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Consumers like me, lucky enough to have found out about these proposals in the paper, very much want and need transparent information on the cost of airline tickets.  Airlines must be required to display basis fees up front, when the fare is displayed.  How can DOT possibly allow airlines to hide their costs from customers?  I also want the DOT to ban the preferential ranking of certain carrier' flights  over others without disclosing to the consumer that they are doing this.  Again, I am amazed that travel websites are currently allowed to do this.  I am also in favor of the other consumer protection proposals such as compelling large travel agencies to adopt minimum customer service standards and to require additional air carriers to report their on-time performance, oversales and mishandled baggage rates to the DOT.

Title: Karen Herwig
Comment: Let's stop this ridiculous 'fee' system. Give the price for a ticket with a bag and a seat! The airlines keep dithering with fees because they pay taxes on fares they charge but not on the fees...so we get less fare and more added on fees. Let's just call a fare a fare and the airline pays taxes on the money coming in regardless of what they call it. Revenue is revenue.

Title: Lynn Fox
Comment: Why do I even have to make this request? Of COURSE I want to know what I am paying for regarding airline ancillary fees. This is my absolute right as a consumer, and should be without recourse to a government rule.

Title: Thomas Reinhard
Comment:
Government regulations should require easily amalgamated price information for all charges. They could be broken down into standard categories, i.e., "certain charges and fees", "optional charges", "taxes", etc. The categories should be standard so that any air traveler can readily compare what services will cost on different airlines for a given set of services. Travelers should not have to dig through multiple web pages in different formats to piece this information together. It is a tremendous waste of time for each flight a traveler makes and an enormous waste of national effort when all travelers are considered.

The airlines may balk, but American industry espouses free enterprise and the competitive market when it suits them and as any student of elementary economics knows, the ability to compare prices for similar goods and services is a pillar of competition. Regulation is necessary because free competition is not in the best financial interest of the airlines but is required to make this market fair.

Title: Anonynmous
Comment: I think it is import that airlines be required to identify all fees that are being imposed when the ticket is purchased and be indicated in the total price of the ticket.  It is important to know the bottom line price, not just the price of the "seat".

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am in favor of the rule and all it's components. Especially important is the inclusion of code share partners in data reporting.  As a consumer I evaluate my experience based on the airline I booked with and who's "colors" I'm flying under.  If I book with Delta, pay Delta and fly a Delta or plane flying on behalf of Delta, I evaluate my experience as Delta.  This is regardless of the flight code, business partner or aircraft size.  If it looks like a rose and smells like a rose it should be described and presented as a rose.

I appreciate that some carriers display "% on-time" stats by segment on their web sites. I would think that data could be rolled for the airline as a whole.

I hope the airlines understand, and have pride, that consumer loyality is brand related and they would do their best to ensure that all real or perceived entities of the brand are deserving of the brands name.  If they are embarrassed or feel the need to hide business partners' data maybe they shouldn't be doing business with them.

Title: Pieter Joost Van Wattum
Comment: As a passenger and frequent flyer, I request transparency in pricing and on-time performance by the airlines: One final price shown when searching ticket prices and breakdown in taxes etcetera only before paying. Clear indication which airline or its subcontractor is operating the flight and the on-time performance of the actual operator

Title: Edward Robbeloth
Comment:
•  Do you have a problem finding fee information? And if so, how significant is that problem? If you have a problem finding fees, how does it affect your ability to comparison shop?

     Under the present system, all carriers should be required to utilized a standard list and format for describing fees so travelers can make easy comparison.  This would be analogous to the required information on prepared food products/beverages:  standard information appearing in standard formats.  However, my absolute preference would be to have ticket prices be “all inclusive” and include all fees into the ticket price.

•  What types of fees would you most like to have more information about during the shopping process, prior to purchase?

     All fees assessed should be listed.

•  When would you like to see that information displayed in your search process—as soon as you see a list of fares or later in the process? How would you like to see the information regarding ancillary fees displayed—as a link, as a specific dollar amount shown with the airfare quote, as a table or menu on the homepage or flight search results list? Should the Department require a standardized format for disclosure?

     Fees should appear as a specific dollar amount shown with the airfare quote.  The Department should definitely require a standardized format for disclosure.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe that transparency is a must so that the consumer can compare oranges to oranges and apples to apples. a great example of comparing like businesses is the banking industry as each company must use the same formula where the consumer can make an informed decision when comparing rates for savings or loans.  The APR and APY rules make banking easier.  The airline industry needs to have a like regulation to aid the consumers.

Title: M. Perry
Comment:
1.  Customers need better information about operating carriers and checking in, including rule changes such as baggage allowances.  I was almost stranded in London, because Delta hadn't transmitted my travel documents for travel onward to Istanbul to KLM.  I was going to be charged extra for bags, because Delta also hadn't communicated my elite status.  I was sent back and forth between KLM and Delta agents to resolve the issue.  Had I not followed my gut feeling and inquired upon landing at Heathrow, I would not have had time to make my flight the next day.  It took hours of my time, which was hours lost exploring London.

2.  On time is a joke.  They have extended flight times by 25 % to 50%, so they can arrive on time even when they leave late.  Customers have no way of verifying reasons given for delays.

3.  The airlines overbook and then threaten not to have the flight take off - even if it means being late - unless enough people volunteer to be bumped so they can avoid federal mandated passenger compensation for involuntary bumping of passengers. 

4.  The airlines try to get you to wait 24 hours before filing a lost luggage complaint to make their numbers look good.  I was asked to wait around 4 to 6 hours before filing a complaint, which I promptly refused.  

In short, the rules need to be strengthened and the loop holes the airlines use to get around the intent of the rules need to be closed.

Title: Richard Devers
Comment: I agree with J. Clayton Baum.

Title: Marianna V.
Comment:
Department of Transportation 
DOT-OST-2014-0056
I support this DOT policy. We need greater transparency about pricing and who is providing flight services. Not knowing that a regional carrier is actually doing the flying impacts my ability to make decisions about which flight I take. If I purchase a flight on a major airline and pay the price for that service, I want to know that a regional carrier is substituted instead of the major airline whom I paid.

Tarmac delays of more than 3 hours should have a contingency plan and give each passenger the right to deplane.
No overcharges or any additional "surprise" charges once the flight has been booked and paid for.
Disclose all baggage/food/fuel/other fees upfront during the ticket purchase.
Disclose if the flight is overbooked.
Prompt refunds for undelivered services, flights, cancellations, passenger bumping.
Reservation hold for 24 hours and no fees for cancellation within 24 hours.
Notify customers promptly of any changes to itinerary.
Respond promptly to customer complaints.
Report statistics on mishandled luggage.
What the ontime performance of the airline is including that of code share partners i.e. regional carriers.
I want the pool of "reporting" airline partners to be detailed and accurate.

Title: H. Nayar
Comment:
I fully support this regulation. The air carriers operating in the United States are taking taking consumers for a 'ride'. Fees adn chargers are poorly defined and is subject to last minute interpretation. I would like the following to be addressed as well:
1. Multiple stop bookings: When a consumer wants to make a multiple stop booking, most outlets (website that are either carrier owned or third party) does not give you option to do this. The consumer is forced to call the carrier and in most cases are charged 'phone reservation charges'. These charges should be abolished. Why should a consumer pay more because the carrier has not provided the option?
2. Canceling for medical reasons: If a consumer has to cancel for medical reasons, he/she should be given full refund of the ticket. Do we want a situation where a medically unfit traveler starts a journey and fall ill along the way? If one were to think logically it is obvious that a lot of people do this when they are medically unfit, just because they stand a risk of losing the ticket money. Give consumers the option to get a full refund for medically required cancellations (either for themselves or caused by medical conditions for immediate family) and it will save money and headaches for everyone around.
3. Consumers should be given one fare whether it is on the web or through a phone reservation system. Many carriers operating in the US including international carriers (specifically Etihad, Emirates, Singapore Airways) have one fare posted on their website. When the consumer calls the reservation folks to make a reservation they quote a different fare with the explanation that 'they are not able to see the web fares'. This makes a significant difference in pricing and should NOT be permitted. The reason consumers are forced to call is mainly due to issues with names and how to enter them in the reservation system, particularly for passengers who culturally do not go by First Name, Middle Name, Last Name format.

Title: Harlan Aliment
Comment:
29970 - Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issue

My issue is with the checked bag fee. Airlines must offer compensation to the traveler if they are over booked, flight canceled, etc. Traveler is also paying a fee for their bags, there should be compensation when the airline fails to meet the standard of checked bags traveling and arriving with the traveler.

I propose the airlines be required to refund the checked bag fee(s) if the checked bag(s) are:
1. Not on the same plane the traveler is on or arrives on another aircraft landing 61 minutes or more after the traveler's flight actual touch down time.
2. Lost or destroyed by the airline.

No refund would be required if: 
1. Bag(s) sent ahead on another flight, waiting for the traveler to arrive. 
2. Bag(s) sent on a later flight to land at the airport under (1) one hour after the traveler's flight arrives. 

Any flight landing 61 minutes or longer after the traveler's flight landed would trigger the automatic refund. Weather or mechanical issues delaying the bags on another flight from meeting the (1) one hour arrival window will not be an excuse to block the refund. All airlines would be required to refund the fee for every bag not on time or arriving with the (1) one hour window. Traveler would fill out a refund slip with the airline's airport baggage office, maintain one copy. May be done electronically at a kiosk with a copy emailed to the traveler.

Refund must go directly to the credit card. Posted within (10) ten working days. Airlines would be prohibited by law to bargain with the traveler, offering them a voucher, coupon, frequent flier miles, or other type of non-cash compensation. By law, cash refund only. Information about the refund required to be printed on the checked bag receipt and viewable during the website process to pay for checked bags. As an incentive to the airline to process the refund with 10 working days, any refund not processed within the time limit automatically doubles.

Too many times I have checked in hours early, had flight delays, yet when I arrive at the baggage carousel, my bag is missing. Later I find out the airline, while having more than enough time to ensure bag was on same flight as me, willfully failed to meet the standard. Hours to the next day it finally shows up at my hotel or home, greatly inconveniencing me. 

Roughly two million bags disappear, arrive late, become damaged, or are stolen every year. Airlines keep the checked bag fee, the traveler is left out. If this fee was returned, @ $25 per bag X 2,000,000 = $50 million dollars. An amount the airlines cannot ignore, baggage fees making the difference between a profitable or not profitable flight. Having every airline refund the checked bag fee would directly affect the airline's bag fee profits, lowering them. Nothing gets a Corporate CEO's attention faster than the company losing money does. Problems would be identified and quickly worked.

Ref: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/travel/handling-luggage-problems-from-damage-to-delays.html?_r=0

Title: Susan Davis
Comment:
As a consumer and regular air traveller for both work and pleasure, I strongly advocate that DOT side with consumers over disclosure of ancillary fees related to seat selection, baggage check, and boarding priority, among others. It is not only inconvenient, particularly when checking in at airports, but it seems like a bait-and-switch from the airlines. I understand that having to include the fees in the base price will give the appearance of rates going up, but I am certain the vast majority of consumers just want to know what the price is going to be for any service--not just airlines. And the added costs seem like a way to "game" the system to no one's benefit but the airlines.

For example, today I searched for a flight from Washington D.C. to Alaska on Kayak.com. I was quoted an $802 fee. When I clicked through to purchase, I was then forced to pay for each seat on each leg of the four-leg journey. There were NO options for seats without additional cost. And it increased the cost of my fare by $179 in the end. I purchased it because it is a work trip and I have to go, but when I submitted a cost estimate to my employer for approval, there is no way to account for those fees unless you go all the way through the booking system--which is a tremendous hassle to the consumer, particularly for professional restrictions on flights costs.

I am fully aware of and comfortable with higher ticket prices on the front end of the purchase, if I can be confident that that is the price I will pay--or very close to--when I hit "purchase." The perpetual adding of fees to every facet of airline travel is cumbersome, overly burdensome to the consumer, and never streamlines what is generally a multi-step process.

Thank you for your time on this matter. 

Sincerely,
Susan Davis

Title: Gail H. Marcus
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

This letter is in enthusiastic support of requirements for airlines to disclose fully all ancillary fees when they advertise prices for air travel.

As a person who has traveled frequently for many years, I have been appalled at the trend toward a proliferation of fees, and even more appalled when I face unexpected surprises at the last minute.  

I am retired now, and one aspect of retirement that I had looked forward to was the opportunity to do more personal travel.  But understandably, I have to be even more careful than I was before to compare prices and seek the most cost-effective option for my travel.  This has become increasingly difficult as the number and types of fees increase, especially since it is not always easy even to find out what additional charges may apply and how much they are.   

It seems to me that the only possible reason that airlines want to withhold information on their ancillary fees is in hopes of MISLEADING the public.  Even though we have learned that there are extra fees, they can vary a great deal between airlines, so what looks like a good price for a ticket from one airline might actually turn out to be more expensive than the price the traveler would pay on another airline.  These hidden extra costs are magnified for families traveling together.

It seems to me this is a very simple issue:  honesty in marketing demands full disclosure of additional costs.  If airlines are competing on price, they should compete on the actual price.  Period.

I do realize that there are a lot of "optional" services, and not everyone will opt for all the services.  However, some of the services are pretty basic and do apply to many travelers, for example, luggage fees (for both checked and carry-on bags) and fees for preferred seating within a section of the aircraft.  It should not be that difficult to post a basic price and somewhere in the same ad or on the same page, have a list of "extras" and their prices.  To me, this is not much different from requirements of pharmaceutical companies to disclose possible side effects of their drugs.  I'm sure the pharma companies didn't want to do that, either.

Therefore, I applaud efforts to change the current airline practices, and want to encourage the Department of Transportation to implement new rules to require that would require the airlines to make it easy for a traveler to know all the additional charges they might incur.  

Sincerely,

Gail H. Marcus

Title: Lisa Evans
Comment: I urge you to pass all aspects of the Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees rule.  It is only right that consumers know full price information before purchasing a ticket.  The airlines' reasoning that the free market will produce the best result for consumers is faulty - if consumers do not know what final costs are, how can they make an educated decision on choice of carrier?  The airlines contend that regulation results in decreased profits for them - but they continue to reap record profits.  Protect the consumer!!

Title: John Parks
Comment:
While I understand the airlines' wanting the right to let the marketplace control fees with all the mergers choice has been limited and the time is now for more regulation. The first thing that should be done is a national law requiring 1 free bag checked which would actually speed the boarding process so that people don't try to cram the overhead compartments which  slows loading and unloading. Europeans kick our tail in this area. 

Second ALL AIRLINE FEES MUST BE TAXED. The airlines are using these fees as tax loopholes where only fares are taxed. Please address this issue.

Finally why are we allowing airlines to ban the use of cash on-board planes? Our currency by law must be accepted for all debts public and private and to only allow credit or debit card purchases is illegal and an unfair market practice.

Title: Balboa Travel, Inc.
Comment:
RE: DOT-OST-2014-0056 

My comments follow as the Chairman of a large travel management agency focused primarily on business travelers.

Travelers and the general public who rely on the DOT to protect them from unscrupulous airline practices need the DOT to make changes in the ancillary fees proposal in the NPRM. These are absolutely necessary to restore true transparency and the ability for a consumer to do comparison-shopping of the all-in price of air travel alternatives. The DOT needs to put an end to unfair and deceptive practices which the airlines are doing all possible to protect, despite the fact that they harm the consumer.

The DOT must require airlines to allow consumers to pay for their basic ancillary services at the time of ticket purchase through any distribution channels airlines use. Failing this, the consumer is exposed to the GREAT SURPRISE at the airport where the cost of the trip is suddenly much more than s/he thought. Furthermore, even if there is some cumbersome way for the consumer (and particularly the business traveler) to calculate these extra charges separately, having to separate them from the air ticket itself creates a terrible accounting hassle for the traveler and for his company's accounting department.

Given the high percentage of airline tickets purchased through travel agencies, the DOT must ensure that airlines share ancillary information with all of the ticket agents they use, including global distribution systems (GDS), to ensure that the information can be broadly, efficiently and effectively disseminated to travel agencies in a usable format. Requiring airlines to push out this vital price information to travel agencies via the GDSs that issue airlines tickets is the only workable solution.

"Ancillary services" must be expanded to include priority boarding and change/cancelation fees as well as any bundles that include the basic ancillary services under the rule.

The role of the DOT is to provide that the public, and specifically the consumer of air travel be able to travel safely and securely and be dealt with fairly by the airlines. REQUIRING THAT AIRLINES MAKE IT CLEAR FROM THE OUTSET EXACTLY HOW MUCH A TRIP IS GOING TO COST IS SOMETHING EVERY TRAVELER SHOULD BE ABLE TO RELY ON. And it is the duty of the DOT to see that this is a reality.

Jose (Joe) G. da Rosa
Chairman
Balboa Travel, Inc.
San Diego, CA
jdarosa@balboa.com
858-678-3301

Title: Neil Hopwood
Comment:
Docket Number DOT-OST-2014-0056 

Dear Sirs,

As a TMC serving the business community we urge the DoT to review and reconsider all the implications that this proposal will bring to life.
It is vital that airlines show all charges associated with a  booking to allow all TMCs booking for business consumers to make a valid judgement and to be able to directly compare like with like when intending to book travel. Anything but absolute clarity exacerbates the current confusing situation fort everyone. As far as I can see the only entity to benefit from underhand or hidden fees and charges are the people who wish to purposefully maintain this position of subterfuge to their own gain at the total expense of the most important people in this equation - the travel bookers and travelers. It is true that the consumer always pays in the end, but it would be nice for them to know exactly what they are paying to be able to make an informed decision at the point of sale and not when the booking is almost complete (known as drip pricing), when it may to too late to do anything but be sucked into the transaction and make the booking. Airlines must show all fees and associated charges early in the booking cycle to ensure above board clarity. What is fair and equitable about hiding fees until the end of booking?
I hope the DoT will consider it's actions before anything is done and it is too late for the people and indeed the very travelers and bookers of travel who elected them into power.

Many thanks.

Neil Hopwood
Chief Operating Officer
Redfern Travel

Title: Kelly Johnson
Comment:
U.S. Department of Transportation 
Docket Number DOT-OST-2014-0056 

Recommend three changes to the ancillary fees proposal in the NPRM that are necessary to restore true transparency and comparison-shopping of the all-in price of air travel alternatives and to put an end to unfair and deceptive airline marketing practices.  

1 - Require airlines to allow consumers to pay for their basic ancillary services at the time of ticket purchase through any distribution channels airlines use.

2 - Ensure that airlines share ancillary information with all of the ticket agents they use, including global distribution systems (GDS), to ensure that the information can be broadly, efficiently and effectively disseminated to travel agencies in a usable format. To be sure, requiring airlines to push out this vital price information to travel agencies via the GDSs that issue airlines tickets is the only workable solution.

3 - Expand the covered ancillary services to include priority boarding and change/cancellation fees as well as any bundles that include the basic ancillary services under the rule.


Kelly L. Johnson, A.A.E.
Airport Director Northwest Arkansas Regional Airport

Title: Ellen Dunn
Comment:
DOT-OST-2014-0056
In my humble opinion, this rule should be passed without anymore delay. I am an infrequent flier, maybe once or twice a year. After searching and booking online for the cheapest airfare using most of the available sites over many months, it is very upsetting to arrive at baggage check-in and be hit with more costs. Now some airlines are charging a fee for carry-ons too!
The airlines should state all fees and extra costs upfront and on all online formats so the consumer can make an educated decision before purchase. I am a senior citizen and cannot afford the extra, unknown before-hand, expenses imposed on me.

Title: Kevin Mitchell
Comment:
September 10, 2014

The Honorable Anthony Foxx
Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Regarding DOT-OST-2014-0056-0079

Dear Secretary Foxx,

We consumer groups are writing to you to urge the Department to focus on what we consider the core issue in the current airline consumer protections NPRM - the consumers ability to see, compare and buy ancillary fees. Consumers do not want to see this issue delayed again should other portions of the complicated NPRM require more study and analysis.

A robust docket shows that American consumers need and demand price transparency, the ability to comparison shop increasingly complex airline tickets along with fees for ancillary services and the ability to purchase those services wherever airlines choose to sell their tickets.

The solution is simple. The DOTs final rule should ensure that:

 Airline consumers can see the full cost of flying including basic ancillary fees.

 Airline consumers are able to comparison shop across airlines including passenger and flight specific ancillary fees.

 Airline consumers are able to purchase these ancillary products at the same time that they pay for their airfares.

The free market works only when prices are transparent, and consumers have waited long enough.  As you know, the debate on this issue has been exhaustive.

 More than three years of industry studies, government analyses and economic papers.

 Detailed congressional hearings and meetings of the DOT Advisory Committee for Aviation Consumer Protection.

 Newspaper editorials.

 Hundreds of pages of rulemaking comments.

 Tens of thousands of consumer signatures.

 An extraordinary year-long review by the Office of Management and Budget.

We urge DOT to move expeditiously to ensure that ancillary fees are disclosed, searchable and transactable. Consumers have already waited more than three years for this issue to be addressed; we cannot risk further delay.  

Over recent years airlines have made their ancillary fees increasingly complex. Some airlines are even moving to dynamic, real-time pricing for things like carry-on and checked-baggage fees and seat reservations fees. Those airline actions to shroud ancillary fees during the purchasing process have made the buying process unfair and deceptive for consumers attempting to purchase the services they will need on their flights.  

Our organizations are thrilled that DOT has finally, after more than a thousand days, published this rulemaking. Now, we urge the Department to complete its rulemaking with robust requirements for the disclosure and transactability of ancillary fees.

Given the complexity of this rulemaking, consumer groups will understand should DOT require additional time to reflect on the new and important issues that have been added to this rulemaking such as a new definition of what constitutes a travel agent, expanding the pool of airlines reporting operation statistics, customer service plans from ticket agents, transparency of codeshare operations, disclosures of marketed carriers by online travel agencies and screen bias displays.  If so, the DOT could follow its precedent with ancillary fees in the last consumer protection rule and request additional comments on any or all of those topics.

We urge you not to allow the complexity and scope of this NPRM delay the relief consumers have so desperately needed for the last six years since airlines begun aggressively unbundling their products. Consumers have waited long enough to know the full cost of airline travel.

Sincerely,

Consumer Federation of America
National Consumers League
Consumer Watchdog
Travelers United
Association for Airline Passenger Rights
Airline Passengers.org
Business Travel Coalition 
PlusInc
Ed Perkins, Retired Founding Editor, Consumer Reports Travel Letter

Title: Lucia Foley
Comment:
Airline travel has become increasingly frustrating. From minimal space to no food (if your connection is late and you didn't pack your own food, you might not eat anything for a good 12 hours!) it's just a nightmare. The ultimate insult, however, are the ridiculous and blatantly greedy new fee policies that have made luggage an optional 'extra.' Seriously? In today's upside down world, everything is for sale, yet it's getting harder and harder to actually know the price for that trip (which is bound to leave you feeling used, abused, and wanting to just smack someone!) before you buy. I can't get my mind around why or how this is happening. Where is the government oversight to reel in this bad behavior? Everything is for sale, it seems. Next, we will need to reserve and pay for bathroom opportunities..

After reading through the long, long, and very wordy PDFs published by you folks, I have my doubts that you get it, but one can hope. It's pretty simple: people are not cattle; they need a little bit of space for comfort and health; when they go far enough that they need to fly they carry a suitcase; they likely started out really early with little sleep and they need food every few hours (but didn't have time to pack a lunch when they got up at 4am, so that rushed late connection means nothing but a tiny bag of nuts because the airline never has enough/any vegetarian stuff to buy); and they need to know how much a ticket for a ride on an airplane will cost, in total,with taxes (really, we know these fees are part of the deal and don't expect a free ride, just a total cost from the folks with the information and software to calculate that). People are cranky these days when they fly, with good reason. It's up to government agencies to keep bad practices from getting completely out of control. Please, end the madness!

Thank you.

Title: Classic World Travel
Comment:
September 22, 2014

Honorable Anthony Foxx
Secretary
United States Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Re: Docket OST-2014-0056

Dear Secretary Foxx:

As the Department evaluates the pending Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) on Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues, please consider these comments for the record.  

I operate Classic World Travel . We are based in Peachtree City, GA and employ 20 people.  I am writing about the NPRM because many of the proposals will directly affect my business and my employees.  

I am encouraged that the Department is finally taking steps to ensure all aspects of a travelers flight costs  including basic ancillary services  are readily apparent when booking the flight.  The situation today is untenable.  My customers, both corporate and leisure, cant with any certainty calculate the true cost of airfare.  The add-on fees are too complex, dynamic, and changeable from airline to airline to allow for 100% accurate quotes.  The NPRM as contemplated will relieve some of that pressure by mandating that the airlines disclose up front the cost of bags and seat assignments.  

But the Department should do more.  The potential for confusion remains high under the contemplated scenario.  A consumer armed with ancillary services quotes from my agency can still be surprised when he or she checks with the airline and finds out that the price has gone up since the quote or, even worse in the case of seat assignments, the seat he or she wanted is gone.   

If the Department wants to ensure true transparency of airfares, it should require that airlines allow consumers to book ancillary services at the same time he or she books a flight.  This small step will add certainty to the airfare booking process.  Travel distributors like GDSs have the technology to enable these bookings, and the airlines should benefit from an increased volume of ancillary sales.  Its a win-win for the entire travel value chain.  

The other provisions contained in the NPRM pertaining to travel agency mandates should not be enacted.  The Department in its filing has not shown any compelling reason why these proposals should be finalized.  

I oppose extending certain customer service requirements to travel agencies.  The move is unnecessary in large part because there is no problem requiring regulation to solve.   The travel agency community is highly respected and well-liked by its customers.  And in contrast to airlines, I have strong non-regulatory incentives to provide top-quality service to my customers.  Very simply, my customers have a choice of providers they can turn to if they find my service lacking.  An airline customer, on the other hand, is often tied to the airline with no real ability to switch providers.  The Department should allow the travel agent industry to continue to function as it is today and not intercede where it is not needed.  

Finally, the Departments proposals to mandate two different travel agency disclosures are similarly flawed and should be rejected.  

Its hard to understand how a consumer would benefit from the disclosure of incentive payments received by travel agents from airlines.  As noted above, any travel agents first priority is to its client.  Incentives always serve the interest of the client by allowing an agent to provide cheaper service for a flight on a given airline. To force disclosure of incentive payments would only serve to demonize what is otherwise a positive thing for consumers, agents, and airlines.  

Requiring a travel agent to disclose the airlines it does not market is similarly misguided.  Todays consumers understand that not all carriers choose to utilize travel agents to distribute their fares.  In fact, Southwest is currently running an aggressive ad campaign touting that carriers independence from travel agents.  The Department would never require airlines to disclose on their websites that travel agents offer a wider variety of airlines and destinations from which to choose.  It should not require the same of travel agents.  

Thank you for entering these comments into the public record.  

Sincerely,

Daniel D. Solly, CTIE
President
