Title: Blue Ribbon Business Travel International, Inc.
Organization Name: Blue Ribbon Business Travel International, Inc.
Comment:
September 22, 2014

Honorable Anthony Foxx
Secretary
United States Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Re: Docket OST-2014-0056

Dear Secretary Foxx:

As the Department evaluates the pending Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) on Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues, please consider these comments for the record.  

I operate Blue Ribbon Business travel International, Inc.  We are based in Edina, MN and employ 23 people.  I am writing about the NPRM because many of the proposals will directly affect my business and my employees.  

I am encouraged that the Department is finally taking steps to ensure all aspects of a travelers flight costs  including basic ancillary services  are readily apparent when booking the flight.  The situation today is untenable.  My customers, both corporate and leisure, cant with any certainty calculate the true cost of airfare.  The add-on fees are too complex, dynamic, and changeable from airline to airline to allow for 100% accurate quotes.  The NPRM as contemplated will relieve some of that pressure by mandating that the airlines disclose up front the cost of bags and seat assignments.  

But the Department should do more.  The potential for confusion remains high under the contemplated scenario.  A consumer armed with ancillary services quotes from my agency can still be surprised when he or she checks with the airline and finds out that the price has gone up since the quote or, even worse in the case of seat assignments, the seat he or she wanted is gone.   

If the Department wants to ensure true transparency of airfares, it should require that airlines allow consumers to book ancillary services at the same time he or she books a flight.  This small step will add certainty to the airfare booking process.  Travel distributors like GDSs have the technology to enable these bookings, and the airlines should benefit from an increased volume of ancillary sales.  Its a win-win for the entire travel value chain.  

The other provisions contained in the NPRM pertaining to travel agency mandates should not be enacted.  The Department in its filing has not shown any compelling reason why these proposals should be finalized.  

I oppose extending certain customer service requirements to travel agencies.  The move is unnecessary in large part because there is no problem requiring regulation to solve.   The travel agency community is highly respected and well-liked by its customers.  And in contrast to airlines, I have strong non-regulatory incentives to provide top-quality service to my customers.  Very simply, my customers have a choice of providers they can turn to if they find my service lacking.  An airline customer, on the other hand, is often tied to the airline with no real ability to switch providers.  The Department should allow the travel agent industry to continue to function as it is today and not intercede where it is not needed.  

Finally, the Departments proposals to mandate two different travel agency disclosures are similarly flawed and should be rejected.  

Its hard to understand how a consumer would benefit from the disclosure of incentive payments received by travel agents from airlines.  As noted above, any travel agents first priority is to its client.  Incentives always serve the interest of the client by allowing an agent to provide cheaper service for a flight on a given airline. To force disclosure of incentive payments would only serve to demonize what is otherwise a positive thing for consumers, agents, and airlines.  

Requiring a travel agent to disclose the airlines it does not market is similarly misguided.  Todays consumers understand that not all carriers choose to utilize travel agents to distribute their fares.  In fact, Southwest is currently running an aggressive ad campaign touting that carriers independence from travel agents.  The Department would never require airlines to disclose on their websites that travel agents offer a wider variety of airlines and destinations from which to choose.  It should not require the same of travel agents.  

Thank you for entering these comments into the public record.  

Sincerely,



Amy Boche
Co-President
Blue Ribbon Business Travel International, Inc.
an American Express Representative
3601 W. 76th Street
Suite 190
Edina, MN 55435

Title: S. H.
Comment:
I think all fees and taxes should be available at the time any future/potential airline passenger is looking at different airlines, flights, etc.    It's always an unpleasant surprise to me to see, after I've compared flight schedules, etc., to choose a flight and THEN and ONLY then, see what the actual cost will be.

Costs of changing reservations, etc., are often shown only after a reservation has been made and credit card information supplied.

If passengers or those making trip reservations for passengers are able to truly make an informed choice, then information about ancillary costs and taxes must be available for comparison.   Otherwise the regulating agency is essentially permitting--really authorizing or legalizing the airlines to repeatedly commit fraud.   Because they are authorized to conceal information about the true actual and potential (if someone must change his/her reservation) costs of the contract to be a passenger (maybe, since the airlines reserves the right to cancel the flight or bump the person off the filght) on a specific commercial airline flight.    Given that the airline is free to cancel the flight and do little to get the passenger to his/her destination (unlike, for instance, Amtrak, which makes a far bigger effort to assist passengers in the event of train delays, cancellations, etc.) with little or no cost to the airline, at the least passengers should be able to determine ALL the costs of the flight at the time they are looking at different flights with different airlines.

I believe it's an appropriate exercise of power for a federal agency to ensure that members of the public can make a fully informed choice on a purchase of a ticket.   If it were not for the rise of corporate "speech" I don't think there'd even be any question that full disclosure at the time a potential passenger checks flight schedules is required.  It's as if I couldn't find out the full cost of a pair of jeans prior to checkout, the retailer could refuse to list some of the price on the price tag of the jeans.

Title: International Airline Passengers Association
Submitter Representative: Michael Cintron, Director, Consumer & Travel Industry Affairs
Comment:
September 22, 2014

Honorable Anthony Foxx
Secretary
United States Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Re: Docket OST-2014-0056

Dear Secretary Foxx:

The International Airline Passengers Association (IAPA) supports the recent DOT efforts to enhance passenger protections with respect to fare and pricing transparency.  The Association believes that the inclusion of the total airline ticket price in advertising and availability displays has been fair and beneficial to air travel consumers, particularly our global membership of frequent flyers.  The inclusion of additional ancillary charges as proposed by the current NPRM (DOT-OST-2014-0056) is essential and IAPA joins with other travel and consumer organizations in urging the DOT to move forward with requiring the disclosure by airlines of all ancillary fee information applicable to an itinerary through all distribution channels.  The availability of fee information through all sales channels is essential to promoting fair competitive practices.  A fare shopper seeking the price of an itinerary through a travel agent, online or otherwise, should have access to the same information on ancillary services and costs as would be available directly through an airline. 
 
IAPA agrees with the Business Travel Coalition and its supporters in the industry in comment ID DOT-OST-2014-0056-0079 that ancillary fees be transactable through all channels where an airlines fares are made available for purchase.  While the Association respects the concerns of airlines and acknowledges the complex variables that influence the final cost of ancillary services (such as frequent flyer status), IAPA believes that existing technical infrastructure should permit the distribution and sale of at least the essential ancillary services as defined by the NPRM.   Concerns over the variables that could alter or waive the costs of certain ancillary services could be mitigated by allowing voluntary information to be input (frequent flyer number) that would validate the final cost of such services for that particular customer.   Lacking the ability to buy such services at the time of booking, passengers should then be protected from price increases by basing the cost of ancillary services on the date of ticket issue.  This could make purchasing these services more complex instead of easier.   

IAPA urges the Department to continue the move toward greater pricing transparency while encouraging all parties to work toward an acceptable standardization across all sales channels.  The goal should not be to place an undue burden on either industry or consumer, but to ensure that the purchase of air travel is transparent and equitable.

Sincerely,

Michael Cintron
Director, Consumer & Travel Industry Affairs
International Airline Passengers Association

Title: Raj Patel
Comment:
Honorable Anthony Foxx
Secretary
United States Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Re: Docket OST-2014-0056

Dear Secretary Foxx:

As the Department evaluates the pending Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) on Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues, please consider these comments for the record.  

I operate Sky Bird Travel.  We have offices across the US that employ over 130 people.  I am writing about the NPRM because many of the proposals will directly affect my business and my employees.  

I am encouraged that the Department is taking steps to ensure all aspects of a travelers flight costs  including basic ancillary services  are readily apparent when booking the flight.  The situation today is untenable.  My customers, both corporate and leisure, cant with any certainty calculate the true cost of airfare.  The add-on fees are too complex, dynamic, and changeable from airline to airline to allow for 100% accurate quotes.  The NPRM as contemplated will relieve some of that pressure by mandating that the airlines disclose up front the cost of bags and seat assignments.  

But the Department should do more.  The potential for confusion remains high under the contemplated scenario.  A consumer armed with ancillary services quotes from my agency can still be surprised when he or she checks with the airline and finds out that the price has gone up since the quote or, even worse in the case of seat assignments, the seat he or she wanted is gone.   

If the Department wants to ensure true transparency of airfares, it should require that airlines allow consumers to book ancillary services at the same time he or she books a flight.  This small step will add certainty to the airfare booking process.  Travel distributors like GDSs have the technology to enable these bookings, and the airlines should benefit from an increased volume of ancillary sales.  Its a win-win for the entire travel value chain.  

The other provisions contained in the NPRM pertaining to travel agency mandates should not be enacted.  I oppose extending certain customer service requirements to travel agencies.  The move is unnecessary in large part because there is no problem requiring regulation to solve.   The travel agency community is highly respected and well-liked by its customers.  And in contrast to airlines, I have strong non-regulatory incentives to provide top-quality service to my customers.  Very simply, my customers have a choice of providers they can turn to if they find my service lacking.  An airline customer, on the other hand, is often tied to the airline with no real ability to switch providers.  Lastly, travel agents are simply agents of the airlines.  When an airline makes a mistake, the airline has the ability to rectify the problem immediately, especially when the traveler is enroute.  Agents are at the mercy of the airline to provide similar levels of service as the airlines are the final decision makers as to what the agent can offer back to the traveler.  The Department should allow the travel agent industry to continue to function as it is today and not intercede where it is not needed.  

Finally, the Departments proposals to mandate two different travel agency disclosures are similarly flawed and should be rejected.  

Its hard to understand how a consumer would benefit from the disclosure of incentive payments received by travel agents from airlines.  Many travel agents work on a tiered and/or market share structure when it comes to incentives.  Agencies are again at the mercy of the airlines accounting reports to know if they have achieved the targets to earn incentives.  There are with such incentives, revenue goals, market share goals, as well as deductions from marketing carrier revenue versus operating carrier revenue that are all taken into consideration for an agency to know what incentive they have earned.  Airlines do not have same accounting programs and rely on several different entities (ARC, BSP, GDS, MIDT) to provide data which they internalize and then present to agencies.  This information provided to agencies is not uniformed nor is it presented by all carriers at the same time.  By virtue of the above it is impossible for any agency to disclose to a customer incentive payments received by an airline.

Requiring a travel agent to disclose the airlines it does not market is similarly misguided.  Todays consumers understand that not all carriers choose to utilize travel agents to distribute their fares.  In fact, Southwest is currently running an aggressive ad campaign touting that carriers independence from travel agents.  The Department would never require airlines to disclose on their websites that travel agents offer a wider variety of airlines and destinations from which to choose.  It should not require the same of travel agents.  

Sincerely,
Raj Patel
VP

Title: Wilfred Robin
Comment:
I generally support the proposed rule because consumers have the fundamental right to know the upfront cost of their entire trip, and not be surprised at the airport with extra fees from the airlines which, at that point, become extortion - not subject to normal free market competition.  That said, to provide basic consumer protections that exist in all other industries, through federal, state and local laws and jurisprudence, the FAA needs to do more.  

The airline industry is unique in being shielded from all normal legal obligations and constraints.  This proposed rule does nothing to repeal of the de facto exemption of airlines from all state and local consumer protection and most tort law, provide measures to reduce excessive travel delays, implement measures to strengthen return of or compensation for lost/stolen property, provide funding of the previously authorized passenger hotline, provide arbitration or small claims adjudication of passenger claims, mandate passenger representation on airport governing boards, and implement restrictions on reductions of frequent flyer benefits without adequate notice and disclosure of actual benefits granted.

Even if not included in this rule, I implore the DOT/FAA to enact these consumer protections in an industry that is now a de facto oligopoly.

Title: Competitive Enterprise Institute
Comment:
On behalf of the Competitive Enterprise Institute (CEI), I respectfully submit these comments in response to the Department of Transportations Office of the Secretary of Transportations notice of proposed rulemaking in the matter of Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues (NPRM). CEI is a nonprofit, nonpartisan public interest organization that focuses on regulatory policy from a market-oriented perspective. 

In our view, this latest action by the Department of Transportation (Department) is part of a broader attempt to expand its unfair and deceptive practices (UDP) authority under 49 U.S.C.  41712 in a manner contrary to Congress intent in passing the Airline Deregulation Act. Bolstering this contention is the Departments admission that the projected costs of the revised rules governing airline ancillary fees greatly outweigh its projected benefits.

In addition, we believe the Departments proposed regulation of ancillary fees reflects a status quo bias that will adversely affect airline competition and consumer welfare.

Title: Arab Air Carriers Organization
Comment:
The Arab Air Carriers Organization thanks the DOT for the opportunity to answer questions prior to rulemaking related to one of the most important areas in the airlines industry and indeed one of the most costly which is the distribution of airline products.
It is important to note however that given the way the NPRM was written, it has proven difficult for us to answer all the questions at the level of details required, as there are over 75 open-ended questions.

In an attempt to provide our input to the major issues in the NPRM, we have extracted a number of questions in the format as stipulated in the file attached and we have provided answers to these questions where applicable (in blue).

As two introductory general comments, first, we would like to highlight that we do not see any basis for the DOT to propose to regulate the interaction between the air carrier and the carriers customer and its proposals in the NPRM that would insert the department in the relationship between air carriers and intermediaries (ATPCO, GDSs). Second, the cost benefit analysis in the Regulatory Impact Analysis (RIA) for this rule is, according to our opinion, and in support to IATAs and A4As opinions and analysis, is highly negative and most areas of the proposed regulation have no quantifiable benefits; hence, following such analysis, we do not see the justification behind introducing such a rulemaking where the benefits do not justify the cost.

Title: Hyannis Air Service dba Cape Air
Organization Name: Hyannis Air Service dba Cape Air
Comment:
We agree with the Departments  proposal  to increase the number of reporting carriers by lowering the threshold from 1% to .5% of domestic revenue, but  do not believe that extending the reach beyond that level to smaller carriers would provide substantial benefit to the public in comparison to its costs.

We  work diligently with our major carrier partners to improve baggage handling and on time performance through a variety of practices including  coordinating minimum connecting times and subscribing to baggage tracing systems, but do not have the  sophisticated database mechanisms to aggregate  and report this data.    As we carry a  small number of customers, further extending the number of reporting carriers would create a significant burden and expense to small businesses like ourselves while providing little benefit to the public.    

We  also believe that it  would not be beneficial to require existing reporting carriers  to include data  of their  codeshare partner airlines  in their reports.    The current model of calculating an airlines on time performance compares the number of delayed flights to the number of operated flights.    Including smaller regional flights into the statistics of major carriers would skew the report by giving equal weight  to flights that carry significantly fewer passengers.   Thus, the reports would not reflect the experience of the majority of customers traveling on the reporting carrier flights.

Title: Williamson County Regional Airport
Comment: The proposed enfocement of the cap that has existed since 1990, along with the process that will provide communities an opportunity to respond to individual circumstances that may justify a waiver to the rule from DOT, seems fair and reasonable.  What is not fair or reasonable however, is maintaining $200 as the same benchmark for determinations to be made that was first put in place nearly 25 years ago.  A moderate indexing for inflation of 1.5% per year since 1990 would set the subsidy cap today around $285.  Given the significant challenges the airline industry has and continues to face since that time with the cost of fuel and recent pilot training requirements, an increase of the per passenger subsidy cap to $300 would be appropriate.  In addition, annual indexing for inflation should be implemented if enforcement of this subsidy cap is to continue in a fair and equitable manner.

Title: Steve Smith
Comment:
The per passenger cap of $200 per passenger was enacted when EAS was served with 34 seat  multi-engine aircraft. Jet Fuel fuel was about half what it is today.  Crew salaries and benefits were also almost half what they are today. The math does not work for smaller communities that are struggling to match 1999 passenger limits with 8/9 passenger airplanes and 6 dollar jet fuel. 

If The department of Transportation wants to reform the Essential Air Service Program, it should start with direct over-site. In most cases when a community is given a carrier to provide daily service to a major airline hub, that community has no input on how the carrier serves their city. In many cases what is promised and sometimes in the service agreement is never followed by the air service provider. Then the city is punished because the airline has not met the passenger subsidy cap.

The amount of the passenger subsidy cap needs to be updated if DOT plans to enforce it.  Fifteen years later.

Title: Offshore Operators Committee
Comment:
On July 2, 2014, the U.S. Department of Transportation announced the intention of the Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) to request the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to approve the following information collection: Voluntary Near Miss Reporting in Oil and Gas Operations on the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS).  The Offshore Operators Committee(OOC)provides the following comments for consideration on this information collection request. 

OOC is an organization of some 61 producing companies and 80 service providers to the industry who conduct essentially all of the OCS oil and gas exploration and production activities in the Gulf of Mexico. Comments submitted on behalf of OOC are submitted without prejudice to any members right to have or express different or opposing views.   We have encouraged all of our members to submit comments on the proposal.  The oil and natural gas industry supports 9.8 million U.S. jobs and 8 percent of the U.S. economy, delivering $86 million a day in revenue to our government. 

Our members and associates recognize that offshore operations must be conducted safely and in a manner that protects the environment.  The offshore industry in the Gulf of Mexico has a long history of safe operations that have advanced the energy security of our nation, and the energy resources in the region are also crucial to our nations economy.

We believe that the BTS effort on near miss reporting should be done from a company standpoint following established criteria rather than allowing for uncontrolled reporting from individuals. Collection of data at the company level will provide more consistent and focused reporting data.  We note that the  BSEE regulations at 30 CFR 250.193 currently provide an avenue for individual employees to report unsafe conditions and activities.  Allowing for individuals to report near misses under the BTS proposal may result in duplicative and unfocused reports that will create unhelpful burdens for the agency.
